webTitle: Beckham delivers a sharp reminder of his dedication to the cause

fields.headline: Beckham delivers a sharp reminder of his dedication to the cause
fields.trailText: The last time Manchester United played in the Champions League at Old Trafford, David Beckham had his most significant game in a red shirt. In those long forgotten days back in December, before the move to Posh Towers and before the battle of Brooklyn's nappy, Beckham was magnificent. Against Valencia he gave the full run-out to his talents: the crossing, the galloping charges down the flank, the tackling back, the non-stop enthusiasm for the task in hand. Rarely has commitment been better personified than on that night.
fields.body:
The last time Manchester United played in the Champions League at Old Trafford, David Beckham had his most significant game in a red shirt. In those long forgotten days back in December, before the move to Posh Towers and before the battle of Brooklyn's nappy, Beckham was magnificent. Against Valencia he gave the full run-out to his talents: the crossing, the galloping charges down the flank, the tackling back, the non-stop enthusiasm for the task in hand. Rarely has commitment been better personified than on that night.

It is extraordinary, then, that as the Champions League resumed at Old Trafford three months on, it was Beckham's dedication to the cause that was most on trial. In the bizarre orbit in which the Spice spouse spins every game seems to have a special significance: the first match against Argentina since he was dismissed at St Etienne, the first game since he was sent off in Brazil, the first time he encountered Leeds fans since he gave them some digitally proffered recreational advice. And now this match in which he was obliged to prove to the manager that he was still interested.

Maybe the Spice PR machine had spun into action and had a word to take the pressure off their client as much of the talk before the game had been diverted by the dropping of Mark Bosnich. He is another whose apparently relaxed attitude to the game has grated with Sir Alex Ferguson's Presbyterian work ethic. But on this occasion it was less the quality of his loafing than of his kicking that was his undoing. An unerring ability to slice the ball into row Z every time his defence shepherded it in his direction suggested he might not be the most comfortable choice against quick, alert forwards. So Raimond van der Gouw was drafted in: a recall for a man who started the season assuming the best he could hope for was a run-out with the reserves.

But, whatever Van der Gouw's well-preserved good looks, there was little doubt who a playercam would have been trained on, had ITV possessed one. For the first 10 minutes of the game any such device would have had little to show as the United players seemed anxious to keep the ball away from the man we have been led to believe is undermining the collective team spirit. As the newly in-touch Ryan Giggs and the ever-focused Roy Keane struggled to wrest control from a confident, slick French side, Beckham was entirely peripheral.

And then, on 16 minutes, a foul on Denis Irwin 25 yards from the Bordeaux goal offered him a chance for early redemption. The French defence seemed unaware of the threat: the wall was understaffed, the goalkeeper exposed and it was clear from the stands there was a space big enough to allow through several of Beckham's stable of cars driving in formation. But seeing such a gap is a different issue from placing a football precisely into it. Beckham did just that, delivering a shot of dip and swerve which just failed to drop sufficiently and struck the bar. Then on 41 minutes he went one better, delivering one of his patented crosses of real perception and threat which allowed Giggs to snap the ball home.

It was a fleeting, pertinent reminder that, if United are to progress with success through the thicket of fixtures which confronts them, a semi-detached Beckham needs to be re-engaged quickly. Quite simply, whatever the nonsense surrounding him, he remains a player whose delivery makes the difference.

webTitle: Johnson piles on misery for Dundee

fields.headline: Johnson piles on misery for Dundee
fields.trailText: Celtic 6 - 2 Dundee
fields.body:
Anything you can do, we can do better - well, not quite. Celtic last night just failed to match the seven goals that Rangers scored against Dundee on Sunday but they came embarrassingly close.

Four of the most horrendous days in the club's history may well have undermined the status of the Dundee manager Jocky Scott. Ironically, his opposite number Kenny Dalglish missed the feast with a dose of food poisoning.

Having left the field with a head wound after an early clash, Dundee's goalkeeper Rab Douglas returned six minutes later only to find the real pain was about to begin as Celtic shot five goals past him in the first half.

The first two came from Tommy Johnson, who opened the scoring when he slipped home a cross from Jackie McNamara. Celtic rested briefly before adding four more goals in 14 minutes as the match quickly descended into a humiliating rout.

With the confidence of the slow-turning Dundee defence evaporating, Celtic's goals did not even need to be particularly well-crafted. In the 36th minute Mark Viduka forced his way through the penalty area to beat Douglas, and a few minutes later Stilian Petrov added a scrappy fourth. On the stroke of half-time Frank Van Eijs brought down Stephane Mahe and Viduka's penalty gave the scoreline that same dreadful look it had on Sunday night.

Dundee regained some respectability in the second half. Hugh Robertson's 30-yard drive was the goal of the night before Johnson completed his hat-trick six minutes later. James Grady tucked away a second for his beleaguered side as the fans left early.

webTitle: So, was this a riot in the stand or not?

fields.headline: So, was this a riot in the stand or not?
fields.standfirst: Chelsea wait as Uefa examines conflicting tales of the trouble in Marseille
fields.trailText: Uefa has launched an inquiry into the crowd trouble during Chelsea's Champions League defeat in Marseille on Tuesday hoping to discover what happened and who was to blame.
fields.body:
Uefa has launched an inquiry into the crowd trouble during Chelsea's Champions League defeat in Marseille on Tuesday hoping to discover what happened and who was to blame.

It will be a tough task. Conflicting versions of events obscured the truth yesterday as completely as the police tear gas had enveloped many of the 2,000 Chelsea supporters packed into a fenced-off corner of the Stade Vélodrome.

Two Chelsea fans arrested during the troubles, one for allegedly hitting a steward, the other for allegedly carrying a knife, are to appear in court.

Before the match there was a stabbing incident in a bar but this is also surrounded in confusion: one police spokesman said the victim was a Chelsea fan, another that he was a Marseille supporter. Seven supporters were also arrested in Lyon for allegedly attacking people on the under- ground but were later released without charge.

With England's bid to host the 2006 World Cup in the balance, Fifa will await Uefa's findings with interest. As well as studying the report from their match delegate, Sandor Berzi of Hungary, Uefa will sift through the conflicting evidence. Marseille police yesterday claimed the tear gas was justified to prevent serious trouble; Chelsea fans said it was an over-reaction and that the trouble started after Marseille fans threw missiles.

Peter Ashdown, a chartered surveyor in his mid-forties, who has travelled in a group of businessmen to watch Chelsea in Europe over the last two years, said: "It was disgraceful. Before the game all 2,000 of us including women and children were kept in a hangar-like room, some for two hours. When people asked to go to the toilet they were told to piss against the wall.

"Then, during the game, Marseille fans started throwing coins, cans, even a flare at us. The stewards did nothing even though people were getting hurt and there were women and kids in there. Those with cuts were stopped from getting treatment.

"Of course, some of our fans started to complain to the stewards and scuffles broke out. That was it. The riot police pulled the stewards out and fired the tear gas. Then they came into the area, hitting out indiscriminately with their batons. The tear gas was a total over-reaction and people were being physically sick.

"What we want to know is why they went after us and no one did anything about the Marseille fans. They even threw a smoke bomb on the pitch. Imagine the outcry if Chelsea supporters had done that. Ken Bates should make a formal protest. The whole thing was disgusting."

The Chelsea chairman Bates says he is studying the evidence. But he, like Uefa, may find the truth all too elusive.

Even among the police, though, stories are varied. One spokesman, Alain Begon, tried to play it down: "The anti-riot squad had been obliged to interfere because the Chelsea supporters had become quite excited, nothing more."

An unnamed police superintendent at the match saw it differently. "A bunch of British fans who were probably drunk started to hit the stewards. After some time it became clear they could not take care of the problem. We decided to enter the stand but we were coming from a low position and that made it difficult to handle. We had two choices: to strike the Chelsea fans or throw two tear gas bombs, which is what we did."

The match commander, who did not want his name published, offered a further explanation. "Some Chelsea fans pushed the stewards because they were unhappy that [the stewards] were so close," he said. "The police were obliged to intervene because, as the stewards left the enclosure by a gate which led to the pitch, they were followed by some supporters. The CRS riot police were sent in to prevent the supporters getting on to the pitch. The order was given to release tear gas. Calm was restored after five minutes."

Uefa will report on March 17.

webTitle: The rest of the world wakes up to Roma's rising sun

fields.headline: The rest of the world wakes up to Roma's rising sun
fields.standfirst: Nakata's growing reputation will be tested against Leeds
fields.trailText: Hidetoshi Nakata is many things to many people: for Japanese, he is a megastar and ambassador; for business analysts, he is the future; for Leeds, he is a combative and capable midfielder who will need close monitoring tonight.
fields.body:
If you ask Hidetoshi Nakata if he is tired of being called the "samurai warrior", "the man from the land of the rising sun", "the star from the Orient" or something equally cliched, he pauses before replying.

"No, this happens everywhere. In Japan, too, we have stereotypes. It is just one of those things but I would like to think I can contribute to changing such stereotypes."

You could argue that at 23 he is on the way, having already reversed the attitude that there is no such thing as a world-class Japanese footballer.

When Nakata signed for Roma he was asked how it felt to be stepping into the shoes of a former Roma legend, the Brazilian Falcao: "I'm sorry. I know Falcao by name, but I never saw him play," he said.

When the imperious Falcao was helping Roma to the 1983 league title, Nakata was a six-year-old kicking up dust in the streets of Yamanashi, Japan. Baseball players were his idols and football was something he had yet to discover.

Today, Nakata is many things to many people. In Japan, he is a megastar and ambassador; in Italy, the media see him as the star with the almond eyes; and for business analysts, he is the shape of the future. As for Leeds United, as far as they are concerned he is a combative midfielder who combines ball-winning with playmaking and who will need close monitoring in tonight's fourth-round, first-leg Uefa Cup tie.

When Perugia paid £2.6m for Nakata during the 1998 World Cup many scoffed at the idea of a Japanese playing in what is arguably the toughest league in the world. When he went to Roma, in January, for £16m, the carping had stopped.

Perugia were laughing all the way to the bank, not just with the transfer fee but also the sales, to Japan, of 70,000 Nakata No7 Perugia shirts.

Indeed, as a former Asian footballer of the year, Nakata is as popular in Japan as the Spice Girls with enormous marketing potential. So much so that when BSkyB attempted to buy Manchester United, preliminary talks were held with Perugia about luring the player to Old Trafford, an act that prompted accusations of it being merely a ploy to increase interest in the club in the Far East.

Nakata has estimated after-tax earnings of £2.6m. It comes from his five-year salary with Roma and sponsorship deals with Asahi, Subaru and Mastercard. Negotiations are under way with Nike. He has his own internet site and an agency, Sunny Side Up, and their representative Maurizio Morana to look after his business interests.

But what about Leeds? "They are a young side with many talented players. But I don't know much else," he says. "I don't get time to watch English soccer." Study time begins tonight at the Olympic Stadium.

webTitle: Italian return a rite of passage for O'Leary

fields.headline: Italian return a rite of passage for O'Leary
fields.trailText: As Leeds renew acquaintances with Roma at the Stadio Olimpico tonight, David O'Leary will learn the true extent of their progress since encountering the same opposition last season as caretaker manager.
fields.body:
There is a tradition that visitors will return here one day provided they throw a coin into the Trevi fountain. Seventeen months ago David O'Leary chucked in his penny and this evening his Leeds side will attempt to leave their hosts wishing he had been out of loose change.

As the Premiership side renew acquaintances with Roma at the Stadio Olimpico, O'Leary will learn the true extent of their progress since encountering the same opposition last season as caretaker manager.

Despite spirited resistance the Italians won 1-0 and O'Leary returned from the Eternal City expecting to be thrown to the lions. Instead he was offered the job full-time.

Since then Leeds have been thinking about European competition in terms of the Champions League. But Roma have themselves blossomed since hiring the former Milan and Real Madrid coach Fabio Capello last summer and for once O'Leary's habitual claims of modesty did not ring false.

"I would take at least four of their players if the chairman would buy them for me," he said. "They are a much better side than the last time that we played them and this will be the biggest test yet. Capello is a great coach."

The assumption is that Leeds will deploy Michael Bridges as a lone striker, crowding the midfield. O'Leary picked out the strikers Marco Delvecchio and Vincenzo Montella, while Francesco Totti has more to offer than an amusing surname.

webTitle: Arsenal on guard for Spanish test

fields.headline: Arsenal on guard for Spanish test
fields.trailText: If Real Madrid or Barcelona were the visitors to Highbury tonight, many would feel Arsenal had been handed a European draw from hell. So what to make of Deportivo La Coruna, who are six points clear of Real and eight ahead of Barca at the top of the Spanish league.
fields.body:
If Real Madrid or Barcelona were the visitors to Highbury tonight, many would feel Arsenal had been handed a European draw from hell. So consider the following about their opponents, Deportivo La Coruna.

Six points clear of Real and eight ahead of Barca at the top of the Spanish league, Deportivo have beaten both those giants. Last month they hammered Real 5-2; in October they defeated Barcelona 2-1, less than a fortnight after Arsenal had lost 4-2 to the Catalans in the Champions League at Wembley.

The good news for Arsène Wenger is that, although Deportivo have won nine of their past 10 league games at home, they look vulnerable away. One point from 15 on their travels since mid-December tells its own tale. For Arsenal this promises to be make or break, particularly as Dennis Bergkamp's fear of flying will prevent him travelling to Spain next week.

The problem for Wenger, on top of Patrick Vieira's suspension, is solving a tactical conundrum which could determine whether Marc Overmars starts. "It's important to score without conceding," the Arsenal manager said, "and that puts you in a difficult position where you don't really know whether to attack like crazy or try to keep a clean sheet."

Deportivo have made it clear where their priorities lie as they look to secure a quarter-final against Parma or Werder Bremen. "We will try to close the door on Arsenal and get the result we need to take us through at home," said their coach Javier Irureta. "A draw would be a good result. English football is open and generous and will allow us to play on the counter-attack."

There they should be dangerous. A five-man midfield will most likely contain three Brazilians, notably Djalminha, a brilliant left-footed player with nine league goals. Ahead of them is Roy Makaay, a Dutch striker. "They have a good balance," Wenger said, "between possession and breaking quickly, especially with long balls to Makaay."

Arsenal's captain Tony Adams had other things on his mind yesterday. The 33-year-old centre-half wants to replace Alan Shearer as England captain and said he had the ability and experience to lead Kevin Keegan's side to the 2002 World Cup finals.

"If the England manager wants me to be the captain then I'd do it, but if he doesn't that's fine too," he said. "If I get a chance to get physically well, then I've got a chance to do it. I'd love to be England captain and I've been grateful the 10 times I've had the job.

"But I don't want to be a hindrance for the future. We've got great young talent in Rio Ferdinand and Sol Campbell and time moves on. I can contribute if I'm still needed."

fields.headline: Arsenal v Deportivo La Coruna
fields.standfirst: Refresh this page for latest updates
fields.trailText: Kick off 8pm
fields.body:
Kick off 8pm

Arsenal: Seaman; Dixon, Keown, Luzhny, Silvinho; Ljungberg, Grimandi, Petit, Overmars; Bergkamp, Henry. Subs: Winterburn, Adams, Suker, Manninger, Parlour, Malz, Kanu.

53 Deportivo Substitution: Victor for Jokanovic. 54 Goal Deportivo: 2-1
Penalty for Deportivo! Ljungberg is adjudged to have nudged Conceicao from Makaay's neat little through-ball. Arsenal complain but to avail and Djalminho tucks away the penalty. Djalminho though is booked moments later for diving and he too will miss a second leg which is suddenly not the formality it was begining to look in the first half. 60 Red card Deportivo Grimandi fouls Djalminha who reacts a little angrily and Grimandi writhes around in apparent agony. There's a general ruckus involving several players, Grimandi picks up a yellow card for the foul but for the Brazilian Djalminha it's not a second yellow card but a straight red. A bit harsh, but a stroke of luck for the Gooners.
65 Arsenal Substitution: Kanu for Overmars.
66 Goal Arsenal 3-1 The lanky Nigerian wastes no time in making his presence felt, winning a free-kick on the right-angle of the Deportivo penalty area. Petit swings over a vicious left-footer to the far post and there's Henry unmarked to nod in his second of the night and put the hosts back in command.
68 Deportivo Substitution: Fernando for Flores
74 Deportivo Substitution Pauleta for Makaay
76 Arsenal Substitution: Suker for Henry.
77 Goal Arsenal: 4-1
It's that man Kanu. Taking advantage of a terrible defensive blunder, he latches on to the arrant back header and simply strolls past poor old Songo'o and walks the ball into the net for a sublime goal. 80 Songo'o restores some self-respect with a fine save from Petit after good work by Kanu and Bergkamp.
82 Goal Arsenal: 5-1
Kanu earns a free-kick, brought down by Donato 30 yards out. Bergkamp hits it, the ball takes a wicked deflection off the wall and wrong-foots the hapless Songo'o before sailing into the unguarded half of the net. Unbelievable Gooner glory. 88 Dispirited Deportivo have little left to offer and now it's just a question of whether Arsenal can make it six which they nearly do when Ljungberg's flick is headed on by Suker and Kanu's stinging volley is well blocked by old Songo'o.
94 After four minutes of added time, Arsenal's triumphant night is complete. As their fans sing odes to the suspended Patrick Vieira, he and his team-mates can look forward to the second leg in Spain with a fair degree of confidence.

fields.headline: Offside errors 'only human'
fields.trailText: Six scientists have proved what every disgruntled football fan knows: the linesman does get it wrong. But do not blame it on malice or myopia - no human can give the right offside decision all the time.
fields.body:
Six scientists have proved what every disgruntled football fan knows: the linesman does get it wrong. But do not blame it on malice or myopia - no human can give the right offside decision all the time.

The Dutch researchers mounted cameras on an apartment block next to a pitch and monitored 200 potential offside situations in matches between two elite youth teams. They found that even professional assistant referees made mistakes at least 40 times because of a problem with the human perceptual system.

In soccer, a player is offside if he is closer to the goal than the last defender (apart from the hapless goalkeeper) when the ball is passed. The team from the faculty of human movement at the free university of Amsterdam considered the challenge for the linesman.

"One explanation for these errors is that the assistant referee cannot see passer and receiver simultaneously," Raoul Oudejans and his colleagues write in Nature today. "This causes the assistant referee to shift his gaze from passer to receiver and so make judgments a split second after the moment of passing - long enough for the receiver to have gone past the last defender and to appear offside."

Dr Oudejans and his team then scrutinised 200 videotaped matches from five national competitions between 1996 and 1998, as well as the 1998 World Cup. The thesis held good. Tim Radford

webTitle: Managers and players to get voice on video disciplinary panel

fields.headline: Managers and players to get voice on video disciplinary panel
fields.standfirst: Football Association volunteers to lose unilateral power to decide charges
fields.trailText: As the number of players disciplined by the Football Association after video evidence increases, so the number of bodies represented on the judgment panel is to rise.
fields.body:
As the number of players disciplined by the Football Association after video evidence increases, so the number of bodies represented on the judgment panel is to rise.

From next season the Professional Footballers' Association and the League Managers' Association will join the disciplinary leaders of the FA on its video-vetting panel. Until then the FA will continue to decide unilaterally whether to charge offenders who are not punished by referees.

The move follows the FA's increasing reliance on television footage to take action against players and managers. The latest to be charged in this way was Sunderland's Alex Rae, who was caught on camera elbowing Derby County's Darryl Powell and has been charged with misconduct.

The funeral of Sir Stanley Matthews will take place tomorrow and the route was announced yesterday. The cortege will assemble at Stoke's Britannia Stadium, which will be open to the public, before moving off at 11.30am under a police escort and on to Stanley Matthews Way.

It will then make its way into the city centre and to the Sir Stanley Matthews statue at just after noon, where the procession will pause.

It will proceed to Boothen Old Road to the site of the former Victoria Ground and to its official entrance at 12.30. After a pause the cortege will then head towards St Peter's Church for the funeral at 12.50.

Matthews died in hospital last Wednesday at the age of 85. His career with Stoke, Blackpool and England spanned three decades until his final game five days after his 50th birthday.

Matthews turned professional with Stoke aged 17, was capped 54 times for England and made 710 Football League appearances for Stoke and Blackpool.

Real Madrid have been ordered to pay their former head coach John Toshack 164m pesetas (£590,000) in compensation for his sacking last November. The payout to the Welshman was based on both breach of contract by Real and unpaid wages.

Toshack was relieved of his duties at the end of last year after a nine-month spell. Real's lawyers have announced they will launch an appeal against the decision.

Tony Fawthrop, Bristol City's caretaker boss, who has been named as the Second Division manager of the month, said last night he did not want the job permanently.

He took over - with Leroy Rosenior and David Burnside - when Tony Pulis left for Portsmouth and since then the club have gone 11 games without defeat.

Fawthrop, who had been chief scout at Ashton Gate, will be in charge until the end of the season.

The England Under-18 coach Martin Hunter has included three players who have already played in the Premiership in his squad to face France in a friendly international at Wigan on March 8.

West Ham's Michael Carrick - currently on loan to Birmingham - and Stephen Bywater plus Coventry's Gary McSheffrey are part of the 18-strong squad.

"These sort of games are important for the development of a player, and several of the last squad have progressed into the under-21s. There is big incentive for them."

England: Bywater (West Ham), Kirkland (Coventry), Halls (Arsenal), Richardson (Leeds), Lloyd-Samuel (Aston Villa), Konchesky (Charlton), Parnaby (Middlesbrough), Clarke (Everton), Carrick (West Ham), Dunfield (Manchester City), McMaster (Leeds), O'Brien (Liverpool), Logan (Ipswich), McSheffrey (Coventry), Defoe (West Ham), Bothroyd (Arsenal), Hamshaw (Sheffield Wednesday), Bewers (Aston Villa).

fields.headline: Hasselbaink blunts Spurs' ambitions
fields.trailText: Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink has dashed Tottenham Hotspur's hopes of finding a striker who can score goals after he said he would be staying at Atletico Madrid.
fields.body:
Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink has dashed Tottenham Hotspur's hopes of finding a striker who can score goals after he said he would be staying at Atletico Madrid.

"I have three more years on my contract and next season I am still going to be here. I am very happy both in Spain and at Atletico," he said yesterday.

Spurs, Liverpool and Middlesbrough have expressed an interest in Hasselbaink, who spent two successful seasons at Leeds United. He has scored 21 goals this season and is joint highest scorer in the first division.

Atletico certainly need him: they are 17th out of 20, one place above the relegation zone, and the club is being run by a government-appointed administrator while allegations of misuse of club funds are being investigated.

Hasselbaink dismissed suggestions that Atletico would be playing second division football next season for the first time since 1934.

"Going down? Please! We are not a team that is going to get relegated. We've had a bit of bad luck but that's going to turn around," he said.

Atletico's rivals, Real Madrid, were for once praised by the Spanish press despite their 4-2 Champions League defeat at home by Bayern Munich on Tuesday night. "Losers, but with their head held high," the sports daily Marca said. "A great Bayern beat a great Madrid," it added.

The Real Madrid players were looking forward to facing Bayern again next week in Germany. "We've got the mental strength to go to Munich and beat them there," the Spanish international de fender Michel Salgado said. "We are the equal of Bayern and are not going to Munich to lose. Everything will change if, say, we win 1-0," the midfielder Jose Maria Gutierrez added. The only Real player to be pilloried was the French striker Nicolas Anelka.

Stefan Effenberg, the captain and inspiration behind Bayern's win, said the troubled German national team could learn from the Munich club.

"The hope of German football is Bayern Munich," Effenberg said. "When people talk about German football they talk about Bayern Munich, sadly not about the national team."

The Dutch media, meanwhile, were ecstatic after Feyenoord's shock 2-1 win away to Lazio, the world's most expensively assembled team. "Majestic Feyenoord" said Algemeen Dagblad. "Imperial in Rome," said the nation's top-selling De Telegraaf, which told how the "Danish dynamite" had exploded on the field.

The dynamite in question was Jon Dahl Tomasson, a flop at Newcastle who was left out of the starting line-up but came on in the second half to score twice. Not that it quelled his displeasure at being dropped.

As his team-mates rushed to congratulate him on his first goal, Tomasson raised his middle finger at the Feyenoord bench. The coach Leo Beenhakker either did not notice or did not care as he enjoyed his team's victory. "You can only dream about such things," he said.

"He took his opportunity with two hands and made his point to the coach in that way. Great. After the match we only needed to look at each other. We shook hands and that was it. Sometimes you know what's meant without words," he said.

A post-match shower seemed to cool the Dane down and he emerged to say: "I'm really angry that I had to begin on the bench but obviously I'm pleased for the team that it went so well," he said.

Dutch attempts to push through a fast-track judicial procedure to handle suspected hooligans at the European Championship have hit major problems.

The authorities want a process whereby suspects appear before a judge within three days of arrest. The theory is they could be deported or put behind bars without a protracted legal debate. However, the supreme court has decided it would need at least six months to review the proposed change in legislation.

Pierre van Hooijdonk showed he has not lost his talent for stirring up controversy by being suspended for four matches after two elbowing incidents in Vitesse's Dutch Cup quarter-final victory against RKC Waalwijk.

The referee missed the incidents in the February 16 game but the Dutch Football Association decided to punish Van Hooijdonk after television footage clearly showed the Dutch international and former Nottingham Forest forward using his elbows.

Vitesse did not plan to contest the decision, although a spokesman said the club was only agreeing to the suspension because the player was injured. "Otherwise we would have brought a case against the disciplinary committee. Pierre still maintains he did nothing wrong," the spokesman added.

webTitle: England reveal hand for first Test

fields.headline: England reveal hand for first Test
fields.standfirst:
Mullally, Tufnell and Thorpe are left out of the contracted 12
Wisden Verdict: A cautious thumbs-up
fields.trailText: The England and Wales Cricket Board yesterday named the 12 players who are to be offered contracts for the summer and, in so doing, stuck its neck out to a degree unprecedented in English cricket.
fields.body:
The England and Wales Cricket Board yesterday named the 12 players who are to be offered contracts for the summer and, in so doing, stuck its neck out to a degree unprecedented in English cricket.

Six batsmen, one of whom keeps wicket, two all-rounders, a spinner and three pace bowlers make up the new elite that for the next six months will come under the jurisdiction of the England coach Duncan Fletcher rather than their respective counties.

Barring ill health or drastic loss of form, says the chairman of selectors David Graveney, these dozen will form the squad to represent England against Zimbabwe in the first Test at Lord's on May 18.

The list contains a number of surprises, with the return to the Test fold of Graeme Hick, Mark Ramprakash and Craig White (on the strength of a good one-day series as Andy Flintoff's replacement) and the introduction of the 21-year-old Lancashire wrist spinner Chris Schofield.

There are notable absentees, most prominently the Surrey left-hander Graham Thorpe, who opted out of the winter tour but must have entertained ideas of coming straight back in, Alan Mullally, Chris Silverwood and Phil Tufnell.

Graveney was keen to stress that though a balanced squad had been selected, with a view to building the sort of camaraderie so evident in touring parties but not necessarily at home, a closed shop had not been created.

"This is the last thing we wanted to do," he said. "It would be good neither for the players selected nor those aspiring to gain contracts. We should also be mindful that even in a five-Test summer we have frequently used 18 or 19 players, and this summer there are seven Tests. There will still be opportunities for others."

After much speculation, the terms of the contracts are much clearer now. In addition to their county salaries (for which the counties will be compensated), the players will receive remuneration from the ECB according to one of four salary bands, based on value to the side as well as experience, with £20,000 at the lower end of band D rising to £50,000 at the top end of band A.

In addition there will be significant team bonuses, as well as personal insurance, healthcare and pensions. The money will come from the board's original Test-match budget, roughly £100,000 a match, plus an additional allocation of £750,000. For this, players will be at Fletcher's beck and call.

Participation in domestic cricket will be at his discretion except for the Benson & Hedges Cup and NatWest Trophy, over which the counties will have control, an unfortunate state of affairs but a compromise reached to push through the principle of contracts.

The inclusion of Ramprakash and Hick brings back two players of undoubted class with something to prove. Ramprakash was omitted from the winter tour for reasons that have never been made public, but created an excellent impression with the management during his brief time in South Africa as a stand-by. He is certain to open the batting with Mike Atherton and, to this end, will fulfil the same role at Middlesex.

Hick, the enigma, is a cause clbre for Fletcher, who has known him since his childhood. It is not Hick's fault that any runs against Zimbabwe and a West Indies side in decline will tell us very little not already known and we must wait until Pakistan and Sri Lanka next winter and Australia in 2001 to find out whether Fletcher has, as Graveney put it, the key to the door. But the coach deserves the chance to give it a go.

Schofield has massive potential and enjoyed a successful A tour last winter, but his inclusion with only 12 first-class games to his name is a comment on the paucity of English spin bowling. "It's a great honour. Hopefully I can do the job for them," he said. "I haven't seen my contract yet so I don't know how it's going to work with it being a new experiment."

As for Thorpe, he has been a complacent Test cricketer for several years but appears to have burnt his bridges not so much by opting out of the tour but by not revealing his intentions until the final day of the last Test against New Zealand shortly before the party for South Africa was selected.

"It was his decision," said Graveney, "and there are implications from that. He has not gone to the back of the queue but an opportunity has been given to others now."

webTitle: Fifa size up Platini plan for standard calender

fields.headline: Fifa size up Platini plan for standard calender
fields.trailText: A harmonised international calendar for world football will be discussed formally for the first time later this month to reduce the number of competitive matches and prevent players from burning out.
fields.body:
A harmonised international calendar for world football will be discussed formally for the first time later this month to reduce the number of competitive matches and prevent players from burning out.

Details of the plan, the brainchild of the former French captain Michel Platini, were made public yesterday. It envisages a February to November season for league and cup competitions, with July and August set aside for international tournaments, and a football-free December.

The controversial blueprint, that could potentially see the FA Cup final played in November, was the subject of intense debate at the final session of the Football Expo international trade fair here after a leading Fifa doctor revealed startling statistics about the effects of overplaying.

Toni Graf-Baumann, a member of Fifa's medical committee, told the conference that at the quarter-finals of a "very important recent competition", believed to be the World Cup in France two years ago, an average of 16 players in every squad needed painkilling injections before they could take to the field.

"These players all had to have local anaesthetics, Graf-Baumann said. "This is far too big a figure but it could continue unless we reduce the number of matches. "Players have been coming directly from their league seasons straight into training camps and that is absolutely impossible from the physical point of view. There is a limit to players' physical and mental capacities, to go over this limit means possible misuse or overuse."

Platini, the right-hand man to the Fifa president Sepp Blatter, failed to turn up despite being billed as the main attraction for the final session of the three-day forum. In his absence, the Fifa spokesman Keith Cooper outlined how the proposed new calendar, which Fifa's executive committee will discuss later this month, would work.

National league and cup competitions would be staged in two phases, from February to June and September to November. July and August would be set aside for international competitions such as the World Cup and European Championship, with December free and January for pre-season training. In all, the Fifa plan embraces 76 match dates of which 46 would be for domestic football and the rest for international fixtures at club and national level.

This could mean staging the FA Cup final in November but Cooper acknowledged this would generate fierce opposition. In theory, he said, England could switch the proposed timetable around, playing September to November and February to June which would be closer to the current format.

Uefa, the European governing body, has already said it would oppose any alteration to the standard August to May timetable, while another stumbling block is that the Platini blueprint is based on a maximum 18 clubs per league; the Premiership has 20.

 The International Olympic Committee and Fifa joined forces yesterday to ease the burden on clubs losing players to the Sydney Olympic tournament.

Following a meeting with the IOC president Juan Antonio Samaranch in Lausanne, the Fifa president Sepp Blatter said he would propose at an executive committee meeting later this month that the 14-day period that clubs are currently required to release players for international duty be temporarily reduced to five in the run-up to the games. Blatter added that Fifa will consider postponing Champions League and Uefa Cup matches in September to facilitate the Olympics.

webTitle: Wenger intervenes to revive Hughes move

fields.headline: Wenger intervenes to revive Hughes move
fields.trailText: Stephen Hughes' proposed £3m move from Arsenal to Everton was revived last night, less than 24 hours after the deal appeared to have collapsed over personal terms.
fields.body:
Stephen Hughes' proposed £3m move from Arsenal to Everton was revived last night, less than 24 hours after the deal appeared to have collapsed over personal terms.

Everton are understood to have increased their offer to the 23-year-old midfielder, who will now hold further talks. It is thought that Arsne Wenger advised Hughes to rethink his decision.

"He's at an age when he needs to play," the Arsenal manager said. "That's why I gave him the opportunity to leave. He is in competition with Emmanuel Petit for a position in the team and I don't want to kill his career."

Portsmouth's striker Steve Claridge has been charged with misconduct by the Football Association after placing a bet on his side to win their home game against Barnsley on January 29.

Claridge, whose side won 3-0, has been accused of breaching the FA's rules, which forbid any bet on a match other than filling out a pools coupon. He has 14 days to respond to the charge.

"Players, managers and directors have to realise that even betting on their own team to win is a breach of football rules on betting," said the FA's spokesman Steve Double.

"Players and officials have access to information which those outside the game do not. For instance, only those inside a club may know that the team's top scorer has returned to full fitness. The use of such information to place bets could be regarded as a form of insider trading."

Michael Owen emerged unscathed from a practice game at Anfield yesterday and seems certain to play some part in Liverpool's game at Manchester United on Saturday.

"The run-out was a great success," said Liverpool's manager Grard Houllier, "and although no final decision will be made until later in the week as to whether he will play against Manchester United, I was encouraged by his display."

webTitle: Emergency aid: what the world is giving

fields.headline: Emergency aid: what the world is giving
fields.trailText: Britain: £6m in aid with promises of a "sympathetic" response to demands for further assistance. The package includes helicopters, rescuers, tents and state of the art communication equipment.
fields.body:
Britain: £6m in aid with promises of a "sympathetic" response to demands for further assistance. The package includes helicopters, rescuers, tents and state of the art communication equipment.

Portugal: Canceled nearly a tenth of Mozambique's debt: Portugal wrote off £92m of its former colony's debt and donated £3.1m to rent helicopters for rescue operations. In previous days Lisbon has donated £1.2m and sent 40 tons of aid including food, medicine, rubber rafts and tents.

Japan: One of the first countries to give aid to Mozambique, Japan donated £63,300 on February 18 for blankets, plastic sheets and generators. It gave the same amount when Mozambique suffered smaller floods last year.

European Union: Considering £49.2m to support Mozambique's infrastructure: £15.4m has already been given for the reconstruction of roads and bridges.

Germany: Sending helicopters: the government has chartered a freighter plane to carry at least four helicopters and other relief supplies to Mozambique's capital Maputo.

South Africa: Seven South African helicopters have borne the brunt of the airlift and rescued at least 9,500 people from the trees and rooftops.

United States: 900 soldiers, six heavy lift helicopters, six military cargo planes to deliver relief supplies, and a number of small boats for search and rescue operations. In addition the US is donating food, cooking oil, blankets, plastic sheets and has given £83,600 to establish emergency cholera protection. £200,000 has been set aside to reach people in flooded areas and deliver shovels, sandbags and wheel barrows to them.

fields.headline: Dances with wolves
fields.standfirst: Many high-profile figures have refused to attend this year's prestigious opera ball in Vienna in protest at the presence of the far-right Freedom party in the Austrian government, writes Kate Connolly
fields.trailText: Many high-profile figures have refused to attend this year's prestigious opera ball in Vienna in protest at the presence of the far-right Freedom party in the Austrian government, writes Kate Connolly
fields.body:
The Vienna opera ball is fast turning into a spectacular farce following the refusal of presidents, porn stars and debutantes to accept invitations to the highlight of the Austrian social calendar in protest at the presence of the far-right Freedom party in government.

French and British actresses Catherine Deneuve and Jacqueline Bisset as well as film diva Claudia Cardinale are among scores of personalities who have said they could not be seen to be rubbing shoulders with the new government members.

Several stars who will attend tonight have employed bodyguards to ensure that they are not photographed with populist politician Jörg Haider, who until days ago was the leader of the far-right Freedom party which entered into a coalition with the conservative People's party under the chancellorship of Wolfgang Schüssel almost a month ago.

Portuguese president Jorge Sampaio, whose country holds the European Union presidency, was billed as the guest of honour until cancelling his visit when the new government was sworn in. Austria has found itself increasingly isolated since European Union leaders announced a collective boycott against it early last month.

Traditionally hundreds of demonstrators have gathered outside the ball's venue, the state opera house, using it as a platform to protest against the gap between rich and poor.

But this year, hundreds of riot police are being brought in to cope with around 25,000 demonstrators who are expected to gather for a protest rally against the new government. Security will be tighter than usual and undercover policemen will mill with the 4,100 ball goers inside to ensure their safety.

To reject a ticket to the opera ball (the cheapest sells for £120 if you're lucky enough to get one) is seen as the ultimate snub. Even porn stars, including Dolly Buster and the American John Wayne Bobbit whose wife famously cut off his penis, as well as a clutch of erotic film actresses, have turned their backs on the event at the last minute. Organisers have been desperately scraping the barrel to find replacements.

The guests of honour are now expected to be the president of Kazakhstan, Nursultan Nazarbajev, who will share a 200,000 schilling (£9,090) box with Austrian president Thomas Klestil, and Sudanese-born beauty Nadja Abdel Farrag, the presenter of the late-night German TV programme, Peep!, which is based on voyeuristic sex.

She is to appear on the arm of Viennese building magnate, Richard Lugner, who in the past has drawn huge publicity by escorting the likes of the Duchess of York, Sophia Loren and Ivana Trump to the prestigious event.

British actress Jacqueline Bisset accepted an invitation and even signed a contract with Lugner, promising to attend. But on the way to the airport she received a call from her friend, Austrian emigre to the States, actor Arnold Schwarzenegger, who warned her that attending the ball might damage her Hollywood career. Bisset then cancelled.

Opera singers Neil Shicoff, Bo Skovhus and Nancy Gustafson also withdrew at the last minute, along with other artists. Shicoff, an American Jew sent an explanation to state opera director Ion Holender saying he had "strong moral reservations about meeting with people who belong to a party which encourages acceptance of neo-Nazi ideas".

But the opera ball, the high point in an intense ball-going season which sees everyone from dentists to coffee-house owners to psychotherapists putting on their own balls, will be the first big party for the new government, most of whose members will attend, joining hundreds of debutantes in their annual "coming-out" ritual.

However, the man at the centre of the scandal himself will not go to the ball. "Jorg Haider didn't buy a ticket," said an organiser.

fields.headline: The Tallulah file
fields.standfirst: This is the full text of an MI5 memo, dated 29 August 1928, dealing with an American actress behaving badly...
fields.trailText:
"The charge against Miss Tallulah Bankhead (an American aged 26) is quite 
simply, (a) that she is an extremely immoral woman, and (b) that in 
consequence of her association with some Eton boys last term, the latter 
have had to leave Eton.
fields.body:
"The charge against Miss Tallulah Bankhead (an American aged 26) is quite simply, (a) that she is an extremely immoral woman, and (b) that in consequence of her association with some Eton boys last term, the latter have had to leave Eton.

"As regards (a) according to informant, she is both a Lesbian and immoral woman. Informant believes that she comes from a respectable American family, her father who was a senator, having turned her out of the house when she was young owing to immoral proclivities. It is also said that she 'kept' a negress in America before she came to this country in 1925 and that she 'keeps' a girl in London now. As regards her more natural proclivities, informant tells me that she bestows her favours 'generously' without payment. Her first of many strings and his general reputation and mode of life, I would prefer not to set out on paper. Informant added that her 'circle' is a centre of vice patronised by at least one of the most prominent sodomites in London (the name was given) and that it was the considered opinion of the more respectable American actresses in this country that she was doing them a great deal of harm as people might be inclined to think that they were tarred with the same brush.

"As regards (b), it is common knowledge among Eton boys that certain boys, numbering 5 or 6, who were convicted of breaking bounds, had associated with this woman. I have not had an opportunity of obtaining the names of all the boys but they include (1) Lord Rosslyn's grandson (2) the third son of Sir Matthew (Scatters) Wilson Baronet (informant added that the two older sons of Sir M Wilson had been sent down from Eton some time ago and that the family is on intimate terms with T.B. and that the third son saved his skin by turning King's evidence during the Headmaster's inquiry) and (3) a boy named Parsons. There is no doubt that TB was seen at Eton frequently last term. I hear from another master that one or both of Sir M Wilson's older sons used to motor down to Eton with her to see the third son who was then smuggled away for the afternoon under a rug in the car. It is said this was the beginning of a TB Eton boys clique. Until we can obtain the names of all the boys and can consider whether one could be picked out who might, if the father consented, be examined on the question of his association, if any, with this woman it will be difficult , if not impossible, to proceed with this enquiry. " J H M 29/8/1928.

Until we can obtain the names of all the boys and can consider whether one could be picked out who might, if the father consented, be examined on the question of his association, if any, with this woman it will be difficult , if not impossible, to proceed with this enquiry. " J H M 29/8/1928.

fields.headline: New Labour, New Language?
fields.standfirst:
Read more about Language, politics, and government
Read more about Blair's rhetorical style
Read more about New Labour keywords: renewal, modernisation, and reform
fields.trailText:
"To those of us who find ourselves carried along helplessly in Tony Blair's rhetorical stream of consciousness, Norman Fairclough offers a life-saving branch to which we can cling, while we work out where we are and where we are being swept."
- Simon Hoggart
fields.body:
At the end of 1998, the British 'New Labour' Government had something of a crisis: two Cabinet ministers resigned in the face of accusations of financial impropriety. The worst blow was the loss of Peter Mandelson, the Minister for Trade and Industry, one of the chief architects of New Labour and of its electoral victory, and one of the closest allies of the Prime Minister, Tony Blair. Mandelson's departure led to intense speculation over a shift in direction on the part of the Government; in one formulation at the time: a move towards rather less of the 'new' and more of the 'Labour'.The Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott was widely interpreted as advocating such a shift. This was the interpretation which was for instance put on an interview he gave to the Independent, in which he said 'we need to get away from rhetoric and back on to the substance of government'. That statement apparently constituted the basis for the Independent's headline: 'Prescott bins the spin for real policies'. 'The spin' is an allusion to New Labour's 'spin-doctors', the people responsible for the media presentation of the Government and for putting a media 'spin' (or angle) on its policies and activities. Media communications are more carefully handled and more centrally controlled by the New Labour Government than any previous British government, and the Government has been accused by its critics of governing by media spin. Mandelson himself had overall responsibility for media communications as the Minister without Portfolio before he was shifted to the Department of Trade and Industry. He was closely associated with New Labour's reputation for being preoccupied with spin, and credited with being the spin-doctor par excellence.

John Prescott was interviewed on the BBC Radio 4 'Today' programme a few days after the interview in the Independent. He was at pains on that occasion to deny that there were any major divisions over policy or strategy within the Government. Indeed he returned to the contrast between 'rhetoric' and 'substance', but used it to set the Government against the press - given the manifesto undertakings it has implemented, the Government 'is a government of substance, of traditional values in a modern setting', it is the press that 'are not really interested in that substance', that go in for 'rhetoric'. But 'rhetoric' seems quite an appropriate way of describing what Prescott is doing here: having taken the opportunity of Mandelson's resignation (as well as Blair's absence abroad on holiday) to publicly air divisions within the Government and to take a position, he neatly relocates the 'rhetoric versus substance' issue as a criticism not of the Government but of the press. If politicians are to successfully pursue internal divisions in public in contemporary mediatised politics, they need the sort of skills Prescott is manifesting in this case: being able to venture a criticism in a sufficiently ambivalent way that one can draw back from it if challenged without bringing into question the unity of the Government or Party or one's own loyalty.

This is how the interviewer, Jim Naughtie, responded to Prescott:

You've made your point very clearly. The point though is that the way that people in government talk about these things is important, you'd acknowledge that. Indeed it was Mr Mandelson's credo that the way you talked about things, they way you used language was very important, because it sent out messages. And you don't need to be told that a lot of Labour MPs - when they saw what you were saying, the language you were using, 'traditional values' albeit 'in a modern setting' - were saying: 'Look, here at last is a little more of the stuff we want to hear. He doesn't talk about 'The Project' doesn't talk about 'New Labour', he talks about 'Labour' .'

And Prescott's answer was:

Yes but then that is presented as a kind of great division. It's not a division because I'm pointing out to you the things that every one of us support Û. the traditional values in a modern setting, what I'm saying is perhaps we should emphasize it a great deal more.

Naughtie is combining, perhaps confusing, two issues. One is the issue of what 'messages' politicians convey to one another through shifts of language - one way of seeing politics is as an ongoing struggle to achieve dominance of one political position over others which is partly enacted as a struggle for the dominance of political language, a struggle for instance to win acceptance for formulations like 'traditional values in a modern setting' rather than the 'Third Way', or 'Labour' rather than 'New Labour'. Naughtie is suggesting that this is what Prescott was doing in the interview, but Prescott rejects the implication of a division within New Labour: the question is only how much 'emphasis' is given to parts of what he implies is a shared language. Again, Prescott seems to be rhetorically covering over internal differences.

The second issue is the perception very much associated with Peter Mandelson that the language which politicians use 'sends messages' to the public, from which it has been seen to follow that the language has to be tightly monitored to make sure that it sends the 'right' message, or in favoured New Labour parlance is 'on message'. In fact one question that Naughtie asks Prescott is whether on this occasion he abided by Government policy that all ministerial media statements should be 'checked' by the Prime Minister's press office (headed by another formidable spin-doctor, Alistair Campbell). Prescott's rather sour reply was that he had 'talked to people' about what he 'was going to say' - he seems to avoid using the word 'check', which would imply the Deputy Prime Minister (Prescott) being subject to the judgement of an unelected official.

fields.headline: Met 'should look at racist killings'
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The police force investigating the mysterious hangings of two black men in Shropshire came under intense pressure to hand over the inquiry to a specialist unit at Scotland Yard following representations to the home secretary Jack Straw yesterday.
fields.body:
The police force investigating the mysterious hangings of two black men in Shropshire came under intense pressure to hand over the inquiry to a specialist unit at Scotland Yard following representations to the home secretary Jack Straw yesterday.

West Mercia police has so far refused to give control of the case to the racial and violent crimes task force, despite pleas from relatives of the dead men - Harold "Errol" McGowan, 34, and his nephew, Jason, 20, - who said they had lost confidence in local detectives.

However, Clifton McGowan, Harold's brother, travelled from Telford yesterday with other members of the family to meet the head of the task force, deputy assistant commissioner John Grieve.

Later they spoke to Mr Straw to press their demand that Mr Grieve's unit, which secured the convictions of the murderers of the black musician Michael Menson, be put in charge of the investigation.

A statement released by the home office afterwards said: "Mr Straw listened carefully to the concerns about the tragic deaths of Harold and Jason McGowan and expressed his sympathy to the family.

"He said he would consider carefully what was said and would communicate in due course with the family, their legal representatives and MPs."

Mr Straw does not have the authority to order West Mercia to hand over the inquiry to Scotland Yard. The decision can only be taken by West Mercia's chief constable, Peter Hampson. But Mr Grieve has indicated that he would be "willing and able" to take charge of the inquiry, and Mr Straw's statement offered no support to West Mercia. If Mr Straw were to support the family's demand, it would be a humiliation for West Mercia.

Errol Robinson, a lawyer acting for the McGowans, said: "We made a powerful case to the home secretary for the investigation to be removed from West Mercia and undertaken by the Metropolitan police's racial and violent crime task force."

Leroy McGowan, another of Harold's brothers, said: "It is our understanding that John Grieve will be willing to take over the case. It is our wish that he do so."

Jason's widow, Sinead, added: "We are satisfied with the way things have gone. I am going away with a positive outlook both with John Grieve and Jack Straw."

The McGowans believe West Mercia was too quick to dismiss the death of Harold McGowan last July as suicide. The family claimed he had been threatened with death by a white racist gang.

Jason McGowan, who was investigating his uncle's death, was found hanging from railings by a roadside on New Year's Day. Relatives said he had also been subjected to racist abuse and had no reason to take his own life.

West Mercia said last night that a fresh investigation into both deaths, led by Detective Superintendent Mel Shaw, had started and that his team would seek advice from Mr Grieve's unit when it was needed.

"The chief constable has not changed his mind about this," said a spokesman. "He has full confidence in the new investigation. We want the family to work with us."

The family delegation to London included two of Errol's other brothers, Deslie and Noel, his mother Icyline, and his sister Lorna. Jason's mother, Doreen, also travelled from Telford.

fields.headline: Oil prices
fields.standfirst: Fuel prices have jumped 55% in the past few weeks, stoking fears that high energy prices will trigger a global recession. Mark Tran explains the reasons behind the recent jump in prices.
fields.trailText: What's behind the rise?
fields.body:
What's behind the rise?

The price of oil has reached $31 (£20) a barrel - a level not seen since the 1990 Gulf war. At the start of last year, oil cost only $10 a barrel, having gone into a nosedive because of the Asian economic crisis in 1997. As Asia slumped into recession, demand for oil fell, driving down prices. The Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries - the cartel of 11 oil-producing countries - decided last year to cut back production by 4.3m barrels per day (bpd) to boost prices and it has succeeded spectacularly.

Haven't we been here before?

Opec used to be a little-known cartel formed in 1960 with five members - Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela. By the end of 1971 six other nations had joined the group - Qatar, Indonesia, Libya, United Arab Emirates, Algeria and Nigeria. The cartel reached public awareness after the 1973 October war, when Egypt and Syria launched a surprise attack on Israel. Arab exporters imposed an embargo on western countries supporting Israel. Oil prices quadrupled in the world's first oil crisis. Three other crises followed, however, the first was the most damaging.

Does Opec want another crisis?

No. Recession in the industrialised world is the last thing Opec wants. The cartel decided to curtail production last month in order to push the price up to a "fair" price of around $18-$20 a barrel. But it is notoriously hard to control markets and they often overshoot the mark. The US stock market is another example of a dangerously overheated market, according to analysts. In the oil market, prices have exceeded the intended target.

So what's being done about these prices?

The US is leading the effort to persuade Opec to raise production and bring down prices. Energy secretary Bill Richardson has been touring producing countries, cajoling them to open the spigots, and oil ministers have been talking about what to do before a formal Opec meeting on March 27. Opec officials say they expect the meeting to recommend that Opec increase output by 1.2m bpd, with a further rise of 500,000 bpd if prices did not fall sharply.

Would this be enough to lower prices?

Analysts believe not because it is only a quarter of the 4.3m bpd cut in production from last April. They argue that the price has already factored in an increase of 1.2m bpd.

Why is the US leading the effort for lower prices?

Because America - Opec's largest customer - is a huge consumer of energy and pressure is building on the White House to do something. Members of Congress have demanded that the Clinton administration cut off aid and arms sales to Opec countries as American citizens start to complain about the high price of petrol and domestic fuel. Even if Opec did respond to US pressure, it may come too late to prevent petrol prices - already at a 10-year peak - from hitting $2 a gallon this summer, when Americans fill up their tanks for the holidays. That would not bode well vice-president Al Gore in the Democratic presidential race for the White House. The US says it may release oil from its emergency reserves to depress prices.

fields.headline: PR, EU and FA
fields.trailText: MORE GREAT NEWCASTLE PR
fields.body:
MORE GREAT NEWCASTLE PR

Six Newcastle fans, who paid £500 for bonds which they believed (rather sweetly and naively as it turned out) guaranteed them the same seat for 10 years, have lost their legal fight against the club's plans to move them elsewhere. The ruling means that about 2,000 season ticket holders will have to move from their seats to make way for executive boxes.

The legal spat began when Newcastle announced plans to knock up a hospitality suite as part of a £45m redevelopment of the ground - which they say will accommodate an extra 15,000 supporters. But, if you ask the Fiver, it's more likely to host 15,000 half-cut and semi-interested businessmen instead. As they weren't allowed to simply chuck a new stand on top of supporters sitting in their seats - although that's an idea - the club informed 2,000 fans they would be shifted to far-flung corners of the stadium with poorer views than the ones they've already got (we're paraphrasing here of course).

Not surprisingly, some fans were unhappy with the scheme, and embarked on an ultimately unsuccessful legal battle, which was lost because it was ruled that the small print in the bond contract gave the club carte blanche to move folk about. However, there is some light at the end of the tunnel; the six supporters were given leave to appeal against the ruling on the grounds that the club had misrepresented its original bond offer in 1994. That's the sort of thing which could cause the Newcastle board some embarrassment in the future. The Fiver can't wait.

LIVE UEFA CUP STUFF

Telly schmelly. Follow Roma v Leeds (5pm) and Arsenal v Deportivo (8pm) live on Football Unlimited.

FA LEAD RESISTANCE MOVEMENT AGAINST FRENCHIE PLOT

Imagine a Europe where football was played in harmony, a world where the football calendar had exactly 76 match days, where all the leagues of Europe were a straight 18-club size, where pre-season friendlies kicked off in January, and the FA Cup final was played in November.

Well, dammit, such imaginings appear to translate as a federalist plot to our chaps in the FA. So this morning they bravely shot down Fifa's plans - fronted by Michel Platini, the Frenchman's Glenn Hoddle - to harmonise world football.

"The thoughts currently being expressed by Monsieur Platini are simply not practical," said FA spokesman Mike Lee in his best French. "We regard the idea of a single set calendar being imposed on world football as unworkable," our man Mike added, while busily tearing up euros in his Union Jack boxer shorts, with only a bull mastiff and a massive roasting joint of English beef for company as he stood proudly under the Arc de Triomphe.

Meanwhile, Mike's FA mate Adam Crozier was busy snuggling up to his Fifa and Uefa chums in Amsterdam, trying to work out a way to stop the flood of footballing Johnny Foreigners by exempting football from the EU's employment laws which enable the free flow of players between European leagues. All of which makes perfect sense in the Fiver's little black book of wartime diplomacy.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Everyone knows how much Tommy Burns loves Celtic. He still has an awful lot to offer the club." - Poor, optimistic Jackie McNamara heads for a terrible fall.

ALL THIS FUSS OVER ONE LITTLE HAMSTRING

The FA aren't very happy with Gerard Houllier's little scheme to play Michael Owen against Manchester United on Saturday morning. Owen, who has been struggling with a hamstring injury all year, sailed through a practice match yesterday and is expected to be named in the Liverpool team for their annual defeat at Old Trafford.

The FA's chief medical officer Alan Hodson doesn't think it's a good idea. "You can play him in five-a-side or practice matches and he may come through fine, but he won't play at the same pace and under stress like he would in front of 60,000." That much is true, although the Fiver reckons training under the watchful eye of Phil Thompson must push the stress levels pretty close to the max.

It doesn't look as though Hudson's polite pressure will have any effect on Gerard Houllier, who, in looking to chalk up Liverpool's first win at United since 1907, is beginning to show signs of cracking up. "I think he's fit," he chuckled, fooling only himself. "He really looks as though he's ready," Houllier tee-heed, his eyes whirling in an intense kind of way. "He's looking bubbly," he added, clearly living on his nerves. "He wants to play!" Nurse!

THE RUMOUR MILL

Niall Quinn could leave Sunderland before the end of this season, according to Opta Soccer. Contract negotiations have apparently stalled, with Quinn only being offered a pay rise for the final year of his current agreement and not a new deal.

Arsenal will pay £6m to land Marseille winger Robert Pires.

Middlesbrough and Leeds are interested in Tromso's Norwegian striker Rune Lange.

Nottingham Forest have joined Portsmouth in the chase for Aston Villa defender Colin Calderwood.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Uefa and Fifa are to increase pressure on politicians in a bid to find a compromise over the European Union's strict employment rules in the game's post-Bosman era.

Slaven Bilic today rejoined his hometown club, Hajduk Split, just 48 hours after his Everton contract was terminated.

Tottenham Hotspur are to freeze ticket prices for next season. Alan Sugar said: "In recognising the cost to our loyal supporters of attending matches, the board has decided that there is to be no increase in ticket prices next year."

Kenny Dalglish will bring Celtic to Anfield on May 16 to face his old club Liverpool in a testimonial for Ronnie Moran.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: World Football (2.30am)

It's a big thing played in a big place.

Channel 4: Football Italia (3.20am)

Nearly as popular as cycling. But a bit more interesting.

Channel 5: Uefa Cup Football - Live (4.50pm)

Roma v Leeds. Look, just have one good laugh at the word Totti and then let us watch the rest of it in peace.

Dutch Football (12.30am)

Even with the chance to indulge in soft drugs and prostitution they find the time to get good at footy.

Argentinian football (2.10am)

Even with the chance to play with little bits of ticker tape they find the time to get good at footy.

Footy Shorts (3.50am)

This week: Blackburn's return to the big time.

Sky Sports 1: Uefa Cup Football - Live (7pm, 12.15am)

Arsenal v Deportivo. It's not Big Cup so we don't care if we lose. Right you are.

You're On Sky Sports! (10.15pm, 4.15am)

Some interesting analysis from Fiver reader Steve Oakes: "McCaffrey is surely some kind of agent of the devil sent to earth to amuse us by tormenting Rodney Marsh. We only have to avoid watching him on TV; Rodney has to sit in a small room with him and act matey until he gets paid."

Spanish Football (11pm, 1.45am)

With possible reference to Real v Barca.

Fifa TV (2.45am)

Sepp's show.

Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5.30pm, 6.30pm SS1, 3.15am SS1)

"Lou Reed's Metal Machine Music is surely the most unlistenable album of all time," argues Paul Peschisolido.

Sky Sports 3: World Cup Classics (10pm)

Portugal play Hungary. Set your videos (for Upstairs Downstairs, which is on Granada Plus).

British Eurosport: Uefa Cup Football - Live (7.15pm)

The whole lot of some game or other.

Uefa Cup Football (9.15pm)

Highlights of this and that.

Sky One: Dream Team (6.30pm, 11pm)

Now that Drew from Eldorado has been booted out, there's a job going for Marcus Tandy. He'll need the work, surely.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Sport (7pm)

"You call this Uefa Cup football? I call it a load of talent-free shysters running after a leather sack."

talkSPORT: Uefa Special (7pm)

Coverage of the Uefa Cup in a Kelvin MacKenzie stylee. Feel free to switch off if you want.

Uefa Phone-in (10pm)

Like You're on Sky Sports! but without having to look at McCaff's face. Should be all right.

The legal spat began when Newcastle announced plans to knock up a hospitality suite as part of a £45m redevelopment of the ground - which they say will accommodate an extra 15,000 supporters. But, if you ask the Fiver, it's more likely to host 15,000 half-cut and semi-interested businessmen instead. As they weren't allowed to simply chuck a new stand on top of supporters sitting in their seats - although that's an idea - the club informed 2,000 fans they would be shifted to far-flung corners of the stadium with poorer views than the ones they've already got (we're paraphrasing here of course). Not surprisingly, some fans were unhappy with the scheme, and embarked on an ultimately unsuccessful legal battle, which was lost because it was ruled that the small print in the bond contract gave the club carte blanche to move folk about. However, there is some light at the end of the tunnel; the six supporters were given leave to appeal against the ruling on the grounds that the club had misrepresented its original bond offer in 1994. That's the sort of thing which could cause the Newcastle board some embarrassment in the future. The Fiver can't wait. LIVE UEFA CUP STUFF Telly schmelly. Follow Roma v Leeds (5pm) and Arsenal v Deportivo (8pm) live on Football Unlimited. FA LEAD RESISTANCE MOVEMENT AGAINST FRENCHIE PLOT Imagine a Europe where football was played in harmony, a world where the football calendar had exactly 76 match days, where all the leagues of Europe were a straight 18-club size, where pre-season friendlies kicked off in January, and the FA Cup final was played in November. Well, dammit, such imaginings appear to translate as a federalist plot to our chaps in the FA. So this morning they bravely shot down Fifa's plans - fronted by Michel Platini, the Frenchman's Glenn Hoddle - to harmonise world football. "The thoughts currently being expressed by Monsieur Platini are simply not practical," said FA spokesman Mike Lee in his best French. "We regard the idea of a single set calendar being imposed on world football as unworkable," our man Mike added, while busily tearing up euros in his Union Jack boxer shorts, with only a bull mastiff and a massive roasting joint of English beef for company as he stood proudly under the Arc de Triomphe. Meanwhile, Mike's FA mate Adam Crozier was busy snuggling up to his Fifa and Uefa chums in Amsterdam, trying to work out a way to stop the flood of footballing Johnny Foreigners by exempting football from the EU's employment laws which enable the free flow of players between European leagues. All of which makes perfect sense in the Fiver's little black book of wartime diplomacy. QUOTE OF THE DAY "Everyone knows how much Tommy Burns loves Celtic. He still has an awful lot to offer the club." - Poor, optimistic Jackie McNamara heads for a terrible fall. ALL THIS FUSS OVER ONE LITTLE HAMSTRING The FA aren't very happy with Gerard Houllier's little scheme to play Michael Owen against Manchester United on Saturday morning. Owen, who has been struggling with a hamstring injury all year, sailed through a practice match yesterday and is expected to be named in the Liverpool team for their annual defeat at Old Trafford. The FA's chief medical officer Alan Hodson doesn't think it's a good idea. "You can play him in five-a-side or practice matches and he may come through fine, but he won't play at the same pace and under stress like he would in front of 60,000." That much is true, although the Fiver reckons training under the watchful eye of Phil Thompson must push the stress levels pretty close to the max. It doesn't look as though Hudson's polite pressure will have any effect on Gerard Houllier, who, in looking to chalk up Liverpool's first win at United since 1907, is beginning to show signs of cracking up. "I think he's fit," he chuckled, fooling only himself. "He really looks as though he's ready," Houllier tee-heed, his eyes whirling in an intense kind of way. "He's looking bubbly," he added, clearly living on his nerves. "He wants to play!" Nurse! THE RUMOUR MILL Niall Quinn could leave Sunderland before the end of this season, according to Opta Soccer. Contract negotiations have apparently stalled, with Quinn only being offered a pay rise for the final year of his current agreement and not a new deal. Arsenal will pay £6m to land Marseille winger Robert Pires. Middlesbrough and Leeds are interested in Tromso's Norwegian striker Rune Lange. Nottingham Forest have joined Portsmouth in the chase for Aston Villa defender Colin Calderwood. NEWS IN BRIEF Uefa and Fifa are to increase pressure on politicians in a bid to find a compromise over the European Union's strict employment rules in the game's post-Bosman era. Slaven Bilic today rejoined his hometown club, Hajduk Split, just 48 hours after his Everton contract was terminated. Tottenham Hotspur are to freeze ticket prices for next season. Alan Sugar said: "In recognising the cost to our loyal supporters of attending matches, the board has decided that there is to be no increase in ticket prices next year." Kenny Dalglish will bring Celtic to Anfield on May 16 to face his old club Liverpool in a testimonial for Ronnie Moran. Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5.30pm, 6.30pm SS1, 3.15am SS1) "Lou Reed's Metal Machine Music is surely the most unlistenable album of all time," argues Paul Peschisolido. British Eurosport: Uefa Cup Football - Live (7.15pm) The whole lot of some game or other. Uefa Cup Football (9.15pm) Highlights of this and that. Sky One: Dream Team (6.30pm, 11pm) Now that Drew from Eldorado has been booted out, there's a job going for Marcus Tandy. He'll need the work, surely.
