webTitle: Who said what: British and international reaction to Pinochet's release

fields.headline: Who said what: British and international reaction to Pinochet's release
fields.trailText:
"At last the home secretary has summoned up the courage to end a grand farce laced with treachery by which this staunch ally of Britain has been imprisoned without trial for over a year. The cost to General Pinochet, the cost to our relationship with Chile and the cost in financial terms to the taxpayer of this mad escapade must all be laid at the door of the home secretary."
Lord Tebbit, Conservative peer
fields.body:
"At last the home secretary has summoned up the courage to end a grand farce laced with treachery by which this staunch ally of Britain has been imprisoned without trial for over a year. The cost to General Pinochet, the cost to our relationship with Chile and the cost in financial terms to the taxpayer of this mad escapade must all be laid at the door of the home secretary."
Lord Tebbit, Conservative peer

"I think there will be a few glasses raised behind closed doors. It's been extremely difficult for everyone but especially disruptive for those with properties closest to the house. It's a most unsuitable place to hold political prisoners. Now life can get back to normal."
Wentworth residents' association chairman Barry Hughes

"Politics and government intervention has got in the way of justice. This cannot be right. He left the estate by a back route like a criminal. He is going on the grounds of compassion not because he is innocent. We feel let down by Britain and in particular by this Labour government."
Demonstrator Sylvia Velasquez

"He was obviously nervous and anxious ahead of the decision. He was told in a telephone call very shortly before it was made public. He will have been delighted."
Patrick Robertson, adviser to General Pinochet

"It's a terrible disappointment for Pinochet's thousands of victims that he will not face trial in Spain. But the very fact that he was arrested, and that his claim of immunity was rejected, has already changed the calculus of dictators around the world. The Pinochet case signified the beginning of the end of their impunity."
Reed Brody, advocacy director of Human Rights Watch

"I'm not surprised by this decision, which confirms that England is still a safe haven for criminals of all kinds."
Bernard Bertrossa, the Swiss prosecuting magistrate who applied for Pinochet's extradition. Reported by right-leaning Spanish daily ABC

"The cases being brought in Chile by Judge Guzmán and judge Muñoz have gone so far now that they should lead to a point at which Gen Pinochet is tried. I can foresee the course of events leading to a trial of Pinochet in Chile. Obviously, these cases will be a helped a great deal by Gen Pinochet being returned to Chile."
Juan Gabriel Valdés, Chilean foreign minister, speaking to centre-left Spanish daily El País

"I respect Straw's decision. What I don't know is, what does everyone else [the opposition Socialist party - which has criticised the decision] have respect for. [My government] has respected the decision of the Spanish justice system to seek Pinochet's extradition, while the same people [the socialists] criticised it. The government's attitude has been the same right from the start. The rest [the socialist stance] seems to me to be an internal rumpus, which makes me laugh."
José María Aznar, Spanish prime minister, quoted by Spanish news agency EFE, talking to right of centre radio station COPE

"The idea that many people have outside Chile that Pinochet is in a position to arrive back here, bang his fist on the table and say 'Nobody here is going to court' is madness.

"I would be sorry if Pinochet's arrival upset the handover of power... We can't rule out the possibility that there will be difficult times ahead, but we hope they won't be too difficult.

"The president doesn't exercise justice, but he must ensure that the judiciary is able to do so without conditions or external pressures, or else we would be looking at a castrated democracy... In my country, no-one is above the law, whatever their name.

"The humanitarian appeal, such as it's outlined in the English system, as we've recently seen, does not exist in Chile."
Chilean president-elect Ricardo Lagos, speaking in Uruguay. Reported in liberal-leaning Chilean daily La Tercera

La Tercera in a separate report suggests that "the imminent return of Augusto Pinochet could allow the Discussion Forum on human rights, which was established last August, to stop being an arena for analysis and enter history as the body which achieved consensus between the armed forces and human rights lawyers as to legal mechanisms for the resolution of outstanding questions such as that of the 'disappeared'." The paper goes on to say that a report from the Discussion Forum was yesterday handed to military authorities.

The return of Pinochet is not a defeat. Even though Pinochet is returning to Chile, he is returning as the accused, we must not forget that.
Viviana Díaz, spokesman for the Group of Families of the Disappeared, quoted in mainstrean Chilean daily El Mercurio de Santiago

"The Spanish government is guilty for this feeling [that Pinochet has] impunity, because throughout this process the government has done nothing but support the arguments in defence of Pincochet - whether explicitly or implicitly, and obstruct the actions of the Spanish judiciary.

"It saddens me, as a Spaniard, to see that Belgium - its ministers and government - reacts, and that the Spanish government does not know how to and makes no response."
Joaquín Almunia, leader of the Spanish opposition Socialist party, speaking to Spanish radio network SER

One of the principal challenges facing Ricardo Lagos, the first socialist president elected in Chile since Salvador Allende - overthrown by the coup of September 11 1973 - will be to better relations with the powerful armed forces. Since the ex-dictator's arrest in October 1998, relations have been "at a standstill", say sources at the Chilean Socialist party.

Mr Lagos, who takes office on March 11, could benefit from having obtained the release and return of the old army strong man. The military had accused the government of "failing to be firm" with Great Britain.

This diplomatic success, however, may have been obtained by way of assurances that the Chilean justice system would be in a position to try Gen Pinochet. How can he reconcile respect for justice with the fierce opposition of the military men to seeing their "natural leader" hauled up in front of the courts?
Christine Legrand, writing in Le Monde

fields.headline: Pinochet case sets international precedent
fields.trailText:
Augusto Pinochet has escaped trial, but there is one substantial and
lasting legacy from his 17 months as an unwilling exile:  international law
will never be the same again.
fields.body:
Augusto Pinochet has escaped trial, but there is one substantial and lasting legacy from his 17 months as an unwilling exile: international law will never be the same again.

The battle to bring the former Chilean dictator to justice, culminating in the law lords' ruling a year ago opening the way for his prosecution, has put the entire international regime of human rights law on an established footing.

The old doctrines of sovereign immunity under which former heads of state were shielded from criminal action at the behest of authorities in foreign states, and "act of state" - which means the courts of one state will not question the legality of official acts by another - have given way to the emerging international law principle of individual responsibility for crimes against humanity.

When Gen Pinochet first went to the high court to challenge the arrest warrant issued against him at Spain's request, the answer seemed simple. Three judges held that the doctrines of sovereign immunity and act of state gave the former Chilean dictator complete immunity from prosecution.

The House of Lords ruled that he could stand trial, but by the narrow margin of three-two. In the opinion of Lord Slynn, one of the minority, international law had moved on, but not that far.

But the lords overturned their own ruling when it emerged that Lord Hoffmann, one of the majority, had links with Amnesty International, which had intervened in the case.

The final judgment by a rarely convened panel of seven law lords, gave the go-ahead for prosecution by six-one. The law lords held that Gen Pinochet could be prosecuted in Britain or extradited to stand trial under British acts of parliament, which gave effect to our obligations under international treaties.

The judgment, probably the most momentous Britain's highest court has ever delivered, now stands as a key precedent in international law throughout the world. It confirms that the whole edifice of international treaties and national laws set up to ensure that those, even at the highest level, who commit crimes against humanity have no hiding place is not just a well-meaning gesture.

Former dictators will have to think twice before setting foot in any of the many countries, which have signed up to international treaties on torture and hostage-taking, and the case stands as a warning to those tempted to commit such crimes in future.

Another legacy of the Pinochet case could be eventual reform for the law lords' court. The debacle over Lord Hoffmann's failure to declare his links with Amnesty damaged the standing of the House of Lords as a court in the eyes of the world.

Apart from revealing a serious and elementary error of judgment on the part of one of Britain's most senior judges, it exposed for the first time what had gone largely unnoticed: the extent to which justice is a lottery in Britain's highest court. Had Lord Hoffmann disqualified himself and a different judge sat, the result could have gone the other way.

In the highest courts of other countries, such as the US supreme court, all the judges sit, giving their judgments much greater credibility. The Pinochet story has strengthened the case for the transformation of the law lords into a true supreme court.

fields.headline: Language, politics, and government
fields.standfirst:
Politics and the mass media
The cult of personality
The Third Way
fields.trailText:
Politics and the mass media
The cult of personality
The Third Way
fields.body:
Language has always been important in politics and in government (I don't see politics and government as the same thing - I shall draw a distinction between them below). Political differences have always been constituted as differences in language, political struggles have always been partly struggles over the dominant language, and both the theory and practice of political rhetoric go back to ancient times. Language has therefore always been a relevant consideration in political analysis. But language has become significantly more important over the past few decades because of social changes which have transformed politics and government. An important part of these changes is a new relationship between politics, government and mass media - a new synthesis which means that many significant political events are now in fact media events (for instance, a TV interview with the Prime Minister can itself be a major political event). There has been what one might call a 'mediatisation' of politics and government.The particular genius of Peter Mandelson has perhaps been in seeing that these changes may have more radical implications for the nature of politics and government than has so far been realised. Mandelson has not been alone in seeing this: to a degree what he has done is bring to British politics developments which have been going on elsewhere, particularly in the USA. But there is also a process of change which is being referred to in the USA, Britain and internationally as the 'reinvention of government', which entails a greater focusing of language.

One consequence of the 'mediatisation' of politics and govern-ment is the transformation of political leaders into media personalities. This probably started in Britain with Harold Macmillan in the 1950s. Tony Blair's immensely successful populist leadership style is comparable in certain respects with Margaret Thatcher's, though very different in other respects. The communicative style of leaders is now recognised as a crucial factor in political success or failure, and Labour is acutely aware of this because their recent history has included failures, notably Michael Foot but also to some extent Neil Kinnock. Communicative style is a matter of language in the broadest sense - certainly verbal language (words), but also all other aspects of the complex bodily performance that constitutes political style (gestures, facial expressions, how people hold them-selves and move, dress and hairstyle, and so forth). A successful leader's communicative style is not simply what makes him or her attractive to voters in a general way, it conveys certain values which can powerfully enhance the political 'message'.

New Labour claims to be a 'new politics'. According to Tony Blair, "ideas need labels if they are to become popular and widely understood. The 'Third Way' is to my mind the best label for the new politics which the progressive centre-left is forging in Britain and beyond". Notice two things about this: first, the 'Third Way' is being 'forged'; second, 'forging' it is linked to making it 'popular and widely understood'. The 'Third Way' does not come ready-formed, nor is it forged once-and-for-all. On the contrary, New Labour politicians are constantly forming and formulating it, in speeches, newspaper articles, books and pamphlets, official documents, etc. They are constantly working on making coherent connections between the policies and ideas - 'enterprise', 'flexibility', 'welfare-to-work', 'social exclusion/inclusion', 'participation','fairness', and so forth.The 'Third Way' is constantly being talked into being, new language is constantly being found to bring these elements together into a coherent whole. This is a process that cannot be completed ¾ circumstances keep changing, and differences within New Labour are worked through in different formulations, differences of language. And crucially this is going on in public - there is no clear line between finding policies that work and finding policies that win consent. As Franklin puts it, 'New Labour' is perhaps the first government genuinely committed to the view that presentation is part of the process of policy formation'. Analysing the shifting language of the 'Third Way' is an essential part of getting to grips with the 'new politics' of New Labour.

At the same time, New Labour is involved in a 'reinvention of government' which in itself entails a greater salience for language. In part, this is a matter of a new form of control from the centre based upon business corporation models, including promotional means for managing consent.This involves 'government by media spin', but also what Blair has referred to as 'experiments in democracy' through for instance 'focus groups' and 'citizens' juries', which allow the Government to develop its policy in a way that incorporates public opinion from the start. But the centralised management of political communication in the New Labour Government seems to be at odds with another aspect of the 'reinvention of government' - the Government's commitment to 'devolving power and making government more open and responsive'. This includes a certain dispersal of government, which is indicated by the concept of 'participation' - a great many task forces, reviews and advisory groups have been set up with memberships that bring together the Government, business, voluntary organisations and other sections of society. Many groups and people who have hitherto not been involved in government are being drawn in, and it is in that sense that government is becoming more dispersed. However, this does not mean that the centre has given up control - it is a dispersal, but not a fragmentation. In so far as 'partnership' becomes a reality rather than just a rhetoric, it entails a new form of control that crucially involves language - shaping the culture, discourse and language of the dispersed agents of government rather than directly controlling what they do.

A successful leader's communicative style is not simply what makes him or her attractive to voters in a general way, it conveys certain values which can powerfully enhance the political 'message'. New Labour claims to be a 'new politics'. According to Tony Blair, "ideas need labels if they are to become popular and widely understood. The 'Third Way' is to my mind the best label for the new politics which the progressive centre-left is forging in Britain and beyond". Notice two things about this: first, the 'Third Way' is being 'forged'; second, 'forging' it is linked to making it 'popular and widely understood'. The 'Third Way' does not come ready-formed, nor is it forged once-and-for-all. On the contrary, New Labour politicians are constantly forming and formulating it, in speeches, newspaper articles, books and pamphlets, official documents, etc. They are constantly working on making coherent connections between the policies and ideas - 'enterprise', 'flexibility', 'welfare-to-work', 'social exclusion/inclusion', 'participation','fairness', and so forth.The 'Third Way' is constantly being talked into being, new language is constantly being found to bring these elements together into a coherent whole. This is a process that cannot be completed ¾ circumstances keep changing, and differences within New Labour are worked through in different formulations, differences of language. And crucially this is going on in public - there is no clear line between finding policies that work and finding policies that win consent. As Franklin puts it, 'New Labour' is perhaps the first government genuinely committed to the view that presentation is part of the process of policy formation'. Analysing the shifting language of the 'Third Way' is an essential part of getting to grips with the 'new politics' of New Labour. At the same time, New Labour is involved in a 'reinvention of government' which in itself entails a greater salience for language. In part, this is a matter of a new form of control from the centre based upon business corporation models, including promotional means for managing consent.This involves 'government by media spin', but also what Blair has referred to as 'experiments in democracy' through for instance 'focus groups' and 'citizens' juries', which allow the Government to develop its policy in a way that incorporates public opinion from the start. But the centralised management of political communication in the New Labour Government seems to be at odds with another aspect of the 'reinvention of government' - the Government's commitment to 'devolving power and making government more open and responsive'. This includes a certain dispersal of government, which is indicated by the concept of 'participation' - a great many task forces, reviews and advisory groups have been set up with memberships that bring together the Government, business, voluntary organisations and other sections of society. Many groups and people who have hitherto not been involved in government are being drawn in, and it is in that sense that government is becoming more dispersed. However, this does not mean that the centre has given up control - it is a dispersal, but not a fragmentation. In so far as 'partnership' becomes a reality rather than just a rhetoric, it entails a new form of control that crucially involves language - shaping the culture, discourse and language of the dispersed agents of government rather than directly controlling what they do. Go back to New Labour, new language? fields.headline: Pinochet flies free
fields.standfirst: Dictators cannot now 'assume they are safe' claims Straw
fields.trailText: General Augusto Pinochet is flying home to Chile after home secretary Jack Straw ruled that the former dictator should not be extradited to Spain to face allegations of human rights crimes.
fields.body:
General Augusto Pinochet is flying home to Chile after home secretary Jack Straw ruled that the former dictator should not be extradited to Spain to face allegations of human rights crimes.

There were cries of "shame" in the Commons as Mr Straw confirmed that Gen Pinochet "has now left the jurisdiction of the UK".

A Chilean air force jet carrying the 84-year-old took off from RAF Waddington, near Lincoln, at 1.10pm today, after a police escort had rushed the former dictator from Wentworth, Surrey, where he had been under house arrest since October 1998.

Mr Straw announced his decision to release Gen Pinochet at 8am this morning in a written parliamentary answer. "I have today decided that I will not order the extradition of senator Pinochet to Spain," Mr Straw said.

The home secretary told the Commons this afternoon that he was "satisfied the conclusion of the medical report was correct", which had led to his January decision that he was "minded" to release Gen Pinochet. A trial "however desirable was simply no longer possible", he said.

But he said the lasting legacy to the 17 months of wrangling over the Pinochet case was "the principle that those who commit human rights abuses in one country cannot assume that they are safe elsewhere".

The House of Lords judgment which denied Gen Pinochet blanket immunity was "a landmark judgment in human rights law, whose impact has been felt far beyond our shores", Mr Straw said. "It will be a permanent legacy of the Pinochet case."

He explained that Britain's extradition obligations had given him a "quasi-judicial role" in the case, making the decisions to allow the extradition to proceed, before revoking it on health grounds "mine and mine alone, and not those of Her Majesty's government".

In the wake of this "unprecedented case", the extradition act of 1989 needed to be reviewed, the home secretary said, confirming that he would publish consultation papers on "streamlining" the extradition process.

After renewed appeals from Belgium and Amnesty International against Mr Straw's January decision, the home secretary revealed that the medical report which found Gen Pinochet unfit to stand trial had been reconsidered by the government's chief medical officer Liam Donaldson, who confirmed its "quality and thoroughness".

Ann Widdecombe, the shadow home secretary, responded to Mr Straw's statement by calling his decision "a satisfactory outcome, but of a deeply unsatisfactory case". Ms Widdecombe asked for an estimate of the "full costs" of the case.

The Liberal Democrats' home affairs spokesman Simon Hughes predicted "huge international anger and disappointment if today's decision means that serious allegations against Gen Pinochet are now never heard in court".

But he said the legal wrangling was "still a victory for international human rights".

"An important precedent has been set. Regardless of the fact that Gen Pinochet himself may not face trial, heads of state and government from now on will know that they may be brought before the courts if they act in violation of the human rights of others."

"This drawn out saga shows that an international criminal court is desperately needed and cannot be set up too soon," Mr Hughes added.

webTitle: LA's deportees send crime rate soaring in El Salvador

fields.headline: LA's deportees send crime rate soaring in El Salvador
fields.trailText: Baggy jeans bought with stolen necklaces. An attitude, a tattoo and a supply of crack cocaine. Malvin Antario looks like a gang leader from Los Angeles. But his home in Soyapango, in El Salvador, is a far cry from even the most deprived LA housing estate.
fields.byline: By Lucy Jones in San Salvador
fields.body:
Baggy jeans bought with stolen necklaces. An attitude, a tattoo and a supply of crack cocaine. Malvin Antario looks like a gang leader from Los Angeles. But his home in Soyapango, in El Salvador, is a far cry from even the most deprived LA housing estate.

The corrugated iron shacks have no running water. There are flies and rats. Sewage runs through the streets of this slum, which is separated from slightly better-off neighbourhoods by a graffiti-covered wall.

"I wanted to be able to get money for drugs and clothes. I wanted to fit in, I wanted something to do, so I joined the 18th Street," says Antario.

The 18th Street is one of several gangs in El Salvador with roots in LA, introduced when the United States started deporting legal and illegal Salvadorean immigrants with US criminal records, following the end of El Salvador's 12-year civil war in 1992.

In the last fiscal year the US deported 62,359 criminals, up from 37,000 three years earlier. But while the deportations are marginally lowering crime rates, freeing up prison space and saving taxpayers' money in the US, they are leading to a proliferation of US gang habits in El Salvador and other countries in Central America.

"Kids see deported gang members from LA who have nice clothes, who do things for money, like sell drugs and do tattoos, and they want to be like them. They don't want to be like their dad working in the fields or their mother washing clothes," says William Huezo, an LA deportee living in the capital, San Salvador.

The two main gangs in El Salvador are the 18th Street and Mara Salvatrucha, both exported from LA. The cities and even rural areas have been divided between these well-armed rival factions, who mark their territories with graffiti. As a result of their activity, crime has soared.

Gang members are thought to be responsible for 10% of El Salvador's staggering annual murder rate of 120 per 100,000 people (Britain has a rate of less than two per 100,000, the US eight per 100,000). Not only do they kill each other, but also passers-by caught in the crossfire. They rob backpackers, kidnap, steal cars, deal drugs and extort money from businesses.

"More than 300 deported Salvadoreans arrive in the country from the US every month. These are people who have not just been in jail but have often committed crimes after they have left jail. They are having a huge impact on the country," saysEduardo Alfonso Linares, head of San Salvador's police force.

But psychologists say the damage done by El Salvador's civil war is also responsible for the rise in membership of gangs. The war took the lives of more than 75,000 people.

As a result, many family units have been destroyed, leaving children in the care of people to whom they are only loosely related. Often these relatives cannot afford to send their children to school.

Meanwhile gang life gives young people something to do and a sense of belonging.

"The war has made people much more tolerant of violence. People tend to solve everyday disputes with violence. This has been passed down to the next generation," says Marcela Smutt, a consultant on gangs for a United Nations research project Violence in a Society in Transition.

El Salvador's congress is debating whether to try children as young as 14 in adult courts, and has agreed to fund more jails for juveniles. But organisations working with children say these are not the right answers.

"Gangs in big numbers are an expression of social exclusion. But what is the government doing? They're constructing more jails instead of providing schools and asking for more family responsibility," says Karla Hanania de Varela, child rights officer at Unicef.

Some government members say the heart of the problem lies with Washington's policy, and have complained to President Clinton.

"Many violent offences, like murder and kidnapping, are committed by young people who have been in the US and are sent back here with no warning. As these deportations increase, so do crime rates," says Milagro Hernandez, of the justice department.

But the signs from the US are that, rather than examine the knock-on criminal effect its policy is having abroad, it is going to step up its deportation of immigrants with criminal records.

 The Association of Journalists of El Salvador demanded last week that President Francisco Flores explain why a radio programme on a state-run station was cancelled because of its frequent criticism of the government.

"We are concerned at the fact that the station's director said she had orders from superiors to cancel the programme, because of dissatisfaction with the opinions it expressed, some critical of the government," the press association said in a statement.

webTitle: Inside the mind of the great survivor

fields.headline: Inside the mind of the great survivor
fields.standfirst: Saddam Hussein: The Politics of Revenge by Sad K Aburish, Bloomsbury 406pp £20
fields.trailText: In the summer of 1996 the British security service MI6 and the CIA were planning a joint operation in Iraq. They believed that senior Iraqi army officers were ready and willing to mount a coup against Saddam Hussein. The CIA provided logistical support, including special mobile phones with direct access to the agency's station chief in the Jordanian capital, Amman.
fields.body:
In the summer of 1996 the British security service MI6 and the CIA were planning a joint operation in Iraq. They believed that senior Iraqi army officers were ready and willing to mount a coup against Saddam Hussein. The CIA provided logistical support, including special mobile phones with direct access to the agency's station chief in the Jordanian capital, Amman.

But Saddam Hussein likes to boast that he knows who will betray him before they know it themselves. He has even set up a special intelligence unit, which has studied every coup of the 20th century. So Saddam moved first. Hundreds of officers were arrested, tortured and executed. In one raid an Iraqi intelligence agent found one of the CIA's special phones and used it to make a call. When an American answered, he told him: "Your men are dead. Pack up and go home."

Saïd Aburish, a distinguished journalist and author of a revealing life of Saddam, has unusual qualifications as a biographer. In the mid-1970s he was a go-between for Western businesses and arms manufacturers, whom Saddam wanted to work in Iraq. So he played a part in Saddam's long-term plan to build an arsenal of chemical and nuclear weapons.

His career as a middleman gave him unusually close access to Saddam, and an insight into the way he thinks. His portrait shows a man who may be cruel and ruthless but who is also a clear-headed, strategic thinker. Significantly, Saddam was still only vice-president when he embarked on his programme to acquire the weapons of mass destruction that could make Iraq the key player in the Middle East. Why a cultivated Palestinian such as Aburish would be willing to work for one of the most blood-stained tyrants of our age says much about Arab psychology.

Like many others, Aburish longed to back a winner and to see one Arab leader grow militarily and economic ally strong enough to stand up for himself. Saddam's Iraq didn't look like a bad bet. Its large population is comparatively well educated. Its women are relatively liberated. To support Saddam in the 1970s was to support the possibility of a progressive Arab state.

At first Saddam did not seem to put a foot wrong. He skilfully played the Soviet Union and the United States off against each other. He used Iraq's oil revenues to build up the economy and the military. However, it is no coincidence that he also created one of the region's most ruthlessly efficient secret police forces. As Aburish shows, Saddam's role model is Stalin. His library is lined with books about the great dictator. Like Stalin, Saddam was willing to do anything, kill anyone to modernise his country. Not that Saddam was ever a communist - but then, as he sees it, nor was Stalin.

This helps to explain the long and close relationship that Aburish documents between Saddam and the CIA. The agency first spotted him when he was an exile in Cairo who had just tried to assassinate Iraq's head of state. Saddam became a regular visitor at the US embassy. When Saddam's faction of the Ba'ath party seized power in 1968 the CIA provided his group with a hit list of known and suspected communist sympathisers.

Saddam showed himself to be an enthusiastic, hands-on killer and torturer. When he finally grabbed supreme power for himself he continued to enjoy wary support from Washington. He may have been a thug, but at least he was not a communist or a religious fundamentalist.

The hypocrisy and amorality of Western policy make uncomfortable reading. Saddam's war on Iran was his bid to be the dominant power in the region. It turned out to be his first great miscalculation. At least Saddam could count on support from the Americans, whose CIA agents delivered regular packages of satellite photographs and military intelligence to Iraq's top brass.

This beautiful friendship came to an end when the Iran-Contra affair showed Saddam how deeply he had been betrayed by the White House. He seems to have blundered into the Gulf war. But faced with the onslaught of half a million allied troops, he is supposed to have said: "If I survive, I win."

In the past decade Saddam has survived everything the world has thrown at him: defeat in the Gulf war, popular uprisings, sanctions, assassination attempts, United Nations arms inspectors bent on destroying his weapons, and an air war in which US and British pilots have flown more sorties over Iraq than Nato flew during the war in Kosovo.

But he survives, an exemplar of do's and don'ts for future dictators. In writing about the life and times of Saddam Hussein, Aburish has set himself a difficult task. Saddam grants almost no interviews, Iraq's official archives remain closed, and second sources are in short supply. Despite this, Aburish's unmatched contacts in the Middle East enable him to provide a rare glimpse into the secret world of Saddam.

The definitive academic history may not be written until long after Saddam's demise. When it does appear, it is unlikely significantly to alter or improve on the insights and perspectives found in this chilling biography.

fields.headline: Gaelic
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about Gaelic on the net
fields.trailText: 1. Fàilte! Which, to all our non-Gaelic speakers, means "welcome" on this auspicious day for the Scottish language.
fields.body:
1. Fàilte! Which, to all our non-Gaelic speakers, means "welcome" on this auspicious day for the Scottish language.

2. Unfortunately the non-Gaelic speaking community extends to all but two members of the Scottish parliament. Unfortunate because the chamber is today having its first debate in the language.

3. They are discussing the future of Gaelic in schools

4. Those who don't speak it will either have to learn the language (as some MSPs are) or get someone else to translate.

5. Gaelic is a Celtic language brought over to the Scottish highlands by Irish colonists in the fourth century AD. It is closely related to Welsh and Cornish - modern versions of an ancient British tongue.

6. However, only 1% of the Scottish population today speaks Gaelic, and even in the middle ages it had to fight against Scots, a form of Old English spoken by the seventh-century Anglo-Saxons who settled the lowlands.

7. As a minority language, many fear that Gaelic is on the wire, but the net has (yet again) come to the rescue - Tobar an Dualchais (the Well of Heritage project) aims to record 18,000 examples of spoken and sung Gaelic.

8. On a smaller scale, the Tocher project at the school of Scottish studies records ditties such as Fhir a' Chinn Duibh - the story of a piper whose seven sons die of a fever within the same year.

9. The Gaelic heartlands are located in the north-east Highlands and Hebrides, where signs supported by the national development agency for Scottish Gaelic Comunn na Gàidhlig proudly announce: "Tha a' Ghàidhlig a' bruidhinn an seo" ("Gaelic is spoken here").

10. And in the 80s, there were 500 Gaelic speakers in Nova Scotia (New Scotland), Canada.

fields.headline: Newcastle fans lose seat fight
fields.trailText: Six Newcastle United fans have lost their legal fight against the club's plans to move them from their places to make way for more corporate hospitality seats.
fields.body:
Six Newcastle United fans have lost their legal fight against the club's plans to move them from their places to make way for more corporate hospitality seats.

Around 70 fans sat in silence at a packed public gallery at the High Court in Newcastle as the judgment was read out.

The six fans believed £500 bonds they bought in 1994 as season ticket holders guaranteed them to the same seat for 10 years.

But Mr Justice Blackburne ruled after a four-day hearing that small print in the bond contract meant the club were able to move the fans.

fields.headline: Israel's Arabs: citizens or subversives?
fields.standfirst: A shoot-out has focused attention on Israel's frequently overlooked minority of Arab citizens. Derek Brown, former Guardian correspondent in Jerusalem, reports
fields.trailText: We don't yet know their identity, but the two men who died in Taibeh today -   and a third who was captured and is now being interrogated - are   uncomfortable reminders for Israelis of the ticking demographic timebomb in   their midst.
fields.body:
We don't yet know their identity, but the two men who died in Taibeh today - and a third who was captured and is now being interrogated - are uncomfortable reminders for Israelis of the ticking demographic timebomb in their midst.

Only 36 per cent of the global Jewish population lives in Israel. That proportion is rising steadily as immigrants stream into the Zionist state. But the number, and proportion, of Arabs living in Israel is also increasing.

At its birth a little more than half a century ago, the modern state of Israel had just 800,000 citizens. The cruel war of independence, in which the fledgling Jewish state had to fight for its life against invading Arab armies, was accompanied by a massive exodus of Arab civilians from the Holy Land, which both Arabs and Jews used to call Palestine.

The borders of the new state of Israel, as defined by the United Nations, expanded dramatically as it beat back the invaders. And within them was a significant remnant of the Arab indigenous population.

In the Six-Day war of 1967, Israel's de facto borders again lurched forward to take in the West Bank, the Golan Heights, the Gaza Strip and the Sinai peninsula. This time the Arab population of the captured territories largely stayed put. Israel acquired a new population of subjects, who were never offered citizenship.

Over the past 20 years, the grindingly slow Middle East process has brought many more changes to the map. Sinai has gone back to Egypt; Gaza and part of the West Bank is now under the control of Yasser Arafat's Palestinian National Authority which yearns for statehood.

Demographically, the situation is also fluid. The population of pre-1967 Israel now stands at around 6.2 million, of whom slightly fewer than 5m are Jewish. Of the rest, well over a million are Muslim, Christian, and Druze Arabs.

As a further complication, some 175,000 Jewish Israelis live as colonists among the 2m or so Arabs of the West Bank and Gaza. Several hundred thousands more have settled in the fiercely disputed areas of Jerusalem which Israel annexed in 1967.

Another ingredient of this unholy demographic broth is the diaspora of Palestinian refugees, displaced in the late 1940s and in subsequent upheavals. They number as many as 6m, scattered in Middle East refugee camps and other ghettoes and communities around the world.

Within the internationally recognised pre-1967 borders of Israel, the overall population is growing by 3% a year. The country is more densely populated than any in Europe, save Belgium and the Netherlands. And although Jewish immigration accounts for much of the increase, the non-Jewish population is growing even faster. In 1960, it stood at 11%. Now it is close to 19%.

Israelis tend to call their fellow citizens 'Israeli Arabs'. It is a term cordially detested by the minority, most of whom prefer to describe themselves as Palestinians living in Israel.

There are regular accusations, from within and without the minority, that Israel's Arabs are second-class citizens. Israel points out, with justification, that they have full voting and other rights. There are Arabs in the Knesset, and a thin sprinkling in the judiciary and diplomatic service. Many Arabs serve, voluntarily, in the Israeli army.

Yet it is plain that Arab citizens do not, by and large, enjoy anything like the same living standards as their Jewish neighbours. That much is evident in the flyblown town of Taibeh, and in the other pockets of Arab population, mostly in the north of the country.

A more explosive charge is that Israel treats its Arabs as potential subversives - and that they in turn identify more with the emerging Palestinian state than with the Zionist/Jewish one. This constant mutual suspicion is inevitably reinforced by clashes like the one today in Taibeh.

webTitle: Hamas and security forces clash in Israel

fields.headline: Hamas and security forces clash in Israel
fields.trailText: Two Palestinian militants were killed and an Israeli commando was shot in the foot during an early morning shoot-out between members of the militant group Hamas and Israeli security forces.
fields.body:
Two Palestinian militants were killed and an Israeli commando was shot in the foot during an early morning shoot-out between members of the militant group Hamas and Israeli security forces.

Gunfire and explosions rocked the small Arab town north of Tel Aviv and according to Israel Radio, the two men were killed as they tried to flee the building with an explosive device.

A third Palestinian was also captured but a fourth remains at large following the siege of the gunmen's hideout. The Israeli who was wounded in the raid later had his foot amputated.

According to Palestinian security forces, the four gunmen were members of the Islamic militant group Hamas. Hamas, the largest Palestinian militant Islamic group, is known to have carried out a series of terror attacks to disrupt Israeli-Palestinian peacemaking.

"I wouldn't say that the level (of terror) has been raised, but there have been more and more incidents," Shlomo Ben-Ami, Israel's police minister, told Israel Radio this morning, citing two other recent alerts of potential terrorist attacks in Netanya and Jerusalem. However, Ben-Ami did say that this raid stopped the Palestinian militants in the planning stages of a future attack.

Deputy defence minister Ephraim Sneh told foreign reporters that the Palestinian gunmen were in the stage of carrying out an operation to lay explosives in the centre of one of the Israeli towns with the aim of causing heavy casualties.

Following a tip from Palestinian security forces, Israeli police sealed off the city and used bullhorns to order residents evacuated the area. The incident, which began around 4 am local time continued for several hours as Israeli special antiterrorist squad surrounded the two story house.

During the raid residents of Taibeh gathered on rooftops to watch the operation unfold. The mayor of Taibeh, Issam Massawa, also said that a number of Palestinians have been arrested in association with today's events.

Ben-Ami said that the resurgence of attempted attacks and an increase of stabbing incidents are related to Palestinian frustration with the delays to the peace process. "We sense irritation among the Palestinians which finds expression in these attempts," he said.

fields.headline: Pinochet leaves Britain
fields.trailText: A 16-month legal battle ended today when the former Chilean dictator left Britain after home secretary Jack Straw ruled finally that he should not be extradited to Spain to face trial on torture allegations
fields.body:
Chile's former dictator Augusto Pinochet left Britain today after home secretary Jack Straw ruled that he should not be extradited to Spain to face trial for torture allegations. The 16-month legal battle over the 84-year-old general's fate ended he departed aboard a Chilean air force plane.

"The senator has now left the jurisdiction of this country," Mr Straw told the House of Commons amid scattered cheers from some MPs. "All the decisions which I have taken have been mine alone."

Gen Pinochet's plane took off for Chile in torrential rain just minutes after his motorcade arrived at Waddington air force base near Lincoln.

In a written parliamentary answer released just after 8am, Mr Straw unveiled his long-awaited decision, declaring: "I have today decided that I will not order the extradition of senator Pinochet to Spain."

Gen Pinochet's departure brings to a close the extraordinary diplomatic, political and legal saga prompted by his arrest in London sixteen-and-a-half months ago.

The crown prosecution service (CPS) confirmed that Gen Pinochet could not be prosecuted in the UK. In a statement, the CPS said it had advised the Metropolitan police that "there is no realistic prospect in this jurisdiction of convicting senator Pinochet of any criminal offence". The statement said that the solicitor general, Ross Cranston QC, had been consulted and agreed with these conclusions.

Even after Mr Straw's ruling, Gen Pinochet's release could still have been blocked, temporarily at least, if interested parties had mounted a last-ditch challenge by seeking a high court injunction to prevent him leaving the country, pending a judicial review of the decision. That did not happen.

Earlier this morning, as Gen Pinochet's convoy left the house in Wentworth, Surrey, where he has been under house arrest, his adviser Patrick Robertson said: "He was obviously nervous and anxious ahead of the decision. He was told in a telephone call very shortly before it was made public. He will have been delighted."

webTitle: Government claims British lead in aid effort

fields.headline: Government claims British lead in aid effort
fields.trailText: Britain is at the forefront of the international aid effort in flood-ravaged Mozambique, the government claimed today as the first direct aid was flown out from an airfield in Kent.
fields.body:
Britain is at the forefront of the international aid effort in flood-ravaged Mozambique, the government claimed today as the first direct aid was flown out from an airfield in Kent.

International development minister George Foulkes rejected criticism from aid agencies working in Mozambique, which claimed assistance was not being given soon enough, saying Britain had given £6m in aid so far. He also promised a "sympathetic" response to demands for further assistance.

"Hindsight is a wonderful gift, but whenever we have been asked to do anything in the UK we have responded," he said.

"If we had had requests from the Mozambique government earlier, as we have had now, we would have considered giving aid sooner. I think this disaster has escalated very quickly and caught a lot of people by surprise, even the aid agencies."

Watching see the first direct aid from Britain being sent out from Kent international airport in Manston he called for other countries to follow Britain's lead.

"Britain is leading the way in its response, in its speed and generosity, and we hope we're setting an example to other wealthy countries which may want to help," he said.

"The situation is one that is escalating and when our rescue teams talk to people out there and if they say they would like additional assistance, we'll make that decision sympathetically in London."

Mr Foulkes reported that the word from Mozambique was that the floods were getting worse, with the river Zambesi about to burst its banks, threatening thousands more homes.

The minister said today's aid flight was Britain's first because until now it had sourced aid as near to the disaster area as possible.

The plane is due to take off around 3pm, but will not arrive in Mozambique until around 3pm tomorrow, following stops in Athens, Jeddah and Nairobi.

However, the leader of the British rescue operation, Martin Ogilvie, said the aid being flown out today will reach Mozambique just in time.

"It is not too little too late. The situation is still getting worse and this aid will arrive just in time as the Zambesi is about to burst its banks and there is a threat of another tornado hitting the country."

Mr Ogilvie will be accompanied by another member of the department for international development emergency response team, four fire service rescue specialists from Wales, and 16 international rescue corps volunteers, along with 10-man tents and state of the art communication equipment.

The flight will also take two Land Rover Discoveries and up to 110 inflatable boats, which can be thrown out of the helicopters to reach stranded people. Further aid is expected to follow tomorrow.

fields.headline: Weblife: electronic books
fields.standfirst: Is the end of the printed page in sight? asks  Lucy Atkins
fields.trailText: Is the end of the printed page in sight? asks  Lucy Atkins
fields.body:
If you believe the hype, library stacks are quaking, paper manufacturers are white as their sheets and publishers are taking cover. Why? Because, according to internet visionaries, the book is dead.

Yes, the book, that hand-held paper and print creation we've loved for around 1300 years, is going to become extinct. We won't stop reading or writing. It's just that, as Dick Brass, Microsoft's vice president of technology and development said, by 2020 "90% of everything you read will be delivered in an electronic form".

We've been moving that way for a while. Anyone with access to the net can visit virtual bookstores and download virtual texts. You can even buy an "eBook", a portable, compact, device that can store several weeks' worth of reading material at one time - enough surely for any beach or long-haul diversion.

Internet booksellers are leaping on this bandwagon. Barnesandnoble.com is selling NuvoMedia's Rocket eBook, which weighs 22 ounces and is about the size of a paperback. Along with it you can buy electronic editions of books or periodicals (encrypted in the Rocket Edition format). Memoirs of a Geisha, in ebook form, could be yours for only $11.20. And Barnesandnoble.com has recently announced plans for an e-bookstore that will sell thousands of texts using Microsoft Reader software.

But if you can't get hold of a Rocket eBook, or a similar device, there's nothing stop ping you from downloading books on to your home computer or handheld device. If the choice of ebooksellers seems baffling you can visit a wide range of elibraries instead and "borrow" books, often for free.

Sounds exciting? Well, it is. As long as your literary standards are, shall we say, flexible.

The problem is that the ebooks you can download vary massively in quality. The classics are a good bet. The philanthropic Project Gutenberg is a free library where you can download literature that's "light" (Alice in Wonderland) or "heavy" (the Bible), or reference books, all in plain text (I downloaded an Edith Wharton novel, free, in only five minutes).

Or there's Netlibrary.com which claims to be the world's largest elibrary. The free "public collection" lets you look at books on the web, but you can download only from the "private collection". At $30 a year, this holds some books still under copyright.

The most impressive selection arrived when a "real" library went online. Last month the French national library (BNF) became the largest single library available online with 15 million pages to download. The books, and the website, are largely in French and downloads are laborious, but the BNF says it will offer an English version by the end of this year. It's apparently the only national library so far to put entire books online - the British Library, for instance, offers only samples of texts on the net.

Still, with competition hotting up, Dick Brass could have been right when he recently advised the Seattle Library Board to make sure the stacks in its proposed multi-million dollar library could, in future, be used for something other than books.

Epublishers with names like Pulpless.com, are springing up all over the place too. But standard publishers are not going to go bankrupt overnight. If you want to get your mouse on the new Joanna Trollope right now you could be disappointed. Only a handful of new titles seems to be available in e-form and the much-hyped sites such as Fatbrain.com, a stockmarket darling that began as an online technical bookseller and now sells "eMatter", are crammed with self-pub lished authors. There may well be an eAlex Garland lurking out there, but you'd have to be pretty diligent to seek him out.

The publishing industry is, however, seeing the dollar signs. Penguin signed a deal last October with Microsoft to use its Reader software on Penguin classics. "The ebook market is definitely going to grow" says Joanna Prior, Penguin's head of corporate publicity. As with the music business and their struggle to regulate MP3, says Prior, the copyright issue is key. "The Publishers' Association, the Society of Authors and lawyers all over the world are grappling with it", but she's convinced that copyright, "along with other barriers to success, like legibility and portability" will soon be overcome.

So should we kiss goodbye to hours spent browsing through dusty library stacks or lattes sipped while flicking through the latest Waterstones offerings? Probably not. At least, not yet.

Recently, shares of Fatbrain.com lost one-third of their value. This slide was said to be largely because matter hasn't taken off as predicted. More than 5,400 writers have signed up to self-publish: not something any sane person would want to sift through. But perhaps the greatest challenge is generational: the love of the book as an artefact runs deep in our veins. This might change, as technology makes ebooks more accessible. Until then, rumours of the book's demise may have been greatly exaggerated.

webTitle: Galleries go for the virtual show

fields.headline: Galleries go for the virtual show
fields.standfirst: The traditional worlds of auctioneers and art dealers are being transformed by the internet, writes  Sean Dodson
fields.trailText: The traditional worlds of auctioneers and art dealers are being transformed by the internet, writes Sean Dodson
fields.body:
The transformation of the auction market from crusty old seller of antiques to cutting-edge 21st industry offers a potent examples of how fast an e-commerce revolution can take hold.

Last year, new kid on the block, eBay bought San Francisco 's Butterfield & Butterfield for $260m. eBay had been trading for less than five years; Butterfield & Butterfield had been trading for 135.

In November, online bookseller, Amazon, bought $45.4m worth of Sothebys equity. But even though the gold dust has yet to settle in the auction houses - expect a further round of acquisitions and launches in the coming months - another online storm is already brewing, this time in the art market.

In the US, a number of online art galleries have already been shifting some very valuable works of art. One anonymous buyer on Artnet.com bought Lucio Fontana's 1959 Concetto Spaziale, Attese, for a cool $168,000 last year, while paintings on Ewolf.com have sold for similar amounts.

Late last year saw the launch of Eyestorm.com, a UK-based company that hopes to revolutionise the global art market by opening up its dealings to a wider public. Eyestorm sees itself as being able to create a "parallel market", by bringing works of art to a new audience. It sells a mixture of unique items - such as Warhol Polaroids and photocollages by David Hockney - and limited edition prints by the likes of Andy Goldsworth and Damien Hirst.

"Our task is to make art more accessible," says Eyestorm's chief executive Don Atkinson. "And we are doing that by showing the work to a world wide audience as opposed to a very limited audience that exists in the gallery system."

To do this, Eyestorm required a budget said to be about $5m. It raised the money through venture capitalists eVenture and Arts Alliance. After some pretty heavy market research, the company thinks it has spotted a gap in the market and is convinced that its investment will lead to a lucrative slice of the e-conomy.

"Another way in which we are making art more accessible is in our price strategy," says Atkinson. "What we have done is manage to persuade artists to run limited edition prints, usually one to 500, and for them to agree a reduced price point - one that averages between $400 and $500."

Londonart, a small independent company, has been selling art exclusively online since 1997. With approximately one tenth of Eyestorm's budget the site initially struggled to make any impact on the London market. But the last six months have seen sales rise by 50% per month, and it might even turn a small profit by the end of the year.

Paul Wynter, managing director of Londonart, says an online art market is emerging because, "gallery spaces are very difficult for some people who feel they are likely to be given the cold shoulder. The internet presents no barrier to anyone entering, viewing or buying art. I think that is fantastic."

Both Eyestorm and Londonart see the key to their success in providing editorial content to accompany their wares. This makes both sites attractive, not just to prospective buyers, but to art lovers as a whole. Londonart carries an online magazine and extensive arts listings. Eyestorm has embraced the interactive aspects on the internet and provided some impressive multi-media "documentaries ' to accompany the artists it represents. It also offers the chance to curate your own online gallery, and if desktop pictures are your thing, you could do worse than look here.

Atkinson says: "We make our artists' work more approachable by expanding understanding about the work itself. We do this by emphasising editorial on our website, because we think that people need to read about the artists and to understand the period when the piece was made." Unlike many e-commerce sites, both Eyestorm and Londonart employ full-time editors and have a brigade of notable critics to back them up.

But what is to stop artists simply selling their work from their own website? Says Atkinson: "When an artist comes to us, they get to concentrate on their work. We give them access to new technology, our considerable marketing clout and our distribution channel."

Wynter adds that new customers will generate new market forces. This, he says, is forcing existing galleries to wake up. "I think most most galleries are already in the stages of building a website or are certainly planning to do so. But I think the key point is that if you are a gallery or an artist, it is going to prove very difficult to be found - even if you are relatively well known.

"I think selling art online will really come down to specialist players who have the expertise to build content and place useful information alongside the art that is on sale."

Also joining the fray next month will be San Francisco-based www.iTheo.com , which claims to provide a site where artists can promote, market and sell their own work to "a world of new collectors, without the barriers of gallery walls".

The site is offering $12,000 in cash grants, which along with the commissioning powers of sites like Eyestorm and Londonart, should prove to artists that the web may be the ideal place to sell their work in the 21st century.

It is still early days, and the art market is notoriously secretive and slow-moving, so don't expect a raft of stock market flotations just yet. But the appetite for buying fine art, antiques and collectables continues to grow. Although no specific figures exist on art sales online, Forrester Research predicts that online auction sales will reach $19bn per year by 2003.

A couple of years ago, who would imagined that the time-honoured auction houses were about to come under the hammer to a set of internet upstarts? A couple of years from now, it may well be the galleries who are forced to transform themselves into an industry of the future.

fields.headline: Cybershopping:  pharmacies
fields.trailText: Good news for anyone who usually has to take a half-day off to collect a prescription: www.allcures.com has started dispensing NHS prescriptions.
fields.body:
Good news for anyone who usually has to take a half-day off to collect a prescription: www.allcures.com has started dispensing NHS prescriptions.

While you still have to get your prescription from a doctor and post it to the pharmacist, the service could have major benefits for those needing repeat prescriptions. First, you register online. Then you can email the online pharmacist with details of the prescription you are posting and pay - if necessary - via the secure server. Next, authorise Allcures by email to contact your doctor directly when repeat prescriptions are due. Delivery is free and guaranteed within four working days. Allcures offers products similar to what you'd find in your local chemist, along with a reward points scheme and bargains to entice reluctant cybershoppers.

Meanwhile www.pharmacy2u.co.uk dispenses private prescriptions only, but it's worth comparing with high street prices. Users are required to log on to the site and complete a questionnaire about their requirements. It offers more than 10,000 products, including pharmacy medicines, healthcare lines, beauty products and toiletries. Free delivery on prescriptions, products delivered at the same time and orders over £30.

There are no immediate plans to introduce a prescription dispensing service at NHS Direct Online (www.nhsdirect.nhs.uk) but it does provide guidance for health worries.

fields.headline: Larwood's batting and Bradman's average
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: I read somewhere that Harold Larwood was quite a good bat, though he never scored a Test century. What is his first-class batting record? asks VL Shankar
fields.body:
I read somewhere that Harold Larwood was quite a good bat, though he never scored a Test century. What is his first-class batting record? asks VL Shankar

Larwood was indeed a handy batsman, who hit three first-class centuries for Nottinghamshire. Christopher Martin-Jenkins, in his "Who's Who of Test Cricketers", describes him as "a useful but under-rated hard-hitting batsman". In all he scored 7289 runs at the serviceable average of 19.91, to go with 1427 wickets at 17.51. He actually made his highest Test score in what turned out to be his final innings: coming in as nightwatchman in the last match of the 1932-33 Bodyline tour, he reached 98 before he was unlucky enough to be caught by Bert Ironmonger, who was nearly 51 and, by all accounts, possibly the worst fieldsman ever to play Test cricket.

In your recent answer about Don Bradman's last Test innings, you said that he only needed four runs to finish with an average of 100. But is that correct? Surely, if your average is 100, you need to score 100 each time you bat to maintain it? asks Robert Heath from Bangkok

Before that famous duck at The Oval in 1948, Bradman had made 6996 runs from 69 completed innings, an average of 101.69. So to maintain an overall average of 100, he needed to score at least 4 in his 70th completed innings. If Australia had batted again (which they didn't, as they beat England by an innings) The Don would have needed to score 104 (out) or 4 not out to get back to an average of 100.

Who scored his maiden first-class hundred opening the batting in his first Test for England? asks Tom Ware

This was SC "Billy" Griffith, who was pressed into service as an opener in the second Test of England's injury-hit tour of West Indies in 1947-48, at Port-of-Spain. Griffith was the team's reserve wicketkeeper, and usually batted low in the order for his county, Sussex. The story goes that early on Griffith ran out Jack Robertson, England's only established opener, and thought he'd better carry on batting to avoid a telling-off from his captain. He finished up with 140, his maiden first-class hundred in his first Test.

Has anyone ever scored a century and taken five wickets in the same one-day international? asks Asif Saleem

The only man to do it is Viv Richards, who followed his 119 against New Zealand at Dunedin in March 1987 with 5-41 as West Indies won by 95 runs. Graeme Hick was close to repeating the feat recently, with 80 and 5-33 for England v Zimbabwe at Harare.

Who scored most Test runs in the 1990s? asks Frank Connolly

This was Alec Stewart of England, who made 6407 runs in 93 Tests in the 1990s, just ahead of Mark Waugh (6371 from 99 matches), Mark Taylor (6306 from 93), Mike Atherton (6217 from 91) and Steve Waugh (6213 from 89). In sixth place was Sachin Tendulkar, with 5626 runs from only 69 matches, at a higher average (58.00) than any of the five men above him.

Who was the last pre-war cricketer to play first-class cricket? asks Ian Pyne

In English first-class cricket this would appear to be Godfrey Evans, the former England wicketkeeper, who made his debut for Kent in 1939. He retired in 1959, but reappeared for Kent in 1967, when Alan Knott was selected for England, and also played a first-class match for the Cavaliers in 1969. Bill Ashdown, another Kent player, holds a unique record: he was the only man to play first-class cricket in England before the First World War and after the Second.

Could you tell me whether Australia ever had a batsman called Wally (not Ross) Edwards? asks GM Waters from America

Wally Edwards was a left-handed opener from Western Australia who played in the first three Tests of the 1974-75 series against England, with modest success (68 runs at 11.33). He was replaced by Rick McCosker, who fared much better. Confusingly, Ross Edwards, another Western Australian, made his debut shortly afterwards, on the 1975 tour of England.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

We regret that not all questions can be answered and that personal correspondence can only sometimes be entered into

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Denzel Washington finally gets bad guy role, Sean 'Puffy' Combs to make acting debut, and role vacant in Unbreakable
fields.body:
 Denzel Washington is in late-stage negotiations to play a bad-apple cop in the Warner Brothers' thriller Training Day, according to Variety. The actor, currently Oscar-nominated for his role in The Hurricane, will play a corrupt member of the LAPD's undercover narcotics unit who is put in charge of an inexperienced rookie cop. Insider sources have rumoured that both Ben Affleck and Will Smith are in line to co-star opposite Washington. David Guggenheim will direct. The role signals a change of pace for Washington. Only last week, the actor was lamenting in the Guardian/NFT interview that he is never offered bad guy roles and would relish the chance of playing one. Eight days later, his wish has been granted.

 Sean 'Puffy' Combs looks set to follow the lead of other rapper-turned-actors Ice Cube and LL Cool J when he makes his acting debut in Jon (Swingers) Favreau's indie comedy Made. Combs is considering signing up to play the New York ringleader of a money laundering scheme. As well as scripting and directing, the lugubrious-looking Favreau will star in the film alongside former Swingers co-star Vince Vaughn.

 Julianne Moore's last minute entry into Hannibal has left a big vacancy in the new film by Sixth Sense director M.Night Shyamalan. Moore had been pencilled in as the female lead in Unbreakable, Shyamalan's Philadelphia-set train-crash drama but bailed out to play Agent Starling. According to industry insiders, Robin Wright Penn is poised to step into the breach - currently locked in talks with Shyamalan and the film's backers, Disney. Unbreakable will star Bruce Willis as the lone survivor of a train wreck and Samuel L Jackson as an eccentric mentor figure.

webTitle: Rowan Atkinson to star as spoof 007

fields.headline: Rowan Atkinson to star as spoof 007
fields.trailText: Rowan Atkinson has signed up to play a British sleuth in a Working Title action-comedy written by Robert Wade and Neal Purvis, the screenwriting duo behind The World is Not Enough
fields.body:
Rowan Atkinson has signed up to play a British sleuth in a Working Title action-comedy written by Robert Wade and Neal Purvis, the screenwriting duo behind The World is Not Enough. Film Unlimited reported the story exclusively last month. Now, it appears, the news is official.

Entitled A Touch of Weevel, the film will star the rubber-faced comic as Johnny Enlgish, a low-level British diplomat who is mistaken by a super-spy by the British authorities and subsequently becomes the unwitting lynchpin of an international conspiracy. Given its writers' James Bond baggage, the script promises to be a spoof of the 007 series, and a British answer to Austin Powers.

 A Touch of Weevel will be distributed by Universal and goes before the cameras later this year. A director has yet to be confirmed.

fields.headline: HEFCE admits 1.5% funding increase is 'unsatisfactory'
fields.standfirst:
The top 20 winners and losers
English universities will receive £4.38 billion for teaching and research in the coming year but it will not be enough to recruit and retain the best staff, the head of the funding council warned today.
fields.trailText: English universities will receive £4.38 billion for teaching and research in the coming year but it will not be enough to recruit and retain the best staff, the head of the funding council warned today.
fields.body:
English universities will receive £4.38 billion for teaching and research in the coming year but it will not be enough to recruit and retain the best staff, the head of the funding council warned today.

Sir Brian Fender, chief executive of the Higher Education Funding Council for England, said the money would create an additional 37,000 places but the basic funding position was unsatisfactory. "An average cash increase of only 1.5 per cent in the unit of resource, following on cuts earlier in the nineties, will pose difficulties for institutions, particularly in recruiting and rewarding staff."

His comments will add weight to calls from the universities for more investment in the light of falling academic salaries. The 1.5 per cent settlement will also encourage the so-called Russell group of leading reserch institutions to step up their campaign for far-reaching reform of the funding system, including higher student fees.

Worst hit among the losers is Thames Valley University which sees its grant cut by 11 per cent after its catastrophic disciplining by the standards watchdog. But leading institutions like the London School of Economics and the School of Oriental and African Studies have also fared badly with real-term cuts.

Smaller specialist collegs have done well in comparative terms - St Martins teacher training college in Lancaster, Harper Adams agricultural college and the Northern School of Contemporary Dance.

Key points of the announcement are:
 £2,923 million core funding for teaching
 £60 million for 37,000 additional student places
 £25 million to widen participation by under-represented groups
 £867 million for research
 £483 million special funding

Of the £867 million allocated for research, 98% is distributed according to judgements of quality made in the Research Assessment Exercise. Additionally, £483 million is available for a number of special initiatives and funding programmes. This includes approximately £150 million for capital projects, both buildings and equipment.

Sir Brian told a press conference in London this morning: "These allocations will ensure that universities and colleges in England can continue to develop high standards of education and research."

He added that the funding would support wider participation. "£20 million will be used to support students from disadvantaged or under-represented backgrounds, and £5 million has been allocated to recruit and support disabled students." "We must continue our efforts to ensure that higher education is equipped and housed to properly fulfil its teaching and research functions. A further £150 million will go to support improvements in infrastructure of buildings and equipment, as part of a continuing drive to overcome problems of past under-investment. Sir Brian Fender, chief executive of the Higher Education Funding Council for England, said the money would create an additional 37,000 places but the basic funding position was unsatisfactory. "An average cash increase of only 1.5 per cent in the unit of resource, following on cuts earlier in the nineties, will pose difficulties for institutions, particularly in recruiting and rewarding staff." webTitle: South Park song whips up Oscar controversy

fields.headline: South Park song whips up Oscar controversy
fields.trailText: Blame Canada - a cheerful little ditty from South Park: Bigger, Longer and Uncut - is running into all kinds of trouble with the industry bosses behind next months Academy Awards ceremony
fields.body:
It is nominated as Best Original Song yet bristles with expletives, toilet humour and references to children running off to join the Ku Klux Klan. Hardly surprising, then, that Blame Canada - a cheerful little ditty from South Park: Bigger, Longer and Uncut - is running into all kinds of trouble with the industry bosses behind next months Academy Awards ceremony.

Oscar tradition dictates that every nominated song is played in full as part of the night's event. In the days of Zip-A-Dee-Doo-Dah (a winner in 1947) or Chim Chim Cher-ee (1964), this arrangement worked just fine. But Blame Canada offers lyrics guaranteed to offend the TV viewers of Middle America, and is predicted to be either censored (the offending language bleeped out) or ignored entirely on Oscar night (March 26). Another solution is that the song's writers Trey Parker and Marc Shaiman will provide a sanitised, PG-version of the song which would suitable for public broadcast.

Parker and Shaiman are currently dealing with the fears of both the Academy, which has organised the event, and the ABC network, which will broadcast it. Academy spokeswoman Jane Labonte has insisted that there is no pressure on Parker and Shaiman to rewrite the song, but her assurance is not borne out elsewhere in the industry. ABC chiefs are said to be demanding a sanitised version of the tune (entitled, perhaps, Don't Blame Canada - They're Nice). Last night, Oscar co-producer Lili Fini Zanuck admitted to the Hollywood Reporter that "I told [Trey Parker and Marc Shaiman] that they need to find a creative solution to the song." Indications, though, suggest that the duo are unwilling to compromise their artistic integrity. "I hope we don't have to change the words," Shaiman has said. "It would be ironic to have to change the words in a movie about censorship."

Last year's Best Original Song winner was the saccharine When You Believe, from The Prince of Egypt. It is not thought that the lyrics had to be bleeped or rewritten.

webTitle: Jean-Luc Godard: A Bout de Souffle

fields.headline: Jean-Luc Godard: A Bout de Souffle
fields.trailText: Godard's extraordinary A Bout de Souffle (Breathless)... reached us like a clap of thunder in 1960, immediately establishing an international reputation for itself and introducing us to a new kind of paradoxical hero who has been copied, usually badly, ever since
fields.body:
There could hardly be a more fascinating, or exasperating, film-maker than Jean-Luc Godard. His work, spanning 40 years, has been enormously influential. Yet, though he was once popular, he is now hopeless at the box office. Not that he seems to mind. He's been two-fingering us for some considerable time.

He has made a huge number of films, so we may as well start at his extraordinary beginning: A Bout de Souffle (Breathless). It reached us like a clap of thunder in 1960, immediately establishing an international reputation for itself and introducing us to a new kind of paradoxical hero who has been copied, usually badly, ever since. "Squealers squeal, burglars burgle, killers kill, lovers love," he says to his American girlfriend. In other words, what we are determines what we do.

Michel (Jean-Paul Belmondo) is a killer. He's just murdered a policeman and goes to Paris to collect enough money to leave the country, trying to persuade his girl (Jean Seberg) to go with him. She, however, is playing at being the American intellectual in Paris and betrays him to the police. That's the narrative - but Godard is not interested in telling us a story. Instead, he relies on a free-wheeling camera style, rambling conversations, incongruous incidents, jump-cuts and iconic bows to the American cinema he loved and hated.

Michel thinks he's Bogart; Seberg's Patricia is like the Seberg of Preminger's Bonjour Tristesse but more phoney. Godard himself mimics the Sam Fuller of Forty Guns at one point. The film is at once playful and deadly serious. Playful because Godard can never resist teasing parody; serious because he was making an earnest statement about deconstructing film forms. Images and sounds create meaning but not in the order they are usually manufactured.

We also learn from the film that you can construct an image of contemporary life not just with location shooting but with a kind of cultural collage of movie posters, art reproductions, magazines and books. This is old hat now. But it was new when Godard first put it on, rendering the film puzzling even to those who admired its liveliness, irony and pawky humour.

The film was romantic too, contrasting the honesty of Michel with the girl's lack of commitment to anything, even him. "C'est vraiment degueulasse [You really are a little bitch]," are his last words to her as he lies dying in the street from a police bullet. "Qu'est-ce que c'est, degueulasse?" she replies.

After A Bout de Souffle, the fragmentation of narrative became more audacious and the films, though frequently brilliant, like Vivre sa Vie, Alphaville or Pierrot le Fou, less capable of being analysed in a conventional way. They've been described as mosaics gone mad. Later still they became more political, more determined to deny art and, with the failure of Marxism, more pessimistic.

Is Godard the great director we once thought? Many of his later films make it difficult to believe he is. But he has spent his life confronting issues central to the future of cinema and, in general, to the world we live in. Besides, A Bout de Souffle and its successors will live longer than most.
