fields.headline: Supporters hail general's release
fields.trailText: Supporters of Augusto Pinochet started celebrating before dawn on hearing that Britain would block the extradition of the former dictator, clearing the way for his return home to Chile.
fields.body:
Supporters of Augusto Pinochet started celebrating before dawn on hearing that Britain would block the extradition of the former dictator, clearing the way for his return home to Chile.

Singing and jumping up and down, allies of the retired general who had gathered in the headquarters of the Pinochet Foundation waved balloons, flags and posters of the father figure of the Chilean military.

"We are full of happiness, the nightmare is over," said Luis Cortes Villa, director of the foundation that awards military scholarships and upholds the general's image. Gen Pinochet was due to leave London, where he has been under house arrest for 17 months, fighting an extradition order that would have meant a trial in Spain to face trial on torture charges.

As his opponents celebrated, the general's opponents vowed to pursue him through legal channels.

"We are going to demand justice," said Viviana Diaz, president of the protest group Families of the Detained-Disappeared. "We do not want impunity. He is going to be put on trial in Chile. The criminals are here among us, he's going to return on grounds of compassion but he returns as he is - a criminal."

A crusading Chilean judge is looking at more than 50 civil lawsuits filed against Gen Pinochet in Chile and human rights lawyers hope the cases evolve into concrete charges against him. There were also harsh words from his critics in Britain for the man who ruled Chile from 1973 to 1990, after overthrowing elected Marxist president Salvador Allende in a military coup.

Labour MP Jeremy Corbyn, a prominent anti-Pinochet activist, accused the general of crass hypocrisy. He said: "Pinochet has shown himself a coward who resorted to pathetic wrangling to avoid justice. He wanted human rights protection for himself but not for his victims."

Home secretary Jack Straw announced his decision early this morning, timed for maximum inconvenience for human rights groups to take further legal action. In a statement, Mr Straw said it was fundamental to the idea of a fair trial that the accused was mentally capable of following proceedings, instructing his lawyers and giving coherent evidence.

"The attempted trial of an accused in the condition diagnosed in Senator Pinochet on the charges which have been made against him in this case, could not be a fair trial in any country and would violate article six of the European convention on human rights in those countries which are party to it," Mr Straw said.

The Spanish government said it would respect Britain's decision to deny the extradition of Gen Pinochet and planned to take no further action in the case. The statement by government spokesman Josep Pique appeared to thwart a Spanish judge's last-ditch bid to block the 84-year-old general's release.

Mr Straw's decision followed his statement in January that he was "minded" to allow the former dictator to return to Chile because a medical examination by four independent doctors had found him medically unfit to stand trial.

In a letter to Spain's ambassador to Britain explaining the decision, the home office said Mr Straw had looked at the medical report "afresh". Having done so, "he is satisfied that the conclusions of the original report were correct and that it is right to regard Senator Pinochet as unfit to stand trial", the letter said.

fields.headline: Baby born in a tree
fields.standfirst:
Mother and child saved by helicopter crew

More about the floods in Mozambique
fields.trailText: Mother and child saved by helicopter crew
fields.body:
Rosita Pedro was born in a tree above Mozambique's swirling floodwaters yesterday and minutes later, with her umbilical cord still attached, was winched to safety by a South African helicopter crew.

Her mother, 26-year-old Sofia Pedro, torn by labour pains as she clutched the branches where she had sought refuge, was exhausted and near the end when rescuers discovered her precarious perch.

An airforce medic was lowered on to the tree to help the mother give birth and cut the umbilical cord. "We spotted her just in time," said the man, who gave his name only as Godfrey. "We then hoisted mother and child on to the helicopter. The crew provided a blanket to wrap the infant and return Rosita to her mother. They are both doing well."

Ms Pedro had climbed the tree on Sunday to escape the surging waters. Late yesterday, shocked and exhausted after her three-day ordeal, she was resting with her daughter in a refugee camp on high ground, knowing that she was one of the very few to be rescued from the flood-ravaged interior of Mozambique yesterday.

She could only muster the energy to tell reporters: "I'm so happy."

webTitle: 100,000 still trapped by waters and 1m homeless

fields.headline: 100,000 still trapped by waters and 1m homeless
fields.standfirst: More about the floods in Mozambique
fields.trailText: • 1m of Mozambique's 19m population are displaced by floods.
fields.body:
 1m of Mozambique's 19m population are displaced by floods.

 100,000 are trapped by rising waters on rooftops, on shrinking islands, or in trees .

 At least 200 people have perished, but the final toll is expected to be thousands.

 Six South African helicopters have saved 8,000 people.

 Aid workers say malaria is running at four times the normal rate.

 The United Nations has appealed for £8.5m in emergency aid; Mozambique has asked for £41m.

 ;£14.7m has already been pledged, according to the UN.

 Britain's international development department has donated £5.8m and cancelled Mozambique's debts.

 British aid includes cash for nine chartered helicopters, an airlift of 100 inflatable dinghies and life rafts, with 30 emergency service personnel, and a military reconaissance team. Four RAF Puma helicopters are being flown out to Mozambique today.

 The international development department sent out two aid specialists to assess the disaster as long ago as February 11.

 Aid agencies admit that they underestimated the volume of water which inundated the Limpopo and Save river valleys of Mozambique after neighbouring Zimbabwe opened its overwhelmed dams. Cyclone Eline added to the chaos.

 Transporting large helicopters by air from Europe to Mozambique is problematic. RAF Hercules transporters are not large enough. Chartered Antonovs-124s are required, but can only carry four Puma helicopters at a time, at a cost of £200,000 a flight.

 Mozambique's armed forces currently have only one functioning helicopter, which is used by the presidency.

 Neighbouring Zimbabwe, embroiled in a war in the Democratic Republic of the Congo and facing its own floods, has sent no helicopters.

 The Disasters Emergency Committee will launch its main appeal for Mozambique today, bringing together the charities Action Aid, Save the Children, Oxfam, Cafod, Christian Aid, Red Cross, Concern, Help the Aged, Merlin, Tear Fund and World Vision.

 Italy has pledged £3.3m of aid. Japan has pledged £62,500 in tents and equipment.

 The French relief agency Médecins du Monde has sent a five-person team and 10 tonnes of medical and sanitary equipment.

 A United States C-17 transport aircraft arrived in Maputo yesterday as the US approved an additional £6.25m in aid.

 The World Health Organisation has appealed for baby delivery kits for the estimated 3,400 Mozambican women who will give birth in the next three months.

 At least 350 people have died across southern Africa in the worst floods in half a century. Mozambique's warns that fresh flooding will hit the centre and south of the country in a few days.

fields.headline: Mozambique's long wait
fields.standfirst:
Until disasters are shown on television news, we do not seem able to accept that they exist
Mozambique floods: special report
fields.trailText: There is something wearily familiar about the sequence of events in Mozambique. For three weeks the country laboured under the worst floods in living memory. No one outside took much notice.
fields.body:
There is something wearily familiar about the sequence of events in Mozambique. For three weeks the country laboured under the worst floods in living memory. No one outside took much notice. South Africa dispatched a handful of military helicopters on rescue and aid missions. Britain gave some money to cope with the medical emergency. The United Nations sent a team to investigate.

But it was only when the television cameras arrived, and viewers across Europe and America got a glimpse of what it is to have your house washed away while you climb the nearest tree, that the crisis was taken seriously.

It was the same story in Somalia, Ethiopia and Goma. The Americans were dragged into Somalia by the television pictures. Western governments pretended the Rwandan genocide didn't exist but as Hutu refugees started dying in their tens of thousands from cholera on the nine o' clock news, the money gushed into Goma.

A disaster is only defined as such when sufficient numbers of people look its way. But by then it is often too late for many victims who might have been saved. Each time there are the same promises that the lessons will be learnt. No doubt some are, but when it comes to the next crisis, they rarely seem to be applied.

One British official yesterday said the worst case scenario in Mozambique is worse than anyone predicted. It is true that natural disasters are notoriously difficult to plan for. But the flooding in Mozambique has been drawn out over four weeks, with sufficient warnings that it was going to worsen and, that when the time came, help would be required very fast and on a large scale.

The first floods hit nearly a month ago, turning vast swaths of southern and central Mozambique into lakes. Cyclone Eline compounded the misery when it ripped through the country more than a week ago. It wasn't difficult to predict what the effect would be.

The cyclone poured rain on already badly flooded settlements before moving on to Zimbabwe and South Africa where, in a double whammy, Eline dumped a huge amount of water into rivers flowing back into Mozambique.

Some of that water hit on Saturday night, consuming large towns such as Chokwe. It left tens of thousands of people stranded on roofs, in trees and on tiny islands of high ground. Hundreds of thousands were made homeless.

The United Nations, and British and other foreign officials, insist they were planning to deal to with an escalation of the flooding. They reel off their donations of blankets and logisticians and what they are going to do in the coming days. But what really mattered in the first hours and days were rescue helicopters, and they were not on hand except for the ones already sent by South Africa. No money had been set aside for additional aircraft. No one bothered to explore where more helicopters might be found.

On Sunday - a day after the latest torrent of water carried away Chokwe - rescue workers were not discussing how many more helicopters were arriving but whether anyone was going to pay to keep the five South African aircraft flying. To its credit, Britain pledged $1m but that did nothing to improve the situation.

Yesterday, British officials were trumpeting London's latest donation to pay for another five helicopters. Even if you take Saturday's night's flooding as the moment that kickstarted the expansion of the rescue effort, it has still taken Britain four crucial days. It is an awful long time if you happen to be perched in a tree. And there was no need to wait until Saturday night to realise the crisis was going to worsen.

The flaw is in the system. Disasters such as the Mozambique floods require a much larger organisation and funds than individual aid organisations or governments can offer. It requires a pot of money already to hand, and people with the authority to spend it to provide whatever is most urgently required.

In Mozambique, it happens to be helicopters and boats. Presumably, that responsibility should fall to the United Nations. After the first wave of floods hit Mozambique three weeks ago, the UN sent a team from its humanitarian disaster office which spent 10 days in the country. Its critics say it left without establishing a means of coordinating relief efforts. A similar team has now returned to do the same job. The two most senior UN officials in Mozambique were out of the country as the latest crisis hit.

Like most disasters, we will never know how many lives could have been saved by a quicker reaction. For the moment, no one even knows if the death toll is in the hundreds or the thousands.

But you can be reasonably certain of one thing. Afterwards there will be hand-wringing and meetings and promises that the lessons of Mozambique 2000 have been learnt. Then sometime in the next few years, another human calamity will befall another African country. And the victims had better hope that it is a slow news week on CNN.

webTitle: Saved but lost - tragic children of the floods

fields.headline: Saved but lost - tragic children of the floods
fields.standfirst:
Mozambique asks: How many dead? as survivors await news of their families

More about the floods in Mozambique
fields.trailText: There is one question at the back of most Mozambican minds at the moment. How many are dead?
fields.body:
There is one question at the back of most Mozambican minds at the moment. How many are dead?

The question is more than academic for nine-year-old Tania Costa. She struggled to safety as the Incomati river consumed her home more than two weeks ago but she still does not know the fate of her family.

Her father works in South Africa but the last time she saw her mother and two sisters they were disappearing into torrential rain as they fled the water sweeping through their home village, Calanga.

Tania's family may have escaped to the other side of the river and through the flooded villages and fields. Perhaps they are still clinging to an island of high ground, or to the roof of a particularly tall building. But she could not remember ever seeing any. Perhaps the worst has happened.

"We were all running away from the water and my mother was holding my sisters and then I just couldn't see them any more. There was so much rain, I didn't even know where I was running. I saw some other people and they called to me and told me to go with them until we got to the road," she said.

"It took a long time and the water was very high. All the time I was praying to God that my mother and sisters were still alive. I'm sure they are but I just can't find them. I ask everyone, but nobody knows where they are."

The charity Save the Children said that more than half of the children it accounted for in some areas are separated from their families.

The children are one more task the Mozambican government and aid workers will have to grapple with once the urgency of rescuing the tens of thousands of people still stranded in the floods is past. For now, the wellbeing of many children is left to the kindness of strangers.

Tania is one of four children from four different families being cared for in the house of Maria Teixeira. All four have lost their mothers and fathers, at least temporarily. Mrs Teixeira took Tania in after she came across her sitting beside the road, soaked to the skin.

Word spread over the next couple of days, and the three other children came knocking at Mrs Teixeira's door. She could not turn them away.

"The flooding is terrible for everyone but it is worse for the children. They suffer so much. They do not understand what is happening," she said.

"I see them crying all the time because they want to be with their mothers. All I can tell them is that there is hope. If they survived then I am sure their mothers survived too."

Mrs Teixeira does not have much money. The food to feed her guests comes from her own harvest of cassava and maize. All the children sleep on a concrete floor in the same room of the tiny house. All consider themselves very lucky to have encountered such caring.

At other sites, dozens of children are crammed into a single house with only a couple of adults to look after them. But they too are lucky.

Many children are still trapped in the flooded areas. They are at even more risk than their parents because they are more susceptible to the cold that sodden clothes brings, and to being forced to drink contaminated flood water.

It is particularly bad for babies. Some can still suckle their mothers, but the women have often not had anything to eat in days.

If there is an outbreak of cholera or dysentery, as some aid workers fear, the children will be most vulnerable.

No one is predicting how many children will require care after the floods pass, any more than anyone knows the number of dead. But it is presumed that tens of thousands of young people, with or without their parents, will need feeding.

Some will also require medical attention for wounds infected by the flood waters. Many will need new homes.

Even those children fortunate to escape with their parents face a difficult time. In parts of the capital, Maputo, whole neighbourhoods have disappeared in the floods.

Now two, three or even four families are crammed into a room. Save the Children has distributed blankets and cooking pots. Doctors have checked the children. But the immediate future is bleak.

Tania does not look her age. Her hair is tightly bound. She looks frail and exhausted. When she speaks, it is in a tiny whisper.

"Every day I go to look at the water, to see if it is going down so I can go home and see if my mother is there. She doesn't know where to look for me so I must find her. But there is still a lot of water and people say it is dangerous to go. I am not like a man. I cannot fight the water. I must wait and hope," she said.

Mrs Teixeira is prepared for the worst. If any of her new charges' mothers are dead, or cannot be found, then she says she will make what is now a temporary home into a permanent one for them.

"It is for the government to decide what should happen to the children who lose their families. Perhaps they have other relatives in their villages. Tania's father is in Johannesburg although she hasn't seen him in quite a long time. Perhaps he will come back for her," she said.

"But if it is necessary, I will tell the government that I will look after any of these children here as if they are my own. We must all endure this together."

webTitle: Leeds don to attack Lawrence findings

fields.headline: Leeds don to attack Lawrence findings
fields.standfirst: Stephen Lawrence: special report
fields.trailText: Leeds university was under pressure last night to prevent one of its lecturers attacking the findings of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry at an extreme right conference in the United States.
fields.body:
Leeds university was under pressure last night to prevent one of its lecturers attacking the findings of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry at an extreme right conference in the United States.

Frank Ellis, a lecturer in the Russian and Slavonic studies department, is due to appear this month at the American Renaissance conference, a biennial event described by anti-fascist campaigners as a "glorified three-day rally" bringing together the scientific racism movement. Previous conferences attracted prominent figures from overt white supremacist organisations, including the Ku Klux Klan and various US neo-nazi groupings.

Mr Ellis's speech will attack what he terms the "racial hysteria" in Britain since publication of the Macpherson report on the bungled police inquiry into the black teenager's murder. His involvement, uncovered by the Guardian and the anti-fascist magazine Searchlight, caused astonishment from academics and students at Leeds, who condemned as highly offensive the subject and timing of his speech.

Jude Corrigan, communications officer at Leeds student union, said: "The university has to take this matter seriously because the students, especially in the Russian department, will be appalled by these views, particularly considering our diverse student population."

Although the conference is unrelated to Mr Ellis's teaching subject, it is being treated as a normal academic event, allowing him to make the trip on work time.

In a statement last night the university said: "Although we do not know what Frank Ellis will say at the conference, we have asked him to make clear he is attending in his own right and that his views do not represent those of his colleagues or the university community.

"It is custom and practice for academics attending conferences to rearrange their teaching schedule in order that student learning is not disrupted, and we will ensure this happens in this case."

The statement added: "While the university has a moral and legal duty to uphold the principles of free speech, it should be pointed out that we are a multicultural organisation with a strong commitment to promoting anti-discriminatory policies to staff and students."

Contacted by the Guardian yesterday, Mr Ellis said he did not have time to answer questions about his trip. An insight into the likely tone of his speech can be found in an article published last December in Right Now!, edited by a former National Front member Derek Turner.

Under the heading Frank Ellis lashes out at egalitarian extremists, the article attacked what was claimed to be the hypocrisy of equal opportunity theory. Citing the Hollywood film White Men Can't Jump, Mr Ellis mused: "What, I wonder, would be the reaction of the equal opportunity commissars to a film with the title No Black Society has Ever Produced a Written Language or Mathematics?"

He continued: "It is considered politically incorrect to say so, but were one to take the 'white' and the 'male' out of science and technology, one would have no science, just witchcraft, third world squalor, misery and mega-incompetence."

American Renaissance is one of the most important publications on the American far right, using so-called scientific theories to oppose multiculturalism and justify racial inequality. Established in 1990, its basic premise is that blacks are genetically inferior and therefore incapable of becoming equal citizens.

The leading American fascist website, Stormfront, which carries a link to American Renaissance, describes its supporters as "racially-conscious conservatives".

Nick Lowles, editor of Searchlight, said: "The fact that Ellis is going during term time to speak on an issue completely unrelated to his post is outrageous. Supporters of American Renaissance like to hide behind a mask of scientific respectability, but they are still racists."

Also on the platform at the conference, from March 31 to April 2 in a Sheraton hotel near Washington DC, will be Bruno Gollnisch of Jean Marie Le Pen's Front National and Sam Dickson, who helped organise a 1991 fundraising visit to the US by the British National Party's founder and former leader, John Tyndall.

fields.headline: Flood aid 'not enough' - UN
fields.standfirst: Mozambique floods: special report
fields.trailText: The first contributions to the growing international effort to rescue Mozambicans from the worst floods of modern times arrived in the country yesterday but the UN warned that they were still only a fraction of what is required, with a new bout of flooding expected before the end of the week.
fields.body:
The first contributions to the growing international effort to rescue Mozambicans from the worst floods of modern times arrived in the country yesterday but the UN warned that they were still only a fraction of what is required, with a new bout of flooding expected before the end of the week.

British-funded helicopters, US emergency supplies and many aid workers have been sent to the Mozambique.

But with up to 100,000 people still stranded in trees, on roofs and high ground - and helicopters only able to rescue a few thousand a day - the crisis is far from over. Some people have been trapped for more than a week with little to eat, only contaminated flood water to drink and malaria rife. The death toll is believed to run into hundreds, if not thousands.

"By no means are things in hand. We've just got a drop in the ocean of the aircraft we need," said Brenda Barton of the World Food Programme. "This disaster could get very much worse."

The UN now predicts that a fresh flood of water on its way down the Save and Limpopo rivers from neighbouring Zimbabwe and South Africa will hit Mozambique by the weekend. That could considerably worsen the plight of those already trapped, and strand thousands more.

Mozambique's president, Joaquim Chissano, pleaded for more aid to rescue people trapped by the floods and assist an estimated 1m forced from their homes.

Three Puma helicopters paid for by the UK began work rescuing people yesterday. A Sea King helicopter is expected to arrive today and a smaller one on Friday.

Britain is also sending two transport planes carrying emergency personnel, inflatable motorboats and life rafts.

Clare Short, the international development secretary, last night announced that four RAF Pumas will be sent later today. They are expected to be ready for search and rescue operations by the weekend.

Two more helicopters have also been hired from the Ukraine, Ms Short said.

The £1.6m cost of the six helicopters announced last night brings the total amount pledged by the government to tackle the floods to £5.8m.

The US has approved an additional $10m (£6.25m) for food and rescue missions.

The South African military has provided most of the air rescue effort but an air force spokesman, Colonel Pikkie Sieberts, said his government hesitated to despatch more aircraft until it knew who would pay for them.

100,000 still trapped by waters and 1m homeless

 1m of Mozambique's 19m population are displaced by floods.

 100,000 are trapped by rising waters on rooftops, on shrinking islands, or in trees .

 At least 200 people have perished, but the final toll is expected to be thousands.

 Six South African helicopters have saved 8,000 people.

 Aid workers say malaria is running at four times the normal rate.

 The United Nations has appealed for £8.5m in emergency aid; Mozambique has asked for £41m.

 ;£14.7m has already been pledged, according to the UN.

 Britain's international development department has donated £5.8m and cancelled Mozambique's debts.

 British aid includes cash for nine chartered helicopters, an airlift of 100 inflatable dinghies and life rafts, with 30 emergency service personnel, and a military reconaissance team. Four RAF Puma helicopters are being flown out to Mozambique today.

 The international development department sent out two aid specialists to assess the disaster as long ago as February 11.

 Aid agencies admit that they underestimated the volume of water which inundated the Limpopo and Save river valleys of Mozambique after neighbouring Zimbabwe opened its overwhelmed dams. Cyclone Eline added to the chaos.

 Transporting large helicopters by air from Europe to Mozambique is problematic. RAF Hercules transporters are not large enough. Chartered Antonovs-124s are required, but can only carry four Puma helicopters at a time, at a cost of £200,000 a flight.

 Mozambique's armed forces currently have only one functioning helicopter, which is used by the presidency.

 Neighbouring Zimbabwe, embroiled in a war in the Democratic Republic of the Congo and facing its own floods, has sent no helicopters.

 The Disasters Emergency Committee will launch its main appeal for Mozambique today, bringing together the charities Action Aid, Save the Children, Oxfam, Cafod, Christian Aid, Red Cross, Concern, Help the Aged, Merlin, Tear Fund and World Vision.

 Italy has pledged £3.3m of aid. Japan has pledged £62,500 in tents and equipment.

 The French relief agency Médecins du Monde has sent a five-person team and 10 tonnes of medical and sanitary equipment.

 A United States C-17 transport aircraft arrived in Maputo yesterday as the US approved an additional £6.25m in aid.

 The World Health Organisation has appealed for baby delivery kits for the estimated 3,400 Mozambican women who will give birth in the next three months.

 At least 350 people have died across southern Africa in the worst floods in half a century. Mozambique's warns that fresh flooding will hit the centre and south of the country in a few days.

Four RAF Puma helicopters are being flown out to Mozambique today.  The international development department sent out two aid specialists to assess the disaster as long ago as February 11.  Aid agencies admit that they underestimated the volume of water which inundated the Limpopo and Save river valleys of Mozambique after neighbouring Zimbabwe opened its overwhelmed dams. Chartered Antonovs-124s are required, but can only carry four Puma helicopters at a time, at a cost of £200,000 a flight.  Mozambique's armed forces currently have only one functioning helicopter, which is used by the presidency.  Neighbouring Zimbabwe, embroiled in a war in the Democratic Republic of the Congo and facing its own floods, has sent no helicopters.  The Disasters Emergency Committee will launch its main appeal for Mozambique today, bringing together the charities Action Aid, Save the Children, Oxfam, Cafod, Christian Aid, Red Cross, Concern, Help the Aged, Merlin, Tear Fund and World Vision.  Italy has pledged £3.3m of aid. Japan has pledged £62,500 in tents and equipment.  The French relief agency Médecins du Monde has sent a five-person team and 10 tonnes of medical and sanitary equipment.  A United States C-17 transport aircraft arrived in Maputo yesterday as the US approved an additional £6.25m in aid.  The World Health Organisation has appealed for baby delivery kits for the estimated 3,400 Mozambican women who will give birth in the next three months.  At least 350 people have died across southern Africa in the worst floods in half a century. Mozambique's warns that fresh flooding will hit the centre and south of the country in a few days.

webTitle: Kudos rules:  Britons show what makes a collection sell

fields.headline: Kudos rules:  Britons show what makes a collection sell
fields.standfirst: London fashion week: special report
fields.trailText: Two very different British designers lit up the catwalks of Paris yesterday: Stella McCartney for Chloe and Alexander McQueen for Givenchy.
fields.body:
Two very different British designers lit up the catwalks of Paris yesterday: Stella McCartney for Chloe and Alexander McQueen for Givenchy.

Both shows posed the question: just what alchemy makes a collection sell? Is it the pedigree of the label, or the kudos of the name behind it?

Clearly the latter. With the British arrogance that has made their careers so successful, both designers discarded any historical references they might have plundered from their labels' archives and presented clothes inspired by London street style but reworked into something new.

Hubert de Givenchy - who dressed Audrey Hepburn - would never have countenanced crotch-skimming patent minidresses, tight purple nappa catsuits and zip-up leather leggings that owed more to Debbie Harry than to Holly Golightly.

McQueen's look for autumn/winter 2000 is sharp and aggressive: hard to pull off if you are 18 and lithe as a lollipop stick, let alone a 40-something Givenchy client. Olive green, bright purple and black were the colours for Clash-inspired leather ties, striped pelmet skirts and billowing pleated blouses. More wearable - just - were loose tuxedo jackets that came belted at the waist.

McCartney produced her most accomplished collection yet for Chloe: a fur and leather-free vision of street chic that will sell.

There was a military feel to cream canvas coats lined with straggly fake fur; an African feel to clasps threaded with ribbon and slung round the hips; a seventies feel to batwing blouses encrusted with gold beading. Yet these disparate influences never clashed.

This magpie approach to dressing, combining elements from different eras and cultures, is wholly British and wholly now. In less confident hands it could have gone horribly wrong, but McCartney dresses her models just as she dresses herself, and this is why the collection worked. She has turned Chloe into a label that mirrors the insouciant style of the London girl.

It is the style that half the designers in Paris are trying to ape this season, but with far less success.

webTitle: Straw lets eight Afghans stay in UK

fields.headline: Straw lets eight Afghans stay in UK
fields.standfirst:
Stansted hijack: special report
The issue explained: How to claim asylum

Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The home secretary last night announced that he had personally decided to allow eight Afghans, including five children, who were aboard an airliner hijacked to Stansted airport to stay in Britain because they had a well-founded fear of persecution by Afghanistan's Taliban regime.
fields.body:
The home secretary last night announced that he had personally decided to allow eight Afghans, including five children, who were aboard an airliner hijacked to Stansted airport to stay in Britain because they had a well-founded fear of persecution by Afghanistan's Taliban regime.

Jack Straw told the Commons three weeks ago that he wanted to see "removed from this country all those on the plane as soon as practicable", on the grounds that nobody should benefit from hijacking.

But he said last night that those who had been given refugee status had reason to fear for their lives "before they had boarded the flight, and it was a matter of chance for them that it was hijacked".

Ministers had previously argued that because the Boeing 727 was on an internal flight in Afghanistan when it was hijacked it was unlikely that any of the claims for asylum would succeed.

Claims for asylum from a further two passengers and their families may also be granted. Mr Straw said last night he was waiting for further information from the Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture before making a decision. He has also postponed a decision in six other cases which are subject to further inquiries.

He said however that he had rejected the claims for asylum by 27 other passengers and their families because he was not satisfied that they had a well founded fear of persecution. It was not yet clear what will happen to this group, but they will be freed on bail from the detention centre at Gatwick airport in which they have been held. In a written Commons answer, Mr Straw said those denied asylum would not be forced to return to Afghanistan, but would be offered assistance if they wanted to go back.

It is expected that they will appeal against his decision - a process which may take a further five or six weeks. In the meantime, the foreign office is "continuing to explore the possibility" of sending them to other countries, such as Pakistan, which may agree to take them.

Asylum claims from a final six passengers, who are relatives of those who have been charged with the hijacking, have also been postponed following legal advice that a decision by Mr Straw could prejudice the outcome of the trials. Those whose claims have not had an initial decision will remain in detention.

A total of 44 passengers and 33 of their dependants who were aboard the plane when it landed at Stansted, Essex, lodged claims for asylum. The eight people who have been given refugee status or exceptional leave to remain in Britain, include two principal applicants, the wife of one whose own asylum application was rejected, and their five dependant children.

Of the other 93 people aboard the hijacked airliner, 73 went back to Afghanistan voluntarily on February 14. Four members of the flight crew are due to re turn with the aircraft and arrangements are being made to return two other passengers who have asked to go back to the country. The remaining 14 people face a criminal trial in Britain for hijacking.

Mr Straw said that in personally considering each of the asylum claims he had taken proper consideration of Britain's obligations under the 1951 convention on refugees, but the home secretary made clear that he was unhappy with the way that international law operated in this area.

"The events surrounding this terrorist act of hijacking have shown serious weaknesses in the way in which international conventions relating to refugees, terrorism and human rights operate. We shall be raising our concerns with like-minded countries and with the United Nations high commission for refugees," Mr Straw said.

He said that he had taken into account the official British assessment of the current state of human rights in Afghanistan. That document says that "executions or other cruel, inhuman and degrading punishments were believed to be widespread, but were not always reported by the authorities. Of those announced, eight people were flogged, including a woman accused of adultery, who was given 100 lashes at the Kabul sports stadium in February 1998, in front of 30,000 spectators."

fields.headline: Return ticket to Kabul
fields.standfirst:
What Jack Straw has done could be risky

Stansted hijack: special report
The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: For the thousands of asylum applicants who have waited for many months, some for years, for a decision on their refugee status, Jack Straw's decision yesterday on the Afghanis who arrived at Stansted last month must seem extraordinary. Within mere weeks a giant investigation has apparently been carried out and some 29 applicants for refugee status have had their replies from the United Kingdom government.
fields.body:
For the thousands of asylum applicants who have waited for many months, some for years, for a decision on their refugee status, Jack Straw's decision yesterday on the Afghanis who arrived at Stansted last month must seem extraordinary. Within mere weeks a giant investigation has apparently been carried out and some 29 applicants for refugee status have had their replies from the United Kingdom government. True, their circumstances were exceptional - carried here on a hijacked airliner. True, the home secretary has been under intense pressure to signal to the world that this country is no "soft touch" and cannot - no civilised country could - allow gunmen a quick route to safe haven. But the speed and scale of his decision still leave an impression of a minister bending in the face of a media and opinion pollsters' gale. If (as reported) the Blair government thinks it about time it rounded on the moulders of public and political opinion in the rightwing press, here would have been an excellent place to have started.

Yesterday Mr Straw indicated his officials had closely studied the individual dossiers. The hijackers, 14 in number, face criminal charges. A number of the 44 who are claiming asylum (who have some 33 dependents) are still being investigated. He definitively rejected the claims of 27 applicants - they have been judged to face no threat of persecution on returning to Afghanistan. A cynic might wonder if the positive decision in favour of two applicants (and their dependents) has useful cosmetic properties, as the sign of a home secretary's compassion and mastery of the details. Without retracing the steps in his reasoning in all the cases, that is hard to judge.

Does Jack Straw deserve the benefit of the doubt? Remember how he pre-judged this decision in his Commons statement at the end of the hijack: he bluntly wondered aloud whether any of the hostages would be eligible for asylum because the plane had been hijacked on an internal flight. Pressure is reported to have been applied to the hostages by immigration officers. Initially only 17 of them were said to be ready to return to Afghanistan. By the time the return flight had been organised, 73 took places. Lawyers have been concerned that not all the hostages had legal representatives present in their initial interviews. Although not illegal, this is neither fair nor good practice. The International Office of Migration, an independent body, noted the hostages were "tired and quite confused" at the time of the interviews.

No one should forget what is happening in Afghanistan under its brutal Taliban regime. About 4,000 Afghan people applied to the UK for asylum last year with 800 of the first 805 being accepted. This is hardly surprising when even the normally hardline home office, in its review of political conditions there, set out a catalogue of public executions, public amputations by doctors (hands and feet of thieves), and public floggings of up to 100 lashes on women as well as men, to audiences of up to 30,000 people in Kabul's national stadium.

Mr Straw has precedents to note in dealing with the consequences of hijacking. In 1982 and in 1996 the Tories were persuaded that hijackers should eventually be allowed to stay. So his mettle will be shown in the asylum decisions still outstanding - and how much effort the government puts into ensuring that those who have been rejected are indeed safe. The handling of these cases is a grim responsibility for the home secretary. We have to hope that Jack Straw's optimism about the fate of those going home will turn out to have been justified.

fields.headline: Palm Pilot off to $18bn start-up
fields.standfirst:
Palm Pilot
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: An alarm clock symbol should be flashing on all Palm Pilots today as the manufacturer of the popular electronic organisers goes public.
fields.body:
An alarm clock symbol should be flashing on all Palm Pilots today as the manufacturer of the popular electronic organisers goes public.

Investor excitement about the growth of hand-held computers have made the flotation, expected today, one of the year's most keenly anticipated.

Demand has been so high that 3Com, the company's US parent, more than doubled the opening price range from $14-$16 a share to $30-$32 earlier this week, putting a market value of up to $18bn on the fledgling company.

The market fever spread to Britain where hand-held gadget maker Psion saw shares rise more than 22% to £64.75.

The atmosphere has been so giddy that shares could rise to $300 soon after opening. Bullish analysts point to the run-up in 3Com's own shares over the past three months as a sign of investor interest. Shares in the group rose more than 8% yesterday.

Most of the upturn reflects 3Com's offer, as yet ill-defined, to distribute its remaining 80% stake in Palm and excitement for all things wireless. But investors may be wise to look more closely at the demands of a fast-changing market. Palm dominates the global market for hand-held organisers, cornering nearly 70%. Research group IDC expects this to more than double in three years' time.

At present there are about 5.5m users of Palm Pilots, mainly in the US. Diana Hwang, programme manager of IDC's mobile research division, believes the expectations are partly justified by customer loyalty. Palm's operating system has largely seen off competition from Microsoft's Windows CE. But this week, the company made it clear it wants to catch up.

On Tuesday it said it was releasing software for hand-held computers that will let the devices play music, video and graphics. A day earlier, Microsoft forged a pact with high-flying mobile communications company Qualcomm to draw up designs for wireless devices. It also unveiled an internet service for mobile phones that will potentially let the 80m users of its Exchange and Hotmail email services write and read messages on the go.

Nevertheless, Palm remains confident. Supporters cite the strategic involvement of America Online, the internet service provider, as well as Nokia and Motorola, the two mobile phone manufacturers. All three are expected to buy a stake in the company. Over the past year, Palm has sought to maintain interest with a series of new versions based on its basic IIIx model. These include a Palm VII which connects to the internet and a colour version of the basic address book.

Ms Hwang is one of several analysts who believes that the flotation will allow Palm to spend more on product development. Others believe the company will find it hard to head off increased competition from rivals, including Handspring, Blackberry and Casio.

The greatest threat longer term is the growth of mobile phones which connect to the internet. Nokia expects one billion cellular phones in use around the world by 2003, a figure which dwarfs the expected number of hand-held devices. Most of these fears are based on the fact that although Palm's 16-bit operating system is popular, it will soon be overtaken.

3Com was accused of infringing copyright with the Palm in a lawsuit filed by E-Pass Technologies yesterday. A spokesman for 3Com said the suit was "absolutely without merit".

Fears about the future could damp enthusiasm for Palm's shares today. But, in the light of recent trends, few analysts predict that they will.

fields.headline: StepStone
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: StepStone has certainly found its path to success easy in the euphoria surrounding internet stocks with the announcement of its £2.41 a share flotation price hitting the top end of expectations yesterday.
fields.body:
StepStone has certainly found its path to success easy in the euphoria surrounding internet stocks with the announcement of its £2.41 a share flotation price hitting the top end of expectations yesterday.

The Norwegian online recruitment firm, which begins officially trading on the London and Oslo markets on March 14, last week had to nudge up its offer range from between 152p and 190p to 205p and 243p in response to the strong investor demand.

British investors have been allocated 5.9m shares with a parcel of 200 each, while 1.5m shares go to Norwegians.

Spread betting firms expect StepStone to soar as high as 480p to 490p. Fred Tulloch, marketing manager at Financial Spreads, said the demand for internet firms continued to amaze the company, which had underestimated its bets on StepStone and Interactive Investor International.

The offer of only 54m StepStone shares, which will raise £121m, is understood to have been at least 20 times oversubscribed with one institutional investor asking for 10%.

StepStone will be capitalised initially at £514m and intends to use the funds to expand across Europe. Giles Clarke, chief executive of StepStone, said the strategy is to be the leading online recruitment and career portal by snatching more employment listings, customer advertising and CV listings.

Mr Clarke who took the helm last September owns about 5% of the company. StepStone boasts clients including Nokia, Andersen Consulting, Coca-Cola and Pizza Hut.

However, losses at StepStone, founded in 1996, have leapt from €300,000 in 1997 to €24.2m (£15m) last year. It operates in Britain, Norway, Denmark, Sweden, Germany, France, Belgium and Italy, and claims that it is the market leader by revenue. Turnover in 1999 was £7m.

It says it has about 1.7m job-seeker profiles in its database and that it is used by more than 10,000 companies.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 I am delighted to hear reassurances from the New Labour high command that there is no concerted or organised anti-Ken drive at any level of the party. Meanwhile, a most intriguing email reaches us, from Colenzo Jarrett Thorpe to almost 100 young mustard-keen Blair loyalists, and the subject is a television appearance by Ken tonight. "Ken Livingstone is appearing on BBC Question Time this Thursday, where it is believed that he may very well reveal that he will stand as an independent," he begins. "It is therefore vital that we have sound voices in the audience to counter this and ensure that you generally clap, cheer and jeer in the right points." To oil the wheels of this master-plan, the Diary rings the BBC and makes sure they see a copy of this document - and the BBC (while insisting that their safeguards will weed out any such fiendish plots) promises to give a special welcome to the names if they apply for tickets. "Don't forget to email Ken to tell him to stay on board," Colenzo signs off, using an email address at the MSF union. fields.headline: Question of security
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Lastminute.com has enjoyed its status as a dot.com star but a series of system failures could knock the gloss off its success.
fields.body:
Lastminute.com has enjoyed its status as a dot.com star but a series of system failures could knock the gloss off its success.

In the past two months several customers have discovered that money has been deducted from their account without them purchasing any travel or gift products from its website.

Charlotte Brett, a London-based customer, was one of 80 Lastminute.com customers who suffered transaction problems with the internet firm. She said that in January and February £50 was deducted from her account on three occasions by the online travel agency even though she had not made a purchase.

The money was recredited to her account but Ms Brett claimed this took four weeks and was only done only after she alerted the company to the problem.

"I'm a very angry customer," Ms Brett said. "In my experience they have failed on the three most key areas - technology, customer service and internet capability."

Brent Hoberman, the chief executive of Lastminute.com, said the problems were caused by its third-party credit authority firm. He said the money had been refunded as quickly as possible and customers affected offered gift vouchers. "We did everything possible to remedy the situation," he said.

Lastminute's spokesman, Ian Jones, apologised to Ms Brett, explaining the flaw was being investigated. But Ms Brett said he failed to address why the money had been deducted without any purchase being made.

webTitle: EU examines the case for e-Vat

fields.headline: EU examines the case for e-Vat
fields.standfirst:
European Commission
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The European commission underlined yesterday that it would not be rushed into putting forward proposals on an "e-Vat" for entertainment on the web.
fields.body:
The European commission underlined yesterday that it would not be rushed into putting forward proposals on an "e-Vat" for entertainment on the web. The commission is sticking to plans to tax sales of items such as music, videos and games which are downloaded from the internet by European Union consumers but "delivered" by companies outside the EU.

But the issue is a complex one and a spokesman said yesterday: "The commission has not yet decided what its policy in this area is going to be and it is not close to deciding."

Gary Burnes, a senior manager for indirect taxes at accountants PricewaterhouseCoopers said there was concern about the development of a big tax loophole because of the ease with which companies outside the EU could set up internet sites to transmit to consumers inside the union.

"E-business has transformed the way we do business so much, it is very difficult to adapt tax rules to deal with that," he said.

Though videos, games and music are still predominantly delivered in physical form, an increasing number of consumers are now using the internet.

The EU wants to levy tax where the consumer is based but, according to Mr Burnes, though the countries in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development broadly agreed, many are "further back in the chain".

The commission is keen to ensure a level playing field for suppliers inside and outside the EU and it is aware that the issue has the potential to cause friction with other countries -not least the US, where internet based commerce is most widely developed - unless a mutually agreed framework can be introduced.

The question of enforcement is also potentially difficult. One suggestion that credit card companies should effectively act as tax collectors for the EU member states has run into widespread opposition from the financial services providers.

There are precedents for levying taxation on services from providers outside the EU - in the telecoms sector, for example. But those proposals, which involved far fewer providers than e-commerce, took two years to draw up.

webTitle: Anglian spreads its net to offset lower prices

fields.headline: Anglian spreads its net to offset lower prices
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Anglian Water is looking to the internet to help offset lower prices and competition in its core business.
fields.body:
Anglian Water is looking to the internet to help offset lower prices and competition in its core business.

Chris Mellor, the privatised water company's managing director, said its web site, inaugurated six months ago, moved into profit last month and would shortly expand its services. The site is one of a number of initiatives Anglian is taking counter the squeeze on its profits.

Mr Mellor said that the company would shortly start to sell electricity and gas to its customers. "It is pretty low-margin business but we can bundle it together and offer it to our 6m customers," he said.

Anglian is also seeking to expand its overseas business and is part of a consortium bidding for the contracts to revamp the London Underground.

Mr Mellor said that one of the latest additions to its web site, a car insurance service, was already attracting 300 in quiries a week. The group has plans to sell an advanced burglar alarm system which could be linked into the telemetry network used for monitoring Anglian's water operations.

The utility also plans to allow customers to notify the company of changes of address over the internet. "When people move house, they often consider buying a new washing machine or cooker and they will be able to buy them from our web site, " Mr Mellor said.

Anglian takes a commission on white goods purchases which are handled by another company, Value Direct.

The company is also using the internet to expand the markets for its Geodysis digital mapping and Powermarque vehicle leasing operations.

Mr Mellor said that Anglian had to provide detailed maps to local authorities by law. It was now selling this information over the internet to local solicitors to help with house purchase searches.

Anglian, which is cutting 400 jobs to reduce costs to meet the 10% price cut imposed by Ofwat, is also seeking to expand its international operations.

New bids include one for the construction of a water treatment plant in Beijing.

webTitle: Pensioner dies five weeks after kidney surgery error

fields.headline: Pensioner dies five weeks after kidney surgery error
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: A pensioner who had the wrong kidney removed during what should have been routine surgery at a south Wales hospital died yesterday without regaining consciousness five weeks after the bungled operation.
fields.body:
A pensioner who had the wrong kidney removed during what should have been routine surgery at a south Wales hospital died yesterday without regaining consciousness five weeks after the bungled operation.

Graham Reeves, 70, a Korean war veteran, was left fighting for his life after a surgical team at Prince Philip hospital in Llanelli removed his healthy kidney by mistake.

He died yesterday afternoon in the intensive care unit of Swansea's Morriston hospital to which he had been transferred as soon as the blunder was discovered.

Surgeons there are reported to have removed Mr Reeves's diseased kidney earlier this week.

A close friend who took the pensioner to hospital for the original operation said his family showed no bitterness towards staff at the Prince Philip. But they would be demanding a full inquiry into his death.

The Rev Walford Roberts said that the former power station worker never regained consciousness after the surgery and had been unaware that the operation had failed.

At least 19 people offered to donate a kidney for transplant when news of the blunder first broke but medical experts said that Mr Reeves was too weak to undergo a transplant operation.

John Roberts, the consultant urologist who led the Prince Philip team, has been suspended from duties since the operation. A junior doctor and a registrar have also been suspended.

In a statement last night Mr Roberts, 58, said that he had been deeply saddened by the events of the last few weeks and was still trying to come to terms with what had happened.

He said that he was "very sorry" to hear about Mr Reeves's death and wanted to extend his deepest sympathy to his family and friends. "My thoughts are with them at this very difficult time."

Mr Reeves's death was announced as officials at Carmathenshire NHS Trust, which runs the Llanelli hospital, prepared to unveil the initial findings of two separate inquiries into what went wrong.

But for legal reasons the trust's internal investigation and a separate inquiry by two leading urologists from the Royal College of Surgeons will not now be released this afternoon as had been planned.

"The report was supposed to go public but this is impossible right now," a spokeswoman for the trust said last night.

"We are all saddened by Mr Reeves's tragic death but his case is now in the hands of the coroner. This is not what we want but unfortunately we are governed by legal constraints."

Mike Jones, chief executive of Carmarthenshire NHS Trust, said that everyone at the Prince Philip hospital was sad to learn of Mr Reeves's death. "We have been in contact with members of Mr Reeves's family since his operation on 24 January when the wrong kidney was removed and we will continue to give them all the support we can."

He said that the trust had been determined to establish exactly what happened to ensure that such an incident could not occur again but he said for legal reasons and out of respect for Mr Reeves's family he was unable to make any further information available.

The Llanelli MP Denzil Davies said Mr Reeves's death was a dreadful end to a traumatic set of circumstances. He added it was important for the truth to emerge as soon as was practically possible.

webTitle: Ministers back MP's bill to prevent GPs dodging complaints

fields.headline: Ministers back MP's bill to prevent GPs dodging complaints
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: A legal loophole, allowing general practitioners facing complaints from patients to avoid investigation by retiring, is to be closed under new legislation.
fields.body:
A legal loophole, allowing general practitioners facing complaints from patients to avoid investigation by retiring, is to be closed under new legislation.

A bill to be presented in parliament tomorrow will give the health service ombudsman new powers to pursue GPs, dentists, pharmacists and opticians, even if they stop practising in the national health service.

The measure is being put forward as a private member's bill by the Conservative MP for Wealden, Sir Geoffrey Johnson Smith, but has government and cross-party support.

Ministers may decide to wrap it into wider legislation tightening checks on GPs, which is being introduced in the wake of the Shipman mass murder case.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, is examining ways to increase the accountability and effectiveness of the General Medical Council, which has come under renewed fire since the Hyde GP was convicted of killing 15 elderly patients last month.

The home office is already reviewing a similar loophole allowing senior police officers to dodge investigation through retirement, following recommendations from the Stephen Lawrence inquiry.

At present, GPs and other health professionals cannot be touched by health service watchdogs once they "officially retire", even if they do so while an investigation is under way. In another "basic injustice" condemned by Sir Geoffrey, they can continue practising as locums or privately while information about their past performance never comes to light.

Both issues were highlighted by the health ombudsman, Michael Buckley, in his 1998-99 annual report. Yesterday he threw his full backing behind the bill.

The proposed legislation, drafted by the Consumers' Association, would allow patients to continue to seek redress for grievances, even if their GP retired.

Sir Geoffrey said yesterday: "There have been a significant number of cases of patients left unable to obtain justice. This is an obvious loophole which needs blocking."

David Hinchliffe, Labour chairman of the Commons health committee and a sponsor of the bill, said: "There is a clear anomaly in the current arrangements which must be resolved."

The Consumers' Association is backing reform as part of a wider campaign to tackle "serious shortcomings" in complaints systems for patients.

Emma Harrison, its public affairs officer, said: "If GPs have got something to hide, there is even more reason for the public to know. Consumers want fair treatment."

The association has been a leading critic of the NHS complaints process, the GMC's discliplinary system and the complaints procedure for private health patients.

It wants the remit of the ombudsman's office extended to cover private health care, and the creation of a "one stop" public sector ombudsman's scheme covering health, housing and social services.

fields.headline: Archer finds a new role
fields.standfirst: The fall of Archer: special report
fields.trailText: Even his fiercest enemies never believed they would see Jeffrey Archer hauled up before an Old Bailey judge charged with murder.
fields.body:
Even his fiercest enemies never believed they would see Jeffrey Archer hauled up before an Old Bailey judge charged with murder.

But the multi-millionaire novelist has ensured that his name will once again dominate the headlines by casting himself in the lead in his new play about a doctor charged with poisoning his wife.

With his flair for publicity undimmed by his recent humiliation, Lord Archer will make his comeback this autumn in The Accused which he wrote after he was forced to resign as the Tories' London mayor candidate in November.

Lord Archer discloses his new venture tonight in his first television interview since he admitted asking a friend to lie in his successful 1987 libel action against the Daily Star.

He tells ITV's Tonight with Trevor McDonald that he felt "very broken" when he was forced to resign.

"You think what a silly mistake," he tells the interviewer Martin Bashir. "I had the opportunity to do the one job I wanted to do but threw it away. In that sense you get angry with yourself, with your own stupidity, your own failings, your own weaknesses."

Lord Archer said he felt particular remorse for letting down his supporters. "[I felt] just total despair, a total feeling of real failure. I was very apologetic and very broken."

Amid the depths of his despair Lord Archer did, however, find time to pen his play.

Drawn from a real life murder trial, Lord Archer will play the part of a doctor who was charged with poisoning his wife over a seven-year period. The evidence is so evenly balanced that Lord Archer leaves it up to the audience to act as the jury at every performance.

fields.headline: Road safety moves dismay campaigners
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Proposals for cutting deaths and serious injuries on the roads by 40% by 2010 were attacked yesterday as half- baked, lacking in teeth and lacking new funding for local authorities to make them work.
fields.body:
Proposals for cutting deaths and serious injuries on the roads by 40% by 2010 were attacked yesterday as half- baked, lacking in teeth and lacking new funding for local authorities to make them work.

The centrepiece of the government's initiative, launched by the prime minister yesterday, is a plan to invite local authorities to introduce more 20mph zones, particularly around schools and in residential areas.

The government is also looking at a "local targeted approach to roads". This could include a normal speed limit of 30mph in villages, and an even lower limit on country lanes where there may be black spots.

Mr Blair said the new targets were needed to stop "lives being blighted and families being devastated". It was not enough for Britain to have a good safety record on the roads: they had to become even safer.

Last year 103 child pedestrians were killed on the roads, and that was 103 too many. The aim was to reduce the number of people killed or seriously injured by 40% by 2010.

The plans were welcomed by the police and motoring groups, but safety and organisations said they did not go far enough. The onus was on local authorities to bring in the changes with no extra cash.

James Parker, national secretary of the Institute of Road Safety Officers, said: "Local authorities are already being forced to shut down road safety posts through lack of money. With no new funding this will continue." He questioned whether 20mph limits around schools would solve the problem. "The evidence is that child deaths occur in a number of disparate places away from schools."

Lyn Sloman, assistant director of Transport 2000, said: "The government has wimped out. With this review it had the chance to make the streets safer for everyone, but apart from minor tinkering it does not seem prepared to do anything that would have any real effect." The Pedestrians' Association, was among several organisations which complained that the government had not gone far enough, and a new national 20mph urban speed limit was needed.

In its strategy document Tomorrow's roads - safer for everyone, the government leaves it up to local authorities to set speed limits and to see that they are enforced.

Debbie Harvey, from south London, whose husband was killed on a pedestrian crossing in 1998, was in a delegation which visited Mr Blair before Christmas to discuss roads safety. fields.headline: The future is calling
fields.standfirst: The way we think about mobile phones is being challenged by iobox from Helsinki.  Victor Keegan reports
fields.trailText: The way we think about mobile phones is being challenged by iobox from Helsinki. Victor Keegan reports
fields.body:
Iobox, an upstart start-up from downtown Helsinki, is nothing if not ambitious. "We want to become the Yahoo! of mobile phones," says Henry Nilert, one of the co-founders. It is already well on the way. Iobox offers a one-stop shop for mobile web access including messaging, entertainment, stock quotes, m-commerce (mobile commerce) and personal management (like calendars). An email sent to your iobox email address also sends the first 160 characters to your mobile and beeps to tell you it has arrived.

Most of these services are already available on conventional mobiles. But iobox also offers expanded options for the new internet-friendly Wap (wireless application protocol) phones including a free email box, access to address books and icons that can be downloaded from www.iobox.com. This week, iobox announced a partnership with FirstQuote to provide share quotes, news, top market movers and the ability to buy and sell shares directly from mobile phones and other wireless terminals.

Nilert claims that its service (costing about six cents a throw) is unique since it is available to any Wap or ordinary phone user regardless of which operator they use.

When I visited the company in Helsinki last September, it claimed 200,000 registered users for its website. While we were chatting in one room, new customers from all over Europe were registering automatically on a computer in another room at the rate of 1,000 a day without the burden of a sales force. It beats selling double glazing any day.

In London last week (where iobox is setting up a second head office) Nilert said that registrations had now topped 400,000 and were increasing by 1,500 a day. And this is before iobox spends its latest £8m fundraising on a marketing push.

Iobox already claims to be the world's leading wireless portal. Nilert, a 28 year old Swede, born in New York but brought up in France, expects to have several million users within the next couple of years and a significant share of a world market expected to grow to 500 million wireless devices by 2001.

Iobox has been riding on the back of Finland's world lead in mobile telephony - it has the highest mobile usage and the world's biggest mobile phone manufacturer, Nokia. Barely a year old, it raised an unprecedented amount of money last year for a Finnish start-up ($3m) before getting the new tranche in December.

What of the future? "My feeling is we haven't seen anything yet," says Nilert. "Of today's services, email to mobile has been very popular and so has chat or instant messaging. Content services will get more popular - like getting time-critical information sent directly to you, say, about a blockage up the road.

"Users won't be happy if they get irrelevant information. Personalisation and location are very important. If I follow a particular stock, I may want to know any major changes.

"Another category is m-commerce. With today's technology there is still, despite the limitations, a huge potential. For example, I may want to know when the next book of a favourite author comes out. In Finland you can now buy cans of Coke or have your car washed while paying by mobile. Last minute deals for hotels and flights are becoming popular.

"Your phone is a very personal product, with you all the time, you almost sleep with it. You can have your own icon and ringing tone, the ability to play games on it. If every week you wanted the top 10 songs, you could get them or the song of your soccer team. It has to be done in a focused way, making it as simple as possible. We have done sales of books and CDs (in association with Boxman. com) by phone since July.

"Looking to the future you will have a device that is 'on' all the time with unlimited bandwidth with better information and graphics. Further on, it would be nice to have voice recognition as I browse through sites. There will be a little video camera there too.

"There will be seamless integration between the internet device you have in your home, whether it is a screen or your fridge or your desk, and the thing you have in your pocket and the device you have in your car. It's going to be all the same service received n different ways. I may be typing an email to a friend of mine from home, and reply when I am sitting in the car. I may listen to it in the car on the phone and then reply talking into the phone".

Iobox's revenue comes from three sources: its take from each phone call, income from hosting wireless services for others, and commissions from e-commerce sales. Like most dot.com executives Nilert is coy about figures - except to admit that losses exceed revenues. He says the company could be profitable in a couple of months if it stopped investing but "that would not be smart".

The name of the game is gaining market share.

webTitle: Just say no to biotech business

fields.headline: Just say no to biotech business
fields.standfirst:
Tony Blair should be brave enough to do a swift u-turn on GM foods

GM food: special report
fields.trailText: The u-turn, mysteriously, has become the gravest of political crimes, even when adhering to existing policies is suicidal. So the efforts this week of the cabinet enforcer, Mo Mowlam, to convince us that Tony Blair has not changed his views on genetically engineered food were sadly predictable
fields.body:
The man who never changes his opinion," Blake observed, "is like stagnant water, and breeds reptiles in the mind." It is, therefore, distressing to see how determined politicians are to persuade us that they never refresh their mental fluids. The u-turn, mysteriously, has become the gravest of political crimes, even when adhering to existing policies is suicidal. Having bred an imaginary reptile out of one amphibian-loving MP, for example, Tony Blair is now becalmed in the stagnant water of his own intransigence.

So the efforts this week of the cabinet enforcer, Mo Mowlam, to convince us that Tony Blair has not changed his views on genetically engineered food were sadly predictable. The government, she insists, remains, as it has always been, neutral: "We are neither for nor against GM."

Well, neutrality, if this is what Mr Blair's position entails, certainly represents a policy shift. Last year, the government allocated £13m "to improve the profile of the biotech industry", by promoting "the financial and environmental benefits of biotechnology". The prime minister, a Downing Street spokesman insisted, "is very strongly of the view that these products are safe". The UK "leads the way in Europe", according to the government's Invest in Britain Bureau, "in ensuring that regulations and other measures affecting the development of biotechnology take full account of the concerns of business". If this is neutrality, the Pope's an agnostic.

Genetic engineering has always troubled Tony Blair, for it divides his two great constituencies - big business and Middle England. When faced, for the first time in his premiership, with the need to alienate one by supporting the other, he chose to side with the lobbyists, and against the electorate. It was only after the business case for GM food collapsed that he changed his position. Even so, while acknowledging the legitimacy of public concerns about the environment and food safety, his article on Sunday avoided the real issue: the corporate capture of the food chain.

Mr Blair's backing for the biotech companies has, as he now appears to have recognised, done him untold harm. It has taught businesses that he's a dupe who will sing to their tune, however off-key it may be. It has encouraged voters to explore the other insalubrious liaisons in which he has become entangled. His conversion to neutrality, even in the narrowest political terms, is long overdue. But it will take a lot more than an article in a Sunday newspaper to make it look convincing.

To recover his credibility, he must snatch government policy out of the hands of the biotech business. This means relieving Lord Sainsbury, whose crashing conflicts of interest remain a major political embarrassment, of his duties as science minister. He must sack Professor Ray Baker, the head of the government's biotechnology research council. Professor Baker has used his post as a platform for misleading public statements in support of GM, while his council gags researchers who wish to speak out against the technology.

Meetings of the biotech advisory committees must all be made public, and their members prevented from voting on decisions in which they have a commercial interest. The flow of research funds should be reversed. Last year the government spent £52m on developing GM crops, for which demand in Britain is approximately zero, and £1.7m on research into organic farming, for which demand outstrips domestic supply by 200%. The Foresight committees, which help guide the allocation of government science funds, but are dominated by business people, must be dismantled.

If field trials are to continue (and it's not easy to see the point of spending taxpayers' money to discover whether plants engineered to destroy wildlife are bad for the environment), they must be isolated from other crops and redesigned. It is absurd that one of the key questions - of how far GM pollen travels - has been left to Friends of the Earth and Newsnight to investigate.

The government must revoke the legislation, passed by the Conservatives, raising the permitted levels of glyphosate pesticide residues in soya by 200 times: a menace to public health engineered to allow Monsanto's herbicide resistant beans to be sold in the UK. It should reverse its support for the European directive permitting the patenting of genes, which resulted in the undignified spectacle, at the end of last year, of the prime minister begging the biotech companies not to use the new powers his government has granted them.

Genetic engineering has become one of the great tests of Tony Blair's premiership. If he flunks it, he will validate his reputation as the corporate prime minister, who treats the electorate with contempt.
