fields.headline: Way beyond our Ken
fields.trailText: I think I am going off Kenneth Clarke. As politicians go, there is a lot to be said for him. He says what he thinks, unspun and unpagered. He doesn't trust focus groups. Though deep into politics he does not drown in them. In Denis Healey's famous formulation, Ken Clarke has a hinterland - though where Denis's is Berlioz* and Cartier-Bresson, Ken's is Sonny Rollins, Nottingham Forest and the great crested grebe.
fields.body:
I think I am going off Kenneth Clarke. As politicians go, there is a lot to be said for him. He says what he thinks, unspun and unpagered. He doesn't trust focus groups. Though deep into politics he does not drown in them. In Denis Healey's famous formulation, Ken Clarke has a hinterland - though where Denis's is Berlioz* and Cartier-Bresson, Ken's is Sonny Rollins, Nottingham Forest and the great crested grebe.

So when Mr Insouciance turned up the other day on a Britain in Europe platform, despite mutterings in his local party about deselection if this kind of practice persisted, nobody was surprised. On Europe above all issues, Ken does not pull his punches. Nor, as he often reminds us, does he ever attack William Hague. Though he could not resist observing during a Christmas chat with old chums on the BBC that the Tories under Hague's leadership had lurched to the right and developed a "mad obsession" with Europe and that Hague was leading them into electoral defeat, or describing Hague's campaign against Euro-taxation as "a farce", "fuelled by high-pitched Euro-hysteria", or saying of Hague's call for a referendum on the Amsterdam summit that Britain was becoming "like Switzerland without the cowbells". His message to the BiE meeting was no surprise either - a "strident and unrepresentative minority" (guess who) was trying to hijack the debate on the single currency.

Which is where a tinge of disbelief starts to set in. Two and a half years ago, after John Major quit, he ran for the party leadership. In the final round it was Clarke versus Hague after John Redwood dropped out. Who was first on the phone to John Redwood 10 minutes after the result? Not Hague; he didn't get round to making his call for a further 45 minutes. And was Ken ringing to say that, whatever the circumstances, he would have no truck with strident and unrepresentative Europhobes? Not exactly. It was rather to concoct the oddest alliance conceivable: the Tory equivalent of a Mandelson-Livingstone ticket to take over from Tony Blair. "John and I," he declared, "are going to work closely together at the heart of opposition and at the heart of Conservative government.

"I expect," he said, "to form a shadow cabinet with prominent Eurosceptics playing a proper role in it." Suppose this astonishing tandem had actually wobbled on to the road: can we really suppose it would it now be pursuing the principled line which Kenneth Clarke preached at the BiE meeting? Or would not it rather be something more muddied and compromised - rather like William Hague's?

Then there is the smoking. When Margaret Thatcher sent him to health, the health establishment found itself, to its horror, in the clutches of a man who was palpably overweight and hugely fond of a large cigar. Now he not only smokes them, he markets them too, as deputy chairman of BAT. In which capacity he was invited a fortnight ago before the health select committee of the Commons to reply to allegations raised in this newspaper that the company had been knowingly involved in the smuggling of cigarettes around the world. When asked to comment on internal documents on which these allegations were based, he said he could not answer as he had not read them.

That might in one sense have been believable: he is a famous non-reader, who cheerfully admitted just after Black Wednesday that he'd never got round to reading the Maastricht treaty. But in this case, it seemed rather odd, since a few days before he had written a piece in the Guardian defending BAT against these same allegations. Even more curiously, that piece had contained what looked like a candid admission that BAT had done what he said that it hadn't. But when this was put to him, he got quite cross, said it was not an admission, and complained of selective quotation.

What did for the Clarke-Redwood ticket in 1997, apart from its ludicrous line-up, was the intervention of Margaret Thatcher: no fan of Clarke - as he, to his credit, has never pretended that he was a fan of hers. Taking Hague by the hand, she announced that the lad stood for all the things she believed in. Whereupon various dithering rightists, having heard Mummy speak, had their doubts swept away and voted for Hague. No doubt at the time Lady T thought she was doing William a service. In the light of the party's present disarray, even she might reflect that the chief beneficiary was less bruised and beleaguered William than cheerful, insouciant Ken.

* "Hector Berlioz, like me, had found it necessary for much of his life to earn a little extra by writing weekly articles as a feuilletoniste" - Denis Healey, The Time of My Life

webTitle: Blizzard blows up a storm in rush for greasers' gong

fields.headline: Blizzard blows up a storm in rush for greasers' gong
fields.standfirst: Life in Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Six months to go, but we're already excited about the golden pager award, the prize for the most sycophantic MP of the year.
fields.body:
Six months to go, but we're already excited about the golden pager award, the prize for the most sycophantic MP of the year.

The 1999 winner was Barry Sheerman, on the grounds that a middle-aged white guy could bear this tremendous honour. But early signs are that the committee may go for someone quite different.

The first challenger yesterday was Oona King, whom I like a lot. Hers was a dazzling bid for glory. She said to the prime minister, "I have never started a question by congratulating you, but I have to break this habit of a lifetime because of the astonishing work by you, the chancellor and Clare Short in combatting world poverty."

To preface a piece of boot-licking with a disavowal of boot-licking! That will win plenty of bonus points.

Then we heard from Eric Martlew of Carlisle, who was thrilled by the new hospitals, "including one in my constituency, for which we have waited 20 years, and which is 30 weeks early, and on budget!" Good greasing, but not quite great greasing.

However, the judges (of whom I have the honour to be one) were thrilled with the bid from Bob Blizzard. He used the cunning stratagem of attributing his obsequiousness to the media, in this case "Beach Radio, which serves East Anglia".

Anyone tuned in would have heard the glad news about a local hospital which has just employed 20 new nurses, which had coped well over the millennium, had a £700,000 refit, and where miracles had begun to occur, such as the halt being made lame, the blind made deaf, Tony Blair's face appearing in a bedpan, etc. (I may have got some of the details wrong).

"This is proof on the ground that the NHS is being rebuilt! Unlike the opposition which would privatise it," he told MPs. Straight on to the shortlist with you, Bob. This Blizzard will be no storm in a teacup.

One person who doesn't stand a chance is Sir Sydney Chapman, who appeared to pay glutinous tribute to Sir Edward Heath on the 50th anniversary of his arrival in the House. "Will you join me in congratulating him?" he began. Sir Edward shifted slightly in his seat and a small smile appeared on his face. Clearly this was to be the start of a flattering full-body rub.

But Sir Ted has no patronage left, and within nanoseconds Sir Sydney was on to police numbers. Very slowly, and looking almost aghast, the Father of the House turned round to glower at him, like King Lear hearing Cordelia's first speech, or a walrus seeing the keeper give his fish to a penguin. The sheer outrage on Sir Ted's face brought a ripple of delighted laughter from the spectators.

Next we had the debate on Teresa Gorman. The standards committee reported that she should be suspended for a month because of her failure to declare interests in rental properties, and her attempts to cover this up.

She adopted the "I'm just a dotty old duck" defence. It had all happened a long time ago, she'd been confused, her husband looked after the business side of things, and so on. She had got things wrong, but, dearie me, it was so difficult to keep track.

She was defended by Peter Tapsell, who pointed out that it costs a small fortune to get maids these days. This may not have helped her cause.

And there was a devastating speech by Alan Williams, for the committee, who listed innumerable low crimes and misdemeanours. Basically she and her husband had sold their houses to off-shore companies, which in turn were sold to another off-shore company, which just happened to be owned by Mr and Mrs Gorman.

To many Tories, such a transaction would be no stranger than buying a tin of beans would be to the rest of us. But Labour MPs looked shocked. Suspension, yes, they were thinking; possibly from a rope.

fields.headline: Major faces fees inquiry
fields.standfirst:
Tories in opposition: special report
Life in Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: The former prime minister, John Major, is to be investigated by parliament's standards commissioner, Elizabeth Filkin, over whether he should be made to declare up to £1m he is believed to have received in lecture fees from international engagements.
fields.body:
The former prime minister, John Major, is to be investigated by parliament's standards commissioner, Elizabeth Filkin, over whether he should be made to declare up to £1m he is believed to have received in lecture fees from international engagements.

Desmond Turner, Labour MP for Brighton, Kemptown, has complained to the commissioner that Mr Major has failed to declare the cash he had received for some 12 speaking engagements. The complaint is likely to be an important test case into whether MPs should be obliged to disclose such sums.

In the register published last week, Mr Major listed 12 speeches for which he received fees, free travel and accommodation. He visited the US at least six times, as well as Kuwait, Bermuda, Spain, Switzerland, France and Saudi Arabia. He also registered a directorship of Mayflower Corporation plc, a lucrative book deal with HarperCollins, and referred to receiving fees for speeches in the UK.

Mr Turner said: "I think the public should know how much he is coining in."

Mr Major's spokeswoman last night said Mr Major had been "scrupulous" in declaring his interests.

webTitle: Gorman barred from Commons for a month

fields.headline: Gorman barred from Commons for a month
fields.standfirst:
Tories in opposition: special report
Life in parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Teresa Gorman, descibed by one Tory colleague yesterday as a "combative and zany MP" was barred from the Commons last night for a month after MPs accepted a damning report on her failure to declare her business affairs.
fields.body:
Teresa Gorman, descibed by one Tory colleague yesterday as a "combative and zany MP" was barred from the Commons last night for a month after MPs accepted a damning report on her failure to declare her business affairs.

MPs upheld without a vote the findings of a highly critical report by the Commons standards and privileges committee which found the Tory MP for Billericay had "intended to deceive" Elizabeth Filkin, parliament's standards commissioner, over her property dealings held in offshore trusts. MPs were told that while the failure to disclose was not the most serious offence, it was her "untruthfulness" that led to the longest suspension from parliament for five years.

Mrs Gorman did however receive support from a number of Tory backbenchers who argued that the penalty was far too severe.

There was also support from MPs on all sides of the house - led by Sir Nicholas Lyell, the former Tory attorney general, for new reforms to the disciplinary procedures - particularly giving MPs the right to consult and be represented by lawyers when they appeared by the privileges committee.

The debate opened with a statement from Mrs Gorman insisting that she had never intended to mislead parliament, and stressing the properties were part of her husband's business affairs and therefore not covered by rules about registering MPs' interests.

She told a crowded Commons: "I can see in retrospect that I have handled the matter less than satisfactorily. Of course, I could have done better but I do draw the line at being called a liar, which the report states - I find that offensive and quite unnecessary.

"I don't consider that the answers I gave her were dishonest but I do admit that some of them were very muddled." The explanation was "memory is sometimes so mixed and failing after so long a period of time", she said.

"Nowadays you are in danger of being in difficulty if you don't register a doughnut when you've had one at some entertainment or other," she added.

Labour's Alan Williams (Swansea W), deputy chairman of the privileges committee, said it was "unpleasant" to have to move the suspension of a "long-standing parliamentary colleague". The extensive inquiries could have been avoided if Mrs Gorman had "cooperated properly", he said.

The most serious aspects of the complaint against her was that she provided "seriously misleading and inaccurate information" to the registrar of members' interests, the commissioner, the committee chairman, and the committee, Mr Williams said. She also made "false allegations" about a member of the public using parliamentary privilege and "improperly contacted" a witness in the case, he added.

Sir Peter Tapsell (C. Louth and Horncastle), called the proposed penalty "disproportionately severe" and said Mrs Gorman had not been corrupted or set out to corrupt anyone else.

He attacked the report's scrutiny of her overseas property interests - which he said were "irrelevant" - and the implication that without publicity surrounding difficulties in her marriage, now "happily overcome", the proposed punishment might have been harsher.

"The fact is she is a combative and zany lady and I have known a great many combative and zany ladies in the course of my life. Indeed I rather like combative and zany ladies and I particularly like Mrs Gorman who is a woman of courage and integrity and patriotism with no malice in her at all."

The Tory former minister Patrick Nicholls (Teignbridge) expressed concern about the length of sentence passed on Mrs Gorman.

He said the Northern Ireland Secretary, Peter Mandelson, had escaped without suspension over failure to disclose a loan from the former paymaster general, Geoffrey Robinson. "By contrast Mrs Gorman gets the severest penalty of all ... it seems to me the punishment meted out is not based on the gravity of the offence but because the committee felt that their corporate dignity had been infringed," Mr Nicholls said.

Privileges committee member Martin Bell, the Independent MP for Tatton, stressed the committee was non-partisan and defended its rigorous procedures "because we want this parliament to be held in a higher esteem than the last parliament. We owe this to ourselves, we owe this to our constituents, we owe this to the institution in which we sit. I believe that the report is outstandingly fair".

Another committee member, the Lib Dem MP Malcolm Bruce (Gordon), said he was "extremely concerned" about the tone of the debate.

He accused Tory supporters of Mrs Gorman of trying to "undermine the judgment of the committee" and the work it had done. "We should be very cautious about that," Mr Bruce warned.

fields.headline: Both good and gracious
fields.trailText: I write as a bishop who did see the Asian comedy show Goodness Gracious Me last week, which came under fire at the general synod in the debate on the BBC (Synod decides to monitor broadcasters, March 1). While I was uneasy about the sketch on the holy communion, I did feel this programme brilliantly exposed, in a reverse way, the institutional racism in the police and in the Church of England.
fields.body:
I write as a bishop who did see the Asian comedy show Goodness Gracious Me last week, which came under fire at the general synod in the debate on the BBC (Synod decides to monitor broadcasters, March 1). While I was uneasy about the sketch on the holy communion, I did feel this programme brilliantly exposed, in a reverse way, the institutional racism in the police and in the Church of England.

The group of Asian policemen investigating, and then making excuses for, the stabbing of a young white man, spoke vividly of the pain and anger felt in the black community about the police investigation into the murder of Stephen Lawrence. Many in the black community see the Church of England as a white man's club, and the sketch involving the black bishop conveyed a message which the general synod needs to hear. Thank you BBC for Goodness Gracious Me.
Rt Revd Roger Sainsbury
Bishop of Barking

The protesting bishop has completely missed the point - the sketch is laughing about Asians who are trying to be more English than the English. If some of us find men in long dresses offering wine cups as the blood of Christ rather, well, odd, this ritual was not invented by the Goodness Gracious Me team.
Norma Haemmerle
London


Why on earth (or heaven if you like) did the synod take such offence to the sketch? They obviously completely missed the point of it. As GGM has a history of making a little fun of all religions (Hinduism, for example), do I take it that the synod doesn't mind having a laugh at them? Or do they just sit with a straight face in front of their TVs with clipboards poised, waiting for a stray reference to Christianity? Would anyone with a spare sense of humour please send it to the right reverend.
Julian Maynard
Rayleigh, Essex

webTitle: Let him die if that's what he wants

fields.headline: Let him die if that's what he wants
fields.trailText: I oppose capital punishment because I do not believe the state should have the right to impose death as punishment, but that is very different to permitting a prisoner, in this case Ian Brady, to decide that he chooses death to spending the rest of his life in prison (Brady begs for the right to die, February 29).
fields.body:
I oppose capital punishment because I do not believe the state should have the right to impose death as punishment, but that is very different to permitting a prisoner, in this case Ian Brady, to decide that he chooses death to spending the rest of his life in prison (Brady begs for the right to die, February 29).

Brady's crime was horrific and it costs money that could better be spent on people in need to keep him alive. Surely this is the kind of case where we need a legal ruling that ends the idiocy of preserving a life that has lost its value to the owner as well as society?
Angela Neustatter
London
a.neustatter@dial.pipex.com


The Guardian thinks it's perfectly reasonable to let Ian Brady kill himself (Leader, February 29) and that keeping people alive so that they can be punished is barbaric.

At the same time you think it would have been inhuman for the officials of a democratic state to execute Mr Brady after a jury had concluded, beyond reasonable doubt, that he had murdered three children.

Aren't you elevating the rights of the individual to absurd heights?
Keith Hindell
London


Myra Hindley, if she is to be believed, is a reformed character of religious conviction (The Hindley letter, G2, February 29). Surely a Christian should understand that atonement for her sins and an acceptance of the punishment meted out by the law of the land without complaint would be the best way of demonstrating the desire for forgiveness in the hope of eternal salvation?

Hindley's quest for release shows a paradox in belief.

Do we really need to get into the psyche of someone so cold, calculated and evil? Wouldn't we rather hear the silence of Hindley accepting her punishment and truly showing that she seeks forgiveness by offering her victims' families some dignity and respect?
Mark Windsor
Devizes


I am appalled that you devote seven pages to the two unspeakable Moors murderers. As a reader for 66 years, I have to tell you that this belongs in the realm of the worst tabloids.
Henry Mortimer
Leicester

fields.headline: Exit pursued by lions
fields.trailText: Reading the article on the broadcaster Sarah Kennedy suggesting black people are such good athletes owing to their experience of evading lions (DJ attacked over remarks about black athletes, March 1), I was almost moved to tears: of laughter. Writing as a black person who has lived in a number of UK cities, I know what real racism is. I have experienced it. This comment is not racist. Silly, probably; badly chosen, undoubtedly but funny, definitely.
fields.body:
Reading the article on the broadcaster Sarah Kennedy suggesting black people are such good athletes owing to their experience of evading lions (DJ attacked over remarks about black athletes, March 1), I was almost moved to tears: of laughter. Writing as a black person who has lived in a number of UK cities, I know what real racism is. I have experienced it. This comment is not racist. Silly, probably; badly chosen, undoubtedly but funny, definitely.

Having only seen a real lion at Longleat and never having been chased by a lion in Edinburgh, Aberdeen, Bradford etc, I can only assume that Ms Kennedy is badly informed about the lion population of the UK. The only creatures I regularly have to evade are politically correct, po-faced media darlings lecturing me, a British black person, on racism. I am disappointed to see the fight against racism being hijacked by humourless political wannabes.
Mark Morley
London
The real question is how such glib racist assumptions are allowed to continuously circulate in the British media. Kennedy's remarks are part of the general mass of "inferential racism", particularly when it comes to discussing black people and their bodies (eg in sport and entertainment). "Black success" is all too often attributed to "black genes". Why do we never hear debates about Scandinavians being so naturally adept at the forehand smash in tennis?
Dr Sarita Malik
Isleworth, Middlesex
saritamalik@hotmail.com

fields.headline: Pumas ready to pounce
fields.body:
No mainstream American politician has yet made the connection between events in the Michigan school (Six-year-old boy shoots girl dead, March 1) and the need for gun control. May we expect that they will continue to support that other great preserver of law and order and begin the construction of a child's size electric chair?
Ian Tunnacliffe
Taplow, Bucks
Why do we have RAF Puma helicopters on standby (Whitehall argues over helicopters, March 1)? Are they waiting for an emergency to arise?
John Craddock
New Barnet, Herts


Could not the helicopters returning to pick up the unfortunate victims of the floods load up with anything that floats; inflated tyre inner tubes, lilos, dingies etc?
Ron Day
Hutton, Essex
ronday@barclays.net


I was sickened to hear the comments from Kent residents concerning the rise in council charges of £3 per year necessary to provide a response to asylum seekers (Councils told to halt 'export' of refugees, February 26). So I have decided to send Kent county council £3 and urge others to do the same to express support for councils on the front line.
Allison Bennett
London


If Branson wins the lottery (Camelot pledges £5bn in lottery bid, March 1), punters will presumably be eligible for the jackpot only if they have bought a ticket three months in advance.
John Cundill
London


I assume that Guardian columnists don't give their email addresses (Letters, February 29) because a) they have lives and b) do not have an unhealthy fear of sunshine.
Gelnn Hackney
Burnham on Crouch, Essex

fields.headline: We're banking on a rip-off
fields.trailText: I was appalled to read that the banks intend to levy a surcharge on customers of other banks using their cash machines via the Link network (Banks agree to cashpoint surcharges, March 1). This move is anti-competitive (since it gives people more incentive to open accounts with larger banks with more cash machines) and, worse, will disproportionately hit the less well off who use cash more.
fields.body:
I was appalled to read that the banks intend to levy a surcharge on customers of other banks using their cash machines via the Link network (Banks agree to cashpoint surcharges, March 1). This move is anti-competitive (since it gives people more incentive to open accounts with larger banks with more cash machines) and, worse, will disproportionately hit the less well off who use cash more.

Originally the Link network consisted of small banks and building societies who found it in their interests to share cashpoint facilities. One solution would, therefore, be to go back to this; the small banks should leave Link and form their own network again. At least then the small players would have more chance of competing.

The banks do not have to pass these charges on to their customers. It is to be hoped that some of the members of Link will refuse to pass the charges on and that people will vote with their feet to use those banks/building societies. If this week's agreement dictates that members cannot do this, the government must legislate to ensure that they can.
HW Lean
Reading
Not satisfied that they already deny over 20% of the public access to a bank account and an even larger number access to local branch services, banks now want to further penalise those people who choose to use cash for their transactions.

Is their motive to make us a fully paid up plastic-only society? This move to extract more money from their customers, flying as it does in the face of the recent government's policy action team report on access to financial services, will serve to further marginalise those already at the limit of financial inclusion.

The government's stated wish is that all benefits should be paid directly into bank accounts. Picture then the pensioners who find that they lose some of their pen sion just by cashing it; or the person in a rural area who might have access to an ATM but cannot get to a branch of their own bank and so constantly has to pay this surcharge.
Alan Titcombe
Westbury, Wilts
adtitcombe@hotmail.com


Could these be the same banks who closed lots of branches - forcing one to use cash machines?

Thank god for all the regulators, ombudsmen and watchdogs, eh?
Kit Jackson
London
KitJack@compuserve.com


There is a very simple way for customers to fight back. We should boycott all cash machines and queue up in the banks to carry out all transactions over the counter.

After a few days of having business grind to a halt in all their banking halls, the banks would surely give in to people power and allow us the privilege of withdrawing our money without incurring any charges.
Michelle Jones
Cookham, Berks


Banks have long operated on the principle that you give them your money so that they can sell it back to you. Cash machines were introduced because they are cheaper for the bank than employing staff. Now they want us to pay for using them to gain access to our own money.

There are alternatives, including the "cash back" scheme operated by most supermarkets. The prospect of unused expensive cash machines might make a few banks see sense.
Jim Roberts
Beckenham, Kent
jimrob@compuserve.com

fields.headline: A hand in your pocket
fields.standfirst:
The greed of the banks must be checked

The issue explained: cash machine charges
fields.trailText: If there was a Bafta for cheek it would surely go the high street banks. Just a day before new competition laws, permitting fines of up to 30% of sales for discussing anything that reduces competition, came into effect yesterday, they solemnly negotiated among themselves charges of up to £2.50 for withdrawals from cash machines
fields.body:
If there was a Bafta for cheek it would surely go the high street banks. Just a day before new competition laws, permitting fines of up to 30% of sales for discussing anything that reduces competition, came into effect yesterday, they solemnly negotiated among themselves charges of up to £2.50 for withdrawals from cash machines. They agreed charges of up to £1 a time for ordinary withdrawals, plus a "disloyalty" fee of up to £1.50 when their own customers use other banks' automatic teller machines (ATMs). It is just as well that banks do not allow withdrawals of £1 or we could end up paying them more than we take out.

The whole thing is disgraceful and should be investigated by the office for fair trading forthwith. The banks are making very large profits, partly from the low interest they pay on customers' deposits and on the interest they do not pay on current account balances. Even if there is a case for charging, then it should be within the 15p to 30p range to cover the real costs suggested by Don Cruickshank, the treasury's special investigator who has been examining the banks. The surcharge will fall particularly heavily on poor people making small withdrawals, especially in rural areas where they might have to drive a long way to find their own bank's ATM.

The Link system, set up originally by the building societies, enabling customers of rival banks to use each other's machines was undoubtedly a cartel, but one in the public interest since it is clearly in everyone's interest to use the nearest machine. One option would be to hand the whole operation over to a new not-for-profit body operating as a common carrier. But that is unlikely to impress the hard-nosed banks. The only thing that would shift them, short of a successful investigation, would be for consumers to vote with wallets and purses and move their accounts en masse to banks that provide a cheap withdrawal service.

fields.headline: Gordon's modest squeeze
fields.body:
Anthony Giddens is wrong to call for tax cuts (A third way budget, February 29). Tax cuts will mean further job losses in manufacturing, because they will lead to rises in interest rates and an even higher pound. The chancellor has a modest fiscal squeeze in the pipeline, due to the end of mortgage tax relief this April. Tightening his stance a little will take the pressure off interest rates and stop the pound soaring to more unrealistic levels on foreign exchange markets.
John Edmonds
General secretary, GMB union
Labour's welfare policies have typically served two groups - the mass of the population (most people want good quality health care and education) and poorer minorities (benefits for unemployed people, lone parents, low-income pensioners and so on). Lower taxes benefit the better-off and will further increase the already widening gap between richer and poorer. Giddens' objective is to pay for better mass services. Does the third way involve abandoning the poorest and most vulnerable groups to gain the votes of middle England?
Peter Taylor-Gooby
University of Kent
P.F.Taylor-Gooby@ukc.ac.uk


Gordon Brown says there are jobs available for everyone who is unemployed (Brown tells jobless to fill vacancies, March 1). Would he like to advise those who have been made redundant and who are experienced and qualified but aged in their late forties and fifties exactly how they even get to the interview stage, thanks to the rampant ageism amongst most employers?
M Melville
Coventry

fields.headline: Heath's half-century
fields.standfirst:
At 83, he is one of the great survivors

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The Labour party was 100 years old at the weekend. The former Conservative prime minister Edward Heath was 50 this week. Fifty in the sense that it is now half a century since he was returned by the people of Bexley in the general election of February 23 1950, and 50 years yesterday since he first took his seat.
fields.body:
The Labour party was 100 years old at the weekend. The former Conservative prime minister Edward Heath was 50 this week. Fifty in the sense that it is now half a century since he was returned by the people of Bexley in the general election of February 23 1950, and 50 years yesterday since he first took his seat. There is a second anniversary, which understandably Sir Edward is not celebrating. It is 25 years since he lost the party leadership. There is no other case in the past hundred years of a party leader deposed but still around and active in the house a quarter of a century later.

All of which makes him very remarkable and even old political enemies, of which there are rather a lot in the Tory ranks, have been honouring him this week. Two achievements stand out: his victory, against all the odds, in the 1970 election, and his success where, given his long allegiance, it mattered most: in taking Britain into Europe in 1973. His premiership lasted less than four years. He was dumped by his party after losing two elections. Margaret Thatcher, propelled to victory on a tide of Tory opinion which said that things had to change, inspected her predecessor's legacy, got out her axe, and proceeded to hack it to bits. Edward Heath was logged, along with Macmillan and Labour, as an agent of soppy collectivism and economic depravity. That assault, compounded by his bitterness over his ousting, helped reduce him, in party terms, to the status of a non-person.

Yet compared with skipper Hague's floundering vessel, Ted Heath's Tory party was a successful ship. And, no doubt to his satisfaction, the origins of the party's present unseaworthy state are traceable to the successor he resents and mistrusts. The feuding which wracks it is not just about Europe; it is also about the Thatcherite legacy and the imputed treason of those who seek to erase it. The result is today's wrangling and unworkable coalition, mingling unrepentant Thatcherites with realists who accept that the show is over. Sir Edward was right to say as he celebrated his anniversary that the Tories cannot win next time unless they woo back the middle ground voters they now seem to spurn. Right, but irrelevant. For how can they woo such people back without forfeiting the support of that core of the party which still seems to believe that Margaret - like King Arthur or Charlemagne - will one day awake from her sleep and bring the glory days back again?

fields.trailText: So Irn-Bru is seeking to conquer new markets beyond its native Scotland (Irn-Bru to take on Coke, February 28) . This presents a problem to those of us who seek to sniff out spurious Scots by quizzing them on their knowledge of the ambrosial liqour. At least there remain two other key questions that separate wannabe Caledonians from the genuine article: "Who are the Jags?"; and "Who lives at 10 Glebe Street?" Correct answers are sure indicators of genuine Scottishness.

webTitle: Norway solves riddle of Mossad killing

fields.headline: Norway solves riddle of Mossad killing
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israel's intelligence service, Mossad, acted without Norwegian help in a botched 1973 assassination in the ski resort of Lillehammer, a national commission concluded yesterday.
fields.body:
Israel's intelligence service, Mossad, acted without Norwegian help in a botched 1973 assassination in the ski resort of Lillehammer, a national commission concluded yesterday.

Norwegians have long speculated about involvement by their own police or intelligence service in the killing, which has been shrouded in secrecy for 27 years, and which has been a sore point in otherwise warm relations between Norway and Israel.

On July 21 1973, a team of Israeli hitmen shot dead a Moroccan waiter, Ahmed Bouchikhi, as he walked home from the cinema with his pregnant wife in the resort, 110 miles north of Oslo.

The assassins apparently mistook Bouchikhi for Hassan Salameh, a PLO intelligence chief suspected of masterminding the killing of 11 Israeli athletes at the 1972 Munich Olympics.

"This was much more than a murder," said Gullow Gjeseth, head of the six-member government commission. "This was a violation of Norwegian sovereignty. It is a completely special case."

The commission's 179-page report said that its two-year investigation, which included reviews of previously classified material and interviews, found no evidence of Norwegian involvement.

"Even the court sentence - the sentence itself - was classified as secret until this commission got it declassified," said Mr Gjeseth, a retired Norwegian general. "A lot of the speculation came about because of this secrecy."

Mr Gjeseth said Israel would say nothing except "there was no Norwegian involvement. Period".

In January 1996, Israel paid undisclosed compensation to Bouchikhi's family but did not admit responsibility for the killing.

"No one pays out compensation unless they are guilty," Torill Larsen Bouchiki, widow of the murdered waiter, said yesterday.

Five suspected agents - Marianne Gladinkoff, who was born in Sweden; Sylvia Rafael, of South Africa; Israeli Abraham Gehmer; Dan Aerbel, who was born in Denmark; and Brazilian-born Zvi Steinberg - were convicted and jailed in Norway for the killing shortly after it took place. They were later pardoned.

According to the report, about nine others escaped from Norway, including the suspected leader, Michael Harari, a senior Mossad agent who has now retired. The commission said Norway did little to catch the suspects in the early 1970s.

"Norwegian authorities were clearly under pressure. The Israeli side presented wishes that links to other countries not be followed up," said the report.

Norway reopened the case in 1990. In 1998, it issued a global warrant for Mr Harari but closed the case the next year saying it would be impossible to get a conviction. AP

webTitle: Men with a mission: no women

fields.headline: Men with a mission: no women
fields.standfirst:
Lesley Abdela was thrown out of Kosovo by international bunglers, for promoting the feminist cause
Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Last August I was asked by the foreign office to leave at short notice for Kosovo. Six days later, after a brief induction course in Vienna, I arrived in Pristina as deputy director for democracy at the Organisation for Security & Co-operation in Europe (OSCE).
fields.body:
Last August I was asked by the foreign office to leave at short notice for Kosovo. Six days later, after a brief induction course in Vienna, I arrived in Pristina as deputy director for democracy at the Organisation for Security & Co-operation in Europe (OSCE).

In the first bloom of peace after the Nato bombardment, I was really pleased to be in at the reconstruction of Kosovo. Ethnic Albanian Kosovans smiled when they recognised my UN/OSCE identification tag. They still saw the international community as a liberating force. People sat at pavement tables in cafes in the warm sunshine, looking forward to a brighter future.

But while Kosovans were able to leap from exile into rebuilding homes and shops, the UN from the start became ominously mired in bureaucratic tangles. Although a local cafe quickly opened with internet access on 10 computers, round the corner at the OSCE HQ we managed to get one computer to cope for email access for 700 staff, and virtually no phones. As the international community failed to produce tangible results, the Kosovan population began to feel impeded rather than liberated.

A Kosovan NGO leader summed up the mood: "You 'internationals' are polluting our air and clogging up our roads with all your white vehicles," she said. "You refuse to employ us as professionals in your organisations. There are thousands of you. You all make promises but we neither see action nor do you provide us with funds to get on with things ourselves."

Albanian Kosovans are energetic and self-starters. For a decade under Serb hegemony they organised their own alternative society beneath Belgrade's ethnic and religious apartheid system. They ran more than 500 schools and paid a voluntary 3% tax. The educated and professionals, by contrast with Bosnia, returned to Kosovo.

Within days of my arrival I noted that with one exception, all senior posts in the OSCE mission and the UN mission in Kosovo (Unmik) were held by men. Unmik and the OSCE were deeply imbued with a "dolly-bird" culture, a sure sign of corporate early-onset sclerosis and entrenched behaviour. Exclusion of women from the democratisation process was highlighted by the fact that Dr Bernard Kouchner, special representative of the UN secretary general in Kosovo, had appointed not one woman to the Kosovan transitional governing council, even though the UN global platform for action states that at least one third of all decision-making positions in politics and public life should be filled by women.

Deeply ignorant of the majority gender, the OSCE regularly discussed what percentage of Serbs and ethnic groups should be represented on judicial, political and public bodies, but not the role of women. When I pointed out this discrepancy I was told women in leadership posts would be "alien to local culture and tradition" and, in any case, "no women in Kosovo are interested in participation in politics or public life."

Women comprise more than 50% of Kosovans, not least because so many of their men were murdered. They not only took the brunt of the ethnic cleansing, many served with the Kosovan liberation army.

Luleta Pula, leader of a social democratic party, told me that in 1990 she had headed a 60,000 strong women's wing of the LDK political party. From the Russian revolution to decolonisation days, from Togo to the India of the Raj, women have been instrumental in the fight to defend freedoms and rights.

Kosovan women's NGOs were especially angry at being entirely ignored in the democratisation process. I was told by a leader of Motat Qiriazi, an umbrella of four rural women's networks, "The international community has marginalised us women in a way we never had been before. We have never felt so pushed aside as we feel now."

Prompted by the frustrations of the Kosovan women, a UN colleague and I faxed UN secretary general Kofi Annan to ask him to intervene. As a direct consequence, three Kosovan women NGO leaders were invited to meet with Kofi Annan and Bernard Kouchner. Unmik agreed to hold regular consultations with women NGO leaders. One woman was subsequently invited to join the interim transitional council.

But there was also, to me, an unexpected result. Just as I was getting into my stride in helping to build civil society - yes, including women's campaign groups - the fax to Kofi Annan was to be used by the OSCE head of mission to rid his boys of my turbulent presence. I was "uncollegiate" (yes, women do indeed do things differently) and "too zealous" in advancing the needs and roles of Kosovan women.

The fax was considered a "major breach of protocol" by senior males. It had embarrassed the hierarchs of the OSCE in Kosovo. It was given as a main reason for my being told to leave the mission a few weeks later.

By mid-December Unmik had squandered the honeymoon period. A sinister atmosphere of incipient thuggery and danger was developing fast. Today Serbs and Roma have either been terrorised into fleeing the province or hide, frightened, in their homes. The crime rate has increased dramatically, night by night. Law and order have broken down. Tales of intimidation and shoot-outs between rival criminal gangs are part of everyday life. Barely nine months after Milosevic capitulated, the Kosovo to which I was sent out with such high hopes, has become a scene of the utmost horror. And as for the position of women: they are now regularly kidnapped - an estimated five women a week in Pristina alone. And by November women no longer went out after dark. They were too afraid.

Kosovo was and is hardly a little matter of a far-away people of no interest to Britain. The first shot was a missile fired from a British submarine. Tony Blair put much of his leadership credibility behind the bombing, to the extent the new German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder only half-jokingly dubbed him "the young god of war".

Kosovo was an unusually complex situation not typical of most post-conflict situations, in that Nato had acted outside the customary UN collectivist approach, primarily to avoid a Russian veto. This may well have hampered planning efforts by Unmik. It was bogged down in a nightmare of bureaucratic entanglement, miscasting of characters and the wrong design of organisation taking on the job. But from that point on they dug their own (and many a Kosovan's) grave.

Deeply ignorant of the majority gender, the OSCE regularly discussed what percentage of Serbs and ethnic groups should be represented on judicial, political and public bodies, but not the role of women. When I pointed out this discrepancy I was told women in leadership posts would be "alien to local culture and tradition" and, in any case, "no women in Kosovo are interested in participation in politics or public life." Women comprise more than 50% of Kosovans, not least because so many of their men were murdered. They not only took the brunt of the ethnic cleansing, many served with the Kosovan liberation army. Luleta Pula, leader of a social democratic party, told me that in 1990 she had headed a 60,000 strong women's wing of the LDK political party. From the Russian revolution to decolonisation days, from Togo to the India of the Raj, women have been instrumental in the fight to defend freedoms and rights. Kosovan women's NGOs were especially angry at being entirely ignored in the democratisation process. I was told by a leader of Motat Qiriazi, an umbrella of four rural women's networks, "The international community has marginalised us women in a way we never had been before. We have never felt so pushed aside as we feel now." Prompted by the frustrations of the Kosovan women, a UN colleague and I faxed UN secretary general Kofi Annan to ask him to intervene. As a direct consequence, three Kosovan women NGO leaders were invited to meet with Kofi Annan and Bernard Kouchner. Unmik agreed to hold regular consultations with women NGO leaders. One woman was subsequently invited to join the interim transitional council. But there was also, to me, an unexpected result. Just as I was getting into my stride in helping to build civil society - yes, including women's campaign groups - the fax to Kofi Annan was to be used by the OSCE head of mission to rid his boys of my turbulent presence. I was "uncollegiate" (yes, women do indeed do things differently) and "too zealous" in advancing the needs and roles of Kosovan women. The fax was considered a "major breach of protocol" by senior males. It had embarrassed the hierarchs of the OSCE in Kosovo. It was given as a main reason for my being told to leave the mission a few weeks later. By mid-December Unmik had squandered the honeymoon period. A sinister atmosphere of incipient thuggery and danger was developing fast. Today Serbs and Roma have either been terrorised into fleeing the province or hide, frightened, in their homes. The crime rate has increased dramatically, night by night. Law and order have broken down. Tales of intimidation and shoot-outs between rival criminal gangs are part of everyday life. Barely nine months after Milosevic capitulated, the Kosovo to which I was sent out with such high hopes, has become a scene of the utmost horror. And as for the position of women: they are now regularly kidnapped - an estimated five women a week in Pristina alone. And by November women no longer went out after dark. They were too afraid. Kosovo was and is hardly a little matter of a far-away people of no interest to Britain. The first shot was a missile fired from a British submarine. Tony Blair put much of his leadership credibility behind the bombing, to the extent the new German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder only half-jokingly dubbed him "the young god of war". Kosovo was an unusually complex situation not typical of most post-conflict situations, in that Nato had acted outside the customary UN collectivist approach, primarily to avoid a Russian veto. This may well have hampered planning efforts by Unmik. It was bogged down in a nightmare of bureaucratic entanglement, miscasting of characters and the wrong design of organisation taking on the job. But from that point on they dug their own (and many a Kosovan's) grave.

webTitle: Barak loses vote on Syria peace talks

fields.headline: Barak loses vote on Syria peace talks
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, yesterday saw his hands potentially bound in future peace negotiations with Syria, and in managing his own coalition, after he lost a crucial vote in parliament.
fields.body:
The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, yesterday saw his hands potentially bound in future peace negotiations with Syria, and in managing his own coalition, after he lost a crucial vote in parliament.

In a vote of 60 to 53, with one abstention, the Knesset gave preliminary approval to a private member's bill from the opposition Likud party which would make it far more difficult for Mr Barak to win his promised referendum on a future peace deal with Syria.

The bill would require Mr Barak to win the support of more than 50% of Israeli voters, including the 10% who live outside the country, rather than a simple majority of those who cast their votes in a referendum on Israeli withdrawal from the occupied Golan heights.

Although the measure must undergo three more readings to become law, and could disappear into committee for a further six months, it is a humbling moment for Mr Barak. The defection of his coalition's rightwing religious partners, who voted with the Likud during this the government's first serious crisis, also raises questions about the viability of the coalition.

The repercussions from yesterday's vote may spread outside the country, deepening the concerns of the Syrian president, Hafez al-Assad, that Mr Barak may not be capable of marshalling enough support to make peace.

Syrian doubts about Israel's desire for peace rose sharply last week after Israel's foreign minister, David Levy, vowed to retaliate "blood for blood, soul for soul, child for child" against Hizbullah for firing across the border from Lebanon.

However, Mr Barak said he would bounce back from the vote, and that his coalition was as stable as ever.

"I don't take what happened in the Knesset lightly, but neither should too much be read into it; 1.8m Israeli citizens have charged me with a mission, and no parliamentary ploy can prevent the majority of the nation from expressing its opinion and determining what will happen," he told Israel Radio.

"Any agreement [with Syria], if reached, will be brought up for referendum in such a way as to ensure that the majority of those who participate in the referendum will determine the future of the state," he said.

Other members of his government denounced the measure as racist for seeking to undercut the influence of Palestinian voters on Israel's electoral list. They are widely presumed to vote for an exchange of territory for peace and to have propelled Mr Barak to victory in last May's elections.

"It's a mark of Cain on a democratic society and it is a harsh signal to President Assad," said the MP Ahmad Tibi.

There is also belief that the bill represents a serious blow to Mr Barak's prestige and will significantly reduce his room to manoeuvre if or when negotiations with Syria - suspended in January - resume. The urgency of reaching an agreement was further underscored yesterday when a bomb planted by Hizbullah in Lebanon killed five pro-Israeli militia men and a Lebanese civilian.

Although the immediate topic of yesterday's stormy debate was a peace deal with Syria, the causes of Mr Barak's defeat lie within Israel, in the clashes between the dovish members of his coalition and the religious right.

Yesterday's defections represented a show of anger from religious parties, which have been blocked from gaining further influence over religious schooling and have had several clashes with the secular education minister.

Some commentators said the defeat exposed Mr Barak's relative political inexperience in putting together so disparate a coalition. They feel the vote could destabilise his government, which would set back both the Syrian and Palestinian peace processes.

"Barak actually formed a very awkward kind of coalition. He could have formed a narrow coalition [and] promoted all kinds of policy directions far more easily," said Abraham Diskin, a political scientist at Jerusalem's Hebrew university.

"Now the time has come when you cannot hide any kind of disagreement within the coalition under the carpet."

fields.headline: Elf bribery scandal claims Dumas
fields.standfirst: As France's former foreign minister resigns from key post, the spreading sleaze investigation threatens to tar a cultural and political elite
fields.trailText: A Gallic corruption scandal of staggering proportions yesterday claimed the highly placed scalp of Roland Dumas, the former foreign minister and intimate of the late Socialist president François Mitterrand when Mr Dumas confirmed his resignation as the country's top legal authority.
fields.body:
A Gallic corruption scandal of staggering proportions yesterday claimed the highly placed scalp of Roland Dumas, the former foreign minister and intimate of the late Socialist president François Mitterrand when Mr Dumas confirmed his resignation as the country's top legal authority.

Mr Duma, France's fifth-highest ranking official, is awaiting trial for allegedly accepting some of the £250m that the oil giant Elf Aquitane is thought to have spent in the early 1990s to further its own interests and those of the late president.

The long-awaited announcement from Mitterrand's confidant came as public prosecutors promised to start investigating Edith Cresson, France's first woman prime minister, in the same affair.

Slowly but surely, Elf's slick of sleaze is beginning to spread to the upper reaches of French political life. And as frantically as they may paddle to escape it, some of the most important members of the late president's entourage will not, this time, avoid being tarred.

Mr Dumas, 76, has been a member of France's political and cultural elite for four decades. He was twice foreign minister during Mitterrand's 14-year presidency and, as a lawyer in private practice, held briefs for renowned artists such as Matisse and Giacometti. He was the executor of Picasso's will, and played a role in returning his masterpiece Guernica to Spain.

Mr Dumas, dubbed by one French paper as "the prince of intrigue in Mitterrand's palace", will stand trial this autumn for complicity in the misuse of Elf funds. He is alleged first to have persuaded Elf to employ his then mistress, Christine Deviers-Joncour, a former lingerie model who has written three bitter if entertaining kiss-and-tell books about her experiences, one entitled Whore of the Republic.

Once installed at the then state-owned multinational, Ms Deviers-Joncour has admitted, she received some £6.6m from Elf to lobby her lover to approve the controversial 1991 sale of six frigates to Taiwan by another state-controlled firm, Thompson. Elf had allegedly promised Thompson, in exchange for a slice of the profits, to use its influence to help push through the sale, which was strongly opposed by China and initially by Mr Dumas himself - until he suddenly changed his mind.

To help her in her task, Elf allegedly furnished Ms Deviers-Joncour with a monthly £20,000 company credit line and a £1.7m Left Bank flat.

Mr Dumas, who used the rue de Lille apartment to host lavish operatic soirées for le tout Paris, has been unable to explain several million stray francs that found their way into his bank account. But he has denied any wrong-doing, saying he was unaware where the money - or the gifts - came from. The prosecutor's case against him is that this cannot possibly be true.

In the six years that they have been investigating the Elf scandal, the magistrates Eva Joly and Laurence Vichnievsky have placed more than 20 people under investigation. Among those also accused or suspected of benefiting from Elf's generosity are the company's former boss, Mitterrand's golf partner, a former Gaullist interior minister and a well-known woman novelist. The defence of Elf's embattled ex-president, Loik Le Floch Prigent, has always been that he acted according to a deal worked out with Mitterrand.

"I'm being made a scapegoat," he said last year. "It's easier to crush me than to investigate the role of France itself, which benefited enormously from this subtle game of shadows and light, which I inherited but did not start or gain from."

That does not quite explain how he could increase his company credit card debit by £6,800, spent on CDs in a single afternoon. Nor does it explain how Laurent Raillard, Mitterrand's doctor and twice-weekly golf partner, came to benefit from an Elf salary of £5,000 a month.

Meanwhile, investigators are expected to turn soon to the case of the former Gaullist interior minister Charles Pasqua, who allegedly travelled free on Elf's private jets under the codename "Fernandel" and whose senior advisers were apparently on the company's payroll.

They are already looking into Françoise Sagan, the author of Bonjour Tristesse, who allegedly received £900,000 from an Elf go-between known as "Dédé the Sardine" in exchange for persuading the president to intervene on a contract in Uzbekistan.

The alleged chief fixer and bagman for most of the missing millions, Elf's former corporate affairs director Alfred Sirven, has been on the run for the past three years. The subject of an international arrest warrant, he is thought to be hiding in a suburb of the Philippines' capital Manila.

As the investigating magistrates' net spreads, more senior figures from the Mitterrand era are finding themselves trapped. Mitterrand, who died in 1996, was himself implicated last month following so far unproven allegations that he ordered £10m of Elf's cash to be slid into his friend Helmut Kohl's 1994 re-election campaign.

Above all, it is the dark shadow of Mitterrand that floats over this entire tangled affair. If nothing else, Mr Dumas's trial will hammer a final nail into the coffin of what remains of the marred reputation of France's first Socialist president.

fields.headline: National Roundup
fields.trailText: Boy, 9, shot by girl with air pistol
fields.body:
Boy, 9, shot by girl with air pistol

A girl aged 10 shot a boy of nine in the leg with an air pistol outside their West Sussex school last month. Details of the incident emerged after the killing of the American schoolgirl Kayla Rolland by a six-year-old classmate.

In the British incident the girl shot the boy as children left Northgate middle school in Crawley to go home on February 9. She has been permanently excluded from the school. The boy was treated in hospital for two days for a wound in his left thigh.

West Sussex council said security at all its schools had been stepped up, with teachers asked to be extra vigilant as they await the results of the police investigation.

Spokeswoman Jane Robinson said: "We are not going to be searching children's bags. You cannot have a prison-like regime in a school." Parents had been assured that the school was "a safe environment. The headmistress has written to reassure them that the incident was very rare."

The mother of another pupil said: "Some serious questions need to be asked. It is very worrying that such a young child was able to get her hands on a lethal weapon."

Julia Hartley-Brewer

£115,000 payout for diver

A deep-sea diver who broke his back in an accident hundreds of feet under the North Sea has received £115,000 in an out-of-court settlement, it was revealed yesterday.

Andrew Binney, 46, fractured his back in two places after a crane on a support ship lowered a metal lifting frame on top of him while he was working off the coast of Denmark. He returned to work six-months after the accident in 1992 but two years later doctors declared him medically unfit to continue. He took out a civil action against his former employer, Aberdeen-based Rockwater, claiming £300,000 in lost earnings.

The company argued that the accident was Mr Binney's fault because he had breached safety procedures by working underneath the lifting frame.

But Mr Binney, of Crookes, Sheffield, claimed the company was to blame because his supervisor failed to check whether he was under the frame before passing on his request to lower the crane.

The £115,000 settlement was agreed out of court yesterday, halting proceedings in Sheffield high court and ending an eight-year legal fight.

The court was told the settlement meant the blame was split between the company and Mr Binney.

After leaving his job Mr Binney, who has a partner and two children, was forced to sell his £200,000 detached home to make ends meet. "I'm not saying we are on the streets but our lives have changed because of this accident. What I have been given is the equivalent of a year's salary."

He now works part-time for Sainsbury's Homebase.

A Rockwater spokesman said that the company had no comment to make.

Composer's 'incredulity' at diary libel

A composer yesterday told the high court that he could not believe his eyes when he read in the Times diary that he had gone about "wrecking" performances by other artists.

Simon Burstein is seeking damages for what he calls a "straightforward lie". He told the jury: "I just couldn't believe it. I just looked at [the diary story] in disbelief, and then was shocked and dismayed. I thought, 'if people believe what they have said, then I have lost my personal and professional credibility'."

The item, in 1997, referred to a forthcoming memorial concert. It said: "The music is by Keith Burstein, an aggressively self-righteous, rather slushy composer who used to organise bands of hecklers to go about wrecking performances of modern atonal music, particularly anything by Sir Harrison Birtwistle."

The judge, Richard Walker, has ruled as a matter of law that the words are libellous, and the jury is being asked to decide the scale of damages, which Mr Burstein's solicitor advocate said should be between £20,000 and £50,000.

In the witness box Mr Burstein admitted that he did once "voice disapproval" at a performance of Sir Harrison Birtwistle's work, and had "heckled and booed" at the end of the concert at Covent Garden in 1994. He said it was "perfectly acceptable to voice pleasure or disapproval". However, he had not organised bands of hecklers to wreck performances.

Justin Rushbrooke, for the Times, said: "We say libel it is, but it's a very, very long way from being a grave libel ... We say that he has taken offence at the piece as a whole; as far as this wrecking allegation goes, he's blown it up out of proportion."

The judge is to sum up today before the jury retires. [Audrey Gillan]

Coup for sanctions protesters

Campaigners against sanctions imposed on Iraq after the 1991 Gulf war last night secured their biggest coup yet when one of the two RAF crew captured during the war agreed to join them on a flight to Baghdad later this month carrying medicines. John Nicol will urge an end to sanctions, the organisers said.

It is the first flight from London to Baghdad since the Gulf war and will carry several tons of medicines. The Labour MP George Galloway, one of the most outspoken critics of the sanctions, and Mr Nichol will be the first off the plane when it lands in Baghdad. [Ewen MacAskill]

Gene hope for victims of haemophilia

American scientists claim today to have successfully delivered gene therapy to people with the inherited bleeding disorder haemophilia.

Haemophilia B affects one male in 30,000 worldwide, and severe cases usually need frequent treatment with a clotting factor to protect their joints and prevent internal bleeding that can lead to death.

The scientists report in the magazine Nature Genetics that they altered a human adenovirus to carry the genetic instructions to make a blood-clotting protein, factor IX, and injected three adult sufferers. After 100 days, two required significantly less of the infused clotting factor to keep their disease at bay, none showed any adverse effects, and all three showed evidence the gene had transferred to the patient's muscle cells.

"This exciting new treatment offers the possibility of converting severe haemophilia B to a milder form through a relatively non-invasive procedure," said Katharine High, of the children's hospital of Philadelphia, who led the study.

Gene therapy has been proposed as the ideal treatment for up to 4,000 diseases based on single gene defects. Attempts to treat inherited disorders began 10 years ago, but were disappointing and caused alarm in the US at the deaths in such experiments.

"We are at the beginning," said Dr High, "but our results strengthen the possibility that gene therapy may help patients with other diseases." [Tim Radford]

Woman sues over drill in foot

A grandmother is suing a London hospital after discovering part of a drill in her foot.

Greta Buckle was checking her x-rays after doctors at the Central Middlesex hospital had operated on osteoarthritis in her foot and discovered that part of their drilling equipment had been left in a toe bone.

Mrs Buckle, 48, of Harlesden, north London, took the x-ray back to her consultant.

The centimetre-long section of drill, used in an operation to fuse bones affected by osteoarthritis, is thought to have snapped off and been left in the bone. Mrs Buckle said she had suffered pain and swelling which had forced her to leave her job as a care assistant and wrecked her social life.

A spokesman for the Central Middlesex said: "Drills are very brittle and these things do happen from time to time, but as soon as this was discovered we took the appropriate action and referred the patient to a specialist."

Mrs Buckle's lawyer, Kurit Kshual, said: "Our client deserves compensation for what is clearly a case of medical negligence." [Martin Wainwright]

[Audrey Gillan] Coup for sanctions protesters Campaigners against sanctions imposed on Iraq after the 1991 Gulf war last night secured their biggest coup yet when one of the two RAF crew captured during the war agreed to join them on a flight to Baghdad later this month carrying medicines. John Nicol will urge an end to sanctions, the organisers said. It is the first flight from London to Baghdad since the Gulf war and will carry several tons of medicines. The Labour MP George Galloway, one of the most outspoken critics of the sanctions, and Mr Nichol will be the first off the plane when it lands in Baghdad. [Ewen MacAskill] Gene hope for victims of haemophilia American scientists claim today to have successfully delivered gene therapy to people with the inherited bleeding disorder haemophilia. Haemophilia B affects one male in 30,000 worldwide, and severe cases usually need frequent treatment with a clotting factor to protect their joints and prevent internal bleeding that can lead to death. The scientists report in the magazine Nature Genetics that they altered a human adenovirus to carry the genetic instructions to make a blood-clotting protein, factor IX, and injected three adult sufferers. After 100 days, two required significantly less of the infused clotting factor to keep their disease at bay, none showed any adverse effects, and all three showed evidence the gene had transferred to the patient's muscle cells. "This exciting new treatment offers the possibility of converting severe haemophilia B to a milder form through a relatively non-invasive procedure," said Katharine High, of the children's hospital of Philadelphia, who led the study. Gene therapy has been proposed as the ideal treatment for up to 4,000 diseases based on single gene defects. Attempts to treat inherited disorders began 10 years ago, but were disappointing and caused alarm in the US at the deaths in such experiments. "We are at the beginning," said Dr High, "but our results strengthen the possibility that gene therapy may help patients with other diseases." [Tim Radford] Woman sues over drill in foot A grandmother is suing a London hospital after discovering part of a drill in her foot. Greta Buckle was checking her x-rays after doctors at the Central Middlesex hospital had operated on osteoarthritis in her foot and discovered that part of their drilling equipment had been left in a toe bone. Mrs Buckle, 48, of Harlesden, north London, took the x-ray back to her consultant. The centimetre-long section of drill, used in an operation to fuse bones affected by osteoarthritis, is thought to have snapped off and been left in the bone. Mrs Buckle said she had suffered pain and swelling which had forced her to leave her job as a care assistant and wrecked her social life. A spokesman for the Central Middlesex said: "Drills are very brittle and these things do happen from time to time, but as soon as this was discovered we took the appropriate action and referred the patient to a specialist." Mrs Buckle's lawyer, Kurit Kshual, said: "Our client deserves compensation for what is clearly a case of medical negligence." [Martin Wainwright]

webTitle: Veteran producer reveals plan for 'modest' musical

fields.headline: Veteran producer reveals plan for 'modest' musical
fields.trailText: After 30 years in show business, Sir Cameron Mackintosh disclosed yesterday that he is on the point of achieving one of his life's ambitions: to stage a modest little song and dance show.
fields.body:
After 30 years in show business, Sir Cameron Mackintosh disclosed yesterday that he is on the point of achieving one of his life's ambitions: to stage a modest little song and dance show.

"A proper musical comedy, it's what I've always wanted to do," said the producer of Cats, Les Miserables and the Phantom of the Opera.

He is mounting a £4.5m production of the Witches of Eastwick, based on John Updike's novel, and the film starring Jack Nicholson. It will open in July in the Drury Lane theatre, London.

"The Lion King on Broadway cost, what, $25m? The Witches is costing a million more than Miss Saigon, but that was 11 years ago. It's spectacularly modest."

The show has the entire cast flying through the air before the first act curtain, and ends with a church collapsing on stage while the devil flies out through a smashed stained glass window.

Following in Jack Nicholson's cloven hoof will be Ian McShane, best known as the rogue antique dealer Lovejoy, who has never starred in a musical.

"They used to be very nice about my singing at RADA," he said. "But I always thought that meant they were telling me to give up the acting."

Miss Saigon closed last year at the Drury Lane theatre after 4,263 performances, making it the fourth Mackintosh production to run for more than 10 years. The cast of the Witches is committed to at least a one-year run.

The origins of this show lie in a rare Mackintosh failure: The Fix, a musical comedy about American presidential spin doctoring, which was an off-Broadway hit when it opened in the wake of the Lewinsky scandal and was imported to the Donmar Warehouse in London.

fields.headline: 'Mock cannabis' found to ease MS
fields.trailText: Scientists have proved that cannabis-like drugs can alleviate some of the worst symptoms of the progressive disease multiple sclerosis, possibly bringing hope to the 85,000 or so sufferers in Britain.
fields.body:
Scientists have proved that cannabis-like drugs can alleviate some of the worst symptoms of the progressive disease multiple sclerosis, possibly bringing hope to the 85,000 or so sufferers in Britain.

There have been claims for decades that cannabis could help MS patients with spasticity and tremors. But scientists from London, Aberdeen and South Carolina report in Nature Today that they have direct proof that a cannabinoid compound used on mice with a multiple sclerosis-like condition helped ameliorate symptoms within minutes.

"Although not a cure," said David Baker, of the institute of neurology at University College, London, "our research suggests that cannabinoids can play a crucial role in controlling some of the neuromuscular problems seen with MS."

Lorna Layward of the Multiple Sclerosis Society said: "The study provides a firm basis for the human trials of cannabis in MS that will commence shortly."

Cannabis was used medically for thousands of years. The Greeks knew of it. Queen Victoria is believed to have been prescribed it. Until 1971 doctors in Britain were able to prescribe it for patients. The drug has been said to help quell nausea during cancer chemotherapy and relieve the pressure in the eye in glaucoma.

But because cannabis is a scheduled drug, and a herb that comes in varying strengths, serious analysis of its value has been difficult.

The London team - backed by pharmacologists in Aberdeen and South Carolina, and a government-funded medical research council group - chose to work not with the drug itself but with cannabis-like chemicals.

"We have naturally-occurring cannabis receptors in our body," said Dr Layward.

"We used compounds that stimulate the receptors. Whether these are safe and acceptable remains to be seen."

fields.headline: Chemists fined over deadly medicine
fields.trailText: Two Boots pharmacists who dispensed a peppermint solution which killed a four-day-old baby were fined yesterday after they admitted supplying defective medicine.
fields.body:
Two Boots pharmacists who dispensed a peppermint solution which killed a four-day-old baby were fined yesterday after they admitted supplying defective medicine.

The medicine given to Matthew Young, from Runcorn, Cheshire, contained 20 times too much chloroform. He suffered a heart attack and brain damage, and died in hospital 18 days later.

At Chester crown court yesterday a verdict of not guilty to manslaughter was ordered against pharmacist Lisa Taylor-Lloyd, 27, and Ziad Kattab, 25, a trainee pharmacist, who were fined £1,000 and £750 respectively after they admitted supplying the solution.

The preparation was made up at Boots in Runcorn by Kattab in April 1998. Matthew became ill and had a cardiac arrest after he had a few drops of the solution.

A postmortem examination concluded that he died of cardio-respiratory arrest after inhaling chloroform. Mr Justice Forbes said it was an extremely sad and tragic case which should never have happened.

"He died as a result of ingesting what should have been a harmless mixture intended to deal with nothing more than colicky wind," said the judge.

He said Kattab and Taylor-Lloyd were not criminally responsible for his death. "Instead of a bonny healthy baby, the parents had visited upon them the appalling tragedy of premature death."

It emerged during the hearing that Taylor-Lloyd was not qualified to supervise Kattab. But she asked him to mix the medicine as she thought it would be good experience.

Peter Hughes QC, prosecuting, said: "The fundamental mistake for Kattab was to confuse chloroform water in its dilute double-strength form with concentrated chloroform water - which is a solution 20 times stronger." He said the bottle of chloroform used by Kattab had no dilution instructions on it.

In police interviews Kattab, from Eccles, Greater Manchester, admitted he could not make head nor tail of the formula for making up the peppermint preparation. When he had prepared the same medicine on two previous occasions at different pharmacists he had always asked someone to check his work. Pauline Meredith, a dispenser at the pharmacy, had explained it to him.

Mr Hughes said it was significant that there was a difference in the supervision of pharmacists in hospitals and within the community. "In hospital pharmacies it was standard practice for all work on extemporaneous preparations to be properly verified and checked independently," he said.

But within community pharmacies this practice varied considerably. "One consequence of Matthew's sad and tragic death was the Royal Pharmaceutical Society has issued a warning to all pharmacists of the need to check work on its extemporaneous preparations."

He said Taylor-Lloyd had not checked the preparation before it was handed to Collette Jackson, Matthew's mother.

In mitigation for Kattab, Richard Ferguson QC said the seeds of the tragedy were due to the misunderstanding between Kattab and Pauline Meredith.

He described Kattab as a good and competent pharmacist who had stopped working in August 1998 due to a loss of confidence and had not worked since. He had suffered depression and the effects of the tragedy on him had been very severe.

Brian Leveson QC, for Taylor-Lloyd, said she recognised the devastation caused to the baby's family. He said she was a competent pharmacist of exemplary character.
