fields.headline: Mendes debut earns 14 Bafta nominations
fields.trailText: American Beauty, the first film by British director Sam Mendes, won 14 nominations for the British Academy film awards yesterday, to add to the eight Oscar nominations it was given three weeks ago.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
American Beauty, the first film by British director Sam Mendes, won 14 nominations for the British Academy film awards yesterday, to add to the eight Oscar nominations it was given three weeks ago.

Mendes, a London theatre director who has made the transition to Hollywood golden boy, is just short of last year's record 16 nominations for Shakespeare in Love, but his film is in contention for best film, best director and best cinematography, as well as acting, design and music awards.

There was consolation for the wounded pride of director Neil Jordan and his team on The End of the Affair. His adaptation of Graham Greene's novel has 10 Bafta nominations, after being hotly tipped for but then left off the Oscar list.

Whatever the Bafta judges' verdicts, the awards will be dominated this year by British directors and actors: only one of the five nominations for film of 1999 is American, the science fiction The Sixth Sense.

Anthony Minghella's film of Patricia Highsmith's thriller, The Talented Mr Ripley, has four nominations, and the three British directors have also been nominated for the David Lean director award.

The fourth British contender for best film title is the surprise British box office hit East is East, a comparatively low budget comedy .

Ralph Fiennes is nominated for best actor in The End of the Affair, against Jim Broadbent, who played WS Gilbert in Mike Leigh's Topsy-Turvy, and Om Puri for East is East. American actors Kevin Spacey, in American Beauty, and Russell Crowe, in The Insider, have also been nominated.

The same films dominate the best actress list: Linda Bassett for East is East; Julianne Moore for The End of the Affair; Annette Bening for American Beauty; and Emily Watson for Angela's Ashes - which had been eagerly anticipated but was not well received by the critics, and has done poorly in both Oscar and Bafta nominations.

Actor Rhys Ifans continues the inexorable rise to stardom based on his revolting underpants in Notting Hill, which have won him a best supporting actor nomination. He is in competition with Wes Bentley, for American Beauty, Michael Caine, for Cider House Rules, Jude Law, for the Talented Mr Ripley, and Timothy Spall, for Topsy-Turvy.

Nominees for most promising newcomer in a British film are Justin Kerrigan, writer and director of Human Traffic, Ayub Khan Bin, writer of East is East, Kirk Jones, writer and director of Waking Ned, and Lynne Ramsay, writer and director of Ratcatcher.

The awards will be presented at the Odeon cinema in Leicester Square, London, on April 9, and covered live on Sky TV, co-sponsors of the awards with Orange. However Bafta said there would also be a later broadcast on ITV.

Audiences will have the last word on one award, and can vote for their choice from the top 10 box office hits - which range from A Bug's Life to The Spy Who Shagged Me - through coupons in newspapers and in the Radio Times, in person at Blockbuster video and Orange shops, or online through www.orange.co.uk.

Best film

American Beauty, East is East, The End of the Affair, The Sixth Sense, The Talented Mr Ripley

Best direction

All About My Mother (Pedro Almodovar), American Beauty (Sam Mendes), The End of the Affair (Neil Jordan), The Sixth Sense (M Night Shyamalan), The Talented Mr Ripley (Anthony Minghella)

Best British film

East is East, Notting Hill, Onegin, Ratcatcher, Topsy-Turvey, Wonderland

Best actress

Linda Bassett (East is East), Annette Bening (American Beauty), Julianne Moore (The End of the Affair), Emily Watson (Angela's Ashes)

Best actor

Jim Broadbent (Topsy-Turvy), Russell Crowe (The Insider), Ralph Fiennes (The End of the Affair), Om Puri (East is East), Kevin Spacey (American Beauty)

Best supporting actress

Thora Birch (American Beauty), Cate Blanchett (The Talented Mr Ripley), Cameron Diaz (Being John Malkovitch), Maggie Smith (Tea With Mussolini), Mena Suvari (American Beauty)

Best supporting actor

Wes Bentley (American Beauty), Michael Caine (Cider House Rules), Rhys Ifans (Notting Hill), Jude Law (The Talented Mr Ripley), Timothy Spall (Topsy-Turvy)

webTitle: Poverty no excuse for failure, says Blunkett

fields.headline: Poverty no excuse for failure, says Blunkett
fields.standfirst:
Education secretary threatens underachieving schools with closure as teachers argue that new exam targets will hit disadvantaged
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Poverty will be no excuse for secondary schools failing to achieve ambitious new government targets to raise the GCSE pass rate, David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, warned yesterday as he announced plans to close underachieving comprehensives.
fields.body:
Poverty will be no excuse for secondary schools failing to achieve ambitious new government targets to raise the GCSE pass rate, David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, warned yesterday as he announced plans to close underachieving comprehensives.

By the end of Labour's second term in 2006, he said, there should be no secondary in England where less than a quarter of pupils gained at least five good passes at grade C or above, equivalent to the former O-level.

Many of the 530 schools with a current pass rate below 25% would find the target challenging. "I can already hear the cries from those who say it can't be done. We know it can," Mr Blunkett told a National Union of Teachers' conference on secondary education.

He was greeted with hoots of derision when he said salaries of £100,000 would be paid to a small team of "superheads" for taking over clusters of up to five failing schools to set them on the road to recovery.

But Mr Blunkett challenged teachers in the audience to send their own children to schools where a fifth of the pupils left with no qualifications and just sit by and watch them fail.

"There are cynics out there who say that school performance is all about socio-economics and the areas that these schools are located in. No child is preordained by their class, gender, ethnic group or home life to fail."

Comprehensive education required equal oportunities for all. "I can't bus children from one end of a city to another, but I can do something to spread what is working. I can bring in to schools which are not succeeding people who have made it work elsewhere."

Mr Blunkett said there was no precise match between underachievement and poverty. In schools with a pass rate below 25% the proportion of pupils on free school meals varied from 6% to 96%.

The 530 underperforming secondaries included more than 200 with less than 35% of pupils on free school meals. Yet there were 175 schools with more than 35% on free meals which were already managing to achieve the 25% pass rate.

He announced three targets to secure improvement:

 By 2003 all secondaries must have a pass rate of at least 15% of pupils getting five good GCSE passes. Those failing to make consistent progress towards this target would be candidates for closure and reopening with a different name, a new head and reorganised management. In those circumstances, the teachers would have to reapply for their jobs and some would face redundancy.

Discretion about whether to close the school would stay with the local authority. Last year 86 secondaries got a pass rate of less than 15% and they were now in the front line for sanctions if they could not achieve the target.

 By 2004 there should be no secondary with a pass rate below 20%. But Mr Blunkett did not mention any additional sanctions against schools failing to make this grade.

 By 2006 all secondaries should get a pass rate of 25%. The government said higher standards in primary schools and extra resources for secondaries in difficult areas should help achieve the goal.

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the NUT, defended teachers in schools taking children who lived in appalling poverty. "How do you think they will be feeling?" he asked Mr Blunkett. Constructive criticism could be helpful, "but constant denigration is discouraging, dispiriting, demoralising and plain bad judgment".

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said the government's announcement would make it harder for schools with low GCSE results to retain and recruit good staff.

"The proportion of children with five A-C grades is the wrong measure to use. It invites schools under intense pressure to concentrate resources on the small number of children at the grade C/D borderline."

Peter Mortimore, director of London university's institute of education, said: "All the work of school improvement professionals shows that schools can make a difference, but they cannot completely overcome the effects of disadvantage."

Jan Woodhead, headteacher at Abbeydale Grange, the Sheffield comprehensive featured in a Guardian series last year on poverty and education, said: "Poverty is not an excuse for failure. But it is a factor that leaves some students with a bigger mountain to climb."

fields.headline: Head defies the statistics to give school a fighting chance
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Last year the Phoenix high school in west London achieved GCSE results that would lead most headteachers into thinking about another career.
fields.body:
Last year the Phoenix high school in west London achieved GCSE results that would lead most headteachers into thinking about another career.

Only 5% of pupils managed to get five passes at grade C and above, the benchmark set by education and employment secretary David Blunkett.

But the headmaster William Atkinson is defiant. "In many respects we are a successful school," he said.

Mr Atkinson, 49, has attracted a blaze of publicity after supposedly turning the school round since becoming headmaster in 1995, and was appointed to the government's standards task force.

In 1995, 5.4% of pupils had gained five passes at GCSE at grades A-C. Within two years that figure had tripled, only to plummet last year. "In one sense, looking solely at the exam results, it looks like the school has gone back to where it started," admitted Mr Atkinson.

If Mr Blunkett's new plan were in place, Phoenix would be a prime candidate for closure. For the past two years it has failed to reach the level of GCSE passes wanted by Mr Blunkett and probably will fail to meet that target this year also.

However a 1999 Ofsted report has made Mr Atkinson confident. "The school has improved significantly since the last inspection and now has many more strengths than weaknesses; it benefits from excellent leadership and is well placed to improve even further."

Mr Atkinson asked: "How can you improve on excellent?"

He argued that the league tables of exam performance were misleading. "The league tables have led to a superficial understanding in the public's mind that good equals top and bad equals bottom, and that is patently not the case."

He railed at the league tables' failure to measure how much value a school adds to the pupils it receives. "There is no recognition for that in the league table. It goes out of the way to denigrate and dismiss the achievement of half of our school because they are not getting grades A-C."

The reason for the poor GCSE results in 1999, Mr Atkinson said, could be found in the low level of skills possessed by those pupils when they arrived at the school, which took the "problem" pupils others did not want. "The ability of that intake was extremely low, not just skewed towards the bottom end, but non-existent. That was the raw material we started with."

Tests on their non-verbal skills aged 11 found 60% in the lowest categories, compared with a national average of 22%. Results for their verbal skills rated 79% as poor or very poor, compared with the average of 9.9%.

Forty per cent of last year's GCSE candidates were children of refugees, arriving with English as their second language or none at all. Two thirds of pupils are classed as requiring special needs.

Two thirds also get free school meals, the classic measure of a poverty stricken background. But Mr Atkinson said that poverty was too simple an explanation of his school's exam performance with a myriad of other factors providing a better explanation.

He said that the government needed to pay more attention to the challenges faced by each school. "They are beginning to understand that it is not just a question of having outstanding leadership, excellent teachers and good organisation," he added.

webTitle: One in three jobless say they are ill

fields.headline: One in three jobless say they are ill
fields.standfirst: Survey casts doubt on Brown plan to cut unemployment
fields.trailText: One in three jobless people claims to suffer from a longstanding illness that limits his or her activities, a survey reveals today, casting doubt on ministers' confidence of making further big cuts in unemployment.
fields.body:
One in three jobless people claims to suffer from a longstanding illness that limits his or her activities, a survey reveals today, casting doubt on ministers' confidence of making further big cuts in unemployment.

The number rises to more than half the unemployed aged over 45, complicating the equation of job vacancies and numbers of jobless drawn this week by Gordon Brown, the chancellor.

The latest government general household survey also shows that workless households are significantly less likely than others to have items like home computers, CD players, microwave ovens and dishwashers.

However, between 1996 and 1998 the proportion of households with satellite or cable television increased from 18% to 29%, with the numbers owning home computers rising from 27% to 34%.

Some of the largest differences in access to consumer goods are in respect of four items identified by the survey as "luxuries": CD players (63% of workless households compared with 86% of working ones), microwave ovens (71% against 86%), tumble dryers (44% against 61%) and dishwashers (12% against 31%).

The researchers for the study conceded that some of these disparities could be accounted for by class differences between the employed and unemployed, but said a clear contrast remained even when this was factored in.

The survey also shows that while smoking declined greatly in the 1970s and 1980s, it levelled out over the last decade, with 28% of men and 26% of women still smoking.

One in four families is now headed by a single parent, an increase of 17% from the 1971 figure of 8%.

Headline findings of the survey were published by the office for national statistics last December. But the full results include an analysis of more than 1,200 "workless" households, defined as those containing at least one person of working age but having nobody in a paid job or self-employment.

Overall, 19% of households were classed as workless and six in 10 of these contained only one adult, although they included markedly more children - 32% of all household members, as against 25% of all members of working households.

Compared with working households, more than three times as many women and four times as many men in workless households described their health as "not good".

In workless households 34% of men and 30% of women said they had a limiting longstanding illness. Among working households, the equivalent proportions were just 12% and 13% respectively.

Lorna Reith, chief executive of the Disability Alliance, said the results showed the flaws in making simple assumptions about unemployed people's ability to take jobs.

 Living in Britain: Results from the 1998 general household survey; stationery office; £39.50.

webTitle: Chile rules out hero's return for Pinochet

fields.headline: Chile rules out hero's return for Pinochet
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: An enthusiastic flag-waving crowd waiting at the airport at Santiago is not the image the Chilean government wants to see going around the world. If it could squirrel General Augusto Pinochet into Chile in the dead of night at some airbase far from Santiago and far from public view, it would.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill, Duncan Campbell  and Jonathan Franklin  in Santiago
fields.body:
An enthusiastic flag-waving crowd waiting at the airport at Santiago is not the image the Chilean government wants to see going around the world. If it could squirrel General Augusto Pinochet into Chile in the dead of night at some airbase far from Santiago and far from public view, it would.

The socialist government has opted for a compromise, flying him into Santiago, but with no bands, guard of honour, bunting or flags. It will not be hailing this as a triumphant diplomatic victory or the return of a hero. Gen Pinochet will arrive back to a country divided about his record, and which on the whole wants to see the issue buried as quickly as possible.

One of his supporters in Britain disclosed yesterday that even the military wanted to keep it quiet.

The Chilean ambassador to Britain, Pablo Cabrera, conceded last night it could not prevent some pro-Pinochet campaigners turning out for a spot of emotional flag-waving but it would not be government backed. "The goverment is not planning anything else. He might be received by some people close to him but the government is not promoting anything. On the contrary, we hope it will be as quiet as possible," he said.

Receptions are planned round Chile by pro- and anti-Pinochet campaigners. The far right UDI (Union Democrata Independiente) is planning a reception, according to its senator Andres Chadwick. Pinochet supporters in the far north are planning a motorcade reception in Iquique. The coalition of human rights groups, relatives of the missing, communist party and other leftwing groups will be rallying in the Plaza de la Constitution just beside La Moneda where President Allende died as the military bombarded and strafed the building in 1973.

If Gen Pinochet flies out of RAF Brize Norton today aboard the Chilean air force plane around midday, he can expect to arrive in Santiago tomorrow just before midday. In line with its attempts not to encourage publicity, the Chilean embassy was refusing all media requests to accompany him on the plane.

On arrival in Santiago, he is expected to go almost directly to a heavily guarded army hospital. A second floor room is being specially outfitted to receive him, known as the "Pinochet suite" and is designed to provide the best medical care available for an officer, including maids, butlers and a cook. The hospital is separated into different units, divided by rank.

Moving between floors is difficult as the elevators are erratic and prone to breakdowns. The hospital was built in 1912 and because the upgrades have been piecemeal, sections of the hospital suffer regularly from electrical failures.

Conflicting views about the state of Gen Pinochet's health remain, with Chilean government sources adamant he is mentally frail while one of his supporters provided a different prognosis: "He is not a walking wreck. He is not at death's door. He is not ga-ga."

Chilean diplomatic sources predicted Gen Pinochet, who is a senator, was unlikely to make a speech in the senate in the near future, if ever.

The issue of what will happen to him next is uppermost in the minds of his supporters and the relatives of the disappeared.

The socialist president, Ricardo Lagos, who was jailed under the dictatorship, said he had no intention of intervening in the judicial process but few from either side believe that they will see the general in the dock.

Juan Guzman, the judge investigating 57 charges against the general, has been interviewing witnesses. He has already indicated that he does not accept that the general is mentally unfit to stand trial or answer questions.

While no one doubts Mr Guzman's intention to carry out a thorough investigation, there are many obstacles in his way.

Gen Pinochet may try to use his senatorial immunity to block prosecution; failing that, his lawyers may argue that he is genuinely mentally incapacitated although many feel that this would be too humiliating for him to accept. If the charges progress, he might also seek to be tried by a military court, for whose composition he was largely responsible.

Mariela Garcia, a member of the group of the families of the disappeared, is doubtful as to whether he will ever face his accusers in a Chilean court.

"But it will be impossible to have reconciliation without justice," said Ms Garcia who has a faded photograph of her disappeared 19-year-old leftwing brother pinned to her flowered blouse.

"We hope for the impossible - in Chile you always have to hope for the impossible."

Flight ready and waiting

The Chilean air force plane that will take General Pinochet home has been in Britain for more than a month. The plane is a "tanquero", used by the air force for in-flight refuelling.

As a military plane used for such a basic purpose, it is extremely functional. A Chilean source who had been aboard said that though it had now been specially altered to take passengers - and not just any passengers, but an ex-head of state - it was still fairly basic.

It does not have luxuries such as video films but there will be a medical crew aboard, a doctor and his assistant.

In addition to the crew of about half-a-dozen - two pilots, a navigator and two stewardesses - Gen Pinochet will be accompanied by his wife and by an air force representative, General Molina, and an air force attache.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Social worker given sack
fields.body:
Social worker given sack

A social worker has been sacked after leaving a nine-year-old boy with learning difficulties in a layby, reportedly as a punishment for misbehaving.

East Ayrshire council dismissed Maureen Law, and has recommended the same for a teacher, Michael Roos, who was also in the car taking three children back from an outing on February 3. The boy, who cannot be named, was found by police wandering on a railway line but was unharmed. The two have the right of appeal.

Bullied pupil carries alarm

Ben Smith, 14, yesterday went back to Sir John Leman high school in Beccles, Suffolk, carrying a personal alarm in case of attack.

The head gave permission after the boy's mother removed him three weeks ago when he complained that bullies had kicked and beaten him. Police have spoken to four pupils.

Op date came year too late

A man was given a date for a triple heart bypass a year after dying of a heart attack, it emerged yesterday.

His widow, Pat Booy, 60, of Little Stoke, Bristol, re ceived the letter from Bristol royal infirmary's cardiac unit last month, 2 years after Brian Booy was put on the waiting list, and days before the anniversary of his death at 60. The hospital, which last week said 10 patients had died awaiting operations, regretted the letter but said it had no way of knowing of a death unless told by the GP.

Hitler's notes up for auction

Cards written by Adolf Hitler for a speech in 1939, with references to the Jews, are expected to fetch £15,000 at auction today in Swindon in Wiltshire.

An RAF flight lieutenant, Ronald Mason, now 79, kept the cards after swapping a pack of cigarettes for them with a German inside the Berlin chancellery just after its capture in 1945.

webTitle: Edward and Mrs Simpson cast in new light

fields.headline: Edward and Mrs Simpson cast in new light
fields.standfirst:
The Monckton papers King's true love was prepared 'with deepest sorrow' to abandon plans for marriage in order to avert abdication

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: New evidence of how far Wallis Simpson was prepared to sacrifice herself to allow her lover Edward VIII to remain on the throne is revealed in the Monckton papers released yesterday.
fields.body:
New evidence of how far Wallis Simpson was prepared to sacrifice herself to allow her lover Edward VIII to remain on the throne is revealed in the Monckton papers released yesterday.

A handwritten document signed by the future Duchess of Windsor and which might have changed the course of history says: "With the deepest personal sorrow Wallis Simpson wishes to announce that she has abandoned any intention to marry His Majesty."

Though the document was undated it is assumed to have been written at the height of the abdication crisis in December 1936. It was written in pencil in the handwriting of Lord Brownlow, one of the duchess's courtiers, when they were staying at Lou Viei, her villa in Cannes.

The document was apparently unearthed in 1948 among political papers belonging to the prime minister at the time of the abdication, Stanley Baldwin. They are referred to in correspondence between Walter Monckton, the Duke of Windsor's confidant, and Alan Lascelles, the king's private secretary.

It seems that Mrs Simpson's signed note was never seen by George VI, Edward VIII's successor, or his wife, now the Queen Mother.

Though Mrs Simpson issued a press statement at the time of the abdication referring to her wish to avoid any action that would damage the king, and was willing to "withdraw", the document released yesterday goes much further.

Its existence surprised Lascelles who asked for copies of all Monckton's material on the abdication crisis. Monckton replied: "I will see to it that the abdication material ... is delivered to you for Windsor [home of the royal archives] as soon as it is available."

The prevailing view, however, is that Edward VIII had made up his mind to relinquish the throne to marry the woman he loved. Papers released yesterday show that the future duchess's lawyer - Theodore Goddard - told Downing Street that "his client was ready to do anything to ease the situation but the other end of the wicket [Edward VIII] was determined."

The Monckton papers paint a picture of growing hostility between London and France - where the duke and duchess exiled themselves - and between the two royal brothers. They include a letter sent by the duke to Neville Chamberlain, the prime minister, in 1938 with the former king mentioning he had attached copies of his correspondence with George VI.

This correspondence - along with many other papers - is missing from the Monckton documents. However they give a flavour of the tension between the two men with the duke describing his brother as "stupid and rather impertinent".

The papers also reflect the depth of the duke's resentment at what he regarded as the unfair way in which he was treated, including the rebuff of his repeated attempts to return to Britain.

Yet on the day before the war began - September 3 1939 - when George VI offered to send his personal plane to France to fetch the duke and duchess, the former king responded by saying that unless he could use one of the royal houses they would not return to England.

The British ambassador in Paris noted that the duke had wanted two aeroplanes to take "a maid and of course luggage".

The papers contain a long personal account of the abdication crisis written by Monckton a few months afterwards. Monckton argued that the public could not understand the events of the abdication unless they appreciated two factors.

The first was the "intensity and depth of the king's devotion" to Wallis Simpson. "To him she was the perfect woman. It is a great mistake to assume that he was merely in love with her in an ordinary physical sense of the term. There was an intellectual companionship and there is no doubt that his lonely nature found in her a spiritual comradeship."

Monckton referred to the king's abdication speech on December 11 1936. "When he said in his final broadcast that he could not carry on his task without her by his side, he said what he really meant from his heart."

Monckton believed that the second factor was "much less generally recognised" by the public.

The duke had "remarkable determination, courage, and confidence in his own opinions and decisions." He added: "Once his mind was made up one felt he was like a death adder 'that stoppeth her ears and refuseth to hear the voice of the charmer'."

Monckton believed that in the quandary of his marriage or his throne, "the trouble was that ... his mind was made up for himself long before he knew it." This, Monckton believed, was "the explanation of what must have seemed to many strange and obtuse obstinacy."

Monckton wrote: "For myself I am free to confess that I always underestimated the depth and strength of the king's devotion and of their united will."

Monckton added a later note saying that the duke had told him that he had made up his mind to marry her in 1934, "and from that time onwards, his mind never wavered".

The private papers contain one letter written by the queen, now Queen Mother, to Monckton - an anodyne query in June 1941 about the official work of her brother, David Bowes-Lyons.

The papers show that 11 days after her lover abandoned the throne Wallis Simpson was upset with the model of herself in Madame Tussaud's. She complained to her lawyers: "Is there any way you can have that appalling wax figure of me removed from Madame Tussaud's - it really is too in decent and so awful to be there anyway."

But they found that there was no legal way of forcing Madame Tussaud's to remove the figure.

At the outbreak of war, the duke was given the rank of major general as liaison officer with French forces in Paris. After France was overrun in the summer of 1940, the duke and duchess fled to their villa on the Riviera. They then moved to Spain where the duke responded to flattery from Franco and German diplomats by saying how much he wanted peace. The couple subsequently moved to Portugal where the duke ignored Churchill's instructions to return to Britain. He was finally persuaded to take up a governership of the Bahamas in 1940.

The telegrams exchanged with Hitler

The papers shed no new light on the Duke of Windsor's relationship with the Nazi regime. The duke and duchess had visited Germany as Hitler's personal guest in 1937.

The papers, however, do contain copies of telegrams exchanged between the duke and Hitler shortly before the outbreak of the second world war.

On August 24 1939, the duke wrote of "my entirely personal, simple though very earnest appeal for your utmost influence towards a peaceful solution of the present problems".

Hitler replied saying it depended "upon England whether any wishes for the future development of Anglo-German relations materialises".

German documents referring to the duke and his alleged sympathies with Nazi Germany were published in the 1950s despite fierce opposition from Churchill. An introduction insisted on by the government says: "The duke was subjected to heavy pressure from many quarters to stay in Europe, where the Germans hoped that he would exert his influence against the policy of his majesty's government. His royal highness never wavered in his loyalty to the British cause or in his determination to take up his official post as governor of the Bahamas on the date agreed."

Though Mrs Simpson issued a press statement at the time of the abdication referring to her wish to avoid any action that would damage the king, and was willing to "withdraw", the document released yesterday goes much further. Its existence surprised Lascelles who asked for copies of all Monckton's material on the abdication crisis. Monckton replied: "I will see to it that the abdication material ... is delivered to you for Windsor [home of the royal archives] as soon as it is available." The prevailing view, however, is that Edward VIII had made up his mind to relinquish the throne to marry the woman he loved. Papers released yesterday show that the future duchess's lawyer - Theodore Goddard - told Downing Street that "his client was ready to do anything to ease the situation but the other end of the wicket [Edward VIII] was determined." The Monckton papers paint a picture of growing hostility between London and France - where the duke and duchess exiled themselves - and between the two royal brothers. They include a letter sent by the duke to Neville Chamberlain, the prime minister, in 1938 with the former king mentioning he had attached copies of his correspondence with George VI. This correspondence - along with many other papers - is missing from the Monckton documents. However they give a flavour of the tension between the two men with the duke describing his brother as "stupid and rather impertinent". The papers also reflect the depth of the duke's resentment at what he regarded as the unfair way in which he was treated, including the rebuff of his repeated attempts to return to Britain. Yet on the day before the war began - September 3 1939 - when George VI offered to send his personal plane to France to fetch the duke and duchess, the former king responded by saying that unless he could use one of the royal houses they would not return to England. The British ambassador in Paris noted that the duke had wanted two aeroplanes to take "a maid and of course luggage". The papers contain a long personal account of the abdication crisis written by Monckton a few months afterwards. Monckton argued that the public could not understand the events of the abdication unless they appreciated two factors. The first was the "intensity and depth of the king's devotion" to Wallis Simpson. "To him she was the perfect woman. It is a great mistake to assume that he was merely in love with her in an ordinary physical sense of the term. There was an intellectual companionship and there is no doubt that his lonely nature found in her a spiritual comradeship." Monckton referred to the king's abdication speech on December 11 1936. "When he said in his final broadcast that he could not carry on his task without her by his side, he said what he really meant from his heart." Monckton believed that the second factor was "much less generally recognised" by the public. The duke had "remarkable determination, courage, and confidence in his own opinions and decisions." He added: "Once his mind was made up one felt he was like a death adder 'that stoppeth her ears and refuseth to hear the voice of the charmer'." Monckton believed that in the quandary of his marriage or his throne, "the trouble was that ... his mind was made up for himself long before he knew it." This, Monckton believed, was "the explanation of what must have seemed to many strange and obtuse obstinacy." Monckton wrote: "For myself I am free to confess that I always underestimated the depth and strength of the king's devotion and of their united will." Monckton added a later note saying that the duke had told him that he had made up his mind to marry her in 1934, "and from that time onwards, his mind never wavered". The private papers contain one letter written by the queen, now Queen Mother, to Monckton - an anodyne query in June 1941 about the official work of her brother, David Bowes-Lyons. The papers show that 11 days after her lover abandoned the throne Wallis Simpson was upset with the model of herself in Madame Tussaud's. She complained to her lawyers: "Is there any way you can have that appalling wax figure of me removed from Madame Tussaud's - it really is too in decent and so awful to be there anyway." But they found that there was no legal way of forcing Madame Tussaud's to remove the figure. At the outbreak of war, the duke was given the rank of major general as liaison officer with French forces in Paris. After France was overrun in the summer of 1940, the duke and duchess fled to their villa on the Riviera. They then moved to Spain where the duke responded to flattery from Franco and German diplomats by saying how much he wanted peace. The couple subsequently moved to Portugal where the duke ignored Churchill's instructions to return to Britain. He was finally persuaded to take up a governership of the Bahamas in 1940. The telegrams exchanged with Hitler The papers shed no new light on the Duke of Windsor's relationship with the Nazi regime. The duke and duchess had visited Germany as Hitler's personal guest in 1937. The papers, however, do contain copies of telegrams exchanged between the duke and Hitler shortly before the outbreak of the second world war. On August 24 1939, the duke wrote of "my entirely personal, simple though very earnest appeal for your utmost influence towards a peaceful solution of the present problems". Hitler replied saying it depended "upon England whether any wishes for the future development of Anglo-German relations materialises". German documents referring to the duke and his alleged sympathies with Nazi Germany were published in the 1950s despite fierce opposition from Churchill. An introduction insisted on by the government says: "The duke was subjected to heavy pressure from many quarters to stay in Europe, where the Germans hoped that he would exert his influence against the policy of his majesty's government. His royal highness never wavered in his loyalty to the British cause or in his determination to take up his official post as governor of the Bahamas on the date agreed."

webTitle: Focus group tells church about the root of its ills

fields.headline: Focus group tells church about the root of its ills
fields.standfirst: BR>Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The Church of England yesterday followed the example of the political parties by resorting to focus groups to tell it what it is doing wrong.
fields.body:
The Church of England yesterday followed the example of the political parties by resorting to focus groups to tell it what it is doing wrong.

Research given to the general synod asserted that young people saw it as an isolated club, constantly tearing itself apart and trying vainly to be trendy.

And that is only what the believers thought.

The findings were obtained from consultations with eight groups, largely across the Midlands, conducted over the last three months, among the under 25s and over 40s.

Although only 62 people took part, the organisers are sure they have got to the heart of the matter for their report, entitled Hopes and Dreams for a Future Church.

The research has received the backing of the Archbishop of Canterbury, Dr George Carey.

webTitle: Anti-drugs chief led double life as dealer

fields.headline: Anti-drugs chief led double life as dealer
fields.standfirst:
Agency in disarray as operation ends in jailing of former team leader
Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: One of the biggest anti-drug agencies in the country was in disarray last night after a former manager admitted being in possession of half a kilo of heroin with intent to supply and was jailed for seven years.
fields.body:
One of the biggest anti-drug agencies in the country was in disarray last night after a former manager admitted being in possession of half a kilo of heroin with intent to supply and was jailed for seven years.

Addaction - formerly known as the Association for the Prevention of Addiction - had investigated complaints that Dave Francis, 37, who ran their crack awareness team in Nottingham, was an active professional dealer. They disciplined staff who complained about his behaviour and attacked the Guardian which exposed Francis as a dealer in May 1997.

Sentencing him at Nottingham crown court, Judge Dudley Bennett told Francis: "You more than anybody else should have known the misery of people who have become addicted. I have to deal with people day after day in this court who appear before me after committing crimes to fund their drug habit." A second charge of conspiracy was left to lie on the file.

Under cover
Although the events which led to Francis's arrest occurred after he left the agency, evidence collected by the Guardian and by Nottingham detectives leaves no doubt that Francis was dealing under cover of the agency for nearly four years, and continued to deal on a city-wide scale after the Guardian forced him to resign in 1997.

While Francis managed the crack awareness team, posing as a crusader against drugs, he organised regular supplies of crack cocaine and heroin to addicts in the city, including those who had come to the team for help. He also dealt in stolen goods, firearms and prostitutes. He employed a second dealer, Henry Warner, as his deputy and allowed the team's office to be used for drug-taking.

Police believe that, while he was running the agency, he became one of the biggest dealers in the Midlands, controlling an illegal organisation of more than 100 workers in Nottingham.

In the summer of 1996, a group of Francis's colleagues made written complaints to the agency about his activity. Twenty other professionals in the city expressed anxieties about him.

His lifestyle ran far ahead of his income. He earned £21,000 a year from the agency and yet he drove a £49,500 Mercedes, had two homes in Nottingham, wore a £30,000 watch and sported diamonds drilled into his front teeth.

The then head of the city's major crimes unit said publicly that he was 100% certain that Francis was an active dealer. But when the parent agency, Addaction (then APA), finally held an internal inquiry, they concluded in March 1997 that there was no evidence against him.

"He's a good guy as far as we're concerned," the agency's then chairman, Sir Geoffrey Errington, said at the time. "These things were rumours. There was no hard evidence."

Addaction, which still receives annually £3.5m of public and charitable funds, continues to claim that there is no evidence that he committed any offence while he worked for them.

Since Francis was exposed, the agency, which includes the wife of the former home secretary, Michael Howard, on its board, has won new home office contracts to work with drug users in prison. After being exposed by the Guardian, Francis resigned from the crack awareness team and continued to deal on a huge scale, flaunting his wealth and power.

Nottingham police reacted by setting up a "total surveillance operation", codenamed Odin, which was of such unprecedented scale that finally it not only arrested Dave Francis but took out 134 of his alleged associates and dealers.

Detectives say that Francis's role in the crack awareness team directly assisted his rise to power. According to one detective: "It gave him a perfect excuse if he was ever caught with drugs or with people in possession of drugs. It also made it much more difficult for us to hassle him, because he had political connections in the city." Tapes from Francis's house showed he had been running crimes in the city for years.

Before he was hired by Addaction, he had headed a team of armed robbers from the Meadows estate and he had already been convicted of more than 30 offences involving burglary, theft, firearms, unlawful sexual intercourse and possession of drugs. He told Addaction that he had become a Christian and he was given access to some of the most vulnerable people in the city and a budget of more than £170,000 of public money. He attended planning meetings with senior police and was invited to give evidence to a parliamentary select committee.

'Bags and bags of weed'
In the autumn of 1995, five current and former staff filed written allegations, accusing Francis of dealing in heroin and cocaine, of trading in firearms and supplying women for prostitution. Witnesses detailed incidents where Francis had been seen with "bags and bags of weed" and huge quantities of cash; where he had used heroin to buy stolen goods and helped one of them to sell a firearm.

Staff complained that the subsequent inquiry was serviced by managers who had already defended Francis and that it failed to call key witnesses. Addaction produced a report which exonerated Francis, and threatened leading witnesses with legal action if they repeated their allegations. One staff member who complained was suspended for supposed racism, even though neither Francis nor his deputy had been suspended when accused of systematic criminal activity.

It was only when the Guardian exposed Francis and the local health and social services withdrew their funding that Addaction was forced to withdraw from its schemes in the city.

Addaction's chief executive, Peter Martin, told the Guardian that "any allegation that APA or Addaction knew of, approved or condoned in any way any such inappropriate behaviour by David Francis while he was at APA or that we neglected our duty of care is categorically denied."

Caught red-handed by surveillance squad
During the huge Odin operation, detectives planted electronic bugs inside one of Francis's homes with six officers manning a listening post around the clock, set up video cameras to record his movements, clamped tracking devices on his cars, trawled through his bank and telephone records, used army special forces for surveillance, followed him to Jamaica and back (even bugging his seat on the plane), hired informers on weekly wages and, most destructive of all, used a mixed-race officer from another force to infiltrate the community, recording sound and pictures of numerous drug deals.

By monitoring Francis so intensely, the police exposed his operation, which turned out to be a highly organised corporate structure, headed by Francis and a group of lieutenants who formed what police call an army council. Each lieutenant was responsible for supplying a different area of the city through his own network of middle men and street dealers.

Francis organised the supply: sometimes through his Nigerian contacts in London, sometimes through a Midlands gypsy who has become a millionaire from armed robbery and drug deals, sometimes through delivery "mules" whom he escorted to Jamaica. In a six-week period just before his arrest, Francis moved seven kilos of heroin into Nottingham.

The police bugs recorded Francis playing the part of the conventional entrepreneur, urging his men to be the quickest, the cheapest and the most reliable suppliers in the city.

He and his lieutenants held monthly board meetings at safe houses on the Meadows estate, where many of them had been born, to discuss supply lines and pricing. He warned his men: "Be paranoid."

But the bugs recorded his every move recruiting new workers, haggling over money, organising supply, plotting to cut out the competition and then spending hours watching old soaps on cable television.

Finally, on February 23 last year, detectives heard Francis discussing the sale of a load of heroin that was due from London that night. They sent one surveillance team to follow the London suppliers as they drove up the motorway, and another team to Francis's flat in the city centre. With the key players all in place, the detectives took the door off its hinges and found their target with a carrier bag containing half a kilo of 67% pure heroin. Francis also had a roll of cash which were so heavily stained with heroin, cocaine, amphetamines and ecstasy that the traces went off the scale of their laboratory equipment.

Police arrested a total of 134 suspected dealers, including Francis's former crack awareness team deputy, Henry Warner, who last year admitted possessing heroin with intent supply.

fields.headline: Millennium blamed for abortion rise
fields.trailText: Excess drinking and partying over the millennium, combined with a lack of access to emergency contraception during the holiday season, are being blamed for a 20% rise in abortions by a family planning charity.
fields.body:
Excess drinking and partying over the millennium, combined with a lack of access to emergency contraception during the holiday season, are being blamed for a 20% rise in abortions by a family planning charity.

Marie Stopes International, which runs a network of clinics throughout the country, said the impact of Christmas and the new year was beginning to be seen in thousands of unwanted pregnancies.

The news came as MPs and peers urged improved access to NHS abortion services, after research showed more than a quarter of women having terminations in England and Wales had to pay for private treatment.

According to Marie Stopes, abortions always rise in the first four months of the year, but this year's figures were unprecedented. In January and February, 6,900 women had terminations at the charity's seven clinics in the UK, compared with 5,759 for the same period in 1999.

Its deputy chief executive, Helen Axby, said: "This increase could be the tip of the iceberg. We may just be seeing the first swath of women who missed their periods after the holiday season. Others, particularly teenagers who are sometimes less aware of their bodies, may not yet have realised they are pregnant."

Franca Tranza, a spokeswoman, said: "Looking to the future, there are a number of things the government could do, for example allowing emergency contraception to be sold over the counter."

Britain has the highest teenage pregnancy rate in western Europe, with more than 8,000 girls under 16 getting pregnant each year. About half of the pregnancies end in termination.

A report for the all-party parliamentary pro-choice group found that of the 46,000 women each year who have private abortions, almost half would have preferred NHS treatment but were either refused by their GP or found the waiting time too long.

Baroness Gould, the group's chairwoman, said: "It is shocking that more than 30 years after abortion was made legal, some women still have problems getting an abortion within the NHS."

fields.headline: Danger warning on herbal remedy
fields.trailText: The government yesterday issued an urgent health warning over the popular herbal remedy for mild depression, St John's wort, amid fears it can stop certain prescription drugs from working.
fields.body:
The government yesterday issued an urgent health warning over the popular herbal remedy for mild depression, St John's wort, amid fears it can stop certain prescription drugs from working.

Women taking the contraceptive pill, HIV patients taking drugs to suppress the virus, epilepsy and asthma sufferers, and people prescribed certain heart drugs could all be affected by the remedy, the medicines control agency said.

Alisdair Breckenridge, chairman of the committee on safety of medicines, said: "The consequences may be serious for some patients. That is why we are issuing this health warning after studying the evidence over the last two weeks."

Sales of St John's wort, available without a prescription, have increased dramatically in recent years to the point where the market is now worth $6bn (about £3.75bn) in Europe alone. An estimated 2m people have tried the remedy in Britain to treat mild to moderate depression. US sales are growing by 2,000% a year.

Prof Breckenridge said new evidence, including studies published in international medical journals, show that St John's wort may stop some medicines working effectively. "We are advising anyone who is taking a prescribed medicine to seek the advice of their doctor or pharmacist before taking St John's wort."

The medicines control agency said it was holding discussions with herbal practitioner organisations and trade associations on the information that should be made available with unlicensed herbal remedies containing St John's wort.

The deputy chief medical officer, Pat Troop, said: "St John's wort when taken alone, and with many drugs, causes no harm. When taken with the drugs listed today, there are health concerns. This is why we are taking this balanced approach between public safety and consumer choice."

Michael McIntyre, chairman of the European herbal practitioners association, said: "Herbal practitioners are aware that herbal medicines need to be prescribed and taken with care."

"Just because something is 'natural' does not mean that it is 100% safe... but people who are not on other medicines can take St John's wort safely."

St John's wort is a yellow hedgerow plant (Hypercium perforatum) known as "nature's Prozac". According to legend it was discovered by St John the Baptist, and the dried flowers of the plant have been used to treat depression since the Middle Ages.

Recent studies have shown that it can affect drug metabolism, speeding up the rate at which other medicines are broken down in the liver and reducing their effectiveness.

This can mean that patients are prescribed higher doses of the drug to begin with, and if they stop taking St John's wort levels of the medicine in their blood may be too high.

It can also add to the effect that some drugs (for instance, prescribed anti-depressants) can have on the brain, triggering adverse reactions.

Herbal remedies do not need to be licensed, and as such cannot make any claims to be clinically effective, but manufacturers and herbal practitioners say this also stops them from printing adequate advice about products.

The government is holding talks with manufacturers to look at changing labels to warn people of the risks.

fields.headline: Abdication papers missing
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: A letter from the Queen Mother, written weeks after she described the Duchess of Windsor as "the lowest of the low", is among a number of documents missing from thousands of private papers on the post-abdication crisis released yesterday.
fields.byline: Richard Norton Taylor and  Rob Evans
fields.body:
A letter from the Queen Mother, written weeks after she described the Duchess of Windsor as "the lowest of the low", is among a number of documents missing from thousands of private papers on the post-abdication crisis released yesterday.

The letter is listed in the index of personal papers collected by Walter Monckton, the private lawyer and confidant of the former King, Edward VIII, who left Britain with Wallis Simpson, the American divorcee, in December 1936.

Dated August 14 1940, the missing document is described as a letter from the Queen to Monckton relating to the arrival of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor in the Bahamas where the former King was appointed governor. A second missing document, dated a few days later, is described in the Monckton index as an exchange of letters between the duke's lawyer and Gray Philipps, the duke's equerry.

Buckingham Palace said yesterday that some Monckton papers had been deposited for safe-keeping in the royal archives at Windsor.

webTitle: Juice drinks 'have more sugar than Coca Cola'

fields.headline: Juice drinks 'have more sugar than Coca Cola'
fields.trailText: Several best-selling fruit drinks, often seen as healthy alternatives to pop, contain more sugar than Coca Cola. Some had up to six teaspoons of sugar, while others had a fruit juice content of 5%.
fields.body:
Several best-selling fruit drinks, often seen as healthy alternatives to pop, contain more sugar than Coca Cola. Some had up to six teaspoons of sugar, while others had a fruit juice content of 5%.

Which? magazine analysed 19 orange flavour fruit drinks to assess which were most harmful to children's teeth. Those without artificial sweeteners all contained between 8% and 12% sugar, and half had more sugar per 100ml than Coca Cola.

The sweetest, a 250ml carton of Del Monte Fruit Burst, was found to contain more than six teaspoons of sugar, making it 60% sweeter than Del Monte pure orange juice.

The survey was also critical of Sunny Delight, third best-seller behind Coca Cola and Pepsi. Its ads, aimed at children, emphasise the health aspects, but Which? found it contained three to four teaspoons of sugar in a 200ml bottle.

Which?, part of the Consumers' Association, also called for the British Dental Association to withdraw its endorsement of Ribena Toothkind. It contained less sugar and was less acidic than other fruit drinks, but research showed it was not truly "kind" to teeth.

fields.headline: Pinochet prepares to fly home
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: The former dictator of Chile, Augusto Pinochet, is widely expected to begin his return journey home today when Jack Straw makes his announcement on whether or not to halt extradition proceedings against him at 8 o' clock this morning.
fields.body:
The former dictator of Chile, Augusto Pinochet, is widely expected to begin his return journey home today when Jack Straw makes his announcement on whether or not to halt extradition proceedings against him at 8 o' clock this morning.

The home secretary is almost certain to uphold his decision, taken in early January, that he was "minded" to release the general on the strength of a medical report which found the 84-year-old had suffered extensive brain damage as a result of a series of strokes.

Barring any last minute legal challenges, Pinochet is likely to be freed from his 16 months of house arrest today to board a Chilean air force jet that has been waiting at RAF Brize Norton in Oxfordshire for the 15-hour flight to Chile.

In a written parliamentary reply yesterday afternoon Mr Straw said he would give full reasons for his decision when he makes his announcement. The home secretary has spent the last week studying representations on the medical report made by the four countries seeking to extradite the general.

Spain, Belgium, Switzerland and France all challenged Mr Straw's assessment that Pinochet was unfit to stand trial in their submissions to the home office, calling for the general to undergo further medical tests.

Despite the early morning timing of the announcement there is nothing to stop any of the states involved from seeking an immediate injunction of the home secretary's decision at the high court. Last night none of the four countries involved appeared to be preparing a legal challenge to Mr Straw.

Even if a last-minute appeal was launched, it would be unlikely to succeed as the home secretary's discretion in extradition matters is so wide-ranging.

The Belgian authorities, who have led recent attempts to keep the former dictator in Britain by forcing Mr Straw to release Pinochet's confidential medical report, hinted they might hold back from challenging the home secretary's decision.

A spokesman for the Belgian foreign ministry said they would wait for the home secretary's announcement before deciding on a course of action. "We are aware that of course we could appeal. But we consider that the margin for action is very narrow. We are also aware that Pinochet can refuse to sustain another medical examination."

A spokesman for the Swiss authorities, who despite having a warrant out for Pinochet's arrest have so far played no part in any of the legal proceedings, stressed they would also wait for Mr Straw's decision before deciding whether to take any action.

Baltasar Garzon, the investigating Spanish magistrate who has been the driving force behind international attempts to bring Pinochet to justice, is unlikely to be able to appeal against Mr Straw's decision even if he wanted to.

It was an arrest warrant from Judge Garzon that led to Pinochet's arrest while the general was recovering from back surgery in a London hospital in October 1998.

The Spanish government, which has never been comfortable with the prospect of the former dictator arriving in Madrid to stand trial, has already made clear that it will accept Mr Straw's final decision on the matter and will not allow Judge Garzon to order an appeal.

Amnesty International and Redress, two of the human rights organisations involved in the recent legal action, indicated they were not planning to launch any legal challenge if Mr Straw decided to free the general, while Human Rights Watch said it was waiting to see what the result was and the reasons for the decision.

Pinochet has spent most of his 16 months in Britain under armed police guard at a rented mansion on the Wentworth estate in Surrey.

webTitle: Blair volunteers to give up a day

fields.headline: Blair volunteers to give up a day
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's a busy prime minister, with a baby on the way. But yesterday he pledged to do a day's voluntary work as part of a government initiative to encourage people and employers to give up time for the community.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's a busy prime minister, with a baby on the way. But yesterday he pledged to do a day's voluntary work as part of a government initiative to encourage people and employers to give up time for the community.

Mr Blair announced that all No 10 and Cabinet Office employees will be given one day's paid leave a year for voluntary activities. The prime minister will probably spend a day helping classroom activities at a school in his Sedgefield constituency. His official spokesman said he will probably do something similar himself. Some 12.4m people already did some kind of voluntary work, the spokesman said. "Hundreds of thousands would like to be more involved, but can't find a way that suits them or simply don't know where to begin."

At a convention in London today, Mr Blair will announce the creation of an Experience Corps, a new drive to harness the volunteering potential of older people."Volunteering, voluntary action and community development are essential parts of a country trying to be inclusive, cohesive, and mutually supportive," Mr Blair will say.

Yesterday in the Commons Mr Blair said: "I know a number of major companies are intending to embrace the scheme to allow their staff to take a day off, paid, once a year, to work in the voluntary sector. I intend to do this myself, both as an individual and as an employer, with people in Downing Street and the Cabinet office able to take a minimum of one day's paid leave a year to do voluntary work."

Other government departments are likely to join in.

webTitle: Special advisers tripled as No 10 staff hits new high

fields.headline: Special advisers tripled as No 10 staff hits new high
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has tripled the number of special advisers and doubled the size of his private office since he won the general election, according to official figures released by Sir Richard Wilson, the cabinet secretary, last night.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has tripled the number of special advisers and doubled the size of his private office since he won the general election, according to official figures released by Sir Richard Wilson, the cabinet secretary, last night.

The figures - requested by Andrew Tyrie, Conservative MP for Chichester and former special adviser to ex-chancellor Nigel Lawson - reveal that Downing Street now employs a record number of 149 people.

Sir Richard's breakdown of the staffing figures is the first time details have been disclosed by the government on arrangements inside No 10.

Mr Tyrie claimed last night that the figures showed "that Tony Blair is well on the way to setting up a presidential style of government.

"For the first time a political appointee, Jonathan Powell, is now in total charge of Downing Street and not a senior civil servant.

"Under John Major Down ing Street was run by the principal private secretary." Sir Richard's figures show that compared with Mr Major's eight special advisers Labour has 29 advisers to help Tony Blair - the biggest rise in political appointments at No 10. Tony Blair's private office has increased from six staff under his predecessor to 11.

Three new Downing Street units have been created. One for Cherie Blair - known as the social unit - arranges her diary and the Blairs' social and charity engagements at No 10. John Major's wife Norma had a part-time secretary. Two other new units have ben created - the strategic communciations unit under civil servant, James Humphreys, and the research and intelligence unit under political adviser, Bill Bush.

Both are involved in preparing information for Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's press secretary, and between them have 11 staff.

Mr Campbell has two full-time special advisers in the Downing Street media moni toring unit, so that press stories can be rebutted within hours of articles appearing. Altogether there are now 25 people monitoring and answering press inquiries, on duty almost 24 hours a day.

Tony Blair has declined an invitation to give evidence to the Commons public administartion committee inquiry into modernising government, MPs were told last night at a private meeting. Instead he is sending Mo Mowlam, the Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster.

fields.headline: The truth about Myra
fields.trailText: What Myra Hindley hoped to achieve by her collaboration with Duncan Staff for Modern Times (BBC2) is a mystery. Greater public sympathy for her appeal against continued imprisonment? A fuller understanding of what could drive a young woman to what she did? Whatever the intentions, the results could only serve to remind all and sundry of the overwhelming horror of the moors murders. The careful planning and execution of each crime was described alongside extracts from the 150 pages of Hindley's letters to Staff - and the yawning discrepancy between the cold facts, and Hindley's recollection of them, was there for all to see.
fields.body:
What Myra Hindley hoped to achieve by her collaboration with Duncan Staff for Modern Times (BBC2) is a mystery. Greater public sympathy for her appeal against continued imprisonment? A fuller understanding of what could drive a young woman to what she did? Whatever the intentions, the results could only serve to remind all and sundry of the overwhelming horror of the moors murders. The careful planning and execution of each crime was described alongside extracts from the 150 pages of Hindley's letters to Staff - and the yawning discrepancy between the cold facts, and Hindley's recollection of them, was there for all to see.

Staff's film was impressive in its objectivity. "It is always wrong not to seek to understand," said crime expert Brian Masters at the start of the film, "but to understand is not necessarily to condone or forgive". The focus of the next 20 minutes was on Hindley's relationship with Ian Brady, a charismatic sadist who, Hindley stressed in her letters, corrupted her both sexually and morally. Again and again she cast Brady as the homicidal pervert, herself as his brainwashed disciple - if only I hadn't met him, ran the constant refrain, all would have been well. "All I'd ever hoped for from a relationship with him was marriage and children", Hindley said, plumbing new depths of disingenuousness.

Hindley had no control over the editorial content of Modern Times, as was clear from the fact that, after this bout of special pleading, Staff's film shifted focus to the murders. As the stark narrative of first victim Pauline Reade's abduction and death unfolded, Hindley's excuses seemed transparent. Brady had beaten Hindley up and threatened to kill her grandmother in the days before the murder, and so "I sacrificed Pauline so that my own family would be safe". Not only did she stand by while Brady killed the girl - Hindley went home with Brady, shared a romantic evening on the sofa and, four months later, went out looking for a second victim.

And so it went on, Hindley's credibility wearing thinner and thinner with each crime. Faced with the prospect of writing about the murder of fourth victim Lesley Ann Downey, whose cries for mercy were tape recorded, Hindley pleaded that the memory was still too painful for her to go into detail. Psychiatrist Malcolm MacCulloch, who has heard the tape, said that there was "no sympathy" in Hindley's recorded voice. Finally, the film's big question - was Hindley a brainwashed accomplice or an active perpetrator - was answered. Another of Brady's disciples, Hindley's brother-in-law David Smith, was in the house when the final victim, Edward Evans, was battered to death. Unlike Hindley, he lost little time in going to the police.

Duncan Staff, to his credit, resisted the temptation to indulge in too much discussion of the rights and wrongs of Hindley's current situation. He ended on a canny note, reminding us that any question of her freedom is academic as she would very likely be murdered within days of release. Hindley's final remarks - that it would have been better if she'd hanged - at last had the ring of conviction.

While Modern Times: Myra Hindley was an exemplary film in many ways, it made for profoundly uncomfortable viewing. Why was it made at all? And why was it screened just now, when Hindley is once again challenging the home secretary's right to keep her in prison? Yes, it's extraordinary that Duncan Staff corresponded with Britain's most hated person, and fascinating to pick apart the flimsiness of Hindley's "oh my God what have I done?" routine. But beyond that, did the film add substantially to an understanding of what makes people murder, as it set out to do? Of course not, because Hindley's testimony is unreliable, the facts of the case still too horrifying to comprehend in a 50-minute format.

TV is always proving the old adage that if something can be done, it will be done - and in this case the fact that Staff had Hindley's "confessions" in his hand proved too much for BBC2 to resist. The material is astonishing, but why make it into television, where it nestled uneasily between Home Front: Inside Out and The Fast Show? However intelligent Staff's film, it could only serve to whip up hatred against Hindley - and hatred, as Hindley's former prison chaplain pointed out, corrodes the soul.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Mimic (Guillermo Del Toro, 1997)
fields.body:
Mimic (Guillermo Del Toro, 1997)

8pm, Sky Premier

Another superior sci-fi chiller from the Mexican director of Cronos. This has scientists Mira Sorvino and husband Jeremy Northam introducing their genetically modified cockroach-eating bug into New York. Well done. But within years the bug has mutated into a people-eating creature that can take on human shape. Best get down those subway tunnels to find and destroy their nest...

Purple Rose of Cairo (Woody Allen, 1984)

9pm, 3.30am, Carlton Cinema

Woody Allen's warm and witty comedy takes a skewed look at the Hollywood dream factory. Mia Farrow is a downtrodden Depression housewife who seeks solace in the cinema; Jeff Daniels plays the film star who steps out of her favourite movie to take her away from all this. Allen plays cleverly on the comic outrage of the abandoned film characters, and on the difficulties of a highly unusual relationship.

Heat (Michael Mann, 1995)

10pm, FilmFour

Mann's masterly gangster movie uses the familiar tale of cop chasing cunning criminal to set up a deadly contest between two of the screen's most charismatic performers: Al Pacino's driven detective cat-and-mousing with hood Robert De Niro in the coffee shop is a classic scene, both recognising they are two of a kind. The acting throughout is beefy and authentic, the action is superbly staged.

The Violent Cop (Takeshi Kitano, 1989)

12.50am, FilmFour

Like Bad Lieutenant, the title is a pretty succinct description of its protagonist, though Kitano's customary deadpan, edge-of-sanity cop is more like Dirty Harry here. His working method is naturally brutal, but things go into overdrive when he discovers corruption within the force, and the Yakuza get personal. As usual, Kitano is the eye of the hurricane, and the direction is economical but eloquent, interspersed with bursts of violence and climaxing in a gunfight so tough no one even bothers to dive for cover.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Tonight's edition of In Business (8.30pm, Radio 4) may be Peter Day's last. Having seen so many others become overnight millionaires, he's rounding off the season by establishing his own web site and dot-com enterprise. If the various experts he has recruited for the exercise manage to put their mouse where the money is none need ever work again. There is, naturally, no indication of how the company proposes to make its zillions, but that's standard operating procedure in cyberspace.
fields.body:
Tonight's edition of In Business (8.30pm, Radio 4) may be Peter Day's last. Having seen so many others become overnight millionaires, he's rounding off the season by establishing his own web site and dot-com enterprise. If the various experts he has recruited for the exercise manage to put their mouse where the money is none need ever work again. There is, naturally, no indication of how the company proposes to make its zillions, but that's standard operating procedure in cyberspace.

On the first anniversary of her death, Paul Jones launches Remembering Dusty Springfield (10.0pm, Radio 2), first of four programmes looking back on the singer's career. Springfield became one of Britain's top female vocalists in her 20s, getting into the 1963 Top Ten both here and across the Atlantic. This first programme recalls her early days with the Lana Sisters and The Springfields, the folk trio she formed with her brothers. Then came her decision to go it alone.

There is, naturally, no indication of how the company proposes to make its zillions, but that's standard operating procedure in cyberspace. On the first anniversary of her death, Paul Jones launches Remembering Dusty Springfield (10.0pm, Radio 2), first of four programmes looking back on the singer's career. Springfield became one of Britain's top female vocalists in her 20s, getting into the 1963 Top Ten both here and across the Atlantic. This first programme recalls her early days with the Lana Sisters and The Springfields, the folk trio she formed with her brothers. Then came her decision to go it alone.

fields.headline: Enter the dragon
fields.standfirst: It's the longest-running animated series in television history - and a global phenomenon that rivals Pokémon. So the question is: why haven't you heard of Dragonball? That may all be about to change. By  Richard Vine
fields.trailText: It's the longest-running animated series in the world, a global phenomenon shown everywhere from Spain, where its products outsold Olympic mascot merchandise during the Barcelona games, to the States, where it is the top-ranking show on the Cartoon Network across all ages (a figure that's rumoured to have attracted the attention of Disney), and there's a Dreamcast game in production, to follow the Playstation releases. It's about to touch Britain when Cartoon Network launches into the middle of one of the most impenetrable, but rewarding storylines ever on Monday.
fields.body:
It's the longest-running animated series in the world, a global phenomenon shown everywhere from Spain, where its products outsold Olympic mascot merchandise during the Barcelona games, to the States, where it is the top-ranking show on the Cartoon Network across all ages (a figure that's rumoured to have attracted the attention of Disney), and there's a Dreamcast game in production, to follow the Playstation releases. It's 16 years old, and yet the chances are you'll never have heard of it. It's about to touch Britain when Cartoon Network launches into the middle of one of the most impenetrable, but rewarding storylines ever on Monday.

The Dragonball saga stretched for over 500 episodes during its 10-year run in Japan, taking three series (Dragonball, Dragonball Z and Dragonball GT) to tell the story of a young boy, Goku, and his quest to find seven mystic dragon balls said to make a dragon appear and grant a wish to anyone who collects them all.

He learns martial arts from a lecherous old man who lives with talking turtles on a tiny island in the middle of the sea, encounters a world of characters (Raditz, Lunch, Oolong, Vegeta) who all seem to be named after food and drink and intent on proving their superior power levels, measured by some of the weird technology they acquire, and along the way discovers that he's actually an alien, who arrived on Earth in a tiny space pod.

Unlike most cartoons, whose characters are caught in a timewarp where nothing ever changes and no one ever evolves, Dragonball breaks the eternal youth rule by having the characters grow up and offering plot twists and changing elements like a manga EastEnders. Goku gets married, has a kid, and, at the start of Dragonball Z, (where, just to make things even more complicated, we join the action on Monday), finds himself fighting an evil older brother he didn't know he had. The action shifts from tiny villages to huge intergalactic vistas and back again. The Simpsons killing off Maude Flanders is nothing compared to the continual blood-letting and reincarnation that's been going on in Dragonball for years. One character, Trunks, ends up co-existing with two time-travelling versions of himself. Over the three series, Goku's hair grows into a huge mane, and turns blonde as his power level grows from Sai-Yan to Super Sai-Yan status, giving him the ability to destroy planets with his hi-kicks by the end of the series.

If you're already getting confused with the divergent narrative structures in Pokémon, then this is probably not going to get you rushing home. But if you're excited by the idea of a show that takes its inspiration from the same ancient Chinese Journey To The West story that the 80s Buddhist kung fu cult hit Monkey was based on, and then extrapolates wildly, piling on subplot after subplot with wild abandon, careering from martial arts, to slapstick humour, intergalactic qi battles that take weeks to resolve, problems with homework, ostrich farms and cameos from Jackie Chan-lookalikes, then it won't disappoint.

It's easy to overhype something in today's media feeding frenzy, to have a desperate one-night stand with a show, and then wake up in the cold cathode light of day, stumbling to swap your vodka vision for contacts that work as you realise you've been getting a little too infatuated about something that maybe you should have walked away from after the first sly wink in a darkened room. In all truth, there's a severe lack of TV really worth having a serious relationship with, so that good (or, not totally crap) becomes "brilliant", adequate imagination (or, managing to find a new way to squeeze some kind of pond life from the drying carcass of genres X and Y to create Z) passes for "inspired", and when something is actually pretty good, it becomes the best thing ever, and the machine steps in and force-feeds it down your throat with a steady diet of ker-razy mouse mats and fluffy keychains until you want to throw up and never watch it again. And of course, as a quick trip to Chinatown will tell you, there are already plenty of Dragonball items waiting to be consumed. If it's as popular here as it is around the world wherever its shown, then there's a fair chance that it won't be too long before you won't be able to avoid the warriors with hair like architecture. But until then, enjoy one of the most original shows you'll ever fall for.

Dragonball Z, Mon, 5pm, Cartoon Network
