fields.headline: Sex and salvation
fields.standfirst: The gospel according to Jeremy Marks is that men become gay through circumstance, not birth. He runs courses for homosexuals who want to overcome their desires.  Angela Neustatter meets him - and talks to one man he tried to 'heal'
fields.trailText: Jeremy Marks sits in the shadows in a small office in the leafy suburban outskirts of Watford in Hertfordshire. He wears a white sweater with a pastel design, which looks rather incongruous against the austere black and white picture of Jesus hanging on the wall behind him. On the bookshelves in the next room are several copies of a paperback book, Homosexual No More, and Marks's desk is piled high with what he describes as terribly moving letters from homosexual men asking for his help.
fields.body:
Jeremy Marks sits in the shadows in a small office in the leafy suburban outskirts of Watford in Hertfordshire. He wears a white sweater with a pastel design, which looks rather incongruous against the austere black and white picture of Jesus hanging on the wall behind him. On the bookshelves in the next room are several copies of a paperback book, Homosexual No More, and Marks's desk is piled high with what he describes as terribly moving letters from homosexual men asking for his help.

These rooms, in a nondescript three-storey office block, house the "ministry" of the Courage Trust. Here Marks spends his days trying to help men overcome their homosexuality, because the gospel according to the trust is that men become gay through circumstance, not birth, and their erotic desires are the product of arrested development.

Marks says that he is full of compassion for such men, who, he believes, have to spend most of their lives fighting their homosexual demons. It was a quest for release from such "inappropriate" yearnings and a desperate need for acceptance by God that led him to the American evangelical "ex-gay" movement, which burst into the public consciousness in 1998 when 15 conservative organisations began a £300,000 advertising blitz in the US. Newspaper advertisements carried photographs of men and women who had apparently struggled with same-sex attraction, but managed to walk away from their homosexual identities.

The Courage Trust, which Marks set up in Britain in the 80s, was inspired largely by the work of America's National Association for Research and Therapy of Homosexuality. There, campaigners are keen on public declarations of conversion. The testimonies of those such as John Paulk, a former female impersonator, are enthusiastically publicised. Paulk was attending a gay pride demonstration in Ohio when he saw boards carried by anti-gay demonstrators reading "God hates fags" and "Turn or Burn". He says he felt sick and that was the beginning of his conversion. Another famous case is that of Steve Simmons, who spent the early years of his marriage having illicit encounters with other men to satisfy his cravings, but found salvation through the ex-gay movement. He says he is now happy to live as a heterosexual.

Listening to Marks talk of a life in which he felt anguished about his longing for sexual intimacy with other men and the belief that he could never be accepted by God, it is perhaps possible to understand the appeal of the full-on evangelical fervour of the US movement. Marks had a Christian upbringing - he was an Anglican choirboy - and realised well before puberty that he "had erotic attraction to the same sex. It was very disturbing and not what I wanted."

As his yearnings grew, so did his sense of self-loathing. He became more deeply involved with the church, and the words of Leviticus - "Do not lie with a male as one lies with a female; that is detestable" - preyed on his mind. Even so, Marks found himself going to gay clubs where, in his mid 20s, he met a man with whom he had a short-lived relationship. As he remembers, his gently creased face softens. "I wanted to experience what it was like to have some intimacy - it was wonderful."

At the time, he says, he thought: "This really is me, what's the point of fighting it?" But then came the crushing guilt. "My faith was telling me to deny my urges, suppress them while I had a hunger for intimate relationships."

Much of the theory touted by the ex-gay movement and the Courage Trust stems from a book by Elizabeth Moberley, Homosexuality and the Christian Ethic, in which she argues that gay men are trying to compensate for an inadequate bond with their father, so that they are constantly seeking men as replacement father figures. The challenge for these men, she argues, is to form close, loving but celibate relationships with other men so that they can develop beyond expressing their feelings in a sexual way.

Marks claims that in the vast majority of cases where a father has been weak, unsatisfactory or largely absent and a mother "domineering or controlling", men find themselves drawn to other men. However, according to US psychologists who have monitored the ex-gay movement, men who see their homosexuality as an aberration frequently come from deeply authoritarian backgrounds where it is considered immoral or sinful, while others have married but cannot reconcile their family commitments with their feelings.

So how does the ex-gay movement try to make men straight? In the US, there are residential programmes such as the one held by Love in Action, which Marks attended for a year. During that time he lived in an all-male, avowedly celibate house. The non-residential programmes he runs in Watford, held three evenings a month throughout the year, with a residential weekend at the beginning and end, follow the US form with Bible readings, confessional sessions where men can admit to lapses, fantasies and feelings they find difficult to overcome. The idea is that the men can offer each other loving, intimate but celibate friendship and that this will compensate for the loss of bonding with the father figure during childhood, enabling them to move on beyond their homosexuality.

But it doesn't necessarily work, says Andrew Daws, who joined the Courage Trust programme in 1989. He speaks warmly of Marks, describing him as a caring and sincere man, but the programmed didn't change Daws's life. At the first residential weekend, he recalls: "We all stated that our goal was to be married or at least to be able to suppress or ignore our homosexual impulses. But although week after week at the evening meetings we confessed to yet another cottaging lapse or our inability to keep thoughts in check, a veil was drawn over the number of illicit liaisons among members and the number who 'went back to the scene'. At the final weekend we said we had been ambitious in hoping that our problems would go away."

And now? "Suffice to say that we all still have homosexual feelings."

Daws had spent 30 years longing to be free of his homosexual desires. He had a Christian upbringing and was sent to a boarding school for boys where he recalls "rutting like a rabbit and repenting afterwards". At Cambridge university he was "prodigiously sexually active" and guilt-ridden to the point of despair. He married and had "an unspeakably awful" divorce five years later .

Involvement with the US ex-gay movement did not help and so Daws grabbed at Marks's offer, when he met him, to help "finally reconcile my sexuality with my Christianity" by changing his sexuality.

Marks acknowledges that there are men who do not emerge from the programme fully "healed".

"It is part of the journey," he says. But he claims many have gone through his programme and come out at peace. Look at him, he says. He has "matured" to the point where he has been married for nine years to a woman, which has removed "practical temptation" and given him "a sense of peace with who I am".

Opponents of the movement believe there is something fundamentally dangerous and damaging in the idea that a homosexual identity may be processed away. The Reverend Richard Kirker (described by Marks as his "flamboyant opposite number"), who runs the Gay and Lesbian Christian Association, says he is "gay to the core of my being and very happy with it". He dismisses the idea that God and homosexuality don't mix. He believes God is more all-embracing than organisations like the Courage Trust will allow and snorts with laughter at the way they isolate biblical passages to target homosexuals. "The Bible has never been used as an infallible guide. If it were, Christians should stone adulterers to death, refuse to wear clothes of mixed fibre or eat shellfish. What people like Marks are doing is using the Bible in a fundamentalist way to overlay their prejudices and its making a lot of gays very unhappy."

Kirker has no doubt that some men and women are born homosexual and that it is "a human sexuality which in all its richness is a gift of God to be accepted, enjoyed and honoured as a way of expressing love and entirely compatible with the Christian faith".

He sees the ex-gay movement as homophobia disguised as compassion, fuelled by a fundamental loathing of homosexuality which gains credence through their belief that gays are aberrant men who could and should be heterosexual. He talks of the men who come to the Gay and Lesbian Christian Association in crisis after "failing" on an ex-gay programme. He cites a recent television documentary which featured people who had been through various ex-gay programmes and afterwards felt such disgust at the urges they were unable to resist that they tried to cut off their genitals. "The ex-gay movement is dangerous and misguided. There's no such thing as a cured or ex-homosexual."

Daws agrees. Looking back he believes "what was started by my earlier teaching was reinforced and given credence by the ex-gay movement so that for 30 years I learned to deny my emotions and to punish myself endlessly for being unable to control my demonic behaviour".

For him the breakthrough has been finding a way to be homosexual and accepted by God. It happened in San Francisco. "I met happy, well-adjusted gay men, and ones who were Christian as well. I went to the Metropolitan community church - a wonderful pink building full of flamboyant fags singing show tunes and I found really warm supportive spirituality and I never looked back."

fields.headline: Remembrance of flings past
fields.standfirst: As a new Channel 4 series examines the eternal conundrum of the ex,  Bonnie Greer recalls running headlong into hers
fields.trailText: I was hurrying down the street after one of my too infrequent visits to the gym, my head full of the immediate future, my eyes cast in the far distance. He was standing there, just at the bottom of the road, ramrod straight, a smile on his face.
fields.body:
I was hurrying down the street after one of my too infrequent visits to the gym, my head full of the immediate future, my eyes cast in the far distance. He was standing there, just at the bottom of the road, ramrod straight, a smile on his face.

At first, I didn't recognise him and that is the part that haunts me. We hadn't seen one another since I'd married six years before and gradually I had taught myself to forget him. And suddenly, there he was. He hadn't dashed into his car when he saw me, he hadn't run away. He just stood there as if we were two old friends who hadn't seen one another in years, but we had never been friends. We had been more than that and less.

This man was my "ex", a strange term to denote someone who had meant so much. He was not an "ex" anything. I was the "ex" because he was my past, my past waiting for me at the bottom of a long road.

I don't know how other women do it. I don't know how they can have strings of lovers, one-night stands, boyfriends, flirtations, and then run into them and later make a joke about it: "Have you seen his latest, she's awful" etc. I guess I admire them, in a way, because life moves on and time waits for no man and so on. And there he was... time itself, standing there smiling and waiting.

Very few things say more about the passage of time, and the getting or losing of wisdom, than an "ex". A past love takes you back not only to the times you spent together but to the way the world was, too. For example, was that great passion I had then something to do with the dour times of the early 90s when "the waif" look was in fashion and everything was spare and poor? Was that love a way of staving off a feeling of despair in the atmosphere, the austerity, the negative equity of the times?

As I approach him, standing there waiting, I can see he has aged. And if he has, so have I, and I feel myself trying to become younger, doing something young with my body because only youth can explain the way we were. No matter how old you are, true love is always young somehow.

It took me two years to realise I'd never see him again, not even on a friendly basis. It took two years of facing the fact that what I'd thought would last forever had not, that there was no forever. I should have been a big enough girl to have known that. But one of the glories and tragedies of our species is that we believe in eternity, we strive for it, and when it dissolves in our faces, we try harder. An "ex" makes you remember that moment of hope and promise. And so to see a former love again is like seeing the skull beneath the skin.

I finally reach him and I smile my biggest smile. Funny now that I can't remember whether or not we kissed. It is a windy day, so I grab the collar of my coat and gather it around my neck and the lower half of my face. I feel myself shrink a little beside him. Because that's the way I was in the relationship. I see myself doing this, see me making myself smaller, weaker, more vulnerable, but I can't help it. It's the way I want to be with him.

We make small talk. He says something about his partner, I mention my husband. On the surface we are settled, more relaxed, and I am genuinely happy for him, as I know he is for me. But why do I want to yell at him, scream at him, have a knock-down-drag-out fight here in the middle of the street in broad daylight? Why do I want to beat him into a bloody pulp and then spit on him afterwards?

Instead I stand there in the wind, chatting, giggling, feeling the minutes tick past. How astounding that a moment I had thought about for years is finally here, a complete accident, and I look a mess because I've been to the gym.

I'm asking him questions about his life and work, but the only question I had once wanted to ask him was: "Why couldn't you make up your mind, why couldn't you choose me? Why did I have to feel that I had to get the hell out of it before I lost all respect for myself?" I want to say: "I saved myself, buddy, without your help."

There is something cheap and stupid about seeking out an old love. An old love can't explain your life, only you can. And this can only happen within the hard graft of living, of being ruthlessly honest within, and in forgiveness. The forgiveness is the hardest part because it is the most important.

And so, as we part, wishing one another well, I know that that is what has happened. We've forgiven one another.

Bonnie Greer will read from her work as part of the Women In Focus Festival at the British Library on Sunday.

Was that love a way of staving off a feeling of despair in the atmosphere, the austerity, the negative equity of the times? As I approach him, standing there waiting, I can see he has aged. And if he has, so have I, and I feel myself trying to become younger, doing something young with my body because only youth can explain the way we were. No matter how old you are, true love is always young somehow. It took me two years to realise I'd never see him again, not even on a friendly basis. It took two years of facing the fact that what I'd thought would last forever had not, that there was no forever. I should have been a big enough girl to have known that. But one of the glories and tragedies of our species is that we believe in eternity, we strive for it, and when it dissolves in our faces, we try harder. An "ex" makes you remember that moment of hope and promise. And so to see a former love again is like seeing the skull beneath the skin. I finally reach him and I smile my biggest smile. Funny now that I can't remember whether or not we kissed. It is a windy day, so I grab the collar of my coat and gather it around my neck and the lower half of my face. I feel myself shrink a little beside him. Because that's the way I was in the relationship. I see myself doing this, see me making myself smaller, weaker, more vulnerable, but I can't help it. It's the way I want to be with him. We make small talk. He says something about his partner, I mention my husband. On the surface we are settled, more relaxed, and I am genuinely happy for him, as I know he is for me. But why do I want to yell at him, scream at him, have a knock-down-drag-out fight here in the middle of the street in broad daylight? Why do I want to beat him into a bloody pulp and then spit on him afterwards? Instead I stand there in the wind, chatting, giggling, feeling the minutes tick past. How astounding that a moment I had thought about for years is finally here, a complete accident, and I look a mess because I've been to the gym. I'm asking him questions about his life and work, but the only question I had once wanted to ask him was: "Why couldn't you make up your mind, why couldn't you choose me? Why did I have to feel that I had to get the hell out of it before I lost all respect for myself?" I want to say: "I saved myself, buddy, without your help." There is something cheap and stupid about seeking out an old love. An old love can't explain your life, only you can. And this can only happen within the hard graft of living, of being ruthlessly honest within, and in forgiveness. The forgiveness is the hardest part because it is the most important. And so, as we part, wishing one another well, I know that that is what has happened. We've forgiven one another. Bonnie Greer will read from her work as part of the Women In Focus Festival at the British Library on Sunday.

fields.headline: If the hat fits
fields.standfirst: The baseball caps, the silly helmet, the bird's nest and the ugly incident with the rasta tam. Why does he do it?  Matt Wells, who followed Charles on his Caribbean tour, explains how the prince leads with his head
fields.trailText: When Prince Charles visited the slums of Trench Town in Jamaica this week, it was widely agreed that only the second coming of reggae king Bob Marley could have generated more excitement among the islanders.
fields.body:
When Prince Charles visited the slums of Trench Town in Jamaica this week, it was widely agreed that only the second coming of reggae king Bob Marley could have generated more excitement among the islanders.

For many watching back home, however, it all seemed a bit embarrassing. Why did Charles insist on putting a rasta hat on backwards, and not once but three times? Rather predictably, yesterday's papers had little to say about how the population of the impoverished area was working to shed its "yardie" image of crime and deprivation. Or how everyone there loved the prince. There were just lots and lots of words about the hat.

And, of course, the rasta hat wasn't the first evidence of Silly Hat Syndrome to emerge on the royal tour. Each day, Charles seemed determined to don an increasingly clownish headdress. What else could he do but accept the gift of a crown of eagle feathers from the Surama tribe in the Guyanese rainforests last weekend? But did the safari-suited prince really then have to dance around to Amerindian music, wearing what was essentially a bird's nest on his head? And then there was the British Gas hard hat, and not one but two ugly incidents involving baseball caps, none of which went unmentioned in the British press.

It all must be pretty frustrating for a man determined to be taken seriously - and he must have known how it would play back home - so why did he do it?

Part of the answer is that what we read about royal tours tends to be somewhat distorted. The first thing that may not have come across is that in the countries Charles has visited, he has been hailed a hero. In each state - Trinidad and Tobago, Guyana and Jamaica - the reaction has been the same: cheering crowds, saturation media coverage and universal approval. While the prince's enthusiasm has earned him ridicule at home, there it went down an absolute storm. Local journalists were utterly amazed that a man whom they had understood to be aloof and arrogant could display such warmth and understanding. For them, the photo opportunities are not the PR stunts they may have appeared to be back in London.

In any case, British newspapers are in a tricky position when it comes to criticising Charles for playing the performing monkey. We, the journalists, stunted many of the pictures that have gained most prominence from this Caribbean tour: we persuaded the deprived children in Port of Spain to hand a baseball cap to Charles, reporters and photographers encouraged Rita Marley, Bob's widow, to give the rasta hats to the prince and goaded him into trying one on; the media made sure that a line-up of sexy limbo dancers was just in shot as the prince left a culture performance staged in his honour.

So is it really fair to set him up, only to use the stunt as an excuse to knock him down later? The royal reporters travelling with the prince's party believe so; after all, the prince doesn't have to put on the hats, he has no obligation to talk to the parrots, and he didn't need to play the pan drums in such a ridiculous fashion. "He's been doing this job for 30 years; he should know by now," says one experienced hack.

It is indeed obvious that Charles must have a shrewd understanding of how the media works - after all, he's managed to completely revamp his image since his ex-wife's death - and he knows that without a picture, the stories of his tour would never make the papers at all, let alone the front pages. He is probably betting that such stunts will not only go down well with the locals, but will also, on some level, boost his reputation as a lovable and kind man back home.

He is certainly making a big effort with the press. During his royal tours, for instance, he has made himself far more accessible than ever before. St James's Palace makes all the travel arrangements; journalists travel in the prince's private jet, the royal rat pack separated from the future monarch only by a thin partition. At the start of the tour and again at the end, the prince strolls to the back of the plane to chat to the press. It is a routine so familiar now that reporters don't rush to the phone later to file the exclusive.

On location, hacks and the royal household share drinks by the pool. "A few years ago, we'd be climbing up those palm trees outside to get pictures of this lot in here," one photographer says.

Now, the prince realises that he needs the media to get his message across, and accepts that he is going to take a few knocks along the way. At an agricultural project in the foothills of the Blue Mountains in Jamaica, the prince was presented to a ram that had fathered 150 kids in its short life. Turning to the photographers who were waiting to snap the prince with the stud, Charles joked: "I suppose you want me to act the goat."

There is a limit, though, and there remains a question over whether Charles knows where it is. What is not on offer, though, is a return to the past when the media actively colluded with the royal family to prevent the publication of stories that would have been detrimental to the institution. "We must not let in the daylight upon magic," Walter Bagehot once warned. Now, in the blaze of the camera flash, everyone knows how the tricks are done.

fields.headline: Wizards of Oz
fields.standfirst: Circus Oz was the original new circus, swapping punks for clowns. As they prepare for their first visit to Britain in 10 years,  Lyn Gardner meets them
fields.trailText: The curtain rises slowly. In the centre of the stage is a miniature big top. The tent structure begins to wobble and out of it rises the unmistakable figure of the Queen. Her Majesty is pleased to note that 51 per cent of the people have voted to keep her particular circus. This is the surreal world of Circus Oz, the Australian company that has put politics (including last year's referendum on the monarchy), fun and meaning into the sawdust ring.
fields.body:
The curtain rises slowly. In the centre of the stage is a miniature big top. The tent structure begins to wobble and out of it rises the unmistakable figure of the Queen. Her Majesty is pleased to note that 51 per cent of the people have voted to keep her particular circus. This is the surreal world of Circus Oz, the Australian company that has put politics (including last year's referendum on the monarchy), fun and meaning into the sawdust ring.

Twenty-two years ago a group of radical theatre-makers in Melbourne decided to run away and join the circus. The result was Circus Oz, credited with being in the forefront of a worldwide movement that has become known as new or contemporary circus. Circus Oz has achieved what British circus still dreams of: the creation of an inclusive, popular, hybrid art form and the spawning of a vibrant, nationwide circus culture.

It is 10 years since Circus Oz last performed in Britain. In that time, British audiences have discovered that circus doesn't necessarily mean sad elephants and corny clowns. They have thrilled to lunatic daredevils Archaos riding their motorbikes, responded to the lyric simplicity of European companies such as Cirque Ici, and can't seem to get enough of the soft focus Canadian outfit Cirque du Soleil, which offers an experience akin to a musical such as Cats.

There is a sense in which circus, once relegated to a field on the outskirts of town, has gone mainstream. Cirque du Soleil packs out London's Royal Albert Hall, otherwise home to extravagant opera productions and the Proms. Later this year another slickly produced Canadian outfit, Cirque Eloise, will play the Barbican, better known as the London home of the Royal Shakespeare Company. Companies such as Circus Ronaldo and Cirque Ici regularly perform at big international theatre festivals. Aerialists and tumblers are at the centre of the government-approved Dome. It is a long way from Something Wicked This Way Comes. Now that body piercing is part of the high street, even the circus as freakshow has been forced to redefine itself.

Much has changed but in the world of new circus, costumes, music and spectacle are often deemed more important than physical skills. That's why Circus Oz's irreverent, act-based style is a breath of fresh air. The punky, tattooed performers may look as if they've been let loose from another zany planet, but their attempts to negotiate flaming high wires, dive through hoops and parachute using dirty washing are recognisably human. Failure is as much part of an Oz performance as success.

Mike Finch, the company's artistic director since 1998, believes that in the 22 years of its existence, Circus Oz has come full circle. The great innovator of new or contemporary circus is now finding that it has more in common with traditional circus than it would ever have thought possible.

"What we do is very much real circus. It's not what you see some new companies doing, which is a ballet about circus. Aesthetically we may not have much in common with traditional circus, but we do in terms of craft. It's like setting out to make a piece of art out of wood. It is different from making a piece of furniture, but you may find that you can learn a lot from the old-style cabinet maker."

Which raises the question: what is so new about new circus? Finch believes that it is all in the eye. "What contemporary circus did was to take the act and say, 'What if we cross-dressed it or did it in slow motion?' Almost all those things have been done now and what we have discovered is that a chair is still a chair, however you upholster it. The real challenge for a circus director is in understanding the frame."

It's also in walking the tightrope between creating a piece of work that is both artistically interesting and physically sustainable. "Acrobats are not empty vessels like actors. They arrive with the script in their bodies," says Finch. "They see things in a very different way to a director. A split second idea means two months of training for them to perfect the craft. Creating a circus act is the opposite of other creative acts. You go into a room, lock the door and just repeat it and repeat it until you get it right."

Oz proves that you can turn the craft into an art if it is contextualised and politicised. The company came out of the radical movements of the 60s and 70s and in its early days was famed for its in-your-face politics. If the performances are tamer now, they are still grounded in the idea that to build a human pyramid you need all sorts of people and that a small group working to achieve the impossible is a political statement in itself. This is reflected in the company's largely non-hierarchical structure: administrators, technicians, performers and musicians are afforded the same status and people change roles according to their personal circumstances. Finch himself began at Circus Oz in 1992 on work experience.

In our culture, circus is more than an act of skill: it is a fantasy. Part of the appeal of Circus Oz is that it represents a whole mythology. In setting up the circus, the original founders - mostly middle class, university-educated people working in theatre - did what so many of us dream of but are too scared to do. Finch is keen to play down the romance angle but points out that if you spend six months hanging from someone else's hands or trusting your life to the person doing your rigging, family-like relationships do develop.

On stage, this is reflected in a performance that works like a piece of brilliantly orchestrated chaos and which is made memorable by the sense that what you are witnessing is a simultaneous celebration of the ensemble and the individual.

Stylistically, the show has much in common with the aggressive energy of stand-up comedy. Its genius is in the framing: each act has an individual flavour that both subverts and salutes traditional circus acts and mirrors our own ordinary lives. Those who try to juggle their busy schedules will see themselves reflected in an act which begins with a man taking a shower and develops as he tries to juggle and get dressed at the same time. The high wire performance turns into a statement about sexual politics and the changing relationships of men and women as two leather-clad, whip wielding women force a man wearing a skirt to walk the wire.

Throughout the evening the performers look surprised by their own prowess and are endearingly unfazed when things go wrong. "What I love about Circus Oz," says Finch, "is that we never play pretend with the audience. It is real. The juggler has the balls and the walker is on the wire and the audience may go 'wow', but they're compelled to believe it because they've seen it with their own eyes. They don't have to suspend disbelief. And they also know that if the performers fall, they will get hurt."

fields.headline: Tantrums and tiaras
fields.standfirst: This week Elton John stormed out of his own Broadway musical. But, says  Oliver Burkeman, he won't be the last star to indulge in a good old hissy fit
fields.trailText: There are a number of possible reactions to yesterday's Broadway-paralysing news that Elton John, the noted spendthrift and knight of the realm, had noisily flounced out of a preview performance of his $15m Disney musical based on Verdi's Aida - besides the most obvious one, viz, "What in the name of all that is holy is Elton John doing making a $15m Disney musical based on Verdi's Aida?"
fields.body:
There are a number of possible reactions to yesterday's Broadway-paralysing news that Elton John, the noted spendthrift and knight of the realm, had noisily flounced out of a preview performance of his $15m Disney musical based on Verdi's Aida - besides the most obvious one, viz, "What in the name of all that is holy is Elton John doing making a $15m Disney musical based on Verdi's Aida?"

One reaction is cynicism: Sir Elton, after all, has flounced out of so many things so often (from a Versace show a few years back, for example, simply because two fashion magazine staffers were having an argument near him) that it's tempting to believe these outbursts are written into his contract. Another is incredulity, since the songwriter's explanation for his hissy fit - that the techno-pop orchestration of his work felt "dated" - sounded, coming from a man with a passion for rococo interiors, golden cherubs and Louis XIV wigs, not a little rich. But another is admiration, if only because of the style of his flounce.

All the essential components of a classic of the genre were present. There was no hanging about: a mere 15 minutes into his reworking of Verdi's opera, Elton decided he'd had enough. He did it in company, reportedly leaving New York's Palace Theatre "dragging his entourage of four young men with him". And he did it raucously, clambering over audience members to exit his mid-row seat. This was a kind of Arrival of the Queen of Sheba in reverse.

Above all, though, Elton had the wisdom to flounce out of one of his own works. This is essential: flounce out of a performance in which you have no creative investment, and you risk appearing as preposterous as Barry Gibb, whose stroppy exit from the studio of Clive Anderson Talks Back achieved the astonishing feat of catapulting the Bee Gees even further down the scale of public esteem than previously. Or Tracey Emin, executing a sort of combined flounce/stagger from Channel 4's Turner Prize programme in 1997. Or Sean Connery at a 1998 Tony Awards party, annoyed at having to stand in a queue for a while.

Flounce out of a project to which you have given your soul, however, and you join a star-studded tradition. Recent alumni include Carly Simon, who stormed out of a rehearsal for her opera Romulus Hunt demanding that her name be removed from all publicity for the work. The historical master of the art, though, is Igor Stravinsky. Crowds rioted at the premiere of The Rite of Spring in Paris in 1913, and stormed out of the theatre. Stravinsky, sensing the moment, decided to storm out after them.

Cinema provides more fertile ground for the dedicated flouncer. The greatest recent specimen was executed last month by Jim Carrey at a Beverly Hills press conference for Milos Forman's Man on the Moon, in which Carrey plays the comedian Andy Kaufman. It was, admittedly, a provoked flounce: at the conference executive producer Bob Zmuda unzipped his fly, removed a rubber penis and pretended to urinate over Carrey's table. Carrey accused Zmuda of being drunk, fetched a jug of iced tea, poured it over the producer's head and stomped off.

The only problem with Elton's latest tantrum is the sneaking suspicion that it is another artist who ought to be doing the flouncing: Giuseppe Verdi, the man whose opera plot he has unceremoniously filched. "Obviously, there is the opera by Verdi that is very solemn and operatic and theatrical," Elton has noted. "This is also very theatrical, but it's very... I would say, very camp. More along the lines of Dream Girls or The Rocky Horror Picture Show."

Or as Verdi might have put it, had he lived to receive the nausea-inducing news that the creative zenith of his career was going to be turned into a ballad-ridden musical by Elton John complete with techno-pop orchestration: "It's a little bit funny, this feeling inside..."

Or Sean Connery at a 1998 Tony Awards party, annoyed at having to stand in a queue for a while. Flounce out of a project to which you have given your soul, however, and you join a star-studded tradition. Recent alumni include Carly Simon, who stormed out of a rehearsal for her opera Romulus Hunt demanding that her name be removed from all publicity for the work. The historical master of the art, though, is Igor Stravinsky. Crowds rioted at the premiere of The Rite of Spring in Paris in 1913, and stormed out of the theatre. Stravinsky, sensing the moment, decided to storm out after them. Cinema provides more fertile ground for the dedicated flouncer. The greatest recent specimen was executed last month by Jim Carrey at a Beverly Hills press conference for Milos Forman's Man on the Moon, in which Carrey plays the comedian Andy Kaufman. It was, admittedly, a provoked flounce: at the conference executive producer Bob Zmuda unzipped his fly, removed a rubber penis and pretended to urinate over Carrey's table. Carrey accused Zmuda of being drunk, fetched a jug of iced tea, poured it over the producer's head and stomped off. The only problem with Elton's latest tantrum is the sneaking suspicion that it is another artist who ought to be doing the flouncing: Giuseppe Verdi, the man whose opera plot he has unceremoniously filched. "Obviously, there is the opera by Verdi that is very solemn and operatic and theatrical," Elton has noted. "This is also very theatrical, but it's very... I would say, very camp. More along the lines of Dream Girls or The Rocky Horror Picture Show." Or as Verdi might have put it, had he lived to receive the nausea-inducing news that the creative zenith of his career was going to be turned into a ballad-ridden musical by Elton John complete with techno-pop orchestration: "It's a little bit funny, this feeling inside..."

fields.headline: God of small things
fields.standfirst: Chardin was an illiterate 18th-century artist who painted bowls of fruit, soup tureens, cups of water - and made them poetry. Now his champion, Louvre director Pierre Rosenberg, is bringing his work to London. Jonathan Jones talks to him
fields.trailText: "It's very difficult to speak of Chardin. I mean he's the reverse of an artist you can speak of." Pierre Rosenberg is one of the most powerful men in French culture. Yet his office in the Louvre is modest and donnish, with art books arrayed on a big table and assistants chatting next door.
fields.body:
"It's very difficult to speak of Chardin. I mean he's the reverse of an artist you can speak of." Pierre Rosenberg is one of the most powerful men in French culture. Yet his office in the Louvre is modest and donnish, with art books arrayed on a big table and assistants chatting next door.

A member of the Academie Française, président-directeur of the Museum du Louvre, and curator of the Chardin exhibition that opens at London's Royal Academy next week, Rosenberg is the world's foremost authority on this strange and seductive 18th-century French artist. Jean-Siméon Chardin, born in Paris in 1699, and the most idiosyncratic and modern artist of the 18th century, painted nothing but domestic scenes and still lifes. Pierre Rosenberg published his first book on the artist for the legendary modern art publisher Skira in 1963; he mounted a previous definitive retrospective of the artist in 1979. Returning to Chardin now, he says, is "a great rest, a great pleasure".

It's also, perhaps, his duty as guardian of the French national patrimony. There's something "very French" about Chardin and it goes to the heart of the national culture and its exportability. The 18th-century critic and philosopher Diderot enthused about Chardin's still lifes as if directing readers to re-create them at home - "suspend a river bird by one leg. On the dresser below imagine some biscuits..." and today you can get that Chardin feeling by shopping for French produce at your local supermarket. On a table arrange some paté and a glass of red wine and you've got that particular French aesthetic of the everyday that appears for the first time in Chardin's paintings and made him a cult figure for modern French artists and writers. The sense that food and wine are themselves culture still pervades French art and life. It's what everyone who eats a slice of Brie is buying into.

The titles of Chardin's paintings convey this perfectly. Preparations for Lunch. A Lady Taking Tea. Or - in a rare moment of violence - A Soup Tureen with a Cat Stalking a Partridge and Hare. Across the river at the Musée d'Orsay, you can see this desire to pay attention to the little things running right through French modern art. The museum is full of paintings that directly quote Chardin. Take some apples, put them on a table, and Chardin's recipe gives you Cézanne. All the great French artists in the second half of the 19th century, points out Rosenberg, adored Chardin. "Manet, Van Gogh, Cézanne - all of them".

They were painting the same world, the world of middle-class pleasures - a world that French culture has dramatised and beautified better than any other. The girls walking through a Monet field are descendants of the lady taking tea in a Chardin genre painting or one of Chardin's scullery maids.

We come back to what Rosenberg says about Chardin being "the reverse of an artist you can speak of". What he means is that there is no history visible in Chardin's pictures. They depict a world absolutely cut off from great public events - a world where nothing seems to happen. "When you speak of David you have French history, Napoleon, heroes - there's nothing of this sort with Chardin. So it's very difficult for art critics to speak of Chardin."

This turning away from the big narrative of history is not a coincidence, he says, it's what made Chardin subversive, even revolutionary in his own century. In the 18th century, history painting was the top genre and every other kind of art was inferior. Still life was tosh. "What was most respected in an artist was the fact of being able to invent. To have imagination; to be able to transform the Bible or Tacitus into an image." The closer art got to real life, the less elevated it was because it was regarded as mere craft, mere skill: only the painter who imagined events in history or myth was a true artist.

Chardin wasn't up to it. Really, says Rosenberg, he couldn't do it. The son of a master cabinet maker, he never had the academic training to be a history painter - he never learned how to animate bodies, how to construct a crowd scene. His still lifes and scenes of everyday life were painted in the opposite way from history painting - by looking. And, argues, Rosenberg, Chardin turned his weakness into a strength.

Rosenberg believes that Chardin is not as silent as he seems. That his painting embodies a philosophy. Eighteenth-century France is where modern exhibitions and art critics began. Every two years a huge public exhibition, the Salon, was held at the Louvre and passionately reviewed. The most famous reviewer was the Enlightenment philosopher Diderot and he adored Chardin.

"For Diderot, meeting Chardin was a coup de foudre" says Rosenberg. "In a certain way, the idea that Diderot had about art is very much the idea of Chardin. Chardin was a man who had thought a lot about what art could do but had not been trained; and he uses Diderot to express his ideas."

This is a very controversial idea; Diderot is regarded the father of modern art criticism. Now Rosenberg is saying he got it all from the supposedly inarticulate and ignorant Chardin. The painter whom contemporaries sneered at as barely literate - he may not have been able to write - was in fact a great philosopher of art. Daring, but it's based on Rosenberg's intimacy with Chardin. These paintings are philosophies: they are ideas. It's thought you can't resist when looking at the calm and clarity with which Chardin puts a glass of water. And that very modern, clear-eyed way of looking at things is what Rosenberg says this art is all about, That's what Diderot says it is about - the "magic" of seeing the world clearly. Paying attention. Seeing what is there.

"Chardin is painting what he sees. He's really painting only what he sees, I think - a child playing or flowers or what you like. By copying what you see you are able to give objects a beauty, a nobility. In a way this is the great idea of Proust when he writes about Chardin in 1895... it is, I think, in a certain way what both Chardin and Diderot thought."

Paris is currently full of Proust books, riding on the back of Raul Ruiz's film Time Regained - you can even buy a Proust cookery book. If you look hard enough you can find Proust's essay on Chardin which Rosenberg says is "fundamental" to understanding the artist. In the article Proust takes a jaded young aesthete to the Louvre and shows him Chardin's still life paintings. Because Chardin found a glass of water or a cup of tea "beautiful to paint", says Proust, he teaches us to find the things themselves "beautiful to behold". Looking at his art, "we see the beauty of the these objects through the eyes of Chardin," as Rosenberg puts it

On the way out I brush against a little green glass object on his desk - don't worry, he says, it's not valuable. Just something with a personal meaning. One of the half-forgotten things we live with, that we scarcely notice, that mean everything. What he would like, says Rosenberg, is for people to look at the paintings in the Chardin exhibition for a long time and give them the attention they need.

Chardin is at the Royal Academy of Arts, London W1, from March 11-May 29. Details: 0171-300 8000.

fields.headline: The girls can't help it
fields.standfirst: It's been billed as a cat fight, but there's more to the battle between the editors of Marie Claire and Company than meets the eye.  Polly Vernon  explains
fields.trailText: You could be forgiven for imagining that, at some point over the past week, the just-about-decorous backstage proceedings of women's magazines exploded into one bloody, bitter bun fight. That editors were pitched against each other at dawn, that MAC was smeared, Sam McKnight dos ripped from the roots. Because borders had been transgressed, words had been had. There isn't any going back.
fields.body:
You could be forgiven for imagining that, at some point over the past week, the just-about-decorous backstage proceedings of women's magazines exploded into one bloody, bitter bun fight. That editors were pitched against each other at dawn, that MAC was smeared, Sam McKnight dos ripped from the roots. Because borders had been transgressed, words had been had. There isn't any going back.

It began with a silly enough column of the post-Bridget Jones variety. Liz Jones, editor of Marie Claire (the politically concerned woman's Cosmo), cooked up a regular pitch for a lover in the Sunday Times' Style section, called The Single File. "Forget Bridget Jones," trumpets the intro. "It's LIZ JONES. [Same name, see?] And she's real. The thirtysomething editor of Marie Claire has been on the shelf for years. And it's not for want of trying."

Jones had herself waxed, hunted for outfits that would straddle the divide between chic and fuck-me, ditched a man because he couldn't lip synch to Macy Gray - and regurgitated it all for Style fans' reading pleasure. You know the kind of thing: Sex And The City grooming regimes merge with pop culture references and Helen Fielding-speak to hilarious ends. For hilarious, read a bit neurotic, really.

Which is where it would have ended, if she hadn't given the column a little extra plug via an interview in London's Evening Standard. An interview that also suggested a teenage eating disorder and her ongoing dissatisfaction with her appearance were related to women's depiction in magazines: "I grew up anorexic, obsessive. I didn't want to date. I thought I was too ugly because I spent every moment looking at Janice Dickinson on the cover of Vogue."

Two days later Sam Baker, editor of Company (the unthinking woman's Cosmo), responded. Women's magazines, she claimed in the Standard's media section, were not a bastion of body fascism. Far from planting the seed of physical discontent, they had supported, nurtured, championed her and were at least partly responsible for moulding her into the fabulously well-rounded being she is today: married, with a high-powered job. Women's magazines, Baker claimed, had always been her friend.

Liz Jones has yet to reply (though fellow Times columnist India Knight defended her last Sunday: "Hands up who wants to be 'friends' with her magazine?" she asked of Company. "Me neither"). But you can bet she's seething. There is more at stake, you see, than personal face. Admittedly, it's tricky not to mistake this incident as a scrabble to self-publicise. Though Marie Claire's circulation has experienced an upsurge since Jones took over, the magazine is lagging behind Vogue and Elle in terms of cultural authority. Company, meanwhile, has suffered a steady decline. Following the release of last month's ABC figures, it's easy to imagine Baker's bat phone ringing off the hook as her personal PR machine badgers her to appear, write, soundbite spew and generally turn into a multi-headed, multi-faceted, multi-media monster.

But there is more to this than a simple battle for editor supremacy; Baker and Jones are each struggling to prove that theirs does something no other magazine does. That behind the glitz and gratuitousness is a giggly, uncertain, flawed, fluffy yet self-aware group of women. Baker and Jones are busily divorcing themselves from the myths they perpetuate. They are better than all that. And so is their product - even if there's no evidence in the pages. They know, they hurt, they bleed, they cry over their chubby ankles, then they think: to hell with it, there's more to life than the gym. At which point they curl up on their sofas with a happy, sexy brand of foodstuff (Häagen-Dazs, say), just like you, sweet reader.

These are tricky times for women's magazines. Caught between the politics of the moment, post-political correctness, the fading spectre of the All Saint/Sara Cox hybrid, the backlash against FHM etc, and a cultural aesthetic that values mild-mannered, David Beckham-style prettiness above all else, they find themselves wallowing in hypocrisy. Add to this advertisers who want to place their product only in a suitably aspirational environment and it all gets a little frantic.

The bottom line is: readers aren't good enough. Too humdrum, too plain, too poor. They have to be. It's pure economics. Tell your readers they're OK and they won't buy the beauty products you peddle. Tell them they're happy, well-adjusted, accomplished and they'll stop trying to cure their existential angst by consulting your glossy life bible.

The "real people" regularly featured (official purpose, to reflect readers' lives; unofficial purpose, to let readers know they should be more like this and less like themselves) have to be vetted for fatness, ugliness, bad hair, suspect taste and dull lives. The pieces that dwell on the misery of eating disorders, the never-say-diet editorial policies, inevitably ring hollow when flatplanned alongside the fashion pages. The constant chinks of insight into celebrity lifestyles serve to remind readers just how limited and suburban their own existences are. All of which makes them shop, not to mention subscribe for more meticulous analysing of their shortcomings.

I know all this because I write for Minx, a women's magazine whose proposition bounces between a desire to be smart and funny and irreverent and feel-good, and also aspirational, glamorous and just that little bit prettier than anything has a right to be. Sometimes they manage it, sometimes they don't. It's really, really hard. The point that Jones and Baker are missing is this: women's magazines are not about helping women feel better. Quite the opposite. They're silly, vacant, extravagant and often cruel. Like the fashion industry, they can't help themselves. When a thing is superficial at its core, no amount of pseudo-clever reasoning from the editors, no amount of soul-baring, no amount of spin or pop political conscience will save it. None of which means it can't also be fun.

Jones and Baker should give this one up. Stop defending the indefensible. Stop looking for ethics in an immoral medium. It certainly won't help you get a boyfriend, Liz.

fields.headline: No 1586 Susanne Riess-Passer
fields.body:
Age: 39.

Appearance: Long lost sister of Cherie Blair and GMTV's Lorraine Kelly.

Status: Vice chancellor of Austria, and the new leader of Jörg Haider's Freedom party.

That bunch of good-for-nothings? But she looks rather nice. Careful, Susanne doesn't like that word. She much prefers her nickname, King Cobra. "It's far better than just being thought of as nice and kind."

Yikes. So she ousted Haider in a titanic battle of wills, then? Er, no. Before resigning as a result of some sticky protests, Haider hand-picked Riess-Passer as his successor.

Still, he must be relieved to hand over to such a formidable political operator. Um, no again. Despite her ridiculously menacing moniker, Riess-Passer's political record is patchy at best.

Go on... She didn't exactly excel at masterminding the party's campaign in last year's European elections when its vote slumped. And her 1998 campaign against the euro was another disastrous flop.

How did she get the job, then? Looks? Unlikely. The dashing Haider has declared himself unmoved by the feminine charms of his colleagues. "I've never met an erotic female politician. It does damage to almost all women."

Years of parliamentary experience? Sad to say, no again. The bulk of her experience within the party is first as a press officer, then as Herr Haider's private secretary.

Still, it's good to see the first female vice chancellor. Well yes, except that the Freedom party's policies on women - such as encouraging them to stay home and have babies - are not in general viewed as pro-feminist. The new coalition government has already abolished the department of women's affairs.

Help me out here - what should we expect from a Riess-Passer Freedom party? Put it this way, asked for her manifesto on assuming Haider's mantle, her reply was: "Continuity."

Don't say: Interesting coincidence that Riess-Passer and Hitler share a home town - Braunlau.

Also don't say: Kinder, kirche, küche, anyone?

How did she get the job, then? Looks? Unlikely. The dashing Haider has declared himself unmoved by the feminine charms of his colleagues. "I've never met an erotic female politician. It does damage to almost all women." Years of parliamentary experience? Sad to say, no again. The bulk of her experience within the party is first as a press officer, then as Herr Haider's private secretary. Still, it's good to see the first female vice chancellor. Well yes, except that the Freedom party's policies on women - such as encouraging them to stay home and have babies - are not in general viewed as pro-feminist. The new coalition government has already abolished the department of women's affairs. Help me out here - what should we expect from a Riess-Passer Freedom party? Put it this way, asked for her manifesto on assuming Haider's mantle, her reply was: "Continuity." Don't say: Interesting coincidence that Riess-Passer and Hitler share a home town - Braunlau. Also don't say: Kinder, kirche, küche, anyone?

fields.headline: End of the Ikea affair
fields.standfirst: It was billed as the company that brought Scandinavian style to Britain at flatpack prices. But, says Anna Tims, the reality of shopping at Ikea can be very different - and she has a postbag of angry readers' letters to prove it
fields.trailText: Ikea, if you heed the hype, blasts fresh pine-scented air into the stale atmosphere of the British establishment. John Prescott reputedly called in the firm last year to furnish the new parliamentary building, Portcullis House; meanwhile the Tories sat at Ikea tables and chairs during their 1998 party conference. "Good quality and low price," trumpets the publicity. "How do we do it?"
fields.body:
Ikea, if you heed the hype, blasts fresh pine-scented air into the stale atmosphere of the British establishment. John Prescott reputedly called in the firm last year to furnish the new parliamentary building, Portcullis House; meanwhile the Tories sat at Ikea tables and chairs during their 1998 party conference. "Good quality and low price," trumpets the publicity. "How do we do it?"

One answer lies in the pile of readers' letters that the Guardian has collected in the past two years, letters which seem to point to a quite astonishing disregard for customer service. The trouble starts if you find - as you often will - that your "good quality" purchase is damaged, that various vital components are missing, or that your goods fail to materialise altogether on successive appointed delivery days. Then, when you attempt to gain redress, you realise why the prices are "low".

"The team is down to its bare bones," says a spokesman, explaining why, as usual, the Guardian can't speak to anyone at headquarters. "It's part of the Ikea concept to keep things frugal and cut costs, and if two or three people are away in head office it's a problem finding anyone you can talk to."

This would explain why calls to the customer service centre - you can't call the stores directly - can result in a wait of up to half an hour and a promised callback that often doesn't come. And why, if you do get through to report dud goods, the onus is on you to return them. "We do ask customers to post the goods back to us if they are unable to return them themselves," says a spokeswoman, helpfully - a weighty operation if, like reader Jonathan Ben-Ami, it's a 2m-high wardrobe.

Then there are the cases of Jonathan Lorie, James Sloan and Ben Timmis, all of London. They each recently ordered Ikea kitchens. Lorie eventually acquired his after two missed delivery appointments, only to find that three items were missing.

Seven weeks and many promises later, he was still waiting. Sloan's delivery also lacked crucial components, and included an incorrect work surface and an extra cupboard which he was told to send back himself. Eleven calls to the helpline got him nowhere and, after three months with an unusable kitchen, he spent several more calls persuading Ikea to take back the whole thing. Timmis' experience was almost identical.

Ikea has promised that its customer services are expanding, but that this will "take some time". Equally stretched is its delivery firm Hays, which regularly misses appointments - five times in the case of Jillian Le Jeune of New Malden. Ikea last year confessed to a "logistical problem" and was obliged to extend waiting times by two weeks to cope with demand.

"We are aware of the occasional difficulties and frustrations that some of our customers encounter," says Matti Naar, UK marketing director. "Ikea is a high-volume operation, that's how we keep our prices so low. But the tremendous demand is one of the main causes of the problems." Such problems could, he believes, be solved if the company could double its 10 UK stores, but "the current presumption against edge-of-town development makes it difficult for us to find new sites".

The difficulty for consumers is that Ikea doesn't need to worry about their grievances. Why should it when demand is so large that those with internet access are advised to check a live photo of their local Ikea carpark before risking what could turn out to be a two-hour queue (a service of limited use since Ikea doesn't always update its pictures).

Ikea's UK profit amounted to £522m last year, and 130m people visited 150 branches in 28 countries. Ikea likes to claim that it is steered not by figures but by "vision", including an environmental empathy which is belied by the huge blue and yellow hangars on open ground and traffic jams for a mile around.

Unlike most retail businesses, it declines to adapt to local markets, preferring to evangelise Swedishness and what it calls "democratic design" - a problem for Ben Timmis, whose kitchen units were not designed to accommodate the English system of exposed piping. Employees are referred to as co-workers, some of the stores are run as franchises and last October a day's profits were split among its 4,000 UK staff.

It's a pity that this cosy cameraderie doesn't extend to customers. The company has endeavoured to maintain a small-management philosophy, appropriate 50 years ago when Ingvar Kamprad founded it as a mail order business, but often ineffective when running a worldwide empire. To compensate for its minimalist staffing levels, stores are governed by a "system" and the system can do no wrong.

The system assured John Gath of Sheffield that the dining set he wanted was in stock and could be delivered. When it failed to appear at the collection point, the system told him it was inaccessible. By then the system was showing that the goods weren't in stock after all - the only solution would be for him to return the next day. In fact, the dining set had been in the collection point all the time with its label hidden. The same system tells multiple customers that the goods they require are in stock, but, when they hire a van and arrive at the store, there are none available. One reader, wanting three footstools, found only two on the shelves, the other three being aloft in storage and too dangerous to reach during opening hours.

The system only permitted two such stools to be out at any one time, and anyone who wanted three would have to make two trips. Nor was it possible to request a third to be forklifted down overnight: Ikea only sells what's on the shelf: no advance orders are allowed.

Ikea argues that stripping overheads to the bare essentials is what keeps prices low. But that has its own cost. Last year, it was discovered that, to meet its relentless quest for bargains, Third World manufacturers were employing child labour and furniture makers in eastern Europe, who were existing in inhuman conditions on wages of 17p an hour.

The irony is that those cheaper prices are deceptive, being up to 75% higher here than on the Continent. Competition in the UK, where Ikea has 4% of the furniture market, is so poor that it can undercut it without sacrifice, but the company insists the reason is the government's stern view of out-of-town retail centres which prevents them expanding (an unconvincing moan given 25m shoppers visited its UK stores last year).

Yet when it's good, it's very good. The returning droves are testimony to the fact that reasonable furniture can be had at reasonable prices. But this success is what has undermined Ikea's service. IKEA simply can't cope with the demand but, while the demand continues, has little incentive to reform. The attitude is that the customer is privileged to shop there and there's an extraordinary arrogance about a store which commands a nation to become more Swedish, erects signs telling drivers they have two more hours to wait, and holds customers captive, requiring them to circulate the entire store in one direction before permitting escape.

But maybe that's part of its charm. "Ikea," says its publicity notes, "has its roots in Smaland... where the harsh countryside demands thrift, inventiveness and hard work."

webTitle: P&G brings delight to the ad business

fields.headline: P&G brings delight to the ad business
fields.standfirst: American consumer goods group spends £165m bolstering brands in Britain
fields.trailText: Procter & Gamble - the American conglomerate whose brands range from Sunny Delight to Fairy Liquid - and the government have topped a new league table of Britain's biggest advertisers.
fields.body:
Procter & Gamble - the American conglomerate whose brands range from Sunny Delight to Fairy Liquid - and the government have topped a new league table of Britain's biggest advertisers.

The US consumer goods empire and the central office of information spent more than quarter of a billion pounds between them on television and newspaper advertising, billboards and cinema last year.

P&G, which has its British base on Tyneside, is by far the country's biggest advertiser. It spent £165m promoting 160 brands last year - £70m more than its nearest rival.

The group's biggest outlay was £8.3m to encourage consumers to switch from squash to Sunny Delight, the orange drink which became the most successful grocery product launch of the 1990s.

Some £7m was earmarked to launch of the group's Secret deodorant last year. Other big P&G brands that command multi-million pound campaigns include Pantene, Fairy Liquid, Ariel and Always.

The league table, compiled by AC Nielsen MMS and Marketing magazine, shows that the government is now pouring £1.7m a week into advertising - more than 50% more than in 1998.

The Action 2000 millennium bug campaign cost £9m, and promotions for the army and Action for Jobs and the inland revenue's Hector the Inspector campaign also soaked up millions of pounds.

The COI was the largest press advertiser in 1999, buying £26m of space. Electrical retailer Currys was the second biggest newspaper advertiser with a £25m spend.

The government is also the biggest radio and cinema advertiser, while the tobacco industry dominates billboards, spending £29m a year on roadside campaigns.

Television company ONdigital recorded the biggest leap in advertising expenditure. Its near £34m outlay, including the television commercials featuring Chris Tarrant, was a 458% increase on 1998.

Although the huge leap was a result of the company only having launched in 1998, it is now spending almost the same as its larger rival, BSkyB.

Marks & Spencer pulled out all the stops and spent more than £21m on advertising in an attempt to halt its sliding sales. Until last year the retailer had spurned traditional advertising but as its profits plunged, it sanctioned a 254% increase in its advertising spend.

Elsewhere, the banking group HSBC increased its outlay by 307% to £21m as it set about rebranding Midland Bank with a high-profile television advertising campaign.

But it was still outspent by NatWest - which laid out nearly £28m to reinforce its brand strength just before it succumbed to the takeover bid from Royal Bank of Scotland.

fields.headline: On message
fields.trailText:
• Broker's break
Patrick Smith, former managing director of Norwich Union's direct insurance arm, has left to set up an online general insurance broker called Its4me.co.uk . The service, which goes live in June, promises customers savings of 15% on premiums and covers motor, home and travel.
fields.body:
 Broker's break
Patrick Smith, former managing director of Norwich Union's direct insurance arm, has left to set up an online general insurance broker called Its4me.co.uk . The service, which goes live in June, promises customers savings of 15% on premiums and covers motor, home and travel.

 On offer
The ISP founded by Nina Brink, World Online International is coming to the stock market with a value of up to €12.1bn (£7.4bn).

The company said it will sell 20% of its shares at between €35 and €43. The offer price will be announced on March 16 and trading is set to start on the Amsterdam stock exchange on March 17.

 Partners
America Online will look for partnerships rather than acquisit- ions in its attempt to provide wireless email and other services, chairman Steve Case said yesterday. AOL this week announced deals with Sprint PCS, BellSouth and others to catch competitors like Yahoo which signed on with wireless carriers last year.

 Visitors
Online travel specialist Ebookers.com said it had 1m website visitors in February, an increase of more than 41% over January's 708,000.

webTitle: Blackpool's future looks in the pink

fields.headline: Blackpool's future looks in the pink
fields.standfirst: Gay market helps revitalise seaside town's ailing entertainment business
fields.trailText: In the trade it is known simply as an expanding leisure chain named ITP. Few people these days spell out the initials - In The Pink - because the enterprise long ago moved from a novelty undertaking to a serious empire which helps underpin the economy of Blackpool during the off-season.
fields.body:
In the trade it is known simply as an expanding leisure chain named ITP. Few people these days spell out the initials - In The Pink - because the enterprise long ago moved from a novelty undertaking to a serious empire which helps underpin the economy of Blackpool during the off-season.

In a small first floor office between the Flying Handbag pub and the Flamingo nightclub, Basil Newby happily plots further expansion and enthuses about his boldest move so far - franchising his premier brand, a camp cabaret spot titled Funny Girls, around Britain and beyond.

With an annual turnover of around £4m, and a real estate empire worth another £8m, ITP might at first seem a modest business, concentrated entirely in Basil's beloved Blackpool. But as one of Britain's largest gay enterprises, embracing not only the Flamingo but five other bars and clubs, it is anything but small time, small town.

Newby, a former Pontin bluecoat, would-be French teacher and one-time fancy goods shop owner, is now poised for his biggest deal so far - conversion of the big Odeon cinema across the road from his office into an entertainment and shopping complex, complete with specialist health centre, for the gay community. He wants to make it into the world's biggest gay disco.

A small, fast-talking, amusing man with an easy west Lancashire lilt, he refuses to discuss his forty-something age or his millionaire cult status in the old resort. "Child entrepreneur, born in the 1960s," he laughs.

"I don't just sit down and think I'm a guy worth all this money, isn't it wonderful," he smiles. "Things have just happened, that's all. I've got a nice house [in a nearby village], nice car [a BMW 8 series]; that's it."

Newby's parents ran a theatrical boarding house across the road from Blackpool's Imperial Hotel. There he met Norman "over the garden wall" Evans, Hylda Baker, Max Bygraves, and many more. He also developed a taste for showbiz. After boarding school in Wales, he went to a teacher training college in Blackpool - but left after two years to start a fancy goods shop, which he named Gone Gay. "We sold rings at 99p each and a vast range of naughty toys."

After a year or so he sold out, banked the £15,000 plus from the sale, and joined Pontins in Devon as a bluecoat "to chill out".

Two years later he returned to Blackpool and bought the Flamingo with his savings and a bank loan. It then had a capacity of 200. Soon he decided to turn it into a gay club. Twenty years later, and "several million pounds on", it has a 2,000 capacity and opens seven days a week. "It's one of the largest gay clubs in Europe," he says proudly. "We use our own design team to continually refurbish it. You can't stand still in this business."

Then he bought a succession of other premises - Pepys Bar, Basil's on the Strand, the Flying Handbag and then Funny Girls - with the full co-operation of the local council and the licensing magistrates.

They balked at only one of his suggestions. He wanted to turn a pub named the Kings Arms into the Whippet Inn. "They said, 'we don't think so, if you don't mind', so I said how would you take to the Flying Handbag and they had a bit of a laugh and said yes.

"They've been great. No problems. Don't forget, I was the first gay person to have a club licence in the town."

Success soon bred success. The big brewers, once so hostile to his enterprise, were desperate to come on board once they saw the value of the pink pound in Blackpool.

But when he started 20 years ago, things were very different. "No brewers wanted to be involved and only Vaux [the late Sunderland brewer] would lend us any money," he recalls.

"I remember going to one of the biggest brewers, and when I said I wanted help and it was a gay club they turned away and faced the wall. Wouldn't look at me. A few years later they things had changed. They were desperate to come in."

Newby's big breakthrough came six years ago when he opened Funny Girls in Blackpool's Queen Street. He wanted an all-singing and dancing cabaret joint -camp, over the top, yet suitable for all the community.

While the bar staff are all in drag, the shows sometimes outrageous, he reckons that only 10% of the clientele is gay. "We get a good mix, all types - celebs from Coronation Street and the soaps. It's very safe and secure."

He has already been approached by the First Leisure group to franchise the Funny Girls brand in a converted London theatre. "Michael Grade put the idea to me. I was a bit nervous at the time - could we keep up the standard we have in Blackpool?" So he did not proceed.

He thinks, however, that the franchising idea has great potential. "But I wouldn't open anywhere outside Blackpool. You either love it or hate it, and I love it. It's like Las Vegas on heat."

Newby's next big idea is to take over the old Odeon cinema, once licensed for up to 3,500 people.

It comes within a redevelopment area, and he has already signed a contract with developers. "If if goes pear-shaped they'll have to buy it back from us, but I don't think that will happen.

"I want to make it a gay complex with a small and a large disco, a gay shopping mall and a gay health centre. We'll even incorporate a Whippet Inn this time."

He sees great potential for turning Blackpool into the Las Vegas of Europe. "It has to move away from being a family resort - those days are gone.

"Families can go abroad so cheaply now and get guaranteed sun, so you have to move on. So my idea would be to develop more casinos, have more neon lights, more excitement - a hit-you-in-the face kind of place."

The boss of ITP also knows that his enterprise is central to Blackpool's economy, with Funny Girls now as well known as the tower and the golden mile. "The good thing is that people come to our venues throughout the entire year, stay in [50-plus] gay hotels, use taxis and local shops and theatres, go on the piers. They're not just helping me, but helping to keep a lot of other businesses going as well."
