Newby, a former Pontin bluecoat, would-be French teacher and one-time fancy goods shop owner, is now poised for his biggest deal so far - conversion of the big Odeon cinema across the road from his office into an entertainment and shopping complex, complete with specialist health centre, for the gay community. He wants to make it into the world's biggest gay disco. A small, fast-talking, amusing man with an easy west Lancashire lilt, he refuses to discuss his forty-something age or his millionaire cult status in the old resort. "Child entrepreneur, born in the 1960s," he laughs. "I don't just sit down and think I'm a guy worth all this money, isn't it wonderful," he smiles. "Things have just happened, that's all. I've got a nice house [in a nearby village], nice car [a BMW 8 series]; that's it." Newby's parents ran a theatrical boarding house across the road from Blackpool's Imperial Hotel. There he met Norman "over the garden wall" Evans, Hylda Baker, Max Bygraves, and many more. He also developed a taste for showbiz. After boarding school in Wales, he went to a teacher training college in Blackpool - but left after two years to start a fancy goods shop, which he named Gone Gay. "We sold rings at 99p each and a vast range of naughty toys." After a year or so he sold out, banked the £15,000 plus from the sale, and joined Pontins in Devon as a bluecoat "to chill out". Two years later he returned to Blackpool and bought the Flamingo with his savings and a bank loan. It then had a capacity of 200. Soon he decided to turn it into a gay club. Twenty years later, and "several million pounds on", it has a 2,000 capacity and opens seven days a week. "It's one of the largest gay clubs in Europe," he says proudly. "We use our own design team to continually refurbish it. You can't stand still in this business." Then he bought a succession of other premises - Pepys Bar, Basil's on the Strand, the Flying Handbag and then Funny Girls - with the full co-operation of the local council and the licensing magistrates. They balked at only one of his suggestions. He wanted to turn a pub named the Kings Arms into the Whippet Inn. "They said, 'we don't think so, if you don't mind', so I said how would you take to the Flying Handbag and they had a bit of a laugh and said yes. "They've been great. No problems. Don't forget, I was the first gay person to have a club licence in the town." Success soon bred success. The big brewers, once so hostile to his enterprise, were desperate to come on board once they saw the value of the pink pound in Blackpool. But when he started 20 years ago, things were very different. "No brewers wanted to be involved and only Vaux [the late Sunderland brewer] would lend us any money," he recalls. "I remember going to one of the biggest brewers, and when I said I wanted help and it was a gay club they turned away and faced the wall. Wouldn't look at me. A few years later they things had changed. They were desperate to come in." Newby's big breakthrough came six years ago when he opened Funny Girls in Blackpool's Queen Street. He wanted an all-singing and dancing cabaret joint -camp, over the top, yet suitable for all the community. While the bar staff are all in drag, the shows sometimes outrageous, he reckons that only 10% of the clientele is gay. "We get a good mix, all types - celebs from Coronation Street and the soaps. It's very safe and secure." He has already been approached by the First Leisure group to franchise the Funny Girls brand in a converted London theatre. "Michael Grade put the idea to me. I was a bit nervous at the time - could we keep up the standard we have in Blackpool?" So he did not proceed. He thinks, however, that the franchising idea has great potential. "But I wouldn't open anywhere outside Blackpool. You either love it or hate it, and I love it. It's like Las Vegas on heat." Newby's next big idea is to take over the old Odeon cinema, once licensed for up to 3,500 people. It comes within a redevelopment area, and he has already signed a contract with developers. "If if goes pear-shaped they'll have to buy it back from us, but I don't think that will happen. "I want to make it a gay complex with a small and a large disco, a gay shopping mall and a gay health centre. We'll even incorporate a Whippet Inn this time." He sees great potential for turning Blackpool into the Las Vegas of Europe. "It has to move away from being a family resort - those days are gone. "Families can go abroad so cheaply now and get guaranteed sun, so you have to move on. So my idea would be to develop more casinos, have more neon lights, more excitement - a hit-you-in-the face kind of place." The boss of ITP also knows that his enterprise is central to Blackpool's economy, with Funny Girls now as well known as the tower and the golden mile. "The good thing is that people come to our venues throughout the entire year, stay in [50-plus] gay hotels, use taxis and local shops and theatres, go on the piers. They're not just helping me, but helping to keep a lot of other businesses going as well."

fields.headline: Iceland considers bidding for Bhs
fields.trailText: Iceland, the supermarket chain, is considering making a bid for the ailing general retailer Bhs.
fields.body:
Iceland, the supermarket chain, is considering making a bid for the ailing general retailer Bhs.

The North Wales-based food group yesterday confirmed it had made a tentative approach about buying Bhs from its Storehouse parent company, but insisted that no offer had been made.

The chain, which made its name in frozen food but has recently built a reputation as a campaigner for food safety by outlawing genetically modified food and artificial additives, recently struck a deal to open up to 100 food halls in Bhs stores.

Malcolm Walker, the Iceland chairman, believes the group's new image and range of fresh and chilled food means he can take on Marks & Spencer's food halls in town centres. He describes his shops as "the same as M&S but with a quid off".

Last night a source close to the company said Iceland had no intention of "getting into general retailing". He said: "They are keen to ensure the rollout of the full 100 food halls goes ahead."

If a bid is eventually made, Iceland could bring in a partner or do a deal with the existing management to run the non-food parts of the business.

The loss-making Storehouse, which also owns Mothercare, said last week that it had received a number of approaches to buy its businesses. Its shares have collapsed from 300p less than two years ago to just 30p in recent weeks. But since news of the bid approaches they have recovered slightly, closing up p at 43p last night. At that price Storehouse is valued at less than £200m. Iceland shares lost 18p to 256p.

fields.headline: Speculation over Vodafone-Bell rival
fields.trailText: Shares in SBC Communications and BellSouth rose sharply yesterday on the back of reports that the companies were to merge their mobile phone operations. The new network could have more than 16m customers across America competing against the operation planned by Britain's Vodafone and Atlanta-based Bell Atlantic.
fields.body:
Shares in SBC Communications and BellSouth rose sharply yesterday on the back of reports that the companies were to merge their mobile phone operations. The new network could have more than 16m customers across America competing against the operation planned by Britain's Vodafone and Atlanta-based Bell Atlantic.

Telecoms companies are racing to provide national wireless coverage for the growing number of customers unhappy about the cost and difficulty involved in using their phones outside their local area.

Neither SBC, the largest US phone company, nor BellSouth would report yesterday on their talks, which are believed to have been off and on for the past two years.

The Wall Street Journal reported that the recent talks were "fluid and could break down". However, the report was enough to send shares in west coast-based SBC up more than 8% at midday and those in BellSouth up more than 5%.

Both had been trading at or near 52-week lows before yesterday's reports as investors worried about increased competition and their lack of national coverage. Investors are increasingly keen to buy telecommunications companies with a worldwide reach. Vodafone's relationship with Bell Atlantic and acquisition of AirTouch in the US was cited as one factor for its successful attempt to win investor support for its Mannesmann bid.

The Vodafone/Bell Atlantic operation is expected to have more than 20m customers. Vodafone Airtouch closed down 3p at 352 yesterday.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: The London market has gone bio-barmy. Technology, in the bits and bytes sense, is pretty well old hat and the new army of private investors has moved on to a new frontier of science.
fields.body:
The London market has gone bio-barmy. Technology, in the bits and bytes sense, is pretty well old hat and the new army of private investors has moved on to a new frontier of science.

Cambridge Antibody was the one that got the juices flowing yesterday, soaring from £23.62 to £37.25 following its genetics deal with Human Genome Sciences. Back in November, the shares were 200p.

The "moves in sympathy" in the drug sector were astonishing. Cantab Pharmaceuticals surged 86p to 497p, Oxford Asymmetry was up 35p at 525p, Scotia Holdings jumped 27p to 189p, while SR Pharma ended the session 41p higher at 478p.

This action all showed through in the TechMark 100, which takes in biotechnology stocks as well as internet and computing issues. The index leapt 210.1 points to 5,342.37 - a move of just over 4%.

But then the FTSE 100, which might have been expected to be moving in the opposite direction given its "old economy" tilt, was also in sparkling form, chalking up a 132.3 point rise to 6,364.9.

This was partly due to the fact that the big tech stocks were also moving head sharply - isys jumped from 950p to £10.32 and Sema was up 117p to £14.73, while telecoms up-start Colt Telecom surged from £36.31 to £40.75 - a new high.

Amongst the big drug stocks, meanwhile, AstraZeneca put on 95p to £21.54 after news that its hypertension treatment Atacand Plus had gained EU "mutual recognition" in 12 countries.

At the same time, there was continuing interest in old fashioned "defensive" stocks, such as PowerGen, which added 31p to 467p as investors speculated on the utilities companies turning themselves into telecoms companies.

A few rungs down the corporate ladder, Photo-Me International leapt 62p to 277p. Shares in the com pany, which has ambitious plans for to install thousands of internet booths in railway stations and the like, have drifted badly from their mid-January highs, when the stock was changing hands for as much as 470p apiece.

Against this, the price of online auctioneer QXL.com was marked 37p lower to £17.60 - apparently in reaction to the indicative pricing of the coming Lastminute.com flotation.

One or two of the banks were under pressure, as the storm over cash machine charges intensified. Lloyds TSB fell from 583p to 567p, and Barclays lost 50p to £14.76.

webTitle: Pit poser: RJB in plea for aid to keep mines open

fields.headline: Pit poser: RJB in plea for aid to keep mines open
fields.standfirst: RJB Mining yesterday saw its shares plunge to a record low of 27p after delaying its annual results for a month in a last-ditch push for government aid to save four of its 13 pits from closure,  writes David Gow.
fields.trailText: RJB Mining yesterday saw its shares plunge to a record low of 27p after delaying its annual results for a month in a last-ditch push for government aid to save four of its 13 pits from closure, writes David Gow.
fields.body:
The group, whose shares peaked at 620p three years ago, is relying on political pressure from MPs and local coalfield leaders to persuade the government to stump up £73m in operating aid over the next three years.

Pointing out that the German, French and Spanish coal industries enjoyed annual subsidies of £4bn, RJB said it was uncertain whether the British industry would be helped.

RJB's founder, Richard Budge, said its results, which had been due to be published today, would be announced on April 5 - five days after the planned closure of Ellington colliery in Northumberland with the loss of 400 jobs.

Ellington was originally due to close on Tuesday but was reprieved in case ministers agreed to subsidies to help British coal compete against cheaper imports.

Clipstone pit, near Mansfield, is to close in September with the loss of 200 jobs while a further two unnamed collieries employing around 1,000 miners are on the death-list. RJB employs some 8,000 miners.

fields.headline: OFT looks at BSkyB rights
fields.standfirst: 'Exclusive' film and sports acquisitions under fire
fields.trailText: British Sky Broadcasting's acquisition of exclusive film and sports transmission rights will come under scrutiny in the impending review of its market position, the office of fair trading said yesterday.
fields.body:
British Sky Broadcasting's acquisition of exclusive film and sports transmission rights will come under scrutiny in the impending review of its market position, the office of fair trading said yesterday.

The regulator, which in January announced its intention of reviewing BSkyB's position in the market, was inviting comment from the broadcasting industry as a whole to determine whether the company has a dominant position and whether that power was being abused.

The call for comment came on the first day of the competition act taking effect, which gives the OFT much stronger powers of redress on competition issues.

A review of BSkyB's uneasy relationship with the cable industry took place in 1996, and would remain the focus for the present inquiry, the OFT said.

Issues under review include the price charged to carry Sky channels on other platforms, including cable and digital competitors, such as ONdigital. The terms of reference of the review have had widely differing interpretations.

BSkyB prefers to see the review as a prelude to the relaxation of regulation, arguing that the pay-TV sector has become a far more competitive environment since 1996.

The consolidation of the cable industry has created more powerful rivals - notably, Cable & Wireless Communications merging with NTL while Telewest is moving into programming with Flextech.

"We remain hopeful that the review will result in the removal of outdated rules and unnecessary burdens on this company," said a spokesman for BSkyB.

ONdigital, the joint venture between Carlton and Granada, prefers to hope that the review may prise open the market further by reducing the levy paid for Sky channels.

"We want regulatory intervention to ensure that premium television products, notably sports and movies, are available to more people at the best possible price," an ONdigital spokesman said.

fields.headline: Brewers bubble on takeover talk
fields.trailText: It has been quite some time since the beer sector saw so much froth in its collective share price. And for two of the major players - Scottish & Newcastle and Whitbread - the excitement has not come a moment too soon.
fields.body:
It has been quite some time since the beer sector saw so much froth in its collective share price. And for two of the major players - Scottish & Newcastle and Whitbread - the excitement has not come a moment too soon.

Both companies will drop out of the FTSE index of top 100 shares this month unless something dramatic ignites their performance. But as with all the best stories, a cliffhanger is developing which looks likely to keep everyone guessing until the last moment.

But, in the countdown to the FTSE decision, the sector's trickle of news has turned to a deluge and yesterday rumours about the intentions of Belgian company, Interbrew, electrified prices. The group, which is the fourth largest brewer in the world with brands such as Stella, has unexpectedly shut down its London operation. This was only a small presence, as Interbrew's produce - accounting for about 6% of the UK market - is brewed in Britain under licence by Whitbread whose shares climbed 9p to 533p.

However, the axing of the UK office and jobs is being seen as the prelude to a takeover bid either for the whole of Whitbread or for the brewing arm of Bass, whose shares shot up by 46p to 717p. Kronenbourg is regarded as an alternative target, although that company is said to be in the sights of Scottish & Newcastle (up 10p a 420p) which produces the brew under licence in Britain.

Insiders at Whitbread deny that the closure of the Interbrew office holds any significance, saying it had first been mooted a year ago. And a spokesman for Interbrew denied the action would change its relationship with Whitbread, saying that the Belgian group was "quite happy".

He made it clear, however, that Interbrew is determined to play a role in the consolidation of the brewing industry and, at current prices, the privately owned group would have little difficulty in finding sufficient cash to mop up the cream of Britain's beer makers. If prices were to rise, however, speculation suggests that Interbrew might dust down plans to float a third of its shares on the stock market in a move which could put a value of more than £4bn on the enterprise.

fields.headline: £1bn boost from genomics deal
fields.standfirst: Record high for Cambridge Antibody
fields.trailText: Drug development company Cambridge Antibody Technology yesterday announced an alliance with one of the world's biggest genomics companies, sending its market value soaring to more than £1bn.
fields.body:
Drug development company Cambridge Antibody Technology yesterday announced an alliance with one of the world's biggest genomics companies, sending its market value soaring to more than £1bn.

The firm is to share technology with US-based Human Genome Sciences, which has a library of more than 12,000 genes. The company is investing $67m (£42m) in CAT, in return for help developing medicines that target these genes.

CAT's shares rocketed by £13.62 to £37.25 on the news, valuing it at £1.02bn. The price has surged seven-fold in two months, in the stock market's rush for hi-tech biotechnology.

CAT's chief executive David Chiswell said: "We've been on a good roll for a while. We're getting together a run of deals so people can see we really do have the possibility of getting lots of drugs into the clinic and into trials."

The company has a unique method of isolating human antibodies - weapons naturally produced by the body to fight illness - and wants to match these with genes that Human Genome Sciences has linked to the cause of diseases.

Mr Chiswell said: "They were one of the first to drive the commercialisation of gene sequencing. They have all the information on where genes are found."

Human Genome Sciences has a controversial policy of securing patents over genes. It recently won exclusive rights to research a gene considered the "docking point" for the Aids virus. Under the terms of the agreement, CAT will choose 24 targets to attack from the company's biological "library". It will develop six products alone, in return for milestone payments and royalties to Human Genome Sciences. The two companies will share costs and profits equally on the other 18.

Analysts said the most likely areas of research would be blood diseases such as leukaemia. Human Genome Sciences is paying an immediate $12m to CAT in cash, and will invest $55m in a 6% stake of the company.

Analysts welcomed the deal but stressed that it was a long-term project. John Savin of Greig Middleton said: "It's quite difficult to see them making money for many years."

 Diagnostics company Axis-Shield has signed a deal under which German group Bayer will develop its technology for predicting heart attacks. Its shares jumped 162.5p to £11.

webTitle: United wants to sell supply business sale

fields.headline: United wants to sell supply business sale
fields.trailText: United Utilities, the north west multi-utility struggling to cope with regulatory price cuts and increased competition, yesterday put its gas and electricity supply business up for sale.
fields.body:
United Utilities, the north west multi-utility struggling to cope with regulatory price cuts and increased competition, yesterday put its gas and electricity supply business up for sale.

The group has decided to sell its Norweb Energi subsidiary rather than expand the business through acquisition.

It is the first big strategic move by the group since John Roberts took over as chief executive last September. It is de signed to take advantage of the electricity generators' rush to buy supply operations.

A United Utilities spokesman said Norweb Energi had 2m electricity customers and 400,000 gas customers at a time when a supply business was thought to need more than 4m customers or its own generating capacity. Norweb lost 213,000 customers last year as competitors entered the electricity market.

Industry sources said the leading contenders to buy Norweb Energi were British Energy, PowerGen, National Power and foreign groups such as RWE and Eléctricité de France. Analysts thought the business was worth £350m- £400m.

United Utilities, which includes North West Water, intends to retain Norweb Distribution, which owns and operates the wires and cables between the national grid and customers.It also wants its Vertex services business to retain Norweb Energi's customer service contract.

The heavily indebted United Utilities is expecting to see turnover fall by about £140m this year as a result of price cuts imposed by the water and electricity regulators. It plans to float its telecom business within a year and Vertex within four.

A United Utilities spokesman said Norweb Energi had 2m electricity customers and 400,000 gas customers at a time when a supply business was thought to need more than 4m customers or its own generating capacity. Norweb lost 213,000 customers last year as competitors entered the electricity market. Industry sources said the leading contenders to buy Norweb Energi were British Energy, PowerGen, National Power and foreign groups such as RWE and Eléctricité de France. Analysts thought the business was worth £350m- £400m. United Utilities, which includes North West Water, intends to retain Norweb Distribution, which owns and operates the wires and cables between the national grid and customers.It also wants its Vertex services business to retain Norweb Energi's customer service contract. The heavily indebted United Utilities is expecting to see turnover fall by about £140m this year as a result of price cuts imposed by the water and electricity regulators. It plans to float its telecom business within a year and Vertex within four.

webTitle: Retail sales rising at their fastest for three years

fields.headline: Retail sales rising at their fastest for three years
fields.trailText: Britain's high streets enjoyed bumper sales in February, while manufacturing once again wilted under the renewed strength of the pound, figures showed yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain's high streets enjoyed bumper sales in February, while manufacturing once again wilted under the renewed strength of the pound, figures showed yesterday.

Retail sales grew at their fastest pace in more than three years, according to a survey from the Confederation of British Industry. A separate snapshot of the manufacturing sector, from the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply showed activity at its lowest level since last May.

Yesterday's numbers highlight the dilemma facing policymakers at the Bank of England as they prepare for their interest rate setting meeting next week.

The Bank hopes raising interest rates will prevent household spending from outrunning the capacity of the economy and sparking inflation, but it is also propelling sterling's rise against foreign currencies and damaging manufacturing.

The CBI yesterday called for the Bank to keep rates on hold next week, pointing to evidence from its survey of retail prices falling for the first time on record.

"With growth set to cool in March and prices expected to dip further, the clear message from this survey is that interest rates can be kept safely on hold next week," said Alastair Eperon, chairman of the CBI's distributive trades panel.

But some analysts said the evidence that high street sales are gathering pace was likely to tip opinion on the monetary policy committee in favour of higher rates.

"Although the CBI noted that prices are reported to be lower than a year ago, that is unlikely to be enough to convince the hawks on the monetary policy committee that price pressures will not build in the face of rising consumer demand," said Michael Hume, UK economist at Lehman Brothers, "We feel these data are likely to help make the case for a rate hike next week."

However, Bank policymakers have cast heavy hints that they may keep rates on hold next week, to avoid giving sterling further momentum.

webTitle: Chatroom hush: Deutsche and Telefonica silent on merger rumour

fields.headline: Chatroom hush: Deutsche and Telefonica silent on merger rumour
fields.trailText: Technicians arrange flat-screen units on the Deutsche Telekom stand at the CeBIT computer fair in Hanover yesterday as Deutsche, and Spain's Telefonica, were keeping quiet over a report that the two were in merger talks.
fields.body:
Technicians arrange flat-screen units on the Deutsche Telekom stand at the CeBIT computer fair in Hanover yesterday as Deutsche, and Spain's Telefonica, were keeping quiet over a report that the two were in merger talks.

The speculation that the two might be thinking of joining forces was sparked by a report of recent merger talks in yesterday's Wall Street Journal. The report also suggested that the German company could be looking at opportunities in the US.

The latest outbreak of merger fever comes at a time when pressure on the leading companies to build alliances is intensifying.

Deals such as Vodafone Airtouch's acquisition of Mannesmann and the recent battle for control of Cable & Wireless HKT - the leading telecommunications provider in Hong Kong - are adding to investor demands for companies to develop global strategies against a background of a diminishing number of available potential partners.

Deutsche Telekom suffered a setback last year when it intervened in the battle for Telecom Italia. It lost out there to Olivetti, at the same time damaging its links with France Telecom.

fields.headline: BMW reshuffles the Rover pack
fields.standfirst: How 'strategic' is the UK group?
fields.trailText: What are BMW's real intentions for its Rover car business in Britain - specifically for the Longbridge plant near Birmingham? The question is of immediate significance, as Mario Monti, the European competition commissioner, will be in London today to discuss the government's £152m aid package contribution to the £1.7bn regeneration of Longbridge with Stephen Byers, the industry secretary.
fields.body:
What are BMW's real intentions for its Rover car business in Britain - specifically for the Longbridge plant near Birmingham? The question is of immediate significance, as Mario Monti, the European competition commissioner, will be in London today to discuss the government's £152m aid package contribution to the £1.7bn regeneration of Longbridge with Stephen Byers, the industry secretary.

Outwardly Rover still occupies what Professor Joachim Milberg, BMW's chairman, calls a strategic position within the German car group's future progress as an independent company.

This week in Geneva, in public and private, Prof Milberg and fellow board members went out of their way to reassure Britain that the aid package would be approved - "not if but when" - and plans to build a medium-sized car with a distinct Rover identity to compete in the sector dominated by the Golf, Focus and Astra would proceed.

But in his interview with the Guardian, Peter Forster, the production director, reshuffled the cards violently, suggesting that the investment might not go ahead because of the unstoppable strength of sterling - whatever the outcome of Mr Monti's deliberations. His comments suggest that the BMW board, split asunder just over a year ago, remains deeply divided between hawks and doves on Longbridge.

This is hardly surprising, given the horrendous losses Rover has chalked up under BMW tutelage. But there is more at stake here. For months, Ferdinand Piech, VW's chairman - thwarted in his Rolls-Royce ambitions by BMW - has mounted a campaign of destabilisation against his southern German rival, wooing the Quandt family to sell its 48% stake to him and letting rumours of deals over Rover go unanswered.

In Geneva the talk was that Wolfsburg, VW's head office, was the sinister source of weekend stories that BMW would build the new Rolls-Royce in Germany and simply ship it to the UK for finishing .

The fact that a 40-strong design team had been working on the new Roller in a Park Lane safe house for 18 months and was reviewing five British sites did nothing to deter the "dirty tricks" tales.

This is unsettling for Rover's depleted workforce, and it is time that Europe, the DTI and BMW came clean, while Herr Piech would be better occupied in restoring his group's profit margins.

Ultimately BMW may decide it wants to eschew volume in an overcrowded market and retain only the niche players, such as Land Rover, MG, the Mini and Rolls. The sooner it decides Rover's fate the better - and better also for the more profound debate about whether the UK really wants to remain a manufacturing nation.

Buzz moves on
Move over dot.com, the City's latest buzzword is gene. The market's hunger for anything hi-tech has spread from the internet to the drugs sector - with astonishing speed.

Share prices appear to have been injected with steroids - Celltech, for example, was worth £3.7bn last night and could soon be the first biotech start-up to reach the FTSE 100.

Cambridge Antibody Technology is valued at over £1bn, despite having just four products in clinical trials, while Oxford Glycosciences commands a price tag of £880m. Only a few months ago, both were considered tiddlers with appeal to addicts only.

Those with memories reaching back only four or five years will remember that the market has been here before. That bubble burst, helped by the British Biotech fiasco.

Enthusiasts point out that there is an excuse this time - the human genome project. The much-vaunted mapping of every gene in the body could lead to a whole new generation of medicines, with blockbuster products for companies in on the act.

Those who can claim even a remote link to the project have done best - Nycomed Amersham, which makes machines to examine genes, surged by a third yesterday after mumbling in an uncertain manner about spinning off its technology arm.

However, messing about with pharmaceuticals is a dangerous business. Many of those investing in the burgeoning market are private punters, encouraged by their success with internet stocks. Biotech stocks are more complicated - those without a PhD will struggle to understand the exact nature of Oxford Glycoscience's business.

Furthermore, profits can be even further off than they are in cyberspace. Clinical trials take up to five years and the commercial success of drugs is far from predictable.

The biggest problem with the biotech boom is that it tempts companies to raise more money, spend more on research and put back profits even further. It is great news for science, but a mixed blessing for long-term investors.

fields.headline: Meacher to shame 'green slackers'
fields.trailText: Dozens of top companies will be named and shamed this month for failing to take environmental issues seriously.
fields.body:
Dozens of top companies will be named and shamed this month for failing to take environmental issues seriously.

The environment minister, Michael Meacher, said yesterday that many leading businesses are using "voluntarism" as an excuse for doing nothing.

He warned that he would name the laggards and that the government would resort to legislation if companies continued to ignore demands to improve. He suggested that the fundamental review of company law could recom mend mandatory environmental reporting - a move Mr Meacher said he would welcome.

"The days of secrecy are over," he said. "There are still many slackers out there. I have my eye on you and will name you publicly in the near future if you don't make an effort."

Mr Meacher is expected to use the latest research on environmental reporting - due out later this month at a conference organised by the pensions industry research group Pirc - to expose top companies that have failed to respond to years of govern ment pressure. About 30% of the top 350 companies still make no reference to environmental issues in their annual reports.

In the ninth year of these awards, organised by the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants, only 65 British firms produced a separate environmental report.

This included only 39 FTSE 100 companies. Yesterday Mr Meacher announced that the government's advisory committee on business and the environment, ACBE, would lay down what companies should report, so there would be no excuse for failing to address green performance. The chairman of a working group set up to develop the guidelines is Gerry Acher, a senior partner in accountancy firm KPMG.

Mr Acher said: "Ten years' encouragement has produced only 39 environmental reports from FTSE companies. We have got to find a way of speeding up."

He said good environmental performance should be reflected in share prices. "We must demonstrate that businesses which follow sustainable development are worth more than those which don't."

webTitle: Notts woo Asian fans on back of Shoaib

fields.headline: Notts woo Asian fans on back of Shoaib
fields.trailText: Nottinghamshire have launched a membership recruitment drive in curry houses, mosques and Asian community centres to capitalise on the popularity of their latest international newcomer, the Pakistan paceman Shoaib Akhtar.
fields.body:
Nottinghamshire have launched a membership recruitment drive in curry houses, mosques and Asian community centres to capitalise on the popularity of their latest international newcomer, the Pakistan paceman Shoaib Akhtar.

The signing of the man nicknamed the "Rawalpindi Express" has already seen membership rise by 25% this year, and the club has now translated 2,500 membership forms into Urdu and is sending them out to areas where there is a high Asian population.

"Considering the amount of people from ethnic minorities living in Nottinghamshire we have a very low percentage of Asian and black members," said the club's commercial manager Bashar Hassan. "Shoaib's signing has presented us with an ideal opportunity to encourage more Asian families to get involved at Trent Bridge."

Pakistan were frustrated yesterday by the former Sri Lankan captain Arjuna Ranatunga, who defied a broken left thumb to guide his team to a two-wicket win in the first Test at Rawalpindi. The visitors had stuttered to 177 for eight before Ranatunga and Romesh Kaluwitharana carried them home with an unbroken stand of 43.

Australia extended their record run to 14 one-day matches without defeat as Michael Bevan's 107 helped them to a five-wicket win over New Zealand at Napier.

Huge fishing nets will be erected over stands to stop fans throwing water bottles at players in the second Test between India and South Africa at Bangalore which starts today.

fields.headline: Vintage Giggs uncorks Bordeaux
fields.standfirst: Giggs 42, Sheringham 84
fields.trailText: Neatly taken goals by Ryan Giggs and Teddy Sheringham eased Manchester United back into the Champions League here last night against a tactically clever but largely impotent Bordeaux side. Given the chance to bring the scores level just before the hour, Sylvain Wiltord somehow failed to find an empty net.
fields.body:
Neatly taken goals by Ryan Giggs and Teddy Sheringham eased Manchester United back into the Champions League here last night against a tactically clever but largely impotent Bordeaux side. Given the chance to bring the scores level just before the hour, Sylvain Wiltord somehow failed to find an empty net.

For United last night's game posed the threat of not so much a pitfall as a pratfall. Bordeaux had begun the second group stage unimpressively - a defeat and a draw without scoring a goal - and appeared to offer the holders few problems, but United had to beware of sucker punches.

Previous Champions League matches at Old Trafford had sometimes seen United caught by early counter-attacks and it was probably with this in mind that Ferguson preferred to start last night's game with Nicky Butt, rather than Paul Scholes, playing alongside Roy Keane in midfield. Dwight Yorke was also on the bench despite his recovery from a thigh injury, leaving Sheringham to partner Andy Cole up front.

The most surprising change, however, saw Raimond van der Gouw preferred in goal to Mark Bosnich, who had been as poor against Wimbledon at the weekend as he had been excellent at Leeds the previous Sunday. Peter Schmeichel used to have his off-days but his on- days always left him well in credit with the manager.

Bordeaux did not come merely to defend; no wise side ever does that at Old Trafford. At the start Johan Micoud, Michel Pavon and the experienced, talented Corentin Martins carried the game to United, seeking to set up opportunities for Lilian Las landes and Wiltord to catch defenders on the turn.

Yet Manchester United had chances in the opening six minutes to take an unshakeable grip on the match. Andy Cole's through pass exposed a huge gap in Bordeaux's defence but Sheringham could not find the acceleration to exploit the situation.

Then Sheringham turned provider as he laid off a return ball to leave Giggs with a clear sight of goal, but the Welshman's shot was weak and harmless.

From the outset, then, United appeared the more likely winners and as Keane began to assert his authority in midfield, with Giggs and David Beckham starting to turn Bordeaux on the flanks, so the evening promised the European champions an early goal. In fact one almost arrived on the quarter-hour.

After Denis Irwin had been brought down by Martins near the corner of the penalty area Beckham's free-kick swung over the line of defenders in a prodigious arc and with Ulrich Ramé looking beaten hit the underside of the crossbar. Sheringham just failed to reach the rebound but it was a moment to savour all the same.

It took an astutely timed interception by Mikael Silvestre to dispossess Wiltord before the striker could turn on the ball near the penalty spot.

As Bordeaux continued to worry United with the pace, mobility and imagination of their attacks a game delayed by three-quarters of an hour because fans had been held up by a motorway accident looked well worth the wait.

One of United's problems lay in the fact that, with Giggs and Beckham playing wide, Keane and Butt were sometimes outnumbered in central midfield. Yet Bordeaux were always wary of the damage that the speed of Cole or Giggs might inflict.

Nine minutes before half-time a combination of this pair nearly saw United go ahead. As Giggs centred early Cole thrust himself through the Bordeaux defence to toe-end a shot high towards the top left-hand corner.???For a half-second the ball appeared to be beyond Ramé's reach but then the goalkeeper twisted up and back to claw it out of the air.

Not that a goal for United was long delayed. Four minutes before half-time another run from Cole was blocked by Kodjo Afanou, but the United man, turning quickly, played the ball out to Beckham, whose dipping centre was turned past Ramé by a cool flick of Giggs's left instep.

United survived a scare from Wiltord after Laslandes had broken through from what looked like an off-side position before United made certain of the points. Giggs beat two men down the left and crossed for Sheringham to head unchallenged past Ramé.

 A 20th-minute penalty by Predrag Mijatovic gave Fiorentina a 1-0 win over Valencia in the other Group B match last night and kept the Italians on top of the table.

Manchester United (4-4-2): Van der Gouw; G Neville, Stam, Silvestre, Irwin; Beckham, Keane, Butt, Giggs; Sheringham, Cole.

Bordeaux (4-4-2): Ramé; Grenet, Afanou, Alicarte, Bonnissel; Martins, Micoud, Pavon, Diabate; Laslandes, Wiltord. Referee: H Strampe (Germany)

webTitle: India collapse after South African pounding

fields.headline: India collapse after South African pounding
fields.trailText: The bowlers dominated the first day of the final Test between India and South Africa in Bangalore. The tourists, who lead the series 1-0, closed on 11 for one after India crumbled to 158.
fields.body:
The bowlers dominated the first day of the final Test between India and South Africa in Bangalore. The tourists, who lead the series 1-0, closed on 11 for one after India crumbled to 158.

Nantie Hayward started the Indian collapse in his opening over with Wasim Jaffer caught behind. The Indian captain Sachin Tendulkar then hit Hayward twice for four as he became the fourth Indian to top 6,000 runs in Test cricket, but he took his score to only 21 before he pulled Hayward to Hansie Cronje at mid-off.

India's top score was the No8 Anil Kumble's 36 not out. The spinner replied in the fourth over of South Africa's innings when he had Herschelle Gibbs lbw with the score on 10.

webTitle: Sun Life reaps £85m from golden alliance benefits of alliance

fields.headline: Sun Life reaps £85m from golden alliance benefits of alliance
fields.trailText: The potential for cost-saving alliances in the insurance sector were given a boost yesterday when Sun Life and Provincial - which is largely owned by Axa of France - said savings from its acquisition of Guardian Royal Exchange are running 70% ahead of original expectations.
fields.body:
The potential for cost-saving alliances in the insurance sector were given a boost yesterday when Sun Life and Provincial - which is largely owned by Axa of France - said savings from its acquisition of Guardian Royal Exchange are running 70% ahead of original expectations.

The company - which unveiled plans for a series of e-commerce initiatives - said it would achieve cost savings of £85m a year for a one-off cost of £115m. A statement from the company said that after selling unwanted bits of GRE the net payment for the business dropped to £841m from the headline takeover price of £3.4bn.

Details of the merger benefits were unveiled as Sun Life reported a 29% rise in operating profits to £319m with some £53m coming from eight months of Guardian's operations. The smooth integration of Guardian by Sun Life may encourage shareholders to view the planned merger of CGU and Norwich Union, which should provide £200m of savings each year, more benignly.

Sun Life - which already operates an internet site for individual savings accounts, as well as a healthcare advice site in support of its private health operation PPP - yesterday launched an open portal and said it would expand into web-based products for motor and health insurance. Lord Douro, chairman, added that an e-enabled stakeholder pension would be launched this year.

But Lord Douro warned that the outlook for business in 2000 was likely to be tougher than last year when the operating profit on the group's life and pensions business rose by 15% to £246m and the value of new business grew by 27%. Shareholders were rewarded with a 10.4% rise in the dividend to 14.9p.

webTitle: First Direct's online bank with attitude

fields.headline: First Direct's online bank with attitude
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Telephone bank First Direct yesterday announced that it was transforming itself into an "e-bank" and launched a broadside at the spate of standalone internet banks launched in recent months.
fields.body:
Telephone bank First Direct yesterday announced that it was transforming itself into an "e-bank" and launched a broadside at the spate of standalone internet banks launched in recent months.

Giving details of its new online service, First Direct - a division of HSBC - said it was combining its experience of phone banking with the strengths of the net to create "an internet bank you can talk to". It said it expects to double its 1m customer base within three years.

People will be able to register for the Firstdirect.com service from today, but the product range will not be available until June. Until then, would-be customers will have to make do with the bank's promise of "fiercely competitive" rates on current accounts, credit cards and other products. Alan Hughes, chief executive of First Direct, stressed it would continue to offer its phone banking service alongside online banking and expected customers to use both channels.

In a swipe at online banks such as Egg and the Halifax's Intelligent Finance, he said he believed the standalone net proposition "is a terrible one". First Direct differs in that it already has 1m customers and is profitable, he said.

"The difference here is that First Direct is a proven force, we are profitable, there is a clear income stream and we have a record of delivering service across a range of technologies. We will not be here today and gone tomorrow."

Mr Hughes highlighted dissatisfaction in the US with the poor web service associated with some online banks.

fields.headline: Lastminute float pitches low
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Lastminute.com, the online travel agency, yesterday claimed that volatile global stock markets and concerns over the success of the latest clutch of internet companies had forced the company to pitch its value at the lowest end of analysts' expectations.
fields.body:
Lastminute.com, the online travel agency, yesterday claimed that volatile global stock markets and concerns over the success of the latest clutch of internet companies had forced the company to pitch its value at the lowest end of analysts' expectations.

The price range for the company's float was set at 190p to 230p, giving it a potential value of £316m, following much speculation that it would start out at £400m.

However, grey market pricing by IG Index and Financial Spreads for the stock's debut was already putting it at between 360p to 500p yesterday, which would take the company's value to £750m.

Up to a quarter of Lastminute.com - or about 33m shares - is expected to be offered in the float, raising £62m for investment in marketing, technology, product development and expansion into new markets and suppliers.

The founders of Lastminute, Brent Hoberman and Martha Lane Fox, are expected to hold between 15% and 20% or £63m of the company when it lists on March 21.

"It's really exciting finally getting it on the road," Ms Lane Fox said.

Lastminute is expected to offer 8m shares to small investors with the remaining 25m going to institutions. "We still think it's a pretty good chunk, the amount we are selling off, with the volatility of the market," Ms Lane Fox said. "I think it's an exciting time for any dot.com."

Miles Satiel, an analyst at West LB Panmure, said: "The valuation that seems to be emerging is towards the low end of expectations. Do we believe Lastminute.com has a market dominating position? is a question that doesn't immediately bring about the answer 'yes'. That's what the price is telling us."

He said it was likely that Lastminute.com would list at a premium because of its strong branding.

Other major shareholders in Lastminute.com will include venture capital firm Arts Alliance Advisors and Global Retail Partners.

Mobile phone group Orange will acquire 1.65m shares at the market price while Virgin Atlantic Airways and Lufthansa will each eventually own 4% of the company.

Virgin and Lufthansa have both been granted warrants which can be converted into shares at 37p each if three-year performance targets are met.

The firm published December quarter results which showed turnover growing almost fourfold to £409,000 and gross profits up from £111,000 to £350,000.

webTitle: My boss treats me like a child

fields.headline: My boss treats me like a child
fields.trailText: The problem
fields.body:
The problem

My boss wants me to do things which are against my principles. She is also controlling and prescribes what shoes I should wear and where I should put my briefcase. By the way, I am functioning in a professional role but being treated like a child. I need the job and money to survive and cannot just leave. What should I do?

The solution

There are two issues here. The first is the potentially serious matter of being asked to do things which are against your principles. Without knowing what these things are, it is difficult to comment on whether your boss is being unreasonable or not.

For instance, if you were a chef and a vegetarian, it would not be unreasonable for your boss to expect you to cook meat, even though that might be against your principles. However, asking you to lie, act dishonestly or perform a criminal act would obviously be unreasonable and you could refuse.

You should document carefully any unreasonable requests your boss makes and any reaction from her towards your refusal to do them. If she were to subsequently make your life difficult for refusing, you might have a case for constructive dismissal.

The second issue is to do with her controlling behaviour. Again, the little information you provide in your letter is not enough for me to advise as to whether she is acting unreasonably. For instance, it does seem strange to dictate your choice of footwear or tell you where to put your belongings, but if you work in an industry where safety or hygiene is important, then these demands may not be unreasonable.

My best advice to you would be to arrange a meeting with your boss and explain, in a non-aggressive manner, the areas that are causing you concern. Be positive and upbeat so that rather than appearing to moan, you are showing that you are generally happy with your work and are confident that things can be improved. Give specific examples of things you are not happy with and give her the opportunity to justify her behaviour.

If this doesn't work, keep logging her unreasonable behaviour (in case you need to take action against her), keep your head down and start looking for alternative employment.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work
(Purple House, £9.99) and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't (Element, £9.99)

webTitle: Survey's sick list hits drive for full employment

fields.headline: Survey's sick list hits drive for full employment
fields.trailText: One in three jobless people claims to suffer from a longstanding illness that limits his or her activities, a survey reveals today, casting doubt on ministers' confidence of making further big cuts in unemployment.
fields.body:
One in three jobless people claims to suffer from a longstanding illness that limits his or her activities, a survey reveals today, casting doubt on ministers' confidence of making further big cuts in unemployment.

The number rises to more than half the unemployed aged over 45, complicating the equation of job vacancies and numbers of jobless drawn this week by Gordon Brown, the chancellor.

The latest government general household survey also shows that workless households are significantly less likely than others to have items like home computers, CD players, microwave ovens and dishwashers.

However, between 1996 and 1998 the proportion of households with satellite or cable television increased from 18% to 29%, with the numbers owning home computers rising from 27% to 34%.

Some of the largest differences in access to consumer goods are in respect of four items identified by the survey as "luxuries": CD players (63% of workless households compared with 86% of working ones), microwave ovens (71% against 86%), tumble dryers (44% against 61%) and dishwashers (12% against 31%).

The researchers for the study conceded that some of these disparities could be accounted for by class differences between the employed and unemployed, but said a clear contrast remained even when this was factored in.

The survey also shows that while smoking declined greatly in the 1970s and 1980s, it levelled out over the last decade, with 28% of men and 26% of women still smoking.

One in four families is now headed by a single parent, an increase of 17% from the 1971 figure of 8%.

Headline findings of the survey were published by the of fice for national statistics last December. But the full results include an analysis of more than 1,200 "workless" households, defined as those containing at least one person of working age but having nobody in a paid job or self-employment.

Overall, 19% of households were classed as workless and six in 10 of these contained only one adult, although they included markedly more children - 32% of all household members, as against 25% of all members of working households.

Compared with working households, more than three times as many women and four times as many men in workless households described their health as "not good".

In workless households 34% of men and 30% of women said they had a limiting longstanding illness. Among working households, the equivalent proportions were just 12% and 13% respectively.

Lorna Reith, chief executive of the Disability Alliance, said the results showed the flaws in making simple assumptions about unemployed people's ability to take jobs.

Living in Britain: Results from the 1998 general household survey; stationery office; £39.50.

webTitle: Fines threat to banks in cash machines row

fields.headline: Fines threat to banks in cash machines row
fields.standfirst: The issue explained: cash machine charges
fields.trailText: Tony Blair threatened banks and building societies with multimillion pound fines yesterday after their decision to introduce surcharges which could take the cost of withdrawing money from cash machines to £2.50.
fields.body:
Tony Blair threatened banks and building societies with multimillion pound fines yesterday after their decision to introduce surcharges which could take the cost of withdrawing money from cash machines to £2.50.

Infuriated by the decision to press ahead with the new charge next year, the prime minister raised the prospect of enforcing the new competition act which gives the authorities the power to impose a 10% levy on businesses behaving in an anti-competitive manner.

Mr Blair told the Commons that "there are legitimate concerns". He reminded MPs of the powers of the new competition act to crack down on "anti-competitive practices which harm the consumer".

Government pressure was also exerted by Stephen Byers, the secretary of state for trade and industry, who in a letter to John Hardy, the chief executive of the cash machine network Link, called for clarification and threatened to evoke the prices act if banks did not display the charges on cash machine screens.

Mr Byers accused Link of failing to make clear what it would do about "disloyalty fees" where customers face surcharges of up to £2.50.

However, Mr Hardy, insisted the Link board had passed resolutions which were in line with competition restrictions.

He pointed out that the responsibility for setting the price was not Link's but each individual bank or building society's. The 34 members of the Link network finally agreed to surcharging on Tuesday after five months of dispute over the controversial move by Barclays to charge its rivals' customers £1 every time they use its machines.

The Barclays charge, not yet introduced after it was blocked by a threat of court action by Nationwide building society, raised the prospect of customers being charged twice if they used a Barclays machine - by Barclays and also by their own card issuer which might levy a "disloyalty" fee of £1.50. Last night, Nationwide refused to say how it had cast its crucial vote at the Link board meeting.

Barclays yesterday appeared to back down from £1 charge. The bank said it had only ever been a "stake in the ground". If it was to press ahead with the £1 charge it would set itself on a collision course with Don Cruickshank, investigating banks on behalf of the treasury, who has calculated they should charge 15-30p.

These "disloyalty fees"earn banks and building societies £650,000 a day.

fields.headline: This soul is organic
fields.standfirst:
Hil St Soul
Jazz Cafe, London
Rating:****
fields.trailText:
Hil St Soul
Jazz Cafe, London
Rating:****
fields.body:
Winner of the 1999 Blues & Soul Best Newcomer Award, singer/songwriter Hil St Soul (aka Hilary Mwelwa) is part of a healthy resurgence of British R&B. This Zambian-born north Londoner has the same sass and independence as her former label-mate Beverly Knight, and together with collaborator Victor Redwood Sawyerr, has created solid grooves. "This isn't GM soul," says the compere tonight, "it's organic."

A slow, steady buzz has been building up ever since Mwelwa's debut album Organic Soul came out last year. This is her inaugural gig, so the soul contingent are out in force, packing out the venue. Accompanied by a six-piece band, Mwelwa gets off to a careful start, politely inviting the audience to "feel the energy - it's strictly a vibe thing." By the third song, Matter of Time, a brilliantly restless homage to ambition and personal achievement, she has taken off. Like her heroine Aretha Franklin, there is grit, warmth and self-determination in her voice. Propelled by a rootsy bass and vibrant backing vocals, her strongest songs are about the dilemmas of creativity and success, like Concrete Jungle, an angry look at the music industry, "saturated with imitations of what's hip". There's also the mind-talk of Feelgood Factor and the sense of heritage and history in Props.

All this makes a refreshing change from the "I love you baby, why don't you call me" school of female R&B. Mwelwa wisely steers clear of her less distinctive love songs, concentrating instead on stoking the set with declarative mid-tempo grooves. A former backing singer with acts such as Incognito and Fierce, she's at home on the stage, tackling each number with a singleminded focus. She briefly calms proceedings with an acoustic rendition of the Aretha classic Until You Come Back to Me, before returning to the fray with upbeat gospel-style harmonies. Here the energy momentarily dissipates amid more straightforward numbers, including the radio-friendly but "normal" For Your Love. By the time they return for the encore, though, Mwelwa and the band are firing again. They've just found out about the Blues & Soul award. fields.bodyText: Winner of the 1999 Blues & Soul Best Newcomer Award, singer/songwriter Hil St Soul (aka Hilary Mwelwa) is part of a healthy resurgence of British R&B. This Zambian-born north Londoner has the same sass and independence as her former label-mate Beverly Knight, and together with collaborator Victor Redwood Sawyerr, has created solid grooves. "This isn't GM soul," says the compere tonight, "it's organic." A slow, steady buzz has been building up ever since Mwelwa's debut album Organic Soul came out last year. This is her inaugural gig, so the soul contingent are out in force, packing out the venue. Accompanied by a six-piece band, Mwelwa gets off to a careful start, politely inviting the audience to "feel the energy - it's strictly a vibe thing." webTitle: B&B on the hunt for takeover targets

fields.headline: B&B on the hunt for takeover targets
fields.trailText: Bradford & Bingley, Britain's second largest building society, yesterday announced that it might consider more acquisitions in the run-up to its expected flotation at the end of this year.
fields.body:
Bradford & Bingley, Britain's second largest building society, yesterday announced that it might consider more acquisitions in the run-up to its expected flotation at the end of this year.

The society, which bought mortgage broker John Charcol two weeks ago, said its special meeting to vote on conversion would take place in July, and flotation should go ahead by December. Analysts have estimated windfalls will be worth £800 to £1,000 per head.

Christopher Rodrigues, the chief executive, said B&B was primarily focused on its current operations and the demutualisation.

"We have what it takes to float and we don't need to do an acquisition to float. Having said that, over the last three years we have done a series of medium-sized acquisitions. If there was another medium-sized acquisition which would help to accelerate our strategy, we would not be averse to looking at it," he said.

His comments came as the society reported its 1999 results, which showed pre-tax profit before exceptional items up 44% to £184.4m.

Savings balances grew 7.6% to £15.5bn, but this was in spite of the society being closed to new savers from January to July following the acceptance of the conversion resolution, said Mr Rodrigues.

The housing market has "started well," with B&B estate agency sales up 14.5% on last year. Meanwhile, the society said the mortgage market remains strong but competitive.

To date, B&B has spent £15m on preparing for the float, and it estimates the total bill will exceed £50m.

The society is going to market after B&B members voted last spring in favour of carpetbagger Stephen Major's conversion resolution in defiance of the board's wishes.

fields.headline: A sonorous mélange
fields.standfirst:
Britten Sinfonia/ Nicholas Cleobury
Barbican Hall, London
Rating:****
fields.trailText:
Britten Sinfonia/ Nicholas Cleobury
Barbican Hall, London
Rating:****
fields.body:
It's little wonder that Django Bates's arrangement of New York, New York lurched, in the composer's words, from "distinction to extinction" at its first performance during a conference for the grandees of Polygram in New York. The piece is a riotous collection of dissonant harmonisations, impenetrably dense textures, and snatches of the US national anthem, which surface, flail about, and then drown in Bates's all-consuming sonic maelstrom. Bates contributed his own vocals at the Britten Sinfonia's concert, enthroned behind racks of keyboards and samplers in the midst of the orchestra.

The post-Charles Ives clutter of Bates's arrangement was no accident in the Britten Sinfonia's concert. Their programme revealed connections and creative contrasts between Bates, Bach, Ligeti, and Ives himself. A selection of Ives's shorter works ranged from the anarchical rhythmic profusion of the Country Band March and Ragtime Dance No 4, to the transcendent hush of his Hymn.

All of these Ivesian qualities found parallels in the evening's world premiere, Bates's concerto for synthesiser, embedded jazz quartet, and orchestra, 2000 Years Beyond Undo. In outline, it was possible to discern the dim vestiges of a conventional concerto layout: an opening allegro; a set of slow-ish variations, even if they were unconventionally brash; and a grandiose final movement, preceded by the archaic quaintness of a showy cadenza. However, the divisions between these sections seemed as arbitrary as the colours of the accompanying lighting.

But it was Bates's wit and worldliness which were the work's most original features. Announcing to the audience during the Theremin-like swoops of the cadenza, that "one always ends a piano cadenza with a trill", his synthesiser duly obliged and became a genteel concert grand. The mock finale that followed took the musical irreverence to another level in its pilfering of Beethoven's Ode to Joy.

However, Bates's sonorous mélange is not just an attempt to debunk or deconstruct. As demonstrated by his Three English Scenes, there is a warmth and affection behind his energetic eccentricity. Emphasising Bates's regard for the conventional classical world, Joanna MacGregor joined the Britten Sinfonia in two piano concertos: Ligeti's found echoes in the surrounding sound and fury, and the pristine coolness of Bach's counterpoint created an unlikely ally for Bates's souped-up polyphony.

At Basingstoke Anvil tonight, then tours. Details: 01223 300795.

fields.headline: Online share tips warning
fields.standfirst:
Regulator cautions against misleading information designed to force up prices

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Millions of users of internet "chat rooms" were warned by City regulator yesterday of dodgy share tips which could "seriously damage" their wealth.
fields.body:
Millions of users of internet "chat rooms" were warned by City regulator yesterday of dodgy share tips which could "seriously damage" their wealth.

Prompted by the explosion in share dealing by private investors who are swapping news and views in cyberspace, the financial services authority warned about the potential for "the unscrupulous to place false or misleading messages in order to make money for themselves".

"Following such tips blindly can seriously damage your wealth. So the simple message is do not believe everything you read," Phillip Thorpe, managing director of the FSA said.

His warning was echoed by his colleague, Deborah Arnott, head of consumer education at the regulator, who said: "It's the same thing as when you go into a pub and someone gives you a tip."

Motivated by events in the United States, the FSA warned again about "pumping and dumping" where tipsters highlight shares to boost the price so that they can sell quickly at a profit. The FSA illustrated its argument with a case in the United States where the authorities sued a "tout" who had sent out 6m unsolicited emails to boost the price of two companies.

Interest in bulletin boards has risen rapidly in recent months as internet and telephone dealing services have made it cheaper for investors to deal in shares, resulting in low cost brokers being flooded with orders - usually for so-called "tech" or internet-related stocks. The FSA said yesterday it was monitoring these stockbroking firms to make sure they could cope with the demand.

While some the tips being posted on the internet are worrying regulators, who fear shares are simply being ramped, other bulletin board postings have led to concerns about "insider" knowledge. Internet chat rooms broke the news of the record-breaking deal between AOL and Time Warner and also the recent takeover in Britain of insurance group United Assurance Group by Royal London.

The stock exchange is known to monitor the content of bulletin boards for this reason, but refuses to indicate whether it has begun any investigations. The biggest and best known chat rooms are run by Motley Fool, Interactive Investor In ternational (III) and Hemmington Scott, which between them are thought to have 2m registered users. Many are registered with all three.

The regulator, which pointed out yesterday that it was a criminal offence to deliberately create a misleading impression about a share price, urged investors to conduct their own research and be aware that one user can easily create the illusion of widespread interest in a small stock by using a variety of aliases.

"Be suspicious of any invitation which claims to offer privileged information," Mr Thorpe said.

webTitle: Inferno of lust in need of a match

fields.headline: Inferno of lust in need of a match
fields.standfirst:
Miss Julie
Theatre Royal Haymarket, London
Rating:***
fields.trailText:
Miss Julie
Theatre Royal Haymarket, London
Rating:***
fields.body:
It is midsummer eve, madness is in the air. Julie, the aristocratic daughter of the count, is in a dangerous mood, flirting with the servants.

"You can get burned playing with fire," warns Jean, her father's valet and the object of her attentions.

"Not me," she replies, "I'm insured." But the premiums are worthless, and when Julie mates with Jean like a bitch on heat, the result is an emotional inferno.

Michael Boyd recently directed a very different kind of summer madness, with the sexiest A Midsummer Night's Dream that we have seen for years. This evening could do with some of that production's erotic charge.

August Strindberg knew all about the sexual thrill of power and the lure of the masochist for the sadist, long before Hollywood got round to making films such as 9 Weeks.

In Miss Julie it is a short step from ordering your foot to be kissed to discovering that the boot is on the other foot. There is no better drama about lust and hate. Or for reminding you that you really should not play games unless you are prepared to lose as well as win. It is a pretty nasty 90 minutes. Here it is never really quite nasty enough.

Boyd's production and Frank McGuinness's new translation of Strindberg's play are good on the contempt of the servants who discover that their supposed betters are no better than they should be.

The evening hits full throttle in the scene in which Julie and Jean's offstage coupling is accompanied by the servants' invasion of the kitchen, and an initial threat of violence gives way almost to orgy.

Tom Piper's set also gives symbolic meaning to this most naturalistic of dramas, making full use of the height of the stage and dominated by a twisting staircase that spirals ever downwards as if the steaming kitchen really were located in the bowels of hell.

But though both Christopher Eccleston as Jean and Aisling O'Sullivan as Julie are watchable, and he plays cleverly on the idea of Jean as a spiv who dreams, you would have to shut your eyes to really believe in either their attraction or repulsion for each other. It is a lack that acts like a fire blanket on an otherwise combustible play.

Until May 27. Box office: 0171-930 8800. This review appeared in some editions of yesterday's Guardian.
